description:
So yes, you go here for its age and place in literary history, and to see the photos and memorabilia lining the walls and displayed in glass cases upstairs.  That makes it worth the trip, but do remember that this place is OLD.  The small tables wobble and the chairs are ricketty. 

Another old thing here is the menu.  The food is heavy, a caloric throwback to the mid-20th century. Meat, potatoes, pasta, cream sauce, cheese. It's all delicious, and some of it (not all) is surprisingly inexpensive compared to other SF tourist destinations.  Red Snapper in lemon butter (more butter than lemon) sauce was just $17 and came with a generous side of fresh green beans (and two ornamental carrots). The Seafood Cannelloni, at $14.95, was one of the most delicious things I've eaten all week, and it was huge (two cannellonis stuffed with shrimp, crab, mushrooms, and cheese). 

TIP:  If you are a party of two, you will want to sweet talk the host into putting you at a 4 top because the narrow two tops are not large enough to fit the restaurant's giant plates of food, basket of bread, and drinks, especially if you order an appetizer or a bottle of wine.
author: David A.

description:
Tried this place because of the historical aspect and I liked the menu and wanted to try the Oyster Wellington. 
I walked in and it was jam-packed. They told me to come back in about 30 minutes, so I wandered around SF for a bit. I came back and they directed me to the bar area to wait for a table. This was a poor idea, as it was still packed and I was in the way of the servers. I decided to wait outside. 
The host asked me to go upstairs and someone would seat me and walked away - I'd never been there before and I couldn't see the stairs. I was becoming anxious because I was in the way of a lot of people and had nowhere to go. I then went back to the host stand and told him I had never been there and wasn't sure where the stairs were (there is a small label pointing to the stairs in the back area of the first floor). 
I then went upstairs and was immediately seated. There was a gentleman playing music loudly, but it still sounded nice. What I was hoping would be a quiet, nice dinner was actually a raucous-filled party floor. I almost left then, but I knew that everywhere would be crazy since it was DreamForce week in SF. 
What really caught me off guard was the impeccable service. I couldn't say I had one server, because people were constantly taking care of my table. Bringing drinks, taking my order, serving food. It was wonderful. 
I had the jumbo prawns dijonnaise and it was fantastic! I hadn't had a baked potato in so long. 
I loved the mushrooms in the dish and the veggies were cooked perfectly. Oh, and my food literally came out 10 minutes after I ordered, which was extremely surprising. 
I didn't try dessert, but I did have a martini and it was divine.
author: Kristen B.

description:
John's Grill is steeped in history. It opened in 1908, two years after San Francisco's devastating earthquake. This downtown restaurant became a literary pilgrimage stop when Dashiel Hammett's 1930 novel, The Maltese Falcon, published. His main character and lead gumshoe is Sam Spade, who scours the city in search of a mysterious jewel-encrusted statuette known as the Maltese Falcon, and dines on a meal of chops, a potato, and sliced tomatoes at John's Grill.

I came for a business dinner, and was concerned with the Yelp 3.5 star rating. I ordered the ribeye steak medium with fries instead of baked potato. The ribeye was served medium rare instead of medium; however, it was nicely prepared, tender and absolutely delicious. It is as if the chef refused to ruin the steak by preparing it medium and served it the way it should had been ordered. The fries were also prepared the way I like them, crispy and not too thick.

I'll not comment about the service, as the restaurant was extremely busy when I visited and it was a total chaos. Conveniently located close to the Powell Street BART station. Recommended based on the food.
author: Tom S.

description: We went back last night.  I ordered a porterhouse steak. One side was relatively soft, the other was chewy/fatty and required several deposits into my napkin. Take away is I'll either try the fillet mignon next time or stick with the fish/seafood. We were upstairs and they had a solo electric guitarist player doing unrecognizable jazz tinkles.
author: Aba H.

description:
Against all logic, I picked to pick a 3.5 Yelp star restaurant for my 40th in a touristy location.  But I figure its a 110 year old restaurant, it wasn't always touristy was it? And John is my nickname, so there you go. This classic American restaurant feels like an episode of Madmen, with Donald Draper and Roger Sterling having a power lunch.  Traditional American, but not too pretentious. Our friendly waiter kept on top of things, all with a smile and just the right amount of visits. 

Complimentary sourdough bread and butter...yes please!
$14 Half dozen oysters...served the old fashioned way with lemon wedges, cocktail sauce, and horseradish.  

$35 Filet Mignon...wifey's pick, and the wife was happy. I think it was an 8 ounce piece of meat heaven.  She barely finished it.  

$35  Ribeye...my favorite cut of steak, and it was think, fatty, and fabulous. I guestimate it was around 14-16 ounce, I was full AF!  I also got a $10 glass of house red, which was a generous pour of delicious velvet liquid perfectly complementing my red meat.  

FREE Birthday Flan...thank you! Light and creamy, accompanied with a healthy side of fresh berries and cream. 

Ultimately, I wanted a nice thick juicy slab of beef inside of me on my 40th, but without completely emptying out my 401K and selling my body on the Tenderloin. John's Grill hit all the right spots.  Make a reservation, and come hungry!
author: Chun P.

description:
John's Grill is a San Francisco Classic.

Sure, John's is near Union Square, so it can be a little touristy -- okay a lot touristy. But it makes up for it with charm -- the place oozes it. This is a classic San Francisco grill -- think Tadich or Sam's. We are not talking fancy food; we are talking good comfort food, a great bar and friendly service. 

I am a creature of habit -- I always get the lamb chops. The same dish that Dashiell Hammet had, and the same dish his alter ego Sam Spade had in the Maltese Falcon. John's was a favorite haunt of Hammet's back in the 20's when he lived in the area as a Pinkerton detective and later as a writer. Upstairs you can see a little homage to the book and movie, along with a replica of the falcon. Sometimes touristy is great. Do yourself a favor and pay John's Grill a visit.
author: John C.

description:
I have an affinity for "historic" restaurants and the career waiters and waitresses that work there and John's Grill is one of those places.
I ordered the grilled Pacific Red Snapper with veggies and a baked potato. The nice size portion of fish was very good and meaty. The fresh green beans and carrot, as well as the baked potato, were perfect. Sitting at the bar and having two glasses of wine, with generous pours from the busy bartender, was a show in itself. Oddly, my credit card was declined, even though I had used it within the past hour. I did not get any attitude from my waiter and just gave him another card, no issues. I did not have dessert so I can't say anything on that. I left a happy person.
author: Rick S.

description:
I love this place!  I love the fact that I can walk in without a reservation and be seated within minutes!  I look forward to an amazing dinner with my choice of comfort foods!  And if I'm lucky, dinner with the tunes from a jazz guitarist. 

I always scan the whole menu and try to decide between the ribeye steak, lamb chops, chicken Jerusalem or the jumbo prawns dijonnaise. More often then not, I go for my favorite - the jumbo prawns dijonnaise with baked potato and fresh veggies.  "Jumbo" is the operative word here - both in size and taste!  It makes me very happy!  

I'll be back again soon!
author: Lorraine S.

description:
Maybe writing this review is a waste of time because surely everyone on planet Earth has already had the pleasure of dining at this establishment. Of course I jest, but after 110 years in business it's probably safe to say that an endless number of patrons have been served with countless numbers maintaining a regular and semi-regular status like myself. I do not have any idea how many times I've frequented this San Francisco icon, but I'd estimate my visits have topped at least two dozen over my adult years. 

What's good? Well just about everything (skip the pasta, yes, even the Maine lobster ravioli), from the salads to the desserts, undoubtedly has the potential of becoming a personal favorite. I admit that the taste of the food and the service waxes and wanes between a 3.5 and a 5, but considering the longevity of this eatery I am compelled to rank it as positively as it's best days. Whenever they falter I simply look forward to the next visit for complete vindication. 

P.S. The drinks from their bar are always a winner, too.
author: Angelina G.

description:
Considering it was Father's Day we were lucky to get a table for two without reservations during dinner time. 

The service was efficient and great. We were greeted immediately, and had seats within 2 mins. The steak was delicious and filling, came with a side of vegetables and baked potatoes (though I think my potato could have been baked abit longer). The waiter came by several times to make sure that we had everything and made sure everything was tasting okay. We were on a time crunch so we were able to enjoy our meal all within an hour. Location was great too!
author: Tina C.

description:
Needs more stars!
This place is the best of the best !
Fabulous steak cooked mid rare and a real Caesar
The ambience is the real deal and you can feel the history in these walls. 
Waiter and bartender Greg is on spot !
Don't miss this wonderful spot off the beaten path of Union Sguare !
author: C S.

description:
Very pleasant atmosphere and good service. So, I assign two stars. We were in a group. A friend and I decided to split a Porterhouse steak. It cost $39, but was noted on the menu to be 22 ounces. We ordered it to be rare/medium rare, expecting a deep red center. It came back slightly pink to outright gray. Our waiter took it back and within 10 minutes returned with a rare steak. It tasted excellent but I doubt it was more than 14 ounces with the bone.

My wife ordered a Caesar salad, which also was small despite a substantial price.

It's a shame such a beautiful restaurant is stingy and careless. I don't expect we'll return.
author: William L.

description:
I was musing between 3 and 4 stars but the portions pushed it to 4. 
  My husband and I split the oysters which were meh. It annoys me to have shell shards in oysters and this happened in the majority of oysters I had here. 
  The clam chowder, however is GOOD. Shockingly good as I've had it in NE and it was delicious. 
  I had the steamed clams appetizer as my entree and couldn't finish it. There must have been over a dozen clams and that delicious sauce called for sopping up bread. So, so good. Definitely get the clams. 

  Also I liked being seated upstairs with live music and my martini was crispy cold and delicious.
author: Meredith S.

description:
Service: 5 Stars
Ambiance: 4 Stars
Food: 3.5 Stars 

Food was ok, my oysters Wellington were excellent. Up to par with an old traditional style restaurant with a classic San Francisco menu. Friends also ordered the seafood cannelloni and the sea bass. Overall 3-4 Stars for the food. 

Ambiance was nice! Beautiful old wood and walking distance of many of the hotels in union square. A lot of tourists but that's to be expected. 

Reservations were fast and easy using open table via their website and best of all, they did pay attention to my comment that we were celebrating a birthday in my reservation. They placed us at a very nice table and brought out complimentary cheesecake with a candle in it without any reminder from me.  We were also seated promptly and on time which is almost unheard of anywhere in sf on a Friday night. Service was extremely attentive, 5 Stars.  Service alone is reason enough for me to recommend it to friends staying in the area.
author: Courtney Y.

description: The service in all areas was impeccable. The wait was not bad at all. They have plenty of table. It was a great atmosphere. The food was amazing and very fulfilling. I had the filet mignon and really enjoyed it. My wife had the sea bass and it was just as good. Check this place out immediately.
author: Tristan G.

description: Was in SF for an anniversary weekend and just did a google search for seafood nearby. Walking in, were sat right away. The staff was quick and courteous. The food was great. My husband had some pasta and I had a salad and clam chowder. It was great, I'd happily go back again.
author: Heather W.

description:
This is the fastest service in town --period. You will be greeted seated & feeded (yes I know it's not a word but it rhymes) in a NY minute. AND it's
Quality food! I should know : I ate here!
author: Mark B.

description:
1/2 a star if I could. 

The most disgusting thing happened today at this restaurant, I've never expected to be treated with so much disrespect at a place I frequented(until tonight)

I've been coming here for 22 years. I liked it because I could be in and out without wait times. Tonight the fake looking & acting woman at the door with crooked eyelashes and dried blonde hair, responded to my request to be seated in a quiet place, by offering a table in the music room or in the middle of the restaurant. 

There was a free table that would have been perfect. The restaurant was 50% empty. I came early, and she refused to let me peacefully sit down. 

Chris, the "manager" did nothing to remedy the situation, and still tried to seat me at a table in the middle of the restaurant. 

Unfortunately, this type of poor behavior is condoned in this establishment. 

Take my advice and go elsewhere. If they don't value a regular customer, they certainly will not value a new one.
author: G G.

description:
Come hungry, because boy are the portions here generous. For the price, you definitely get what you pay for! I am not a huge fan of American cuisine, but John's Grill was an exception. The jazz music, ambience, and overall historic vibe instantly put me in a different time zone. I felt like I was in a 1920s movie!

If you find yourself wandering the streets of downtown, San Francisco on a late evening when the sun goes down and people come out, I hope you make your way to John's Grill.

I may be bias for I'm a sucker for hidden gems and romantic setups, but this place def left a lasting impression! Check it out for yourself and show the waiters some love if you do, because those plates were crazy heavy!! 

P.S GET THE CLAM CHOWDER!
author: Mary L.

description:
Like the Old Clam House on Bayshore Blvd., Johns Grill is a wonderfully historic piece of old skool, San Francisco. Who doesn't love tourists? I do. I am a tourist on my travels so I don't understand why *some* iffy SF'er's and wanna-be's diss tourists, without them SF would be a very different city.

I digress. This classic San Francisco grill gives you perfectly prepared chops, fish, salads with wonderfully attentive service. I love this place like a hurricane!
author: San Francisco C.

description:
John's is a step back in time; I'd affectionately call it a 'dinosaur'.  It's so charming--well dressed waitstaff, real tablecloths, the whole deal.  It boasts many well-known clientele and most obvious, historical cred being the setting for 'The Maltese Falcon'.

My husband and I took the opportunity to indulge in some classic fair:  the shrimp cocktail, the *divine* escargot, the fillet (for me) and the ribeye (for him).  We also indulged in a little afternoon cocktail--a negroni and a sidecar, both of which were perfect!  The shrimp cocktail was exactly as it should be, with huge shrimp!  The escargot were cooked to perfection and practically melted on one's tongue.  Both steak options were cooked exactly as ordered (being rare/mid-rare enthusiasts, it's always a gamble to order steak out) and they were so tender, one barely needed a knife to slice through them!  As a lovely after-dinner treat, our waiter brought us little Kahlua-milks which was indeed very sweet and much appreciated!

My only complaints are very minor:  it was a particularly warm day and so it was *very* warm in the restaurant.  I understand that that was a particularly rare occurrence in the area for this time of year, but still, a fan or cracked window would've gone a long way!  The chairs in the dining room are also a touch delicate feeling; a slightly more substantial chair would be more comfortable.  But like I said, these are very minor complaints and would not deter me from returning!  Cheers!
author: Lorean W.

description: This place deserves 5 stars.  The food was outstanding.  However the service was full on unacceptable.  Had to ask 3 times for water.  They fave me someone else's food.  The waiter rarely appeared.  There was no bus boy to refill drinks so glasses sat empty for minutes on end at times.  I really should knock another star off...but the food was truly 5 star
author: Jared H.

description: We just happened to walk up to this place! I wanted a drink but my friend wanted a steak so we signed up for a table. We waited at the small bar and ordered a house Cabernet and a margarita. We got our table with not much of a wait. We ordered the surf and turf and they were nice to split it fit us! The steak was perfectly cooked as requested. The prawns were delicious! The green beans were good and the  carrots. The baked potato with butter and sour cream. We also had the cheesecake with blackberries and strawberries! Delicious! The music played overhead was a nice smooth jazz.
author: Teofila R.

description: Food fabulous, staff welcoming and helpful. Great ambience. Highly recommend. My partner had steak, it was cooked to perfection as was my king prawns. Key lime pie was very tasty too. Loved the music   Highly recommend. We ate mid afternoon I would recommend booking for an evening meal as I imagine it gets very busy. Don't let that put you off the restaurant has three floors.
author: Annie D.

description: A great old restaurant, making it in a new time. A slice of Americana with great service and food. Introduce yourself to the bartender, Louie, he has been a fixture for 40 years!  Happy 110 birthday John's.
author: Dan M.

description:
There are a class of restaurants that meet a certain need. They're not the Michelin Star type of place, but that's not always what you have a taste for. Sometimes you want an atmosphere that only time can provide. Sometimes you want food that speaks to quality, but free of pretentious presentation and innovation.  This is John's Grill. 

There are a number of long time San Francisco steak houses. They wear their age with pride and tend to play a part in a diner's past, be it a birthday party or Father's Day or the celebration of a personal business triumph.  The service is superb and the food dependable and generous. The photos on the wall speak to the homage of Dashiell Hammet and his literary hero, Sam Spade and yet this is not some tourist attraction with overpriced burgers. 

I liked the place. It's expensive, it's crowded, it's what I hoped it would be and for that I'm grateful.  It's not a place I will go to often, but I'm surprised it took me this long to get here...and I'm so very hopeful that it will be around for another hundred years.
author: Sam G.

description:
This place is a historic steakhouse 3 stories in union square. We loved our food but the wait staff in the third story was a bit unprofessional. They were noisy and complaining openly about other customers. 

The third floor was quieter bc there was no bar, so I recommend that. I had the salmon which was pretty good (a little heavy on the char).
author: Alex M.

description:
Came here for a dinner in a private room upstairs. We had two tables. Food and drink was plentiful. Started with the pomegranate cosmos - very tasty in a nice size glass. For appetizers we shared mussels, Dungeness crab cocktail, escargots and lobster ravioli. The mussels and escargots were huge and delicious. I really like the escargots - it was not salty and it had a light creamy sauce - the escargots were large and succulent. I couldn't taste the lobster in the ravioli. The crab sat in some cocktail sauce and it was very good especially when you are craving it.  The bread was nice and crusty but wasn't served warm. 

I shared a jack lalanne salad and it was very good.  Would have liked more seafood in it. Waiter was kind enough to split it for us.

I ordered the porterhouse steak medium rare.  When the waiter handed me the plate I couldn't tell it was a porterhouse. I couldn't tell where the filet and the New York steak was. I wanted it to look like the pictures in yelp.  It was still good though it had a little fat and Grizzle. 

The string beans and carrots were cooked perfectly. As was the baked potato. It was wonderful with the sour cream, cheese and real bacon bits. The sauté  mushrooms were good too.   

We ordered 3 bottles of wine - two reds and one white. I was surprised the red wine were twist off bottles. 

All in all,it was a great evening since I didn't have to pay for my meal.  It was a little over $100 per person which was a good value for what we drank and ate.
author: Donna L.

description:
Came in with some colleagues. The food was good and the service was attentive.  

I had the fillet mignon which was cooked spot-on.  

I'd come back on my next visit to the Bay Area.
author: Steve Z.

description: Coworkers dinner. Absolutely fantastic food... gorgeous steaks... great drinks. Warm and comfortable environment. Feels like it's been there forever. Great solid service, lots of repeat local patrons, great food. We'll be back!
author: S M.

description: This review i wanted to post for awhile now.  The owner providing free drink and food on election day is so generous to SF patrons. I went to event and the service was excellent as well. Surprised to see not many people tipping when getting free food and alcohol.  Not a shocker though.  Shout out and thank you to johns grill.  Love the bar area for a lunch and great job chris the manager.
author: David W.

description:
Second visit.  Food is excellent.  Steaks well seasoned and properly cooked.  Veggies also cooked just right, not mushy.  

Decor is a shrine to Film Noir so mystery lovers, this is your place.  

And we got free dessert.
author: Gene M.

description:
This place has a real old school San Francisco drive. It was a Sunday night, but we were able to be seated immediately. 

The salmon was really good and my colleague had the lobster ravioli and that was really good too. The upstairs area seemed like it had better ambience, but overall it was a pleasant experience.

This is a place for adults, so I would recommend not bringing kids. 

Whether you're looking to have a business dinner, date night, or elegant meeting this is the place.
author: Dean W.

description: The steak eaters at the table all said 4-5 stars. Probably the best blue cheese dressing I've ever had.  My snapper was perfectly cooked and plentiful.  Atmosphere quaint.  Somehow my vinaigrette dressing spilled onto my guests salad with blue cheese.  It was significant that we all noticed yet they served it anyway which was a turn off. I'll give them the benifit if the doubt and will most likely return in a few weeks.
author: Tony B.

description:
Old school class!!! I popped out of the BART terminal at Powell and my eye caught the old New York-style signage. I went in for a quick bite and left a fan. White table cloths, great service and fantastic food. 

The drinks are also not to be underestimated. Cant wait to return.
author: Matthew R.

description: Surprisingly I stumbled upon this place roaming lost-like from out of the Powell BART train station. My girl and I were immediately intrigued by its bright flashy lights outside the establishment and their doorman sealed the deal and reeled us in. It was our anniversary and I'm a stickler about going somewhere without at least looking it up to research their menu and checking it's average review, but sometimes something great just falls into you lap. Our server was Bret and he displayed an exemplary level of service, professionalism and attentiveness  (being a server myself I especially look for those things). The food was heavenly I ordered the Ribeye and my lady had the Seafood Cannelloni. Both were mouth-watering and satisfying without leaving me feeling full and bloated, so the portions were well sized. Lastly, I wanted to thank our server Bret once again ESPECIALLY since I've been on my vacation to visit this beautiful city and he's the first person to show us EXCELLENT service.
author: Jalin D.

description: I stumbled into this place with a friend while we were killing time in the city. We were in the area and decided to try this place. It is not what it seems from the outside. My friend and I decided to split the seafood pasta entre since we didn't want to overstuff ourselves and it was a little pricey for us. We got our food within 10 minutes it seemed. It was the fastest I have ever received food at a sit down establishment. They were kind enough to split the pasta for us. We each got our own little plate but it was plenty of food. There was a lot of seafood in our pasta which I liked. Normally you don't get enough when you go somewhere but here you did. Even splitting the pasta we didn't completely finish it. It was very good!
author: Crystal P.

description:
While out in the city we were lucky enough to have dinner at this lovely place 

Food: Started with the SHRIMP COCKTAIL 10/10 im not a huge fan of the cocktail sauce but it was good. ESCARGO 10/10 it was made w a butter garlic sauce wich was nice and creamy. CLAM CHOWDER 10/10 sooo rich in flavor, super creamy. Only thing was i wish they had more appetizer options. LAMP CHOPS 10/10 perfectly cooked, only thing was its on the stronger meat flavor side, got it w the fries which are freaking BOMB there. I ordered a cocktail and since im a lightweight it tasted quite strong and couldn't finish it :(. PECAN PIE 10/10 was probably the best we've ever had so good. CHEESECAKE 10/10 sooo creamy and can deff taste the vanilla hints served with fresh berries yumm

Service: We were greeted by the Manager Chris and he was very helpful. We were then served by Anthony who was very attentive and gave us awesome treatment. My only suggestion would be that i wish they had better lighting. Also didnt like that the table topping were paper maybe glass would be more presentable and nicer on the eyes. 

Overall i would come back would recommend
author: Natalia R.

description: The service was great, efficient, very informative.  The oysters Wellington was fun to try(pics enclosed), probably wouldn't have it again.  The ambiance was great.  The filet mignon was good, asked for medium and received medium rare, the baked potato with it was a little over cooked.  The pecan pie and the chocolate mousse torte were amazing!  Next time would like to sit upstairs.  Pretty cool to eat in a restaurant that is 110 years old.
author: Chris M.

description:
Historic SF spot with larger portions. 

I came here at five-ish on a weeknight and by six o' clock, the after-work rush definitely piled in. I would definitely recommend making a reservation or getting here before the rush begins.

I got the shrimp cocktail, salad, lamb, and flan. Everything was bigger than I thought it would be. My eyes were definitely bigger than my stomach that night. The shrimps on the shrimp cocktail were definitely huge. I really enjoyed the cocktail sauce that came with it. It was tangy and spicy, extra horseradish wasn't needed for me. The salad was packed with crab pieces and shrimp. They definitely used real crab! It came on a huge plate. It could stand alone for dinner on its own. The lamb was great! It was cooked perfectly. I love the taste of char on my game meats and this definitely served that up right. It came with this most perfectly baked potato! Everyone at the table was raving about the potato for sure. Portions were so large, I would definitely have needed to take it home. The flan was creamy and not too sweet. It topped off the meal perfectly! 

I'll definitely come back here again if I'm craving a retro-vibe, straight-shot American dinner.
author: Tina Y.

description:
We have been going to John's Grill for about 22 years. It is amazing.
It is old time San Francisco, with the charm, the food, the service and the atmosphere you would expect. 
Don't go in there dressed like a slob with your day shorts on. They will let you in but you will be out of place. Business casual is perfect.
Everything on the menu is wonderful. Their steaks are cooked to perfection and they have a large choosing.
Their fish is out of this world. Most of it fresh, they will tell you, and all of it great. I love any and all of their White Fishes. Their John Dory is great. 
They have a full bar and serve a mean martini. They also have a good wine list.
You may be able to get in without a reservation, but I would make one to be sure. The place is not huge.
The service is perfect. They know the menu, they are attentive and will even tell you what place to try next.
The walls are awash with photos of authors and celebrties and Presidents who have dined here. It is told that Dashiell Hammett wrote at least part of the Maltese Falcon here. Whether that is true, I am not sure. But they love the falcon that sits atop the restaurant.
John's Grill is family owned and always has been. If you miss it, you have missed part of San Francisco.
author: Elizabeth L.

description:
John's Grill is a historic restaurant has been serving guests since 1908.  It is known as the setting for author, Dashell Hammett's The Maltese Falcon, where Sam Spade was a diner. This old school restaurant has dark oak paneled walls with white linen table cloths has pictures of well-known patrons and old San Francisco. 
The main dining room is on the first floor and private dining rooms were on the upper two floors. I was here for a retirement luncheon, which was set up on the third floor.  Our entrée selections were limited to Chicken Dijonnaise and Pacific Red Snapper, which I selected.

The entrée included a lightly dressed mixed greens salad with two cherry tomatoes topped with fresh parmesan.  A classic style salad. 

The entrée included steamed vegetables - squash, carrots and broccolini.  The Snapper was grilled with a buerre blanc sauce.  The large portion of fish, which consisted of one and a half filets, had a light batter on it was flaky, moist and well-seasoned. 

Dessert consisted of a scoop of very good vanilla ice cream with fresh berries. 

Coffee or tea was part of the menu, but it was never served.  

Overall, the Pacific Red Snapper was very good, salad was ok, and ice cream was good quality.  Service was good except we were not served coffee or tea.
author: Al L.

description: Excellent service on the floor and at the bar! Clam chowder + half order Jack LaLanne salad is a perfect lunch! If I could, I'd eat here every day :)
author: Molly H.

description:
Just had dinner here on a Friday night around 6 pm. The place was starting to fill up but luckily I had a reservation. The waiters here were very attentive and super friendly. My boyfriend and I started off with the shrimp cocktail and the shrimp was HUGE. The sauce was definitely tasty with the nice hit of spicy horse radish. We both had the new york steak and was pretty tasty. It was a little on the tough side but not too bad. We ended the dinner with the Flan and it was soo good! Not super sweet and you can really taste the ingredients in it. 

Overall, I definitely recommend a dinner at this historic San Francisco restaurant!
author: Arda S.

description:
clam chowder is good.  Good flavor.  not too much potatoes.  Fisherman's pasta has a cream sauce so it was very heavy.  Our waiter was a dishonest.  My friend ordered a burger and asked if cheese comes with it.  Our waiter replied, "yes" and told us all the cheeses to choose from.  When he go the check, cheese was an ADDITIONAL charge.  My friend said the burger was meh, no flavor.

I was planning to bring my family here but now I have second thoughts.
author: J W.

description:
Such a great classic SF restaurant! Been in business for 110 as of 2018. We had amazing service - our waiter was so kind and attentive. the walls were lined with black and white photos of famous guests. In terms of food... 
we ordered classic vodka (grey goose) martinis win 2 olives. had a delicious steak (dry aged 21 days) with peppercorn sauce, green beans, and a baked potato. such a great classic old school SF spot!
author: Nazlee H.

description:
I made a great choice choosing this place and my husband thanked me for it. 

We drove to San Francisco from L.A. for a short 1 day trip and we were looking up great restaurants at a decent price. The Yelp pictures of the clam in cream broth enticed me to pick this place and clam we ordered. We ordered not just the clam, but also the escargot in garlic cream, filet mignon, and ribeye. The escargot is equally as great as the clam, I was floored by the flavor of both. My husband said this is the best clam he's ever had, I agree. Very succulent!!! My ribeye was cooked perfectly, but it was kinda bland so was my husband's ribeye (it was more medium well, far from medium rare like he asked). Overall, the service was on point, staff very friendly! We will definitely come back again because I've been craving the clam and escargot in cream broth. This time, I'll order the halibut!
author: Sillage R.

description:
I had a great steak dinner here.  Service was good but kind of slow, but pretty good overall.

The ribeye steak was excellent, also had clam chowder to start and it was pretty good also.  Cheesecake was excellent, very creamy and not overly sweet.  I enjoyed John's Grill overall
author: Dan L.

description:
We really had a great steak at John's!  

If you're looking for an old school gem of a steakhouse, this is your spot.  Tablecloths, real service, and a great menu await you here...no gimmicks, no fusion, no hipster decor.  Just real food in a real steakhouse that knows what to do with meat.  (You know it's true, they don't all know how to cook a steak-even if they say they're experts at it!)

It's been a hectic month or so for us, so we were ready for a nice meal and John's really hit the spot.  They'll start you with cocktails and bread and keep giving you fantastic service all the way through.  I had an amazing, REAL caesar salad-which is hard to find these days.  (I know, run of the mill, but I love a good caesar with handmade dressing-which is what John's is.)  I added chicken to it and had so much, I couldn't eat it all...Hubby had the porterhouse, which in my opinion is the Cadillac of steaks-you don't see it on every menu these days!  Cooked to medium perfection, it was wonderful.  I believe he also had a baked potato and creamed spinach with it. (The spinach was just right.  See, old school. :)  )

We will definitely count John's as one of our regular spots.  Steak is on the menu for us a lot, and when you find a good one, you'd better hold onto it!

Thank you everyone at John's!  See you soon!

TIP:

*Head down Powell to where the streetcar does it's turn and look to the left.  You can't miss the giant neon sign.

*Make a reservation with open table online, you'll walk right in and get your table, no hanging around waiting...nice!

*If you're old like me, you'll go dressed pretty decently-but you'll see people wearing pretty much everything off the street.  I think it's nice to dress for dinner, but then life gets in the way sometimes, so don't freak out if you're not in your tie-they'll let you in!
author: Diana W.

description: Ordered the lobster ravioli, don't think they even thawed it out. Super cold as in refrigerator cold! Worst place ever!
author: Rene D.

description: Steak is superb but they keep asking if you have finished. Guess because they want to clear the table as soon as possible since there are people waiting .
author: Wang H.

description:
Historic eatery in the heart of SF. Made famous in 'The Maltese Falcon', this is a cool stop in the area. 

We tried drinks and several apps. I will say I'm not a huge fan of Escargots, but ours was decent here. Perhaps because of the heavy butter and cream?

The food was above par here but I think you come here for the nostalgia and historic significance as much as anything. Up the narrow stairs there is more dining and usually a live piano. The place was simply buzzing during our weekend night visit. 

After a few healthy drinks and a couple of apps we were ready to take on the hills again. Oh how I regret tackling SF hills AFTER having Asian Pear martinis here! Nonetheless it was a memory maker for sure.

The atmosphere is very cool and takes you back. The service was good and overall we definitely enjoyed it. The Tortelon was good as was the bread.

I did miss getting to try the chowder and it seems that was probably one of the best to try. Next time for sure.
author: Christopher S.

description: This restaurant is adorable inside and out! Its three floors of historic charm. The stair case the upper dining rooms is narrow and steep, there is an accessibility elevator but I'd say parties with any mobility concerns should stick to main floor. The dining areas are like and old fashioned chop house, steak house type atmosphere.  We came for the highly recommended clam chowder and lobster bisque. There are historic photos and architecture paired with classy furnishings. The third floor view is to die for and there's a secret balcony area/fire escape on the front of the building that I have heard they MIGHT let you look at if you're super nice. We had a large party but the service was fast and professional. Our server Mario was very knowledgeable, patient and funny with our group. Ten stars to him. And the food was delicious. Definitely recommend the ribeye! It was huge! The Moscow Mule was very gingery (in a good way). I would love to go back to this place on a date, very fancy and romantic! Great place to start or end the night!
author: Jennie J.

description: We decided to go to this restaurant because of its historical record of being in existence for a hundred and ten years. The food was fair to good overall and the service was a bit slow. Also, the waiter seem to be a bit young and inexperienced and had difficulty describing the menu or answering questions about wine selections. As was commented on by several reviewers, the clam chowder is a very solid contender. The lobster ravioli was good if one is looking for a cheese ravioli but if you are expecting much in the way of actual Lobster you will be very disappointed. My wife had the oyster Wellington which she enjoyed very much. The pecan pie was very good and had a hint of maple which allowed it to stand out relative to many restaurant pecan pies. However, there seem to be a slight taste of freezer burn which of course detracted from the overall quality. I can't say that I would rush back to re-experience this restaurant but was glad we came out rather than staying in for hotel room service.
author: RJ C.

description: This place is ok.  The food is good, not great.  They are famous for being the oldest place in SF.  And they're busy.   We had a reservation and were excited to dine here.  I liked the atmosphere.  We had a quiet booth for two by the bar, it was a perfect setting for a romantic dinner in this dark restaurant.   HOWEVER, shortly after being served our meal the hostess brought a young couple with a stroller and a screaming toddler to a seat AT THE BAR, less that two feet from our previously romantic setting.  That definitely changed the setting.  There is a time and a place for everything!!
author: Sabrina M.

description: Escargot was delicious and we shared the Johns Steak and it was plenty plus a delicious wedge salad.  Cute place looks busy all time but we sat right way This was my third visit .  Service excellent
author: Monique R.

description: It's historic...older restaurant. Pics and letters from Gov Schwarzenegger, George Lucas and more decorate the walls. Jack Lalanne has a favorite salad on menu. Ciopanno was good; escargot was excellent . Chocolate mousse torte delicious. Great older historic restaurant.
author: Julie F.

description:
Fantastic San Fran experience. I honestly
cannot find a flaw in the food, service, quality and waiter recommendations. We had oysters, lobster bisque and steak. I had John's NY steak on the bone and he had Ribeye...... John's steak exceeded by far and cooked to perfection. Have a bourbon! It's a generous pour. Loved the atmosphere too
author: AJ L.

description:
After a full week seafood binge I decided to try out some steak. Luckily at John's Grill I was able to get both. 

Started off with Escargots. They were good, the garlic butter sauce they were in was tasty. 
Had the pleasure of enjoying half of two entrees.

First, the Ribeye. It was a good size and fair thickness for $35. Perfect Medium Rare to my liking with a very good flavor to it. 

Second, the Chef Special Red Snapper. It was wonderful, two large pieces of snapper with a great sauce, mushrooms, and shrimp. It was an amazing dish i wanted to lick my plate. 

The waiter brought out a complimentary Flan after a miscommunication about a food allergy that led to a very late arrival of one entree at the table. 

Other than the small mishap that was not the waiter's fault, John's Grill was an exceptional meal and a great end to my trip to San Francisco.
author: Jackson M.

description:
My husband and I had such a great experience at this fine establishment. We were in town from Orange County on one of our honeymoon destinations. We were not disappointed. As soon as we walked in we were greeted with a warm smile and directed to our table. We were seated at a two top table and felt a little too close to the two top next to us and were moved to a four top by the very attentive wait staff.

All I can say is the service, food and atmosphere was exactly what we wanted this evening. Thank you to everyone of your employees that were there this evening 2/3/18. 

Craig and Amanda Wasserman
author: Amanda M.

description: The service was fine, but not good. The food was less than fine. The ribeye steak was a decent cut, but was not seasoned or salted at all. I don't like much salt or seasoning on my steak, but I want some! My husband got the chef's special fish and it was bad. The sauce was crunch and the flavor was bland. The vegetables were unseasoned and undercooked. The baked potatoes were fine, but not good or anything special. I would not recommend this place.
author: Amber S.

description:
My sister and I were walking around downtown San Francisco the day after her birthday I told her about John's Grill and we briefly ducked inside.  So, I made a reservation to continue celebrating her birthday Tuesday Feb 6 at noon. I told them how we'd been taken to the Z-List room at a steakhouse (not mentioning it had been Ruth's Chris on Van Ness). Was promised that would not happen at John's Grill.

The afternoon of the reservation everything went swimmingly and the birthday girl got to pick out her seat and our guest loved the food.

The lunch menu is fantastic as well as the service.
author: Mrs L.

description: Ehhhh...I wish I liked the food more because the atmosphere here was awesome. Picture this....Dark ornate wood paneling and historic pictures of San Francisco adorn the walls while a piano player is serenading you during dinner. I had an awesome negroni and my friends drinks were good as well. The bread they brought to the table was cold and unappetizing. The entrees were just ok. I had the lemon sole and for $23 dollars it came with a plain baked potato and some undercooked green beans. My friend got a steak and said it was excellent so maybe I should have gone that route. I'm pretty sure I walked right into a tourist trap...oh well.
author: Julie R.

description: Great place for dinner.  Reasonably priced.  Generous portions and great service.  Our bartender recommended.  He was right on the money.
author: Linda S.

description: First time there, my Chilean bass was delicious!  I will recommend this restaurant to all my friends.
author: Diane G.

description:
Great spot in Union Square!
I selected for a business lunch and glad I did.
Food was great and service was even better.
Will definitely go back
author: Art H.

description:
If you ever watched the Sopranos or any other mob related movie, eating at this establishment will make you feel like you having dinner with a mobster in an old Italian restaurant.

I had a business lunch here with a party of six and the host put our party too close to a party that occupied two large round tables.

Each time the servers would bring food or beverages to the large party, someone from my party would have to scoot closer to our table to allow the servers to attend the large party.

My party had reservations so there should have been better planning to accommodate all parties.

The food was good. I ordered a bowl of the clam chowder, a large serving with a lot of clam. Everyone else in my party was pleased with their food.
author: Stephen Y.

description: Had dinner here with colleagues visiting from the Ukraine.  Needed a place that would take reservations on short notice, had some steak and seafood options and would give visitors an SF experience.  I think it was a hit for my dining companions although for us Bay Area residents, we know there are better places for the price.
author: Kathleen W.

description:
John's Grill definitely has the cool factor being one of the older places in the Market District. Super old school style wooden seating with the white table clothes and lots of pictures on the wood plank walls.  It has a feel like an Italian Restaurant for me, not so much like a steak house. I would say they are more known for seafood here, followed by steak. 

Personally, I was looking for something more off the beaten path so I ordered what was featured on Gourmet Magazine, THE OYSTERS WELLINGTON at $28.95that contained
Creamed spinach, smoked bacon, baked in puff pastry on a bed of sherry cream. The cream is super creamy and you receive 3 good size fried oysters on your plate. One of the three oysters was a bit bitter for me so my experience was down to two oysters. The side vegetables were excellent and seasoned well. 

If you need to use the restroom, you'll have to take the stairs up and on your way you'll notice the Maltese Falcon. But if you are going to get up and take the narrow way there, be advised the it is difficult when they're busy as the waiter and waitresses also takes the up and down stairs frequently. So basically, don't wait until last minute to use the restroom. 

I don't dine in the city too often, maybe this is why. It's a bit expensive for my budget and personally I was thinking there should be more. Do order the salmon here as my friend Steve got a nice looking piece and it was done perfectly. Service is was attentive at first but after your entree comes, our waiter was hard to track down.
author: Pete S.

description: Super disappointed.  I was looking for some nice straight forward seafood.  My hotel recommended me here.  At the bar. Asked the bartender for recommendations, his reply is 'whatever you want.'   I'm visiting from a landlocked state..looking for some help here people.  Seems more like a steak house. I was too embarrassed to just walk out, so I felt obligated to at least order a shrimp cocktail & martini..still hungry. Where to next?  In all fairness, it's probably a fine restaurant, but not was I was looking for tonight.  Maybe I should be giving the hotel a bad review for a bad recommendation...
author: Joby W.

description: Great place! Nice atmosphere and very old school SF. I ordered the T-bone steak and it came with grilled veggies and a baked potato. I ordered a medium rare steak but it came back as medium. That's the only thing negative I have to say about it. My cousin had the Maine lobster ravioli and my mom had the red snapper. Both were very good. I also ordered a half dozen oysters and they were very fresh.
author: Michelle C.

description: I love John's Grill.  Food is always amazing and price is good for quality and potion.  I love the classic decor.  I believe Johns has been in business for over 100 years!
author: Robert G.

description: I have a general rule that I don't go to places that have less than four stars. The hotel concierge recommended this place, so I took a chance. Mistake. Place is quaint, but John's needs a visit from Gordon Ramsey for sure. I had the Ciopinno, and sorry, if you're serving this in S.F., it better be top notch. Broth was watery, scallops were rubbery. Pass.
author: Joe T.

description: We showed up for lunch on a Saturday without a reservation, but they found a table for us.  Everything was perfect from start to finish, and most importantly, the service was on point.
author: Yelp R.

description: Nice steak, nice cheesecake, nice atmosphere, what more could one ask for?  I come here a couple of times a year and always enjoy it. You should too.
author: Stewart G.

description: One of the best dinner meals to have in SF. Staff  is was very friendly and accommodating. The food is delicious and comes in large portions. Highly recommend to bring a date or family. Thank you to a special staff member, Chris for recommending John's Grill. This place is the best!
author: Diana C.

description: I'm a local, most patrons appear to be tourists. I was pleasantly surprised with the overall experience: food quality, service and old school SF ambience. Although Taddich still reigns supreme in the seafood department, John's holds its own as a chop house (with baked potatoes!). Nice live music upstairs too.
author: Dr. B.

description: First time here very nice looking cozy place decorated nicely for the holiday I started with a Bloody Mary just ok I've had many that were better, delicious bread had the escargot appetizer the sauce was very good opted for the crab and shrimp stuffed rigatoni it was a large portion good but not great chess cake for dessert was fantastic coffee was not hot spent $100 on lunch for 2 wouldn't do it again there
author: Patricia S.

description: Great steak, but the lunch menus were filthy. If I want to look at BBQ fingerprints on a menu, I can get that experience at Applebee's. For a venue charging 30+ dollars a steak, this type of thing is completely unacceptable. Also, need to cook the veggies better as well as they seemed undercooked.
author: Joseph B.

description:
This is a great family owned operation . 
The owner John really cares about each and every guest !


Don't miss the lobster bisque !

Thanks for being a classy establishment !

I'll be back!
author: Jason P.

description: John's grill is a historic restaurant with fantastic sea food. This cozy place is a little bit expensive but for sure the good service and food justify that. We'll be back again....
author: Babak G.

description: The real deal.  Reasonable prices for superb cuisine in the perfect environment with a professional staff.  Came in for dinner on a busy weeknight but was quickly seated.  Ordered the Sam Spade because I like it's on the menu.  Wow.  Lamb was perfect.  Vegetables excellent and the potato and sour cream an old-school classic.  I last visited in 2010 (last time in town)and ordered the same thing.  It I even better NOW in 2018.  Coffee is vintage diner quality, rich and butter.  Fruit plate is way over priced but very tasty and probably makes split checks or package groups easier.  Whatevs.  The perfect safe escape or cozy clubhouse in downtown SF.
author: Scott B.

description:
Mediocre food at high prices. Poor value. 
We were seated in the 3rd floor dining room with dirty carpet and shaky floor. 12 people they seat at 2 side by side round table at the corner of the room. Half of us were very uncomfortable. I asked to put us at the long table but the manager said all long tables were reserved. We made reservation 3 weeks ahead and came with the family to celebrate mine and my brother in law birthdays and my nieces graduation. Service were ok but the whole experience were very bad. Ruined celebration   Would not recommend this restaurant to anyone and wouldn't come back even if they would offer their food for free.
author: Joseph K.

description:
If I had it to over again, we would not have wasted one of our precious few meals in San Francisco on John's Grill.

We decided to go here based on the large banner next to the sign that says "Jazz Nightly." If you are making your decision to dine here for the jazz...don't. By "Jazz Nightly" they mean a guy on an electric keyboard singing stylized renditions of John Legend, Willie Nelson and Beatles songs. The music was too loud, poorly played, and most certainly not Jazz.

This place has so much going for it, it should be a San Francisco "destination restaurant," but everything is so poorly executed. It's as if everyone there stopped caring decades ago. The restaurant is crowded and dirty. The carpet was stained and needed a good vacuuming. The Maltese Falcon memorabilia was in dusty glass cases. The images on the website shows white tablecloths, but they line the tables in paper for each setting, so the effect of fine dining is completely lost. They should add crayons so people can color as they wait for the incredibly slow service. The bartender acted generally annoyed with having to deal with people. 

The food was average. The New York Steak was reasonably sized but equivalent to supermarket quality. The calves liver was quite good but was topped with overcooked, stale (and in my opinion unnecessary) bacon. The creamed spinach as extremely thin, but had an interesting, almost Mediterranean seasoning to it. The sourdough bread would have been much better served warm.  We normally would have split a salad, but they were priced $10-12ish per person, so it didn't seem as if splitting was an option. 

If they decide at some point to start caring again, and elevate this place to it's assumably previous greatness, here is where they should start:
1.  Clean the restaurant top to bottom.
2. Re-matte and reframe, perhaps even update some of the pictures of celebrities.  
3.  Reduce the number of  tables by 1/3.
4. Put a piano upstairs and hire a true jazz pianist, or put in a 3-piece combo
5. Update the menu, while keeping the standards to include fresh sides and higher quality proteins.
6. Invest in white table cloths and stop using the paper.
7. Customer service training for everyone.

Maybe someone will read this.
author: Diana D.

description:
We went expecting wonderful things, but what we got was a restaurant that is resting on its historic laurels.  
The prices are as one would expect of a high level eatery, but the food was not what it was advertised to be.  
I ordered a ribeye steak but got what appeared to be a sirloin or possibly a lesser cut.  It was tough and flavorless.  
To their credit, when i commented on its lack of provenance, they took it off my bill, but I wanted it to be wonderful, not comped.  I was severely disappointed.  

Everything else was fine and of good quality but when you order a nice steak that's what you should get.
author: Sandra L.

description: Very good steaks for great prices compared to everywhere else in the city. Still good 100 years + in business. I would recommend anyone visiting or living in the city to check it out because it's a piece of SF history.
author: Joshua B.

description:
Old school steak house with traditional old charm.
Everything from the food to service was superb.
Our waitress knew her stuff and directed our party to order perfect rations and variety.
We tried the lobster bisque, shrimp cocktail,  half dozen oysters. Rib eye  and prawn dijonaise to mention a few. We were impressed and loved everything we ordered. 
This will definitely be a stop off each and every time we are in San Francisco. 
I love leaving a restaurant feeling completely satisfied with everything we tried as well as the superb service we were given. 
Thanks John's Grill for helping us enjoy our stay here in the bay area.
author: Tristan K.

description:
John's Grill is a standard.  I thought it was going to be outdated, but it wasn't.  We had a small group of six people, and ordered a fairly wide variety of choices.  We enjoyed cocktails, appetizers, chowder, escargot (more on that in a minute), petrale sole (a favorite among our guests), and good wine choices, even a number of quality selections by the glass.  There was one in particular I've never seen on a restaurant wine list before (Clairborne and Churchill, Pinot Gris), let alone on the "by the glass" list.  Impressive.

As for the escargot... I recoiled when they showed up in a creamy sauce.  You see, I'm a traditionalist.  Our waiter reassured me that they would something new to me, but renowned there at John's, and he warrantied them.  These  tender escargot were out of the shell, and the sauce was a rich, yet subtle, garlic sauce that not only dressed the escargot nicely, but not overly so.  (You do know that all restaurant shells are stuffed from carefully processed snails, not fresh, right?.... except maybe in rural France). Anyway, these were perfect, and the sauce was beautiful with the bread.  Applause!

The New England Clam Chowder could have used, in my opinion, a more flavorful clam broth and more clams.  It ended up being  too smoothly creamy and lackluster in flavor.  Note: it only comes in the bowl size, therefore could pass as a main course, for some people.  Not a morsel left on any plate by the end, so that's a good sign!  Their French Fries are the optimal thickness so they stay nice and hot by the time they arrive at the table.  I hate cold Fries.

We couldn't resist dessert.  Cheesecake, Flan, Chocolate Mousse, all just the right sized portions.  Each was enough to share between two who just want a bite.  Together they made for a great dessert buffet for the table.  Coffee and Cappuccino set the whole meal off perfectly.

But wait, there's more! I need to give props to the wait staff!  They worked like a well-oiled machine.  Courteous, professional, and always available with a mere nod of your head.  Sample a beer, or a wine, before deciding?...No problem!  They had none of that territorial attitude that keeps someone from helping you because you're not in the "station".  
Always a smile.  And they got us out to the theater on time! Yay!
author: James G.

description: This was rated high on OpenTable, which was a lie. The food presentation was poor, oysters were in a plate; no ice. The steak was either too dry, gummy or excessively bloody. The last time I checked ordered medium... if I can add an emoji I would add an eyeroll.  The lobster bisque tasted like salty canned soup but no lobster. So I would warn others that the name means nothing if they can't even make the food presentable
author: Elle 3.

description:
This place saved the day when a friend and I couldn't find any other restaurant with space a couple days before Xmas - the height of tourist season in the height of tourist central.   While it looks small from the street, the dining area actually goes pretty far back, and up a story or two.  In other words, it's massive inside.

Anyway, it's a decidedly mainstream and or throwback experience, with an Italian-centric menu featuring lots of pastas and steaks.  No anything-fusion sauces or exotically herbal cocktails here; your out of town relatives will be completely comfortable!  We had the Tortellone, the ribeye, and a couple drinks.    Of everything we had there was general agreement that the bearnaise sauce on the steak was the biggest winner.   And nothing was bad.

Service was attentive (free bread) even if entree delivery was a little slow due to the crowds.  Would be happy to come back here in another pinch.
author: Aaron M.

description: Try the favorite salad of the late fitness guru Jack LaLanne, with crab, shrimp, avocado, mushroom, tomato, lettuce and blue cheese dressing.
author: Amanda T.

description: Absolutely the best halibut I have ever had.  Delicious cocktails. Augie our server was phenomenal.  Would highly recommend this restaurant to everyone.  Fantastic all around.  Been in business since 1908.  Old school and awesome
author: Lisa M.

description: I tried this steakhouse while visiting San Fransisco for a conference. First off, this restaurant is LOUD, it was hard to hear the person sitting next to me. The wait staff was very responsive but the food was a miss. I started with the lobster bisque and moved on to filet for the main course. The bisque was flavorful but the steak was over cooked and lacking flavor. I ordered the steak medium and a lot of areas on the steak was well done. I didn't send it back because it took so long to get the meal, I didn't want my co-workers to be held up. I would try the restaurant again but order my steak a little more rare than last time.
author: Nicki S.

description:
We were attending a play at the Golden Gate Theater scheduled to start at 6:30p.m. on a Sunday night. We wanted to arrive by 6:00p.m. Where to have an early dinner? We parked near the theater and began walking. Every two blocks, we would check Yelp and look at reviews and ratings. We decided on John's Grill, 4:15 reservation. Plenty of time to order, eat, relax and walk back to the show.

We were greeted immediately, seated next to the front window at a four-top, presented with menus and then shortly with sour dough bread and soft wrapped butter. Our server came to take drink orders and we placed our food order at the same time. 

We had:

New York Steak, medium rare, with Baked Potato and Seasonal Veg - (4) - The steak was flavorful and had a nice grill pattern. The veg were not cooked to death and had good flavor. The potato was what it should be.

Cioppino - (4) - It's too bad that a San Francisco restaurant offers Cioppino without Dungeness Crab during Crab season. On the other hand, the broth was thin but very delicious. The seafood included 3 large sea scallops, 3 large prawns, 4 each of clams and mussels, some bay shrimp and several pieces of fish. Crab would have made this dish a 5.

Pecan Pie ala Mode - (4) - As the server stated, it was a small piece of pie but it was enough to satisfy the sweet tooth. Ice cream appeared to be home made. There were also a few berries to round off the dish. 

Yumm!
author: Dexter D.

description: Just had one of the best dinners out in months, thanks to the staff and culinary pros at John's grill. A historic and neighborhood fixture since 1908, you will not be disappointed. I travel for a living and this place is one of the best. I had the broiled halibut which came with vegs and a baked potato. The pre-meal sourdough was awesome. Do yourself a favor and drop some hard earned bucks here. Great food, excellent service, and a nice ambience. Also, nightly live light jazz every evening.
author: Kevin F.

description: The quality of the food is excellent. I have eaten there twice. Both times delicious. The service is a four star out of a possible five star. The tables are small yet comfortable. The house wine was excellent. If you go there and you eat like a normal human being this restaurant is half the price of most high-end restaurants. I highly recommend this restaurant!
author: Ed M.

description: We love this place we never miss a chance to go here every time we go to the city it's old and it's quaint and it's got that feel of a better time awesome food good strong drinks and a bartender that is always awesome no matter who it is.
author: Nicole S.

description: The place is 110 years old wow! The ambience is quintessential San Francisco I just loved it and I was like and have to be there during New Year's so they still have it all decorated it was beautiful everyone was nice I had the lobster raviolis delicious
author: Mina G.

description: Great steakhouse!  Was recommended by the staff at the hotel we were staying at.  I had a ribeye and my wife had a filet mignon.  Both were tender, had juices flowing and were delicious.  I wanted to point out someone left a review indicating that the ribeye was Outback Steakhouse quality at twice the cost.  I disagree as this was one of the best steaks I've ever had.  I almost decided against eating here after reading that review but it couldn't have been more wrong.  This is a fancy steakhouse and the price are justifiable.
author: Brian F.

description:
I'm so glad that John's Grill is here in SF.  It's as historical and vintage as it gets.   It's a real tribute to San Francisco.  Think B/W old movies and you'll understand the vibe.

 Even the menu is old-school.  I had a bowl of clam chowder, cup of coffee and the Jack LaLanne salad.  (avocado, shrimp, crab, mushrooms, greens, tomatoes and blue cheese dressing)  It was very filling as was the rich, creamy chowder.  The two of us split the bowl of chowder and were grateful that we did because it is extremely heavy.  The food was good--probably 3.5 stars.

We noticed a few elderly birds at the bar.  They were day drinking.  Both were enjoying their martinis at 2:20pm but it looked like they would probably be in bed by 6:30pm.  (heavy eyelids etc)

The waitstaff is as professional as can be and are all dressed in attractive black and white attire.

Take time to look at all of the pictures that are on the walls.  You'll see every famous San Franciscan that you can imagine.
author: Thomas D.

description: Quickly seated at this legendary San Fran restaurant recommended by hotel concierge. Waiter greeted me & brought sourdough bread & water. Had a nice glass of Pinot Noir. Ordered a shrimp cocktail that was ok...Shrimp butterflied & nice presentation but not much flavor. Also had lunch salad with blue cheese dressing. Ok too just average. Waiter brought check & back out to explore.
author: Ellen M.

description: The clam chowder was to die for!! Wish I had time to get cheesecake, it looked delicious but we were in a rush! Definitely would recommend going! It is a little nicer and more expensive, but is definitely worth it. Everyone there was very nice.
author: Jackie A.

description: The history of John's Grill alone is worth stopping by for a drink. The food and service are impeccable. The downside are the cramped dining area and limited beer selections.
author: Mickey B.

description: When you walk in and see photos of glitzy celebrities lining up the walls e.g. Sophia Loren, Humphrey Bogart, etc who'd dined here, you know this restaurant must be classy and expect the food to be the same. We were not disappointed. The ambiance was NY noisy, almost as loud as in a Chinese restaurant, service was thoughtful, and the food delicious! My friends had the Ribeye Steak, Petrale Sole, Grilled Pacific Red Snapper and moi, the Chicken Jerusalem which was featured in Gourmet Magazine - the chicken was velvety soft and artichokes were tender and the gravy was so umami! My friends loved their entrees! Just go there and scratch off your San Francisco must-visit bucket list
author: Sheue L.

description: excellent dinner. husband had house salad & the filet he said both were outstanding,the filet especially! i had the seafood pasta. so so much of a variety of tasty seafood in the pasta,the cream sauce was wonderful,very generous portion too. generous wine pours too. they eere out of caesar salad lettuce but everything else made up for that. our server was attentive. loved the piano music. very quaint cozy "classic" restaurant! can see why its been around for 110 yrs! we visit san francisco every few months & this is one of our favorites! we will be back for another amazing dinner.
author: Carmen B.

description: Had dinner here last night with a group of friends and it was an excellent experience!  The drinks were great.  The shrimp cocktail and crab cocktail appetizers were fantastic.  Do yourself a favor and order their famous lamb chops... soooooo good!  We finished off the meal with the cheesecake and pecan pie.  Can't wait to go back.
author: Sean P.

description: Excellent Filet Mignon and Heirloom Tomato Salad. The server​ was very polite, knowledgeable and fast. Very quick service from time of order for this type of restaurant.
author: Aaron B.

description: Hellllll no. I won't ever come back here. We had a large business dinner. There's was 9 of us and we got a reservation pretty easy. We ordered appetizers and they were pretty good. But the entrees were nasty. A lot of my colleagues got the filet or ribeye. It was okay but one reported that their ribeye was well done when he ordered medium rare. Some others just didn't like it. I had the Oysters Wellington. They were NOT good at all. The oysters were smoked which was weird but they were also really fishy tasting. And not in a good way. It was very salty too. I only gave an extra star because the service was very good and I appreciated that they could accommodate such a large group.
author: Emily P.

description: Great old-timely atmosphere. The drinks were tasty.  The Caesar was perfect. The Ribeye was supreme (but lose a star for being thin-cut, a steak should be 1" or thicker guys). Our only other nit was that the side vegetables qty was minuscule...probably ok for Bogart, not for modern eaters. Will definitely return
author: Jeff J.

description:
My wife and I brought my in laws here for a birthday dinner as they were visiting from overseas.
John's grill is historic, noisy, expensive and not worth visiting if you aren't a tourist. We will not be returning here. 
The food was sufficiently good (I ordered a John's NY steak) but not great. I've had a better steak at Tad's down the street on Powell St. for half the price (which I recommend).
We were seated on the second floor, at our first table the AC was blasting in our neck and when asked, the hostess opted for moving us instead of turning it down (which was fine) but we were moved to a cramped table (we were four).
The music was very loud, the room was extremely loud which caused conversation to be hard to have.
The waiter brought us the wrong wine (perhaps he also had a time hearing us when ordering due to the noise), and upon us failing to explain it was the wrong one, we gave up and kept it instead.
The flan we had for dessert was pretty good though.
I would not recommend this venue.
author: Paolo E.

description: I really enjoyed the atmosphere. The live musician was excellent and the volume was perfect for an evening dinner. Our dishes were all fresh and well presented as well as being tasty. My only complaint would be that they actually close at 9:30 and we wanted to enjoy the evening longer. :)
author: Jim J.

description:
If you want a quiet and peaceful place for dinner- this isn't the place for you.  
If you want a place that isn't overcrowded-
This isn't the place for you.  
If you want an attentive waitstaff that gives colorful descriptions of your drinks and food- 
This isn't ..... you get my drift. 
We made reservations and overheard people discussing that they hadn't and would have a 20 minute wait and then were put ahead of us.  We had to wait about 20 minutes for a table after our reservation time.  I had mentioned on our reservation that we had someone on crutches and they STILL put us upstairs. I had to ask the hostess what the procedure was when we were finally invited to come inside because she just left us standing there.  Then we had this awkward moment where we just stood there upstairs waiting, again, for a table.  Bizarre and not very accommodating given that we had someone on crutches. 
The waitstaff actually hit our arms as they rushed by our table.  The tables are literally stuffed into the space.  They really need to remove some and give better attention to their patrons. 
The pomegranate cosmopolitan is excellent. We had the Jumbo Prawns Dijonnaise   This was an excellent meal. Also, we had the T-bone steak and the menu took pride in now the meat is carefully aged and chosen, but honestly, I've bought better steaks at the grocery store.  

The restaurant is way too loud.  We literally had to shout at each other to hear our own conversations and then just gave up.  They boast about famous people visiting and the history of the place, but more attention needs to be given to the ambiance and customer service.  We are not impressed with this place and will not return.
author: Lora K.

description: Johns grill was recommended by our concierge and I am really happy with the recommendation. When I saw "grill" i thought it would be a little too laid back but decided to give it a try anyway. It was a relaxed atmosphere but definitely a classy crowd and so much history. The food was DELISH. I would definitely return if in the bay area.
author: Tisha R.

description: What a s@*t hole.  If you are under 60 and not with your parents...you should check yourself.  Food is mediocre and the ambiance is a cross between a tired steakhouse and the iron soaked streets of San Fran...not a treat.
author: Adam J.

description:
Great food and service.

Recommend  in order
Lobster Bisque
Prawn cocktail
John's salad
Chiefs fav Red Snapper w mushrooms and Crab
author: John L.

description: Had the best night here on NYE 2017, we were tempted in by the old Skool look and feel of this place. It was perfect for NYE, we did not book but were lucky enough to get 2 seats at the bar. Our server was amazing and the bartender made the best dirty martinis for us. Everyone was having fun and there was a massive line out in the street to come in, so we felt very grateful to get a spot at the bar. The food was fantastic considering it was probably the busiest night of the year and the kitchen was under pressure. So glad we found this place by just wandering along the streets of San Francisco. It Defo has the old New York feel and I'm sure there were a few gangstas mauling around in there!
author: E T.

description:
A wonderful gem!  This restaurant where "The Maltese Falcon" was written has been around since 1908. It was recommended by our concierge at the Marriott Marquis and was a total success. Our server was incredibly friendly and helpful. We had a wonderful 2015 Cabernet Sauvignon from Paso Robles and enjoyed the people and amazing food. 
We started by sharing the best bowl of clam chowder I've ever tasted (huge). I followed with Jack Lalanes favorite salad and my dining companion ( DH) ordered their fishermans pasta per our servers recommendation. Both were fantastic and stuffed with seafood. The pasta was more balanced with the savory notes to offset the sweet fresh and abundant seafood. The salad was delicious but a little too sweet. Perhaps because I ordered it without mushrooms which would have offered a earthy not to ground the sweet heirloom tomatoes, fresh seafood and creamy avocado?
This is a definite repeat for us and I would recommend as a perfect lunch spot if you're looking for seafood and especially a bowl of clam chowder;)
author: Carin B.

description:
The bartender is very welcoming and friendly. He knows the regulars and what they usually have. He whistles while he works. 
I came in from a hot day for just a beer. Then I felt I should have a little something to tie me over until dinner. I ordered the plate of steamed clams, thinking I'd get just a small plate with a few. What I got was a huge bowl, with about 2 dozen clams in the tastiest broth ever. After that and two beers, I didn't need dinner that night.
I'm certainly coming back here, next time I'm in town.
author: Nat F.

description: Real nice classic in town. Good food and service and they even have jazz nights! Park at garage across the street, free valet.
author: Robert M.

description: This place is a classic, paneled walls, pictures of famous people who have visited, white linen, etc. Tables are tight, chairs are old school and not so comfy, it's what you'd expect. The service is very crisp without being overbearing. Very accomodating. The lobster bisque special was different than i am used to, it was thicker,  more creme based, but good.  The filet was very tasty, how could it not be and the accompanying vegetables were tasty. Pecan pie was off the chart. Feeling pleasantly plump now in the afterglow. Only downside is that the noise level escalates when full which is often.
author: Steven D.

description: I am back in 2017 to say that everything in my 2016 review still stands and the excellence is still there with this place. I am a cook so I would know and I gotta say this food is delish. The burgers are really good and the seating is very cozy. This is definitely a great place to bring a date. The lunch menu is incredible.
author: Luke S.

description: I want to say my evening started out just great! This was my first time coming here. I decided to choose this place over Tads Steakhouse. My husband and daughter were welcomed in just fine. William our server was great very patient and understanding due to the fact that we had a lot of questions since it was our first time coming in. Long story short after our meal when leaving out we greeted the doorman and told them thank you. On our way out their was a police car out front. The two doormen on duty along with two other male men were standing out front as we were walking out telling them thank you for holding the door the gentlemen *Made a very racial comment* then begin to *Say oh great your just in time as they pointed towards the police car and said *your ride is here to take you home* and they begin to laugh* When I tell you I left out feeling so bad. I left out feeling soooooo bbaaaddd* I have a 3 year old daughter who was in the mist of it and was just innocent.  And this was by far the worst experience I have ever had from a business. I went in with high expectations and on my way in I felt great! Then when  that happened It turned my night out with my family upside down I felt really low. I will never come back to this place again. Please train your staff to respect all ethnic backgrounds. It wasn't a funny joke to say or laugh at.. It was embarrassing!
author: Sarah P.

description:
Almost didn't go in because of a guy blocking the entrance. First I thought he was a customer leaving but he didn't. He was holding a menu in his hand, looking angry. But I was curious enough about the place so I bumped passed him. No hello. No come on in. Just weird. He was there the whole night by the way. 
Ordered a ribeye medium, came back rare as hell. Sent it back, came back the same. How does a 100 year old steak joint not know how to cook a steak? Saved by my waiter who took it back again and got me a new one cooked just right. Bartender and staff are great. That's why three stars. Get rid of the guy in the front and you get 4!
author: Gaby A.

description: First time visiting, must say, I was highly satisfied with the overall experience. Decided to expand my horizons by trying the escargot and it was delicious.
