Additionally, I ordered the filet mignon which was really juicy, tender overall cooked perfectly. I had the pleasure of being served by Chanteal and even had the chance to meet the manager Alejandro who's customer service was top notch. Needless to say, I highly recommend this place and I will be visiting again soon!!
author: Benny A.

description: Excellent restaurant. Filet was perfect with bearnaise sauce. New York strip was excellent with peppercorn sauce. Dessert was phenomenal Pecan pie. Met former San Francisco Police commissioner, obviously local favorite.
author: Jenny S.

description: Fantastic old school joint in the heart of the city. I'm a sucker for a throwback and quality, and this place has it by the pound. Everything we indulged in was excellent: Oysters Wellington, A great medium burger, steamed mussels, chowder, and an insane Jack LaLanne salad.The cocktails were nothing to sneeze at either. Ordered a Super Dirty Martini, Sidecar,and beer. Loved everything!
author: Ann G.

description: Great classic steak house in Union Square area of San Francisco. My wife and I both had the filet mignon with baked potatoes, while sharing sides of sautéed mushrooms and asparagus with hollandaise sauce. Steak was cooked perfectly and the sides were all very good. Great food, great price, and great classic steak house atmosphere.
author: P. J.

description:
There is a great restaurant in close location near by union square. Their service is excellent and food is also wonderful The day was my husband's birthday and they made us a suprise with a lovely dessert at the end... 
we like their New York steak and rib eye steak (good choice:)) thank u four everything
author: Bercan Ö.

description: Shrimp cocktail is great. Oysters great. Atmosphere is intimate and romantic. Old school
author: Matt R.

description:
Steak was warm, not served hot. Quality of meat was good. The only gluten free option was steak. All seafood has flour in the sauces! Service mediocre. 
Small restaurant, more than 100 years old, has its charm.
author: Bia A.

description: Very unimpressed. I sat at the bar where the bartender really cared nothing for waiting on me. The steak was pretty aweful - extremely fatty and lots of grissle - note to self do not attempt to eat while sitting at the bar. My beer was gone so I asked the waiter - the bartender said, i got it - yeah, 10 min later - VERY POOR SERVICE. $77 for a steak dinner and 2 beers - big mistake.
author: Sean G.

description:
3 stars tonight is being generous... Great build up for a less than underwhelming experience tonight. Crazy packed (not sure why) 

I get it, it's an iconic place but so what! 

The waiter recommended the Johns bone in NY. Sounds great!!!!! But this steak was not only small but over cooked and cold. The weird green beans were way too crunchy basically raw no flavor and the baked potato was also small wrinkled dry like they pulled it out of a microwave 4 days ago. 

Also only having mashed potatoes during lunch, big mistake. At least if I had mashed potatoes that were good and hot, I could have masked my boring steak instead of the weird tiny baked potato 

One more thing.... the seating by the front window is way too cramped. No need to pack everyone in one on top of the other, like its family style.
author: Cba P.

description: Don't waste your money. Steaks, salads, fish all below average. Service was as bad as the food. Asked the waiter for a cup of coffee and he was bothered. Only redeeming factor about the restaurant is the history and old pictures on the wall. I was with a party of fifteen and not one person thought the food was anything special.
author: Dan S.

description:
Great Historical Place.... Great food, great ambiance....
I sat in the booth where Dashell Hammett wrote the 
Maltese Falcon, How cool is that.....
author: Michael G.

description: Atmosphere is great.  Food is a little pricey for what you get, but it is San Francisco.  We would go back if in the area, but won't go out of our way to visit again.
author: Jacque S.

description: Never mind the wonderful John's famous bone in t-bone.  Never mind the great selection of wine. Never mind the expected wonderful big city ambiance.   The waiter forgot to bring me pepper for my Idaho baked potato so he credited two ( not one) glass of wine.  Small mistakes made up quickly resulting in my high praise review.  Nick was my main captain and  rocked it tonight.
author: Craig O.

description: John's Grill is super OG and a staple to SF. Being a San Francisco native I can appreciate the old school vibes, the  classic esthetic and delicious food. The portions are big, the staff are friendly and the live music they had playing definitely set the mood. My new annual spot.
author: David B.

description: This is the best place to go when down by this area.  It's is such a classic San Francisco place with photos of local celebrities all over the wall.  The best part is that the "Maltese Falcon" (yes, from the movie) is in an upstairs cabinet.  Apparently the movie was written sitting in one of the booths.  How cool.
author: Greta R.

description: Service quick and professional.  The bartender makes a smooth vodka martini.  My go to meal is the seafood cannelloni it will surprise your pallet.  It is beyond delicious.  The Red Snapper was ok lacked flavor, in my book.  Don't be put off by the fact that it's downtown.  Touristy but I am a native and have been going there for years.  Try it! They have an extensive menu you will find something.
author: Pam P.

description: Poor service to start, but willing to let it slide if the food was good. Ordered the Red Snapper and it was disgusting! The thinnest piece of fish I've ever seen, breaded (who does that?), and drenched in the most buttery cream sauce I've ever tasted, I couldn't even taste the fish. The vegetables were barely cooked. Disappointing. And that was for $29!!! I tried to order something else, but didn't bother and left, only to get called back because I didn't pay. WHAT??? I sent the food back after two bites, didn't even have the bread brought to the table and only had water. Seriously? Oh wait, it was a mistake, they thought I ordered a drink, nope, just water (And not bottled). Anyway....enjoy.
author: Doctor L.

description:
Took my family here for a birthday dinner.  We were seated right away.  Service was so so.  When we ordered something it came pretty fast, but there were long periods where the waiter was no where to be seen.  
I had a filet steak and it came out warm, not hot, and was just average in flavor and tenderness.  I was disappointed that a steak place doesn't serve piping hot steaks.  The place is crowded and seems to do a nice business.
author: Robert J.

description: I don't usually post on yelp but wow what an experience I had at Johns Grill. Now I know why they've been open 110 years, yes I SAID 110 YEARS!! At the beginning I was kinda doubting my friends decision cause I'm not a steak kinda guy, I try staying away from any kinda beef or pork products. But I heard they had a good sea food menu so I decided what the heck let's go!! Since the beginning I got greeted by the nice gentleman and lady at the door, for not having reservations we got seated fairly quick (less than 5 mins.) We decided to split the "Jack LaLanne's Favorite Salad" as an appetizer, we understand why it was his favorite.. this salad was full of crab meat and baby shrimp it was delicious! As an entree I went with the Sea Food Cioppino And my friend got a Porterhouse Steak. My cioppino was filled with fish, shrimp, scallops,mussels and lots more, one of the best if not THE BEST IVE EVER HAD. My friends steak came with a huge baked potato and some veggies, looked like it was cooked to perfection cause he didn't complain. We ended the night splitting a delicious cheesecake and a bowl of their homemade ice cream. Overall the service, staff, place and the food was amazing. Whenever I'm in town I'm definitely coming back to this amazing SF GEM!!
author: Christian C.

description:
My colleague and I are always on the lookout for"old guard" restaurants around the country... John's Grill sets the bar.

I can't say enough about this place.... Outstanding food and drinks, wonderful service... And you can't find better or more historic venue. 

Don't miss John's Grill...i never do when I'm in the "City".
author: P I.

description:
I revisited this restaurant after an above average meal a bunch of months ago.  I am on business.  I was going to head to a second Hog Oyster House meal, but this is so close to the Hilton Hotel I decided to re-visit and have the Seafood Cioppino.  The bar had seats and the cocktail was excellent as well as the bar tender.  I so waited for the Cioppino.  After snapping some pix, I decided on the large scallop to begin.  As I put it into my mouth expecting a great flavor I was totally shocked with a mouthful of Ammonia.  No doubt this is a taste and experience that cannot be denied.  That was the end of that.  Meal over.  No manager or follow up..I finished my drink.  They did not charge me.  History.  Here is the case that I experience:

The ammonia-like smell is because the fish is not fresh. It is a product of decomposition. Don't eat it if it smells like that. It might not make you sick, but then again it might. Why risk it or have an unpleasant experience? Fish should have only a briny aroma of the sea. If it has a fishy smell from being in plastic, briefly rinse in fresh water. If the fishy smell persists or is strong, take it back and demand a refund. For that reason, it's best to cook fish the same day you buy it.

This means I will not return.  It clearly is not fresh and there is nothing they can do to fix that fact.  YUK.  And no manager visited to ask or anything..they know, I know, and they know I know.  Best to stay away my friends.
author: David G.

description:
I was part of a higher group and we had a separate room, third floor.
Food was fabulous, very tasty and service was excellent as well.
author: Dave J.

description:
Been here before and enjoyed our evening's meal! Lots of nostalgia, after all the restaurants been open for well over 100 year. Lastly, the Maltese Falcon was penned there!! 

This visit was prearranged by our hotels concierge, well let's just say it wasn't handled correctly at all, which wasn't JG's problem or doing! However, after speaking with the Maitre-'d he quickly took action, within 10 minutes all was well! 

Our meal, her filet was wonderful, cut with one Knive stroke and deliciously medium rare. The Johns Steak, was the toughest piece of meat I've ever had at a high end chop house!! So I had them take it away & ordered the filet as well! The pairing itself was perfect and our special desert was superb!!

Other then our arrival which was quickly remedied and not JG's fault. My cut of meat was the sole issue of the night. Which is a big problem, in my book.
Still a 4 out of 5 stars.
author: Alan B.

description:
I love this restaurant!!

Great food, live music, amazing service and ambience. 

 My fiancé and I had dinner here twice so far, and both times the food was amazing. 
I ordered the halibut and he ordered the lamb chops. 
BOTH DELICIOUS! 
For appetizer I recommend getting the heirloom tomatoes salad. Has mozzarella with slices of tomatoes and a tasty balsamic sauce on top. My favorite!
Their wine is all sold in house. We ended up buying a bottle and was at a very reasonable price.  

TIP: try to get seated on the top floors (the restaurant is 3 stories). The higher you go The less crowded, and you get a better view. 
They always have live music on the second floor. 

HIGHLY RECOMMEND THIS RESTAURANT 
Great food, live music, amazing service and ambience.
author: Madina A.

description:
Great spot to go when shopping Union Square area.  Such a nice setting, great service and a restaurant with a lot of history.

We started with great cocktails.  We split two salads between four of us, they plated them so we could share.  I had the seafood cioppino, a very generous plate of prawns, fish, scallops, excellent.  The steaks were perfectly prepared, and the chicken Jerusalem was delicious.  Old school done right, no wonder this restaurant is still popular.  We will be going back.
author: Carole W.

description: Looks like a classic menu that will make your mouth water for what should be a great meal. Don't be fooled!! As cozy as it looks it is not worth forking over any money for their meat. The New York Steak was dryer than a sidewalk street in August. The vegetables lacking in creativity and then having to dig butter out of little packets on top of it all. Being a family that treasures their experiences in restaurants around the world this is not one for the list. The server Chris tried to make up for the overdone cooked elegantly disguised disaster but unfixable at any cost. Pass on by........
author: Hunter G.

description: I'm not that impressed with this restaurant. The food is ok but the service was poor and slow.
author: Bell S.

description: We had a fabulous meal at John's.  The service was great, the ambiance reminded us of San Francisco "in the day".  Prices were reasonable for San Francisco and we will definitely be back!
author: Terri S.

description: I'm not a beef eater, but my husband is, so we decided to try this spot....mainly because it was within walking distance of our hotel downtown San Francisco. It's a cool place with a lot of history. It was a Sunday night and the place was packed at 7:30. We were fortunate to grab a two top on the second level, near the guitar player. We enjoyed the light music he was playing & he was so friendly! The server was obviously rushed, we definitely didn't feel welcomed by him. While he was taking our order, he was looking around the room at his other tables and where the host was seating new customers. It was a not a genuine interaction. We ordered our entrees and a couple glasses of wine. The wine was good but my entrée of the Heirloom Tomato Salad was not great. The tomatoes were hard and not ripe. In addition, they were swimming in the balsamic and olive oil. My husband ordered the New York steak and enjoyed it. Unfortunately, he said he's had a similar steak at a Longhorn......I don't think that's good? His baked potato was huge, fluffy and came with a ton of butter, which made him happy. Next time we're in town, we will avoid John's.
author: Heather H.

description: Always reliable. Good food in an old fashioned San Francisco atmosphere. We sat upstairs where a guitarist played wonderful music.
author: Karen H.

description: We had lunch at John's Grill because we had enjoyed our dinner there so much on our last trip to San Francisco. Our server was prompt, efficient and friendly. My son had the lobster ravioli -- delicious! Perfectly cooked lobster-stuffed ravioli in a tomato cream sauce. I had the seafood cannelloni. Baby vegetables were perfectly prepared. The only disappointment was my husband's oysters - over cooked and greasy. They did not taste fresh. John's Grill remains one of our favorites in the Union Square district -- it's the stuff dreams are made of. We are big fans of The Maltese Falcon, obviously.
author: Teresa B.

description: Clam chowder was creamy and had good size clam pieces. The fried jumbo shrimp was good not great but the porterhouse steak was seasoned and cooked perfectly.
author: Miyako M.

description:
So what drew me to an establishment that has been around for over 100 years?  It had to be the reputation of the food?  It had to be the reputation of the service?  Nope, we were just hungry and saw this restaurant walking down the street.  

Overall we should have kept on walking.  Bang for buck is lacking.  Lunch for two with no drinks was $125!!  Yup, bring your wallet!!!  The person who holds the door open must have been freezing as the wind was blowing and he was in the shade.  I felt bad for the guy.  Our host was very nice and we were seated promptly.  Our server was also genuine and nice.  So, we go off to a good start.

The place is small, so if you come at peak time, you will be waiting.  Old school wood paneling with lots of pictures of many famous people who ate there.

We went ahead and ordered a salad  (no ranch here :) ) along with our meals.  The salad was underwhelming at best.  Very small for the price.  The Filet and Rib-eye were cooked as requested, however there was absolutely no seasoning at all at any level.  Thank goodness for the side of grilled onions and mushrooms.  This was one of the plainest pieces of meat I have ever had, especially at (what I found out later) an expensive steak house.

The rib eye was very fatty and 1/4 was unedible as it was all fat.  The filet had no taste.  The sides were ok, however, nothing to write home about.

The only thing that saved this from going into two star land is the desert.  We had the Cheescake/Berrys and homemade ice-cream.   Both of those deserts popped with flavor and we thoroughly enjoyed them!  The Ice Cream was homemade and very creamy and the cheesecake had a nice crust and I would highly recommend that dessert.  However, for main courses, I would try something else if you are going to spend bug bucks for lunch/dinner.
author: Larry H.

description:
This place gets crowded during meal hours.  When visiting SF we always make it a point to stop here.

Had an club sandwich for lunch which was big enough for two!  Very delicious.

Staff very efficient.
author: Diane I.

description:
Amazing little place!!

I had such a great time going to this place, the service was friendly and fast. I love the old world feel with the white table clothes, photos on the wall, and the decor. It's a historical building and has many stories, the waiter told us we could walk around upstairs and look around even though it was blocked off. The second floor is for special parties. 

My friend ordered a rib eye and he wanted it medium well, sacrilegious I know, but they cooked it right and it was still moist.

The escargot was amazing and I would highly recommend. 

The stuffed sole was filled to the brim with crab and the sauce was to die for.

I ordered the lamb chops and I nibbled the meat off to the bone. Seasoned well, good size portion, and not badly priced.
author: Tina V.

description: Superb. Be forewarned: the place is packed to being overcrowded and a bit on the noisy side. Don't go without a reservation unless you plan to stand outside for a couple of hours. So saying, the ambiance, service and food, once you get seated, are outstanding. Four of us all ate something different and it was all great. The Chef's Special Seafood was simply outstanding. We started with Escargot and Clams; both were excellent with sauces that really complimented. One of our group is very particular about his steak and claimed it was perfect. A good local wine (Dashe- really local) accompanied the meal. Highly recommended and will go again if in the area.
author: Bill T.

description:
On a recent visit had a bad experience. Dinner was OK but a waiter at another table kept kicking my chair every time he went by. He also knocked my sweater off the back of my chair onto the floor and proceeded to step on it as he passed numerous times until I realized the sweater was on the floor and picks it up. He never once apologized.
I have had dinner at John's Grill off and on for the last 15 years and have seen the service steadily go downhill, especially the last three years or so. Will not be returning in the future.
author: Rick H.

description: Nice looking place, friendly staff, however food was not up to par for the price. The two steaks were very under cooked to what we ordered and we had them sent back to be cooked more. Vegetables were simple and could have easily been made at home. Also the mushrooms were very dry and plain. I would not recommend again.
author: Rachael O.

description: Whether you are local or visiting, YOU must checkout this historic restaurant as it offers a variety of amazing food from apps to the main entrees. I have eaten here many times and each time it exceeded my expectations. Plus, the staff and service is excellent. You will not be disappointed!
author: Jay Y.

description:
I had the opportunity to take some business partners out to dinner, and wanted to find them a unique dining experience right in the market district that was both a little more upscale, but friendly and a fun experience. I chose John's Grill.

We had an excellent variety dishes, all of which were very good. The drinks, a little steep in price, were quite good. 

And special thank you to the dining management for taking care of a problem I had with a certain well-known dinner reservation app deciding I really meant I wanted to arrive the next day... It was appreciated!
author: Lance Z.

description:
Here's an update to our experience.  John's Grill graciously encouraged us to come back.  They proved the experience we had in November was an off day.  My husband and I went back and had a perfect lunch.  Service was professional and friendly, but also that lovely in-the-background skill that the best waiters have.  The food was delicious, of course.  The food and conversation flowed, the restaurant was incredibly busy and everything was just right.  What makes John's Grill a wonderful experience is how determined they are to in insure we have a wonderful time and feel appreciated.  I cannot thank John enough for his graciousness.  I would recommend John's Grill to anyone for a special occasion (or just because). - Maureen
___

November 2017 original post:
Oops, John's Grill, we hope we caught you on an off day.  My husband and I visited John's Grill in honor of our dating anniversary, as we have for the past dozen years.  We love the atmosphere, the Maltese Falcon connection and the decadent food offerings.  Those are the reasons for the stars.  What we did not enjoy this year was the service.  The waiter was warm and friendly, so we suspect this is a management problem.  Here's what happened....  We ordered an appetizer, to be followed by soup and then entrees, but both the appetizer and soup came out all at once.  Not ideal.  Then before we were finished with the soup, the waiter appears with the entrée plates and looks hopefully to us to put down our soup spoons, move the bowls and make room for the entrees.  Awkward.  We noticed the waiter was doing that to people around us, too.  It wasn't like they needed to move diners along to make room for others - there were a few empty tables.  There was no reason for rushing diners along.  The waiter never does bring our side of French fries, but does try to charge for them.  When clearing the table, he stacked plates before removing them (a training issue).  Having had the clam chowder (delicious), we could not finish the entrees and asked them to be packed up to go.  When we got home, we found he'd decided not to pack any of the vegetables.  Annoying.  We hope to come back next year and have a better service experience.  The food is still delicious and the décor still classic.
author: Maureen L.

description:
My husband and I took the CalTrain up to celebrate our 23rd wedding anniversary. As requested, we were seated in a quiet area. 

Hugo was an amazing and attentive server. He made us feel extremely special and we left with yet another memory of this fantastic restaurant.
author: Reaching D.

description: It was a busy night but the wait wasn't terrible about 25 mins and the service was definitely great! The food was amazing, first time trying escargot and it did not disappoint. Great atmosphere and great cocktails.
author: Miguel Z.

description:
It was Halloween night(Saturday) at 6.45pm, didn't make any reservation anywhere and going through yelp every single restaurant I wanted to dine with was either full or I had to wait about two hours for an opening. 

Gave up going yelp cos I was starving after 15mins of going through reviews and looking at pictures that made the suffering worse.. decided to do it the pre-internet days..ask the concierge in my hotel..

Wanted something either seafood or steak, they referred me to John's which had both and might have a table if we said we're from the hotel..hmmm.... 

I remember seeing John's Grill on yelp and skipping it entirely therefore I was pretty sure it was not 4 stars and above. Anyway I was hungry and it was either subway or that. 

Called the restaurant and they could get us a table and we were there in 2minutes. 

It's a pretty old restaurant and in a good way, like charming old with history. And the place was packed! Pretty sure they're mostly tourists though.

Fast forward to the food.

Ordered 2 dishes, Fresh Oysters and Clam in Soup (there was a fancy name for this soupy dish..) were great especially the Clam. It was cooked in some milky buttery broth and I loved it. The soup was great with the bread.
Although I did wish they had kept the bread warm and toasty..not a big fan of cold soft bread and thank goodness for the broth from the clam dish.

Of the 3 mains we ordered two were good and one wasn't to our liking. 

NY Strip was as should be and pretty good, Cioppino was tasty as well and went well with toast - I'm probably not the best judge when it comes to Cioppino since it's the first time I'm trying this SF only dish..probably my next trip I'll dedicate 3 days to finding the best Cioppino. 

The Cannelloni was disappointing. For lack of better description it was soggy and salty...I know it's suppose to be saucy but I think there's a fine line between Saucy and Soggy..this was definitely soggy.  

All in all the experience was good. Considering the amount of great food in SFO this will be a tough place to say it's great. I give it a Good and that's 3 Stars in my book.
author: Jive O.

description:
I saw other reviews about this being an authentic San Francisco steak house. The photos seemed to scream "tourist trap", yet we gave it a shot.
Overall, the building is cool and at some point the food was probably good. Now this is just a tourist trap.

Our meal started with cold sourdough bread and ice cold little packed of butter. Paper table cloths. Our server was in training and had his trainer with him when we interacted. He was great. 

It was downhill from there. 

We had the lobster ravioli appetizer and it was OK, no real thought put into it. 

I had the filet and my husband has their famous Jerusalem chicken. I had one glass of wine. 

Total bill was $102.00 without tip. 

The food was on par with a chilis. No flavor or thought, nothing rememberable or great. The building is cool, but take a pic and move on.
author: Jillian C.

description:
Went in with friends. They had just opened for business, Saturday, 7/22/17. The waiter was a complete ass. We're on business and needed 5 separate checks. He tells us he can only do 3 per table. We ask to split up the group and his response,"I'm not gonna debate it with you, understand this, if I get busy, you guys are at the bottom of the list".
The food seemed overpriced and his attitude was so obnoxious, we left. Went across the street to Tad's and had our food in minutes (steaks)for less money with friendly, appreciative people that understand customer service. 
We always tip good service when we're traveling so here's a tip for the owner...fire this clown and get somebody who at least pretends to care.
author: James L.

description: Got the T-bone steak.  Was very good for the price of around $40. It came with vegetables and a baked potato. The peppercorn sauce for the steak is an extra $2 and basically tastes like gravy. It's great! You should always get the sauce!  The free bread is stale and not that great, which is a downer since I'm used to the warm bread and fresh whipped butter at higher end steakhouses. Regardless, good food and good price.
author: Kelly C.

description: Recommended by 2 different concierges at Parc55 so figured it had to be good and gave it a try. But it's your typical tourist trap riding on some past notoriety. Food is just OK and the entire time you get the sense they just want to  turn tables as fast as possible.
author: Chris H.

description:
I was on a Romantic weekend away from the Valley and went to Johns Grill on a good friends advice, she is a local San Franciscoer, we were treated wonderful, and the restaurant was decorated for the Christmas holiday and was just lovely. The GIANT Nutcracker near our table was so cool. Now for the food...wanting to sample many items, we had the utterly delicious tender escargot, the garlic butter also was great to dip our bread into. We had the Dungeons Crab cocktail and it had large chunks of crab throughout. It was delightful. The sundried tomato tortelloni was wonderful and I would have made a full meal of just that!!  Another thing ordered was the Oyster
Wellington, by my companion, that he loved, and the Filet Mignon that was tender, delicious  and cooked to perfection! To top it off the cheesecake was divine and although we were so full, we finished it all, nearly licking the plate! Service was so prompt and attentive without hovering.  We sat on the 2nd floor and enjoyed ever minute. I highly recommend!! A must see historic San Francisco Union Square Gem! Don't forget to ask about the Maltese Falcon!
author: Natalie W.

description: This is our second time here, and it's been amazing both times. A nice atmosphere, we enjoy sitting upstairs in the Maltese Falcon Room. The service was great, and the food Amazing. There's even someone playing live piano music.
author: Arlene M.

description: Was here celebrating a birthday. Got the ribeye which was perfect!!! Birthday boy got fish and he has not stopped talking about it. We are arranging to go back again soon. We ate on the second floor, Live Jazz, patrons a bit loud, but not dinging for that. You have got to stop by, guarantee you won't be disappointed!!
author: Cynthia N.

description: A must when you are in SF! Historic venue with great service and delicious American cuisine. You cannot go wrong. I would suggest calling for reservations ahead of time. Enjoy!!
author: Jason Y.

description:
My husband and I (Mark) made reservations for lunch for Monday , New Year's Day .
Traffic could not have been better for us, coming Across the Bay Bridge , for our 1:00pm reservations.
We were surprised how crowded they were, when we arrived, so it is definitely a good idea, to make reservations, even on a slow day and national holiday.
Everything was absolutely perfect. We each had one of their large bowls of delicious clam chowder . We then split their baby spinach salad.
Mark ordered the seafood cannelloni , I ordered the broiled salmon filet with mashed potatoes, and a pomegranate cosmo and Mark got a tall gin & tonic. Our waiter Greg, was just as wonderful as all the food was.
This is the very same order, we always give, anytime we go, and we are never dissatisfied with the food or the service.
We were not only celebrating the New Year, but also our 30th Anniversary , one day ahead of time. We do this at John's Grill, every year, at the same time. We go back many years with John's Grill, and hope to have many more.
author: Cheryl W.

description: Great feel, and attentive service. The chowder was certainly the highlight of my meal here. The Jumbo prawn dish was good, but a little heavier than I would've liked. Great casual option if you are staying in the area.
author: Angela D.

description:
Good steak; good service; fun history...not sure I can go past 3 stars as there are so many other places w/the same solids
The music was a nice touch
author: Amy G.

description: I'd give the appetizers 4 stars but my entree was overpriced and tasted like something you'd expect to get at a low-end restaurant chain.
author: Patty S.

description: All of our steaks were overcooked a bit, medium was actually medium well, and medium well was actually well done.
author: Yuanxuan W.

description: I came here for my boyfriends birthday and was pleasantly surprised. The steak was cooked perfectly and the service is great. The place is small and there is a wait on busy nights. Will definitely go back here on my next trip to San Francisco.
author: Jessica A.

description: My ribeye was average at best. Luke warm, but cooked properly at medium rare. My wife's steamed clams were good. We sat upstairs, but it was more lively on the main level. We decided to eat here because it was recommended as "The Classic SF Steakhouse". It was just ok.
author: G W.

description:
Our group of four on the 8pm dinner reservation unexpectedly grew to six when we arrive but the hostess was able to easily accommodate the change despite what looked to be a pretty full house for this later hour of the evening. We were shown to a table tucked in a corner of the second floor next to the hostess stand which proved to be loud and distracting at times during our meal. The stairs looked to continue up at least another floor so there must be lots of room in this old building.

Having a member in our party named John, several of us just defaulted to ordering dishes with his namesake in the title. I ended up starting with a Caesar salad ala John and dining on John's bone in strip steak for my main paired with a couple of bottles of John's Cabernet. I thought the service was spotty and found myself on several occasions with an empty water glass looking for a refill. 

My salad was huge and I ended up splitting it with a colleague. It was quite fresh and I loved what I think were homemade croutons. They did come around with fresh ground pepper to top it off as well.

My strip steak arrived in a reasonable timeframe after the salad and cooked to my preferred medium rare temperature. My initial reaction was that the plate it was served on was cold and with its light weight may have been made of plastic?! Not my expectations for a $37 steak. The meat itself was flavorful though and I enjoyed it. I skipped the baked potato and doubled down on the veggies. The mix of green beans and leafy broccoli was also enjoyable and quickly disappeared. Our wine turned out to be quite pleasant and paired well with the steak. At $39, I thought it was a good deal.

For dessert, we split a couple of cheesecakes and a flan. The little round cheesecake with fresh berries turned out to be the highlight of the meal for me and really delicious. I didn't sample the flan but others mentioned it was very light and melted in your mouth. I think that's good.
author: Michael K.

description:
Fantastic service, huge portions, great food, expensive price tag.

Fisherman's pasta was generous in portion, it could probably feed 3.  Steak was well cooked, love the side of brocollini. Clam chowder was okay, but my expectations are way higher due to the hype, and it disappointed me slightly. 

The menu is definitely way overpriced. Feels too much like a tourist trap.
author: Christina N.

description: Filet was excellent as was the Ribeye. Both were ordered medium rare and served perfectly. Veggies could have been done a bit more. Great place to eat and amazing history.
author: Brian C.

description: Great little place.  From the old style decor to the historic references to the place in The Maltese Falcon, has a great ambiance.  Only complaint would be the noise level is quite high when busy (Seated second floor).  Musician started playing later which added to noise (Great player and nice music though).  Service was quick and professional.  Menu has a few options, went with tomato salad and seafood cannelloni. Both were superb.  It is a bit on pricey side, but worth the cost.
author: Chris H.

description: Fantastic salads and the lobster ravioli is worth the trip. Great service, historic atmosphere, moderate prices and a full bar. What more could one ask?
author: Andrew R.

description: Food was delicious & great atmosphere with a jazz player.  Good service. Prices for entrees $26-$36 average
author: Annette M.

description:
This place IS old San Francisco! This is always my go to spot whenever I come to the city for a visit. It's slightly cramped, slightly noisy, lots of wood and that's what makes it all so wonderful!

I unfortunately can't comment on much of the menu because I always get the chicken Jerusalem--that sauce with those artichoke hearts on 2 perfectly grilled chicken breasts--DIVINE! I usually have a hard time finishing because I've eaten so much of the deliciously perfect sourdough bread before the meal. 

It's a great central location if you're in Union Square. Quit wasting your time trying to get a spot at the Cheesecake Factory at Macy's and head to John's if you want a true SF experience.
author: Katie C.

description:
I've always wanted to pop in here, I've heard if for nothing else than a quick cocktail and peek at the Maltese Falcon. Last night, finally made good on that, and then some. 

I recommended this spot for a dinner with a work partner who is in town for business, and upon arriving we were encouraged to wait at the bar for a table, and no longer where the drinks poured that our table was ready, well under the short ten minute wait they had told it it would be.

Our server was very kind and accommodating, for appetizers we ordered the lobster ravioli and half dozen oysters. A few minutes later when a shrimp cocktail and the lobster ravioli, the waitress was quick and apologetic to correct the order get our oysters out. No harm, no foul.

for dinner I went with the bone in new york strip, and my friend had the ribeye - and pro tip - if you prefer fries with your steak rather than a  baked potato, their fries are on point.

want of the better steaks I've had this year, in a year full of great steaks, in a classy old world dining establishment, with a side of Hollywood lore and memorabilia. If the occasiona calls for it again, i would love to return to John's Grill.
author: Andy H.

description: Best lamb chops I've ever had. Good service. Seating could use a little work. Doorman is a nice touch. Just off Market at the Powell Street station.
author: Phillip T.

description: This is a great restaurant because the bartender was fast and fun, the service superb and the food very good.  The Sam Spade is out of this world.  Jam packed during tourist season, very comfortable otherwise.
author: John F.

description:
I had the ribeye. good piece of meat. Not the best Ribeye i have eaten but it was ok. Its just so hard to beat a piece of meat from the midwest. Nice flavor. I have a gluten and shellfish allergy and they were very easy to work with. 

We had a big group and everyone was happy with the choice they made. Lots of history at this place, so that made it cool. The staff was awesome. really took good care of us. nice bar and overall very good.
author: Joe M.

description: It is the best place to absorb real San Francisco history.   Great steaks and fish, super wine list.
author: Steven M.

description:
I'd give it a 3.5, but I'll round up because of the sentimental value this place holds for me. This is a Christmas restaurant. Every memory I have here is from Christmas time, and it's always decked to the nines.

Everything I've had here has been awesome: the lobster ravioli, the fisherman's pasta, the snapper, the salmon, the steak...the list goes on.

The only bother is that because I've only been here around Christmas time, my only memories of John's Grill come with an egregiously long wait and being seated in a cramped restaurant. I suspect that they are not always as busy as they are on Christmas Eve, but on the occasions that I've been, we've needed to wait for ~15-20 minutes even with a reservation. A few times, we had given up on our reservation and eaten at the bar. However, the service is quick to make up for the wait...although it is sometimes so quick that we feel rushed. I still won't hold this against them though...it's a San Francisco staple. They do what they do well, and they've been doing it for over a century.
author: Kelsey S.

description: First time at John's Grill for New Year's Eve dinner. The  restaurant was full with a crowd waiting to be seated outside, with reservations at 9:00pm and were seated at 9:30. Great food, great service, great atmosphere. We will return!
author: Scott G.

description:
Just finished a meal here at John's Grill, one of the settings in the "Maltese Falcon." The majority of people who come here to eat are tourists or conference attendees, and a few locals (like me and my friend).  There is seating on multiple levels/floors -- the first floor is more lit and is perfect for friends and families while the second floor is a little dim, perfect for dates, couples, and lovers.  Maybe you'll spot Sam and Bridgid here on a date here?  Even on weekdays, It can get pretty crowded at dinner time, so eating earlier in the evening or making a reservation would be recommended!  

My friend and I both had the Jack LaLanne salad, ribeye meal, cioppino dish, and lastly the homemade vanilla ice cream for dessert. All the food is kind of expensive, probably marked up for tourists due to its novelty and relation to the "Maltese Falcon." Of the dishes we had, I enjoyed the Jack LaLanne salad as it was packed with seafood, full of flavor, and the textures and different tastes (veggies, dressing, and seafood) all complimented each other.  Because my friend and I aren't a big fan of blue cheese, we substituted the dressing with Italian vinaigrette (tossed lightly), which was tasty.  The Ribeye and the cioppino were unremarkable and pretty average as they tasted similar to other places.  The vanilla ice cream was pretty good, but a little steep for $7.95 as it tasted a lot like Dreyer's ice cream.  Hope it was really home made...

I'm glad I got to come to John's Grill and experience part of history (with the "Maltese Falcon"). Not sure if I would be back since I can get better tasting but similar food for less elsewhere.
author: Matthew L.

description: A SF institution.  Warm and old fashion decor with great service.  Prices on par for it's upscale steakhouse segment.  Portions on par for it's segment.  However, for a top tier steak house, my rare porterhouse did not have a sufficient sear and looked boiled.  That's not a typo, boiled.  The service and cocktails kept it from slipping to a 2-star status.
author: Add C.

description: We had a wonderful meal at John's Grill last night.  We were seated upstairs and the atmosphere and jazz guitar was very nice.  We had the lobster ravioli appetizer, which was good but not great. However we both got the cioppino for our entre and it was fantastic. The broth was so tasty as was the seafood in it, though there was no crab which seems like it should be a staple in the dish. Our server was prompt and polite. The only reason I took off one star is because they could stand to remove a couple of tables as it is very crowded...we were basically dining with the people next to us.  But overall it was a great meal. I would recommend!
author: Danielle R.

description: When a fine Steak Restaurant states they have aged and hand selected aged beef, my minimum expectations are in the Ruth Chris or Capital Grill standard.  Don't waste your money on John's.  You will find a better steak at Long Horns or Outback.  Service was good and they didn't charge us but nonetheless, you can do better in SFO.
author: Cedo V.

description: This restaurant was recommended to us by several people. We got right in at 8pm on Wednesday night.  Once seated, we were ignored for 15 minutes before the waiter took our drink order. 10 minutes later we ordered our dinners.  45 minutes later the food arrived. The three Ribeyes were tough and stringy, what I expect from an inexpensive family steak house.  The creamed spinach was inedible. The seafood cioppino smelled nasty and they took it back but it was so late we chose to order food back at our hotel. All in all, a dreadful experience.
author: Adam R.

description: After hearing so much about John's Grill as the "Sam Spade restaurant," I hoped to find something more evocative and intimate.  This is a super-bustling place with extra-high noise level. The food was decent but not memorable, though the Jack LaLanne salad was particularly good.  My steak was overcooked and a bit dry, and the vegetables were just plain boring.  The service was good, though, friendly and personable.   Overall, a bit disappointing.
author: John S.

description:
Extremely disappointed with this place. Our hotel concierge recommended it. I did the whole Yelp review thing and did read "not good for children" and figured it was because it was small. But we still walked over because my 8 yr old son wanted steak. As soon as we get to the door we get greeted by a guy at the door and my husband asked " How long is the wait? " he immediately looked at my daughter (4yr old) and said an hour. There wasn't even a line of people waiting. Then a couple came right after us and asked the same thing and he said "come on in ". 

I was completely taken back by this I told my husband let's get outta here. I wanted to say something not so PG to that guy. I get the place said " not good for children", it's not like it said No Children Allowed. We're paying customers for someone to turn us away like that. Never again, thanks for nothing.
author: Gissella P.

description: The food is excellent!!!! The atmosphere is historic and the service is terrific!  Ask for Eric - his a a fabulous server.  We had a large holiday lunch and everything was perfect, from the crab cocktail, beautiful salad and steak that cut like butter!  Highly recomend for a wonderful dining expierence!
author: Bailey K.

description: Great food! Wonderful service! A San Francisco must see and experience. Fantastic mixed drinks and amazing food. Now will be a Christmas time tradition.
author: Michelle G.

description: Emergency room visit from food poisoning was a 5 hour experience of agony. The mussels are dangerous.
author: Radne B.

description:
Truly one of the the worst steak sandwiches I've ever eaten. Overpriced, undercooked, and bland. Nobody else had anything good to say about their meals...all the steaks were full of gristle and much too expensive. 

Bread and coffee were good. Extra star for that.
author: Jake B.

description:
I was really expecting more.  Service was good.  

Escargot was smothered in a really heavy sauce I didn't care for.  I asked about a Caesar salad and was informed it had mayo in the dressing, which I don't care for and is really not fine dining style.  I think the Escargot had mayo in the sauce too.  

Bread was good.  Steak was good, cooked perfectly.  Vegetable portion was rather skimpy, I'd rather them charge separately for them than include them only to discover a very small portion.  All in all, I'd go somewhere else for a steak in the city next time.  Honestly, I think the 3 stars here is pretty generous.
author: Kevin L.

description:
My husband and I walked in for lunch on Father's Day 6/18/17. Got a table right away and a great waiter, Mateo. Loved the photos, the ambiance, and the food was very delicious. We had the eggs benedict and grilled salmon, both served with mashed potatoes and wonderul fresh veggies. Also tried the ice cream and the flan, both made on the premises and just
delicious. This is a fun, iconic SF and historical place that serves food that is on par with the best SF places and a history too.
author: Margaret W.

description: I have to say, the menu looks incredible and last year I got seafood that was meh so this year, I thought, "Try it again because shame on me for ordering seafood outside of Hawaii or NOLA." Well, I ordered the "Chicken Jerusalem," which was featured in "Gourmet Magazine" and it tasted like school lunch. Perhaps because we have eaten our way across the globe at some of the most amazing restaurants and we are from the home of the world's best delectables, New Orleans, Louisiana, our standards on taste are higher than most. However, I will say the Bloody Mary was not to die for and the service, same. They rushed us in and out like it was Piccadilly. I will give it five-stars for atmosphere, charm, character and history. They must be trying to cut back, though...it was hot as Hades in there. I'd say come for a cocktail then dine elsewhere. There are too many incredible choices in San Francisco to settle!
author: Susan F.

description: Great old style steakhouse/seafood. The oysters wellington are a favorite. Nice filet mignon. Full bar. The service is very good. It can get noisy and crowded some evenings, so I usually just do lunch. I love the feel of the place, and it is a real survivor in the neighborhood since 1908.
author: Larry K.

description: Does it get any better than this? I think not. This is one of the finest restaurants in the Bay Area. Their stakes Are flavorful and juicy. Cappuccino is amazing. Cheesecake on point. Great service as well. Will definitely be back.
author: Nashwa Z.

description: Service was good.  Food was just ok.  Got the filet cooked medium and it was dry and something I probably could have gotten at Outback Steakhouse = nothing special at all.  Also their sides menu is very limited and they don't even have mashed potatoes which is weird.
author: Kristen M.

description: This is an Iconic white table linen restaurant. Granted it's been open since 1908, and it's owners are connected to so many. I wanted to love this place and I had 2 different occasions to try. On the first, I had the Rib eye. It was just OK. Not spectacular which is what I expected for the price point. On my next visit, I ordered the fried shrimp. Again, it was just OK. I was disappointed because it could-and should be so much better! With so many other great places in the city-save your money and try one that's worthy of the high price point!
author: Raquelle Z.

description:
Service was terrible.

Had the steak sandwich....WOW, it was tasteless, no flavor or kick.

just go to see the old school wood work of the restaurant and its 3 floors. The top floor looks really cool, Harlem nights/Hoodlum-era feel, but i hoped that reflected with their food. 

Major disappointment for how overrated this place is in SF. 

Oh yeah, and that Maltese parakeet is here, is that why I should pay extra for the same meals I could get for lunch at dinner times? 

Just come here to tour the restaurant, that's free. Do not come here for anything else.
author: Wayne B.

description: Excellent food. Loved the crab cakes. Our waiter Brett was most helpful.
author: Drue M.

description:
What a great location and amazing food. It can be hard to find but its on Ellis right around the corner from the Apple Store. The customer service was top notch and everyone was very attentive. I probably saw 3 different servers which included a gentleman filling up my water. Jeremy was patient with my indecisiveness to order and offered up his recommendations no problem. 
This was a recommendation from the staff at the Marriott Marquis and I couldn't have been happier. I went here for lunch on Labor Day Monday and was seated right away. 
This place has a great vibe and nice ambiance for a casual lunch or romantic dinner although the lightening at the tables was more dim than what I am used to and I used my light on my phone to help with the menu.
I ordered an appetizer, soup, entree and dessert.

The sourdough bread basket is fresh and and pairs perfectly with the homemade clam chowder .
One of the best clam chowders I had while visiting SF. The bowl is huge and very filling . 

The shrimp cocktail was delicious and the cocktail sauce had a perfect balance. The shrimp are huge and you get 4 for $11.95.

My entree was Sams lamb chops and while I debated about the fish entrees this entree was perfect. You get a lot of food for your money here . My meal came with 4 chops, a baked potato and veggies . The succulent lamb chops were cooked to perfection and balanced nicely with a dry rub. I also ordered a side of mushrooms which were good but nothing spectacular .

For dessert I decided to go with the cheesecake and requested chocolate sauce instead of rasberry sauce. They made the switch no problem . I will for sure visit Johns in the future . Again one of the best chowders and amazing staff. Thanks for asking my dining experience great and for being so welcoming .
author: Elizabeth B.

description: I had been there for a political fundraiser a year or so before and it was very dark...Was brought here as a surprise date. The place was packed and brought up to top floor. The place smelled like strong detergent-a real turnoff. Ordered prime rib and it came to the table lukewarm, veggies stone cold and raw, not "crunchy."  While historic, I would not recommend it, with their prices and limited menu. Just have a drink and move on.
author: jj c.

description:
The price points here are ridiculous for the food quality and service.  I've had better service at Denny's.  And the food is ok, but not at the prices they are charging.  It's literally a tourist trap, and they milk the heck out of the Monty Python angle, which if you do your research, is a very tiny angle.

I've been here a couple of times, with guests from out of town who bought the hype.  I've had one really good server, I think his name was Nate.  Or Nick.  But then I have had god awful service too.  One Asian guy mistook me and my guests for foreigners, and basically forced bottled water on us, and then at the end, insulted us as he repeated to us that we needed to tip him.  Even if we happened to be from somewhere else, then isn't the obnoxiously circled gratuity guide at the bottom of the bill sufficient?  He didn't seem to get that we were offended, or even American.  

The servers are always too busy to offer even an ounce of personality, it's a real crazy place in there because this is obviously a factory and not an experience.

And then the roach that was hanging out on the wall next to us the whole time, yegods.  Please family and friends, let me take you to a real SF restaurant next time that you come to town.

I wish that they would get some professional servers, better food, and an exterminator.  Then us locals would consider this place a viable place to eat.
author: Super L.

description: Both my partner and I were very disappointed with John's, maybe we went on a bad night since the reviews for the restaurant seem decent? Either way I do not plan on ever going here again and feel the need to write a review because the reviews posted on here did not reflect the service or food that I was served. Our waiter came to our table twice, once to take our order and once to give us the check. Not once was my water or bread refilled. The price of the food does not reflect the quality whatsoever. I had the $32 seafood pasta and the sauce tasted somewhat too familiar like the canned alfredo I get at Costco. The food came out way too quickly for it to have been made when I ordered it leaving me to assume that they premake their meals then just warm them up. Very upset that I spent so much money on a rather tasteless meal for my boyfriend's birthday and I will definitely pass my experience onto all my friends and coworkers in the city because there are much cheaper and tastier meals in the city with better service. Not to mention the decor and ambiance is rather classless for a "fine dining" restaurant.
author: Amber D.

description: Place has redeemed itself with my most recent experience ordering the lamb chops. Amazing! Old San Fran at its best here
author: D K.

description: Just a decent/okay steak. Went here based on yelp reviews and being a middle of the road, $$$, for a steakhouse in san Fran. Spend the extra money going somewhere else. Or save money getting a cheaper steak at the same quality. My wife's mingon was tough and under cooked. The server was embarrassed when shown. She ordered med-well and receive d a rare steak. My t-bone was okay but nothing special. Server was very good though.
author: Jason Y.

description: True San Francisco Restaurant . Very cool Casablanca ambiance . My whiskey sour was perfect and dinner was awesome. Excellent service from everyone . You can eat at the bar too. Love this place!
author: Cecilia D.

description:
Loved it
Yes it is classic, and so is the menu and the setting inside.
Excellent food, steaks are prepared old school style, as is the homemade ice cream.
Awesome bar, but it was a tight fit for our group.
Service was A+
Would go back for sure,...
author: Mark S.

description: I have eaten here many times over the past 10 years or so. Consistently good traditional restaurant, featuring very good meat (the steaks are excellent) and seafood (I particularly like the salmon and the sole). Good service, historic atmosphere (the restaurant was featured in "The Maltese Falcon"), and well priced for a restaurant of this type.
author: Jethro B.

description: Food was amazing. The only thing that really bothered me was the bread they give you as an appetizer. It felt hard and not fresh. The place is kind of uncomfortable, kind of like a maze and you see the waiters running all over the place. Hey, but the food is really good.
author: Mario P.

description: We enjoyed John's. Excellent service.  Great fresh  fish and oysters. Excellent price point for San Francisco. We'll be back.
author: Bill S.

description:
Tourist Trap.  Went here recently for dinner because I was starving after seeing a movie at the Metreon.  I didn't want mall food and ended up trying it out.

It was a busy Sat. night and the place was packed.  We were lucky to get a table.

Started out w/ cold chewy bread that wasn't very good, soft butter helped it a bit.

Got a huge bowl of chowder $8.95 - lots of potato, cream, some clams.  I thought it was ok.

Cesar salad was huge, shrimp were extra $3 ea so $18.95!  They were big shrimp, but nothing special.

B. got dish w/ the huge shrimp, baked potato $18.95- he liked it ok.

Total before tip $80.26.

They have someone playing a keyboard upstairs, that was nice.

Bathrooms upstairs too.  Charged the overpriced meal.
author: Ann L.

description: Ordered the porterhouse well done, came out rare, gristly and tough. Waiter was disinterested and rude, especially after we decided not to have drinks. Won't be back.
author: Dan P.

description:
It was a 4-star experience. But at the last minute, it became 5 stars.

After eating dinner on my birthday, I was about to leave when they put a plate in front of me. It was an entree from the dessert menu, but it was free. They said, "happy birthday".

I recommend this restaurant.
author: Jason C.

description: Amazing customer service. Waitstaff was extremely knowledgeable on gluten free items. The oysters were amazing and fresh. Apparently the lobster bisque was exceptional (I couldn't try it). I had the halibut - freshly caught and you could tell. There's a reason this restaurant has been around since 1908!
author: Stephani O.

description: I went with a group of 5 other ladies and my 1 year old son. We had a reservation and had a high chair already in place at our table. It is a very small restaurant and they seat a lot of people however it didn't feel overcrowded. Our waiter was very nice and we didn't wait long for our food. Everyone I was with got the clam chowder and loved it. I ordered the seafood cannelloni and it was very good and very filling!
author: Jayme A.

description:
Overpriced tourist trap.
Overcooked food and sides.
( veggies had zero taste and baked potato was dried out )
Make sure you do not tip as it is already included in your bill.
I've had better meals at Outback steakhouse...............
author: FLICK R.

description: One first time here.  The waiter Rueben was outstanding and very attentive.  Didn't love my fish dish as I should have asked more questions about it.  I did like the music and atmosphere and it is old San Francisco which I loved.  Several of us were there before the matinee performance of ROMAN HOLIDAY and I enjoyed chatting with other lunch people. Will go back next time I am in San Francisco.
author: C.Michael T.

description: Had the porterhouse steak.  Omg, I think I found my steak place. Perfectly cooked all the way through, medium rare, and seasoned just right. Side note I had this delivered, it was that good even delivered.
author: Lindsay W.

description:
Excellent steaks, excellent service, great location, and there's always room for you!

Great for bringing out of town guests, or just a Wednesday night dinner in the city.
author: DeadlyFo X.

description:
We enjoyed our first experience here, and we felt like we were going back in time to the Maltese Falcon and Sam Spade.  The atmosphere is cozy with hardwood walls and intimate booths and a small bar.

The place is known for its lamb chops which are delicious, and the Jack LaLanne salad is fantastic with good portions of bay shrimp and crab meat.

This is a landmark restaurant in San Francisco, so don't be surprised if you have to wait to be seated, but it's worth it.
author: Ann V.

description: Great San Francisco steak house - marvelous service. Classy atmosphere- when the room is full.. the place has energy. Very good food - don't look st the price, the food is worth it.
author: Gary S.

description:
Interesting that the food was outstanding, yet the rest was terrible.
The men's bathroom had water all over the floor, it stunk, and the trash was overflowing. It sure needed attention.
We were on the second floor and the music was live, make that LOUD!!  People were straining to hear each other talk that were sitting at the same table. At our table we discussed if we should bring up the loud music, it was agreed we would. He did nothing the first time we spoke to him, he just shrugged his shoulder. When the waiter was approached, THE SECOND TIME, to have the music turned down so we could have a conversation, he just said "People came to hear the music" and refused to do anything about it. If anyone in that room had even clapped one time for the music, then you would imagine that they came for the music, but when you looked around and saw how many people were leaning toward the middle of the table to hear their conversations, they probably didnt come to hear the music.
author: Kent D.

description: I was visiting someone in a nearby city and over the weekend we popped into SF. Partly due to my NY ways of never planning anything, I didn't research any places to eat prior to arriving. So we walked around but we both like/need specific kinds of food. Finally we went in here, with no reservations of course, so we waited a good 20-30 minutes at the bar. The food was decent but not exactly mind-blowing. Would I visit them again if I was in the area? Probably not, but if you're not too picky and don't mind waiting (or being smart and making a reservation), it's not the worst place to get food at. Then again if you can think ahead and make a reservation, I would just suggest to find a better place.
author: Eszter H.

description:
Took the Cable Car from Fisherman's Wharf.  Located near the end of the line and it looked interesting.  They had plenty of tables and my wife asked to sit near the window but we were told that they were all reserved.  They took us to a table that was so small that my elbow was hitting the wall and on the other side was the isle right next to the kitchen with constant traffic.

We walked out.  Someone else will have to tell you about the food and the service....
author: Eric H.

description: The food is to die for. I am definitely coming back. The lemon butter snapper melts in your mouth and the vegetables are cooked perfectly. So far the best service I've received since visiting San Francisco. They have live jazz music and good cocktails.
author: Jourdan M.

description:
Never again!
Zagat ratings, really!
The medium done stake was a piece of cardboard.
The rare stake was covered in fat.
The knives are so not sharp at all.
The service is poor at best.
Short order cooks are not worth $140
The whine and music cover it all up nicely!

to Manager:
1. buy your meat at Costco or from a better butcher
2. fire your line cooks and hire me
3. covering up the poor quality meal with decor and music is like letting you turn on my radio while playing a movie and ordering take out at McDonalds.
author: De L.

description: This experience was like taking a step back in time. From the wood paneling to white linens it was instantly the 1930s again.  We started with the Jack LaLane's salad for two and it was outstanding. How do you go wrong with crab, shrimp and a perfect avocado? For our main course, I had the chicken Jerusalem and it was cooked perfect. Great blend of mushrooms and artichokes. My wife had the Oysters Wellington. It was different, but a nice rich pastry and a good helping of oysters in each pastry. I would definitely eat here again.
author: Don H.

description: Rubbery, over cooked prawns. Same for the petrale sole. Place so packed and loud you can't hear the person next to you. For these prices you can find a much better and interesting meal in SF.
author: Alix L.

description:
I came here with my mom and dad at 2:40pm in the afternoon. We walked out at 3:20, after we hadn't received our food. 

We ordered a pasta, a bowl of soup and two desserts. In my eyes, those are all quick dishes likely already pre-made to some extent.

We flagged the waiter down at 3:15 to ask how much longer it would take. The waiter apologized and told us the kitchen staff had taken a break. We asked for the check for the latte my mom ordered. Rather than comp the meal for the ridiculous wait, they charged us out.

Seriously? Crappy service. Will not return.
author: Stefan J.

description: Once again a seafood meal to remember. Thank you Johns grill for making my prawns gluten free. The salmon, sole, snapper were all good. Hint: get the sauce on the side. Creamed spinach & fries were great. The place was packed. Reservations are a good idea. We were four so we fit the table and larger parties were accommodated but the place is a tight fit.  Love this classic place. No drinks so we got out under $100 for four! We were happy and full.
author: Eddie M.

description: Expectations were not high based on reviews.  Setting is very tight for space. Service and food were excellent.
author: Judd L.

description:
Went there by myself for lunch, ordered NY steak and I find it's tastes quite average.
Service is quite good though.
author: Prinya P.

description: Our new favorite place to hang out in SF. Food is great, atmosphere is lively, and drinks are good. It is in an older building so the setting is dated and could use refreshing but why spoil a good thing.
author: Clair R.

description:
A restaurant becomes an institution for a reason.

Already solidified as a landmark in San Francisco, John's Grill will remain so for my lovely lady and I. 

The atmosphere was fabulous, extremely caring  staff, and live music to boot. The decor was classic and clean, beautiful wood accenting the walls decorated by its rich history. Truly reflecting the esteemed steak house it is.


The food was immaculate.

I highly recommend the clam chowder. From living in New England, I can tell you I have had my fair share of chowders, John's graces the top of that list. Thick, creamy, tender clams, with just a hint of what seemed to be red pepper. Truly fabulous

The cheese cake was also quite the highlight, Perfectly portioned, and perfectly sweet. Simply just right!

If you want a classic no frills dinner, you could not go wrong at Johns Grill.
author: Aaron B.

description:
Highly recommend to try this place, famous for the movie The Maltese Falcon. 
Relaxing & very busy.
author: Elsa N.

description:
11/05 8PM John's Grill made up for leaving me hungry not long ago closing early forcing me to go to Black Cat for chow, yikes (not their best night!). 

Tonight we noshed on steak and red snapper, bubbly and chowder, upstairs it was cozy and perfect. I guess they read this yelp? I have no idea but the waiter gave some freebies and a nice desert. I love this place have so for decades. But if you say the last dinner is seated at 9:45pm, do so. I'd love to continue eating here the food is classic tasty and the vibe is historic.
author: SF T.

description: We were excited to return to Johns Grill after our wonderful experience last year. The interior was beautifully decorated for the holidays. Our server was top notch and was very attentive. Our dinner salad was delicious and loaded with shrimp and blue cheese. Our flan was creamy and delicate. Unfortunately, my oyster Wellington wasn't as good as last time. Oysters were chewy, small and too much spinach.  My husbands ribeye tasty and cooked to his order. We highly recommend the Barbera d'asti. John's Grill has historical significance and wonderful SF experience.
author: Sherry A.

description:
I was in the union square area and decided to stop by John's grill for lunch today.  An interesting assortment of patrons: two tables down was former Mayor Willie Brown; one table down, tourists with their tour books; and the table in front us - two uniformed police officer having a sit down lunch.  

I had the Dungeness Crab Louis for a light lunch - it did not disappoint.  Plating style was a bit dated but the salad was fine.
author: John L.

description: I'm only giving it 3-stars because our server was so nice.  Appetizers were good but we ordered a grilled red snapper that came out pan fried and smothered in a heavy butter sauce.  They were very accommodating taking the plate off the bill.  It's was just a 90's presentation in an 80's restaurant.
author: Susan M.

description: I had great expectations when I reserved  a table at this location, wanting an exceptional dining experience for our anniversary as first time visitors from Texas. As it turns out, this restraint didn't live up to the hype. It as col to eat at a place with such history, but unfortunately, the historic coolness was more than offset by the poor service and mediocre food..
author: Waymon P.

description: This is my second time here and it was and I was not disappointed! This place gets 5 stars for several reasons. First the service we received was excellent. Our waiter was attentive and prompt we were never left wanting for anything. Next was the food, I had the porterhouse and it was cooked to perfection. It was flavorful and tender with no extra seasoning needed. The ambiance is nice for a date. The prices are not unreasonable for what you get. We will be back.
author: Fred M.

description: Toooo salty! Should have a reduced salt menu. The crab was really fresh and nice. Other dishes were ok, but again too much salt!!!!!
author: Jun R.

description:
Has a great and authentic feel to it. Was there for a corporate dinner tied to a conference and they handled the giant (80 or so) group perfectly. Wait staff were exceptionally attentive refilling drinks, water and making sure everything was as expected.

I had a fantastic filet but sadly no blue cheese was available (I think it's pretty norm to request).

Can't speak to pricing but the food and service was great and well worth a visit.
author: Phillip S.

description:
This place delivers exactly what it promises -- traditional steakhouse food -- with fast and friendly service. We will
Definitely come again. My husband had a fantastic filet, and there were plenty of seafood choices for me. We really enjoyed it.
author: Harley D.

description:
This place was pretty classy. Very dim lighting, and the tables are extremely close together. It looks like most of the smaller tables are upstairs, and the tables for larger groups were downstairs. Our hotel was a couple blocks away, so we just walked. There was no wait, and they took us right upstairs to sit. 

I had the Fisherman's Pasta. Really good! Huge chunks of fish and other seafood inside. Very Pleased.

My friend had the Seafood Cannelloni. She loved it. She also had a slice of pecan pie for dessert. 

I would probably come back just for that meal alone. Very satisfied.
author: Erica P.

description:
We had no clue where to eat dinner on our last night in San Francisco.   We were surrounded by Chinese and Indian food, but we had already met our fill of each so were looking for something a little different, but didn't know what.   We took to Yelp to figure out a place to eat and came across the reviews for John's Grill.   

While we weren't keen on the price, the history and proximity caused us to decide to give John's Grill a try.  

I love the signage for the building and the ambiance once inside makes you really think about the history and people who have dined in this space before you.  Oh, and about that space, it is a little cramped, but no more so than many restaurants we have dined at recently.   I liked that the tables were not set up bistro style so I didn't feel like I was sitting at my neighbors table, but I wasn't going to back up in my chair for fear of hitting the person sitting behind me.   The chairs were anything but comfortable and by the time we left my back was in such a knot I had to stop on the sidewalk to just take a moment to stretch.  

As I wanted to make sure I wasn't too full before my entree arrived, we decided to pass on any starters, but I did try a slice of bread.   It was sourdough bread.   Nothing remarkable about it.    

My husband ordered the ribeye steak with a side of creamed spinach.   Two of his favorite things.   It could be that I live in a place where beef is prevalent and our steaks are cut thick, but the steak was really thin, like thinner than the soles on my shoes thin.   He ordered it rare and he said that it couldn't have been much rarer.   I take that as a good sign.  He has eaten in a lot of steakhouses around the country and said that this was one of the better steaks he has had.    The creamed spinach also received positive reviews and I don't think I have ever heard him remark on the quality of the baked potato before, but this one caused him to take note.

Now, I'm going to lose a few of you here, but I ordered the calves liver and onions.   One of my favorite meals when I was a kid (the liver without the onions that is).   The liver was prepared perfectly.   The mixed vegetables that were served with the meal really didn't do much for me.   I'm not a huge fan of snap peas and I can't stand cooked carrots.   I picked out the zucchini and yellow squash and called it good.   They could have used a little more cooking time, or been called a salad.   I, too, enjoyed the baked potato (though I didn't eat much of it as my stomach had reached capacity).   

The waitstaff was very attentive and checked back with us regularly.   All in all, the food was good, not rave about it for months and  it was worth it for the experience of enjoying a meal in a San Francisco landmark.
author: Karin H.

description:
Don't go here if you are looking for awesome food.  

John's is a an ancient restaurant (meaning that it has good history), so that's the draw.  If you are looking for the 'go to' place so you can check that off your list, then head this way, but don't have expectations of 'good steak house' quality steaks.  I was honestly very disappointed in my ribeye.  Was thin, tough, and not that flavorful.  Would have rather been at Fleming's or Ruth's Chris.  The other 4 folks in our party had the same ideas about their food.  Dungeness crab appetizer was a little 'fishy' (yes, I know crab is a sea creature, but there is a difference between good crab and fishy crab).  Salads were sparse and side veggies were sparse and slighly overcooked.

Neat restaurant due to its history, but go in with 'a not so great day at Outback steakhouse' expectations and you should be ok.
author: Jeff A.

description:
Are you kidding me? An accidental tourist major league find. Walking about downtown,  in need of a small bite since we have major dinner reservations with friends tonight...we wandered into John's Grill. 

No idea of the literary history. ..sort of an Algonquin Roundtable West we lucked into. The Maltese Falcon partly scribed and filmed here. Lots of pics of other intellectuals adorn the joint. A definite joint. Sensory,  sensually dark atmosphere. 

Food?  Oh yes.

Small bite. We shared the steak sandwich on San Francisco french bread, fresh ripe tomato, lettuce, onion, dill pickle and fries.

Steak tender beyond words. We didn't expect a perfect cut of meat on a sandwich. ..but here it was.

My husband said, "Wait until you try the FRIES." CRISP, not greasy. I'm overusing perfect,  but there it is. 

A must do.
author: Kyle T.

description: Walked by after a magic show nearby and decided to go in for drinks and a light dinner. Shared the lobster ravioli, heirloom salad and New England chowder, all delicious but the chowder was outstanding, thick and flavorful with tender clams.  Service was impeccable and not overbearing, staff were friendly and the atmosphere was busy and fun, with a keyboard player upstairs.  Only negative is that the carpets leading upstairs really need replaced or at least cleaned , otherwise a great find with a cool history (apparently the Maltese Falcon was partially written in one of the booths there)
author: Marijo M.

description:
John's Grill had great service, was conveniently located near Union Square, and had good food.

We were staying at the Westin St. Francis for the weekend and found John's Grill to be a conveniently located lunch option that doesn't cost an arm and a leg.

The service was great.  In particular, our waiter was friendly and very accommodating of my mother's special requests and dietary restrictions (in particular, she can't eat any spices or seasonings and is also gluten intolerant).

I enjoyed my mushroom and spinach scramble, and appreciated the fact it was served with steamed vegetables and mashed potatoes (an unusual, but healthy combo...it's always nice to get extra veggies!)  My husband found his seafood dish to be a bit bland.  My mom's meal of grilled salmon, steamed veggies, and a baked potato was just what she needed and wanted.

Thanks for taking good care of us, John's Grill!
author: Barnali D.

description:
If you're looking for old school San Francisco dining with quality service, hit John's Grill.
From appetizers to entree's the food is solid, tasty and competitively priced.
The New England clam chowder is awesome. Most places ruin clam chowder by cutting the potatoes too big or not cooking them enough, this chowder was perfect .
The fish and beef dishes were correctly cooked, tasty and fresh. The only issue is that the entrees were so good there isn't room for desert!
author: Drew F.

description: My family was visiting from Anchorage Alaska and we heard about John's Grill from my boss. My family is a huge fan of steak and seafood so we took the BART from Walnut Creek which was very easy and pretty much landed us within walking distance of the restaurant. Entering the restaurant the hostess smiled and welcomed us warmingly. We were seated and looking at the menu we decided to start off with steamer clams and the Jumbo cocktail prawns which were amazing! My stepdad ordered the New York steak which was cooked medium to perfection. My mom ordered the Filet Mignon which melted in your mouth so delicious! And I ordered the John's steak having the bone-in made the flavor 1000 times better. We loved this restaurant and will be back to try more of this amazing restaurants food.
author: Rian M.

description: Coldest, toughest Ribeye I ever ate.  I have had better at TX Roadhouse. Both steak and Veggies were not seasoned. French Fries were very good even though they are not listed on the menu.
