author: Walt K.

description: Atmosphere is nice. We got the fishermans pasta and filet mignon. They were both deliciousness but nothing that would stand out to me. Pasta was way to cheesy for my liking. Good chunks of fish. It was ok overall
author: Ohh S.

description: Food was great, very cramped restaurant.  Menu listed in Yelp is dated. Prices are much higher.  Great place to visit once.
author: Mike A.

description: The history of the restaurant was great, but the food was not all that spectacular.  I had the John's steak which was the bone-in strip and the steak was cooked as I requested which was a plus, but the vegetables were cold and the steak was lacking in flavor.
author: Justin S.

description: Landmark SF spot, the food was descent, nothing to rave about.  Had the sole with the mushroom sauce, I felt that the sauce overwhelmed and masked the true taste of the sole.  Lobster bisque was good .  Service was great!!!
author: Karim M.

description:
Looked for a restaurant for lunch before going to see Dirty Dancing at the Golden Gate Theater. 
It was lunchtime and a little crowded, but we were seated in minutes and the service was fantastic and very helpful.  There were five of us and we wanted to try a salad that they split up for three of us, the JACK LALANNE'S FAVORITE SALAD 18.95 Seasonal greens, crab, shrimp, avocado, mushrooms, tomato tossed in our famous creamy bleu cheese vinaigrette dressing; MAINE LOBSTER RAVIOLI  14.95; CALIFORNIA CLUB HOUSE. 14.95 Sliced chicken, bacon, lettuce and tomato  and SEAFOOD CANNELLONI 14.95  Dungeness crab, shrimp, baby spinach, cheese and sherry cream sauce.  And, I had the best clam chowder I have had. 

I would definitely go back and would recommended to everyone.
author: Lisa E.

description:
Clam Chowder is a must!

Ordered the Fisherman's Pasta it was good too... The steaks were ok
author: Courtney G.

description: Food was decent, a bit pricy for the quality. Service sucked, I felt like we were a bother and were rushed out of there. Won't go back and won't recommend it.
author: Mary M.

description: Still the same old Jack's. Great, if nostalgia is your thing. The food is not bad, just not inspired. With the reputation and prices, it is not unreasonable to expect more.
author: George T.

description: Service was good. The broiled salmon was pretty good and good price for being in the heart of union square. The mash potatoes and veggies I didn't really care for
author: Thomas N.

description: the food, service , jazz and atmosphere are fantastic. i was pleasantly surprised on the price point also! i highly recommend this place!!
author: Vicky K.

description: The lamb was amazing! Service was great! The ambiance very nice! We enjoyed the music while dining! Over all great dining experience!
author: Desiree V.

description: This place is worth the Drive. I enjoy the Fish pasta    The service is excellent  they also have plenty of tables  for guest who don't have reservations.  Price very affordable for San Francisco.
author: Jacob H.

description:
We all got 3 different kinds of steaks. They were ok, but not something to write home about. I would've expected more considering they are a long-standing steakhouse in San Francisco, their past clientele (diplomats, etc.), their affiliation with The Maltese Falcon, and of course, being one of the oldest restaurants in San Francisco. Unfortunately, I was disappointed with their food. Their drinks, however, were fantastic! 
My advice: If you want to check this place out, come for the drinks and some light apps but don't bother with a steak dinner. The service, however, was excellent.
author: Luna R.

description:
Had my wedding reception dinner here a couple years ago and just went back May 2nd for our anniversary so this place holds a special place in my heart! 

It's simple, order the oysters and escargot to start followed by the lamb chops. For dessert get the berry cheesecake! 

Very tight knit and the tables are close together. If your closterphopic probably not the place for you. I'm not and it can be a little too close when there's a lot of people and you have to shout to have a conversation.
author: Amy K.

description:
I can't recall how many times I've walked past this place as I was lugging bags from going wild at Westfield. To be honest with you, it's probably the last on my list to try around Union Square area or in general. It's always that one place with some dude in front trying to lure you in as if you're a tourist. Stumbled upon this place on a weekend for the after-Christmas sales, every place was packed with 30+ minute wait. I was craving for a steak and wasn't feeling a Tad's Steak (gets the job done, but cravings will return shortly) or Lark's Creek (I've spent enough this month). So I ended up here since there were many slots on OpenTable for ~$30 steak. Not a bad choice if you were out here casually shopping, the restaurant is a bit narrow, was a bit hard to fit my bags with all these sales going on. The place looked so traditional, I could almost ask an invisible cousin sitting at the table to pass me the bread while my invisible grandma ask where is my significant other at dinner. 

Ordered a ribeye and creamed spinach on the side. I didn't trust them fixing my steak to medium rare so I ordered rare in case they overdo it. My meat came out so pink, I could almost match it with my nails!  They actually were able to prepare the meat just right. The seasoning was your traditional salt and pepper, just enough to bring out the meat's original taste. I liked it a lot actually, just simple and warming. Not as warming as it would have been if I ordered it medium rare though. The steak dinner also came with a baked potato and grilled veggies. The creamed spinach was a bit lacking, too single flavored, missing some type of spice and shallot. Needed a bit more aroma. Overall, dinner was great, it felt just like a holiday dinner on TV.
author: Connie C.

description: Excellent steak.  4 of us had filets, and each was prepared perfectly.  Mine had the blue cheese/bernaise topping was delicious.  Baked potato and steamed mixed veggies were average.  Service was prompt and attentive.  Prices are reasonable for SF.  Would definitely recommend.
author: Michael M.

description: All of a sudden I had a hankering for a steak. I stopped in John's Grill. We ordered a t-bone and a New York Strip steak. They came with a baked potato and seasonal vegetables. We were not disappointed. Every item was cooked to perfection. You get what you pay for.
author: John C.

description: Turn around.  Don't enter.  I love expensive Steak houses and willing to pay extra for the quality.  This place has a low rating for a high end place and it should.  It sucked.  The ratings need to be lower.  The steak was chewy overcooked cowhide and expensive.  The service to wait was terrible and the waiter server was equally bad.  Come here if you want to spend a lot of money in SF, but don't come here to eat.  You will not like it.
author: Darrell K.

description:
Someone recommended this restaurant and we were excited to try it.  The lobster bisque was amazing but the service was terrible.  Our waitress was unfriendly and seemed to be in a hurry.   The people next to us obviously did not order what we did , but the waitress apparently got confused and gave them our plates.  They realized they received the wrong meals and told her.  She wished them away and returned them to us.  I am sorry but that is not okay.  For a $36.00 steak and a $35.00 halibut I do not want it to be in front of someone else, on their contaminated table.  My husband watched her walk to the back and return with them and he told her that it was unprofessional.  She said "they didn't touch them".  We made her take them back.  About a minute later she returned with what she said was new ones but they were warm if not a little cold.  At this point we were afraid of what might go on if we refused to eat them.  I wanted to leave but my husband said we would be fine.  Our bill was $154.92.  We usually tip 20-25% but I could not with a good conscience reward her bad behavior.  I put a big 0 with a note next to it 
"You know why."   Lesson learned.   Next time we pay for what we have consumed and leave. 
SO DISAPPOINTED.
author: Julie D.

description: Very pedestrian. Steaks are not what I would consider steak house quality. This restaurant food and service wise is on par with what you would get at Outback Steakhouse. Menu is boring and uninspiring and food is executed at the most basic of levels. I could compose as good a steak dinner at home for vastly less money.
author: Kyle C.

description:
An average experience. Traveling on business and the crowd wanted steaks. This was the closest. We should have pushed on a little further. It was a wasted evening. 

Unmemorable steaks, boring sides and gruff service. I guess I'm supposed to appreciate that as a "tradition" at steakhouses, but i don't. 

Reminded me of a west coast Durgin Park.
author: Phil C.

description: Came here for lunch with my family who was visiting from Oregon. Very small and stuffy place. Food wasn't too bad, but the chubby Mexican boy host had major attitude. Terrible customer service.
author: Barbara J.

description:
I went last Saturday for a return visit with great anticipation.

I ordered the dinner salad and the snapper with lemon sauce, topped with shrimp, mushroom and clams. The dinner arrived tepid.

This is a pet peeve and should never happen in a quality restaurant. Fish cooks quickly; they don't need to cook it ahead of time and let it get cold while diner eats an appetizer or salad. The sauce was congealed. Good flavor, they know how to cook. 

Potato had large black area I had to cut off. Not burned; anyone who's bought potatoes knows sometimes they have black spots. This black spot was huge; no way should kitchen or server have missed it. I mean, potato was large enough so it was not that I was starch-deprived but a detail that should not be overlooked.
author: Carol S.

description:
Honestly, for the price and the wait, this was less than OK for me. I come from the land of beef/cattle, so I committed a cardinal sin by ordering a steak outside of Texas, but it's also really difficult for me to turn down Surf & Turf at a place that delivers both. 

I should have just stuck with the surf! 

We started with raw oysters which were also pretty disappointing...they were fresh, but tiny, which I was only ok with because the price point was reasonable. 

I ordered the surf and turf, but my steak, ordered medium rare, was barely pink and I had to saw through tendons/gristle even with the steak knife in hand. That was extremely disappointing. I would have caused more of a stink about the state of my steak if I wasn't sitting in a tiny corner where our waiter couldn't even get to us because of the crowded table situation. He literally handed us menus across the backs of diners sitting at the two adjoining tables. 

Services was impeccable. Our waiter was definitely on top of things and I'm sure he would have made it right had I said something about my meal, but when you're edging toward 10 pm, the last thing you want to do is wait for another plate to be brought out/corrected. 

My recommendations for this place would be:

1. Take some tables out. You should NEVER have to sit at a table that you can't easily get into/out of or be properly waited on. The dining experience would just be that much better seeing as how fewer tables equals fewer diners which also means that the noise level would decrease (it was almost hard to hear yourself think). 

2. Don't skimp on beef if you're a steakhouse. Never, ever, ever, ever should a steakhouse serve a steak that has to be sawed through. The cut of the meat was just bad, no other way of slicing it (ba dum dum, ching!)

3. Figure out a way to make the bar easily accessible. If I'm going to have to wait upwards of 30 minutes to be seated, I should be able to enjoy a drink. It helps me and it helps you make more money off of me. Win win. The bar was so cramped you could barely even get to it, not to mention that the unfortunate diners having to sit next to the bar were not able to sneeze without hitting someone. That drops your dining experience down significantly. Bottom line, if you're charging on average $50 a head for a drink and a plate, the atmosphere should reflect that.
author: Emily P.

description:
Firstly the interior of this establishment is beautiful and like stepping back in time. The Saturday evening we were there, was live music.  It was packed, so felt fortunate to be seated fairly quickly, upstairs.

The wait staff was well mannered and versed in the menu.  Every selection was cooked to absolute perfection from the steak to the bread to the creamed spinach and more.  Worth every penny.  

Can't wait to go back again.
author: M M.

description: Simply put the experience was very good.  Table was a little tight on the second floor, but the staff was very attentive and the food was delicious.  Nice touch with a live jazz guitarist playing throughout dinner.  Lamb chops and filet were cooked perfectly. Cheesecake was creamy and wonderful.
author: John D.

description:
Wife's review: On Sunday October 2nd, I took my husband to John's Grill, for a very special birthday dinner. A week prior I had made on-line reservations, in the special request field, I wrote a "Special Birthday," for my husband. After completing the on-line reservations, I called the restaurant directly, and spoke to a gentleman, confirming the reservation, I also, told him, it was my husband's birthday. I asked "does the restaurant do anything special?" His response, "Oh, yes, we receive these requests all the time, no problem."
When we arrived Sunday, October 2nd, after we were seated, I spoke to the hostess, and again, confirmed it was my husband's birthday, and something would be brought out, after our meal, "of course, she said." We ordered our meal, the food was fair. The filet mignon was medium to medium well, even though my husband ordered medium rare. 
After dinner, our waiter came by, checked to see if we wanted dessert, I knew something special was going to be served, after all, I was reassured by 2 people, our waiter returned with the bill, but no dessert?
I immediately excused myself, went to the hostess, asked, "where was my husband's cake?" she looked at me, and wasn't sure what to say. I then asked for the manager, he arrived, I explained, he acted like it was no big deal, even though the check was already delivered to our table, we could still have dessert, he clearly didn't understand. They delivered two small glasses of a sweet liquor and flan with a candle. At this point, the surprise was ruined. 
While our waiter was a very good waiter, because of this incident, how management discounted our experience and, the food which was not that good, I regretfully will not return back to this restaurant. There are far too many wonderful restaurants in the area.

Husband UPDATE: We were contacted directly by the restaurant and we were given a name of someone to contact at the restaurant. We called and were quite impressed with deeply felt apologies from the contact. This contact went above and beyond to make the situation better. We are at this time comfortable with restaurant that we will be returning for a second chance. Everyone deserves a second chance. I will update the review after our return.
author: Brent J.

description: John's never disappoints. We go here every time when we're in SF. Civilized atmosphere,  nonpretentious food,  great service, well mixed cocktails to wash it all down. We absolutely love this place.
author: Heidi W.

description: This is a very old restaurant.  The complimentary sourdough bread comes with plenty of butter. The place is a bit touristy. Their lamb chops (Sam Spade's Lamb Chops) I had was delicious. It was tender, juicy, and cooked to medium. The baked potato was fluffy and hot.  I ordered the clam chowder, it was very thick and tasty. Customer service was very good. However, the restaurant had poor ambient lighting and was a bit pricey. I believe their steak or meat dishes are pretty good.
author: Hiroshi K.

description:
This is the worst steakhouse.  We were waiting for a friend and he was running late, so we ordered a salad to share.  Our friend let us know, he was going to be really late, so when the salad arrived, we ordered our dinner.  We ordered the lobster ravioli and filet (rare) to share.   The waiter did seem annoyed that we were sharing, but we aren't big eaters.  Half way through our salad (that we were sharing) our ravioli arrives.  It's seems odd that a kitchen can get a dish out in 4 minutes, but ok, we will try it.  It lacked any flavor and definitely did not have any lobster in it or lobster flavor.  Then, half way through our appetizer our steak arrives.  What?  How can you even cook a steak in 8 minutes.  Yes, 8 minutes from order to table.  They split the meal on 2 plates, which would have been nice if they would have allowed the steak to rest before cutting it in half.  My husband's steak was cook rare and mine was well done...how was this the same steak??  It was dry and was not seasoned at all.  How on earth has this place been open since 1908?  I have never been in and out of a steakhouse in 45 minutes.  Our bill was $120, which seems too expensive for the quality of food they are serving.  

Worst part was that we were only in the city for 1 night and there are a million excellent restaurants we could have choose from...such a bummer!!
author: Sally T.

description:
Based on the Yelp reviews, I did not think I will like this place much.  

But I was wrong. 

I'm a fan of the building, exterior and interior: old San Francisco, dark wood everywhere, coat hook at each table, nice bar, photos of local celebrities, and of course, the Maltese Falcon.

I'm a fan of the clam chowder: creamy but light, and done just right!  Dunked that lovely sourdough and you won't stop eating until it's all gone and you have no room for your entree.

I'm a fan of the Oysters Wellington.  Old school deliciousness and a lot heavier than you'd think.  

So.

Yay!  I'm a fan.
author: Amihan M.

description:
My family stumbled into this place on a rain day 10 years ago.

We have this tradition, if anyone is in SF they bring back the Jack Lalanne salad for a family member.

Imagine going thru the airport caring around a salad like its gold, keeping it safe and giving it to your family member and seeing the face of gratitude when they take the first bit.

Make a reservation, sure romantic and historic atmosphere.
author: Verenice R.

description:
This place was all right for what they would charge you comparable to what other steak/seafood houses will charge you in the city. Quality of their meats were decent but in term of flavor and overall taste they were OK. I can make a mean steak better than Mastro's so I know my steak. These guys can't even compare.

Would I go back, probably not. Again-the food isn't that bad. it's ok.
author: Miguel Y.

description: Fun evening. Food was good and service ok. Great for a nostalgic experience but a bit loud and wait staff quite busy and almost frantic. So if your looking to unwind in a relaxing environment this may not be the place.
author: David H.

description: As a political scientist, I am obsessed with patterns in data, so it seems fitting I was in town for a political science conference and decided to eat at John's because the Yelp reviews for this place are a fascinating study of patterns. It's pretty obvious that the older a Yelper, the more likely they were to give this place a higher rating. This is an okay steakhouse that has a vibe straight out of "Mad Men", which makes sense, because my friend and I were both under 40 and easily the youngest people there. Nothing here is phenomenal, and I would strongly advise against the Caesar Salad, which is grossly overrated. My friend's sirloin was decent, but honestly - we could have had a better steak at Chili's. If you want an old time feel, sure, eat here; but if you want quality food, go somewhere else.
author: Shyam S.

description: Food was pretty good. Service was terrible. Dinner took 3 hours, I never got a second drink. I was with a large party and the server would not split the check. He stood there while we were forced to separate the check ourselves. After dinner we talked with the manager about the experience and all he said was I will talk with the server. Will not come back.
author: Drew Z.

description: Do not come.  Horrible service.  They treated you as a quick turnaround table.  We had a reunion dinner here.  Asked the waiter if he can take a picture for us, he said he was too busy! Does he know what is customer service?   He is lucky that they added 19% service charge to our bill, otherwise he didn't deserve any tips.The steak is cold, small and no favor.  Yuk! What a waste of stomach space!
author: Kit L.

description: Cheap steakhouse in a historic building; they are trying to be upscale but are not. We ordered a New York Steak (not a strip) for $30. It was 10oz. Yes, that's a lot of meat for $30 but it wasn't the best cut and it was undercooked and chewy. We also ordered the Maine lobster ravioli which was horrible. It tasted like chef boyardee in a can. We tasted the filling by itself and there was no lobster in it. It resembled ground beef.
author: Jamie M.

description:
Birthday with the Blackbird

I went there on a weeknight for my birthday. The food was excellent. The service was top-notch. we also had the pleasure of sitting next to the guitar player who is both entertaining and interesting to talk to you. All that combined with the history of the Maltese falcon and the ambience and character of the restaurant made for a truly memorable dining experience. If you're in the Bay Area treat yourself to a meal at John's Grill.
author: Andrew P.

description: This is a nice but way overpriced restaurant. I decided to treat myself and paid $35.00 for a ribeye steak (which I rarely do). For that price, I would expect it to melt in my mouth but alas, that was not the case. This was one of the worst cuts of meat I've had. It was full of gristle and I found myself unsuccessfully sawing through the meat, I was shaking the whole table. My friend got a New York steak and she said hers was good. My other friend got the clam chowder and said that was good.
author: Corey B.

description: Another dinner and another home run! Never disappoints and it is our staple now in SF! We had our honeymoon trip to the bay area and made a point to make a reservation with Sean and again, they exceeded our expectations with service and quality of food. A very popular place and I understand why. Make reservations ahead of time during busy days becasue this place gets packed! We will be back again...of course!
author: Allen O.

description: My boyfriend and I have been here three times in the past six months! We really like this place! I've gotten the Dijon prawns the last two times and I HIGHLY recommend it. The flavor is delicious and they give you a good amount of prawns. It comes with mushrooms and I don't even like mushrooms but the way they prepare it I ate them all! We ordered creamed spinach and I didn't like it :/ it had a different spicy or something in it I didn't recognize. My boyfriend got the halibut which was also so delicious! The flavor is amazing! Vegetables were good and we each got a potato. Our server was very attentive and great I wish I remembered her name tall thin women with black hair. This place is a bit expensive for a place to just grab dinner on any ol night  but if your in the area and looking for a delicious restaurant  this is your place! It's one of our favorite date night spots! We also ordered the drinks on the drink menu that  you can take the glass home, I'm excited about that!
author: Geena G.

description:
My husband and I are both second-generation San Franciscans; as such, we like to patronize "true" San Francisco restaurants. Tonight - to celebrate my husband's 60th birthday - we had dinner at John's Grill, which was (somehow!) a first for both of us.

Our reservation was for 6:00 p.m.; when we arrived at 5:45, they were ready to seat us (and it wasn't as if they were having a slow night - the restaurant was full). We chose, however, to first have a cocktail at their little bar while we waited for our daughter to join us. We were immediately charmed by the bartender, Gary, who told us about the rich history of the restaurant, offered a sample of a fine Scotch, and talked "shop" with my husband (who is also a bartender).

Once our daughter arrived, and had had a cocktail with us, we decided to eat at the bar, rather than take a table - we were having that much fun with Gary (although I doubt that Gary was having that much fun with US!). As a starter, we shared an order of the lobster ravioli (just a couple of ravioli each), which was outstanding. For the entree, I had the NY Steak, my husband had the grilled sea bass, and our daughter had the Prawns Provencal. No one was disappointed! In fact, all of us were excited to share, and spent a great deal of time happily spooning food into each other's mouths. Even the baked potato and broccoli rabe were great. Everything was...perfect. Truly.

Gary recommended our wines and entrees, and didn't once steer us wrong. He also, very thoughtfully, ordered a flan for us to share at the end of our meal in honor of my husband's birthday - candle and all.

Last, but by no means least, the ambiance here is as good as it gets in San Francisco. This is THE quintessential San Francisco dining experience. Old-timey, dark wood, pictures of celebrities, politicians and dignitaries lining the walls...this is the real deal. And, of course, it's where Dashell Hammit wrote, "The Maltese Falcon," upon which the movie of the same name, starring Humphrey Bogart, was based. There is a mini museum (basically, a cupboard) on the second floor, which features a replica of The Falcon itself (replica because the original was stolen several years ago), among other Falcon-centric memorabilia. 

John's Grill is a must for anyone looking for a "true" San Francisco restaurant and all that that implies, great service, a great meal at a good price, and anyone interested in classic movies. Enjoy!
author: Teresa G.

description: This is best restaurant .i ordered steak and the meal is delicious .they served meal on time .the place was classic and romantic .
author: Mahnaz S.

description: Wow! Couldn't have been any better...the ambiance, the Service, the food! Every year my husband brings me to San Francisco for the Holidays so I can pick my gift out and go ice skating in Union Square. Every year we eat at John's Grill at least twice.  My husbands filet was is always perfect.  I had the Sea bass... fabulous!
author: Judy K.

description: Food was yummy and reasonably priced. Prepared as specified. We brought a magnum with our group of 8, we were charged 2 corkage fees. The chairs were very uncomfortable (much needed updating). Live music on 2nd floor. Small bar area with prompt service as well.
author: Erin S.

description: Nice and quiet place. Not very crowdy even during a lunch time. Try their private Cabernet-Sauvignon, it's pretty good.
author: Vladimir K.

description:
Great place! Great food!! Our waiter Chris was excellent!!! After being seated, we told him that we were quoted a 20 minute wait and after an hour how we went back to complain why people were being seated ahead of us, even though we were there first. The girl at the counter who took our name and who was NOT very welcoming and friendly for a restaurant said "sorry, I see I skipped you"  REALLY! NOT COOL!!!
However, Chris made up for it. He brought us 2 complimentary glasses of wine and at the end of our amazing dinner, brought us 2 complimentary after dinner drinks. His service was impeccable and the food was again, just amazing!! He made up for an uncool situation. Ask for Chris when you go, you will have a wonderful time and will not be disappointed!!
author: Tim B.

description:
How do you best reward
a yelp enthusiast 
who been dragged around
Union Square throughout the month of December?

A good meal.

Not only does John's Grill fit that bill, 
it is also conveniently located around that area.

John's invokes a 
SF history and style
that is not forgotten on the food.

Da Chowdar
is a warm and hearty and creamy way
to fight off the winter chill.

And the simply seasoned steaks
are grilled fairly close
to my ideal of medium rare.

In short,
John's is a fine respite
for the weary non-shopping 
yelper in all of us.
author: Dan B.

description: Crowded on a Sunday night, but staff still attentive and pleasant. My wife had the Chicken Jerusalem and decided this was her new favorite dish. I had the Grilled Red Snapper. It was done to perfection, and I'm hard to please. Most restaurants over cook fish. We had Rye Manhattans to start and they also were excellent.
author: Ralph E.

description: The lamb chops were recommended by our waiter and they were cooked to perfection! Outstanding service, and great value for the quality of food and environment. Will definitely come back on our next trip to San Francisco. Try the lamb chops!!!
author: Jay B.

description: This is a good option in the area for quality clam chowder. On a Saturday evening the restaurant was filled to the brim but there was space at the lively bar. There is a cocktail menu and nice selection of wine by the glass which are poured almost too amply by the bartender. The meal started with a basket of chewy, fresh sourdough bread and butter. The clam chowder bowl was presented with fresh ground pepper. It was piping hot, relatively thick and savory if not borderline salty. It was quite heavy on the clam and overall satisfying. This place had a romantic and timeless feel and is beautifully decorated. The service was perfect. Don't let the nearby street construction deter you.
author: Loretta J.

description: Will rate average for steaks, tried newyork style steak with bones, inspire of medium rare it was rubbery and tasteless. Also hard old bread and frozen butter. Will avoid next time.
author: Mayil D.

description: I was very disappointed by the steak. I came here craving for steak. I got something that was steak, but it was salty, hard to chew, and slightly over charcoaled. The portion was big but almost too big. I didn't pay extra for the sauce because I thought that was ridiculous. The place is dark even during the day and had a stale feeling. The bill was high. I truly do not see any merit in returning.
author: Elizabeth T.

description: Horrible food and bad service. I ordered the seafood pasta, and the seafood were not fresh and there is flavor whatsoever in the pasta. Called service few times and just not coming.
author: Anya C.

description:
It's the rare 100+ year old restaurant that's still good, and John's is one of those. It's old-fashioned -- very old-fashioned -- and that's a big part of it's charm. Grilled meat and fish, and that's about it. All in a room that Sam Spade would still feel comfortable in.

A couple of caveats: weekend crowds can be pretty fierce, so make a reservation; and don't let the seat you in the awful third-floor room. It has the charm of a cheesy hotel banquet room, and it smells bad. Even the second floor is okay, but not the third.

Food and drinks are good, the staff is great, so take care of business, set your expectations, and have fun.

P.S. The Maltese Falcon in the second floor display case is not the original movie prop, but it is still cool.
author: Rick H.

description:
Ok, I really liked this place but my wife was a little less enthusiastic, specifically due to the comfort (or lack thereof) of the chairs.

I had Yelp researched Johns before our trip and even watched the Maltese Falcon so I had a pretty good idea of what to expect.  I knew it was going to be expensive and budgeted for it.  

We used Uber to get there so we didn't have to deal with driving or parking which is always a nightmare in SF.  

The building is OLD but has lots of character.  We were seated in the upstairs dining room which had a vies of the streets below.  We started with an order of the lobster ravioli which had been raved about on yelp, and frankly, I was under impressed.  They were ok, but noting to write home about.  I ordered the Ribeye and my wife had the fillet.  The cuts were prime and both were cooked exactly to order and were delicious!  We had a bottle of Longoria Pinot Grigio which was EXCELLENT and reasonably priced.

We ended our meal with a glass of port (tuaca for the little woman) and a conversation with the young couple at the next table.  

Even though this was a steak house in downtown San Francisco, as is sat there sipping port out of a proper cordial glass, I thought the place had the mob feel of New York or Chicago in the 30's and 40's... I felt a bit like Pete Clemenza.

Our total bill came to about $200 which was what I had budgeted.  My wife's complaint was that if she was paying $200 for a meal, she wanted a chair that didn't want to kick her ass out after 10 minutes of sitting in it.  And she did have a point.
author: Dave P.

description: Of course the legendary John's Grill since 1908 is an amazing staple for San Francisco! Incredible steaks, old world romantic atmosphere, and such history! With it's 'Maltese Falcon' fame, this restaurant delivers on class and quality of food with the charm of old San Francisco. Many floors of tables, but still fills up sometimes but it's worth the wait. You have to try out this place, if it lasted over 100 years, it has to be great!
author: Peter K.

description:
Recently attended a weekend long seminar in the private room on the 3rd floor of John's. Lunch on both days was delicious! Certainly not a place for a diet, I had a creamy pasta dish one day and a spinach salad loaded with bacon bits and a somewhat creamy dressing on day 2. Service was great and the space was perfect for our group.

I look forward to returning for dinner sometime as the place is chock full of character and a glimpse of old San Francisco - there are very few venues like this left in our fair city.
author: Gwynnie P.

description:
You wouldn't know it by walking by but this place is great. The clams for appetizers in garlic sauce was unbelievable , thee best I have ever had ... Not over cooked , just right! Steak was wonderful , cooked to exact order! Music was modern and service was outstanding ....They even help me plan a our proposal on a spare of the moment.  We also liked that they were open a little later than other surrounding restaurants. 

Only reason I didn't give it 5 stars was the bottom floor was a little crammed . But isn't all of San Fran! :) We would go back for sure and recommend it!
author: Darla R.

description: We were looking for a great steak in an authentic San Francisco restaurant. It was our splurge night in San Francisco. We were thrilled to happen upon John's while out walking. We stopped in to make a reservation for later that night and were taken by its charm. The white tablecloths and celebrity photos lining the walls combined to create the exact atmosphere we had in mind. The spunky jazz playing in the background was just the right touch, too. Our meal did not disappoint. To start, we were immediately served a generous hunk of the most heavenly sourdough bread, always a good preview of the meal to come. Our steaks were seasoned and expertly grilled to the perfect medium-rare. The broccolini and baby carrots on the side were perfectly crisp-tender. We've been to San Francisco many times, and this has been our most enjoyable meal. No trendy foods trying too hard to be current here. Just fine old-fashioned, perfect steaks and traditional sides.
author: Janice G.

description:
If you are a fan of the movie and novel "Maltese Falcon", you'll love the decor and the special "Maltese Falcon" showcase located on the 2nd floor of this restaurant.
This was my 2nd time at this restaurant and it was definitely worth coming back. The food and the chef's special is quite good and the service us not too bad.
This place is definitely a throwback to the early 1940's & 50's and it is a must if you are in San Francisco.
author: Louis L.

description: Had a great meal and was great experience with the jazz music dinner was perfect can't go wrong Maltese falcon was awesome
author: Fabrizio S.

description: My husband and I visited John's Grill for our first time in San Francisco.  We were seated quickly.  We ordered steaks.  The steaks were cooked to our specifications perfectly.  We both got baked potatoes. My husband had ordered a loaded back potato but received just a plain baked potato.  I asked for a salad rather than the mixed vegetables and was only offered sliced tomatoes.  The bread was cold.  Who wants to to try to swipe hard cold butter on cold bread?  The quality and service doesnt  justify the price.  I wont be visiting this place again and wont recommend to anyone.  You never get another chance to make first impressions.
author: Kelly V.

description: Very cool place- has a great old time-y grill to it.  I had the ciopinio.  It came with shrimp, clams, mussels and sole.  It was all perfectly cooked.  I don't usually like mussels, finding them to be overcooked and rubbery, but these were perfect.
author: Mike P.

description:
This was expensive, crowded, and the tables were so packed together it was hard to move. However, service was great, food was fabulous, and we had an excellent time. 
We parked in the garage right across the street. 
Also, we had just come from the Golden Gate Theatre and our tickets were good at John's Grill for 1 free glass of wine or a Martini, so that was a very good Perc.
author: Lenny H.

description:
Utterly mediocre and forgettable. Very accommodating service and friendly staff couldn't make up for lackluster food. 

Good recommendations on wine and, again, very good service. Seated us right away when it was tough to get last minute reservations elsewhere. Even added a table when we had an unexpected guest joined. 

Clam chowder came highly recommended. Three out of five of us had it and don't finish it. If this is all you know for clam chowder perhaps you will enjoy it, but, coming from Boston, pretty much anyplace, including chain restaurants, have better. 

People seemed to like the Jack Lelane salad, but it's a $30 salad!

Steaks were unanimously agreed to be terrible. Was the thinnest ribeye I've had, tough, and flavorless. For the money The Outback Steakhouse would be a better choice. 

It would be tough to return.
author: Chris M.

description: I thought the food was pretty good.  The clam chowder was very good.  The vegetables lacked seasoning and the baked potato was a little over cook.  The worst part about the experience was that the chairs are like little torture seats!   Couldn't wait to get out of it.  The other thing was that we sat straight in and got the smell of cigarette smoke the whole time!
author: Lynn F.

description:
What a wonderful surprise to stumble upon this charming, elegant and classic restaurant. 

My family and I had been shopping for ornaments at Gump's, an annual holiday tradition and were seeking a special place for lunch to celebrate the season.

We were smitten from the moment we stepped inside with the festive and tasteful holiday lights and decorations and old school dark wood panels, hardwood floors and cozy tables with antique lighting.

The food was great and the service as well.  Our Waiter, Gary, was thoughtful and gracious and the food and service were excellent.
author: Jane V.

description:
Just had the BEST BURGER  in San Francisco.
Juicy and cooked to perfection, accompanied with golden crispy fries.
This restaurant has a great "old school " vibe and great service. 
Wine list has everything to offer with many gems.
author: Mark R.

description: As always, we enjoy coming for a nice, juicy steak. My wife had the Ribeye and I had Lamb Chops. Service was great. Until next time Maltese Falcon!
author: Tony S.

description: Great place for a large group! We were seated in the front window area and were able to have a wonderful conversation throughout dinner. The customer service was perfection. We all left very impressed, satisfied and happy!
author: Lauren H.

description: This is my first time writing a negative review on any business, but I was so disappointment with food that I have to share my experience.  I've been to John's Grill numerous times in twenty years and this is the first time the food was unacceptable.  We had reservations after seeing the Nutcracker so this was to be special holiday meal.  Our reservations were for 5:15 p.m. on a Friday.  We were seated promptly and order immediately.  We ordered lobster ravioli, red snapper with veggies and a baked potato and the Fisherman pasta (linguine).  Immediately after ordering the waitress informs me that they do not have any baked potatoes ready and that it would be an additional 30 minutes.  Mind you John's Grill does not have mashed potatoes or rice, so the only other option is fries...for a plate that is almost $30.  I waited.  In the meantime the raviolis came and half of them were still cold inside. SMH I was going to send them back but didn't want to make an issue of it since my daughter had chosen this place.  Now for the Fisherman pasta...worst dish of all.  The so called linguine tasted like Pasta Roni, I kid you not.  The noodles were mushy and sauce tasted worse than what comes out of a jar...way too think.  The best part of our meal was the bread and the dessert, which neither John's Grill baked. It is so sad that this iconic restaurant serves such crappy food.  I can not understand the lines of people wanting to get in.
author: Ramona B.

description:
The prawn cocktail was amazing. A good amount of horseradish in the cocktail sauce.

The Filet was great. Not quite as done as a medium well should have been, but amazing flavor. Good flavors were present in the vegetables and potato, too. 

Had the homemade vanilla bean ice cream. Wonderful, served with berries. 

All in all, just fantastic. A grand meal in a wonderful city. 

Oh, and did I mention the Maltese Falcon? Awesome!

Oh, normally I deduct a star for bad parking, but there is a big structure across the street, and it is San Francisco, after all.
author: Kim H.

description: I'm very impressed. We stumbled into this place and able to get a seat. We were underdressed but were treated as well as any 5 star restaurant would treat it's regulars. The food was delicious, cocktails were wonderful and they had a talented jazz guitarist play. Thank you so much! I'll be back!
author: Matt C.

description:
Very nice ambiance... not stuffy but elegant with plenty of history. It's an establishment. Only went in for an app and a beer so my assessment is limited. Non traditional escargot but surprisingly satisfying. The mussels and more importantly the broth was delicious. Although the mussels were somewhat small. Very good service by the bartender and the waiter. Good ambient music. Classy decor. 

Will certainly return for a a full encore.
author: Martin S.

description:
I love the old school signage out front. On the inside it is a traditional steakhouse decor but less luxurious than Mastro's, Morton's etc. Also, it's a tad cramped.

Our server was polite, knowledgeable, and quick.

The Caesar salad was traditional and very good. My rib-eye steak was very tough and had a lot of gristle or not chewable parts. Edible portion was about 65%.

I added a star for the talented keyboardist who pretty much knew every song we requested.
author: Mihir S.

description:
My Hubby and I found this place by accident while visiting SF.  Neither of us are Maltese Falcon fans, so we really didn't know that this grill was a historic place!  When we came up to it I was honestly was expecting some smokey smelling, greasy bar and grill. 

We were shocked when we walked in and saw wood paneling, white linen covered tables and a wall full of pictures.  I really enjoyed looking at all the pictures of former mayors, movie stars,  police chiefs and other public officials.   

Both my husband and I had the chicken club which was reasonably priced.  It came with a side of french fries.   We were served warm sour dough bread and butter while we were waiting.  

The sandwich was  a little dry for me. But the portion size for lunch was good and the french fries were the shoestring type, not at all greasy and nicely seasoned.  

But the best part of the meal for me was the handmade vanilla bean ice cream with fruit.  I could have eaten a couple of servings of this dessert, it was so creamy, but yet light and airy.  It really was amazing.  The biscotti cookie that comes along with it was a real treat. 

I can't say it was a 5 star experience and I wouldn't go out of my way to dine there for lunch but if lunch is just a glimpse of what the food and atmosphere is like for dinner - it would be worth the time to do the full dinner experience.
author: Theresa R.

description: Had dinner there last Saturday, 11/5. Enjoyed the place, had the John's steak and a manhattan. Waitress was old school which was excellent. Steak was not medium-rare as I requested but was well done. They lose a star for that. But other than that, great place; I'll return.
author: Ray C.

description: Ordered a steak and potato, potato toppings arrived at the table 35 minutes later. Cheese for the potato was a Kraft single-slice! Ambiance was okay, nothing special to justify the pricey menu. Unreasonable up-charge for any group larger than 5- completely NOT worth the price.
author: Linda R.

description:
Three of us girls for lunch yesterday.  Fortunately we made a reservation via OpenTable the night before for 1pm lunch date.  

We must have been the only locals eating here.  But so what.  We each ordered our own lunch entree and shared the fried oyster plate.  A basket of crusty French bread started us off.

I ordered the Jack LaLanne salad.  It was very fresh.  Local Dungeness crab, bay shrimp, chopped tomatoes, half a sliced avocado, sliced mushrooms on a bed of mixed dark green salad.  I had the dressing on the side.  (For those of you who have never heard of Jack LaLanne, he was the known as the godfather of fitness).  

We shared the pecan pie for dessert and I had an Irish coffee.  The pecan pie was more like a flat rectangular shape rather than a pie wedge.  Like they made a sheet of it.  I'd probably pass on that next time.  For that matter none of the desserts were appealing.   

$40 p/p inc tax $ tip.  

We each had $25 gift certificate so it diffused the cost of lunch.  

Service was average this time around.  

The place was packed.  Before and after lunch folks were hovering outside reading the menu.  Should we or shouldn't we?  I guess it depends on what you order.
author: Shirley N.

description: Great old school place. Loved hearing groovy jazz through dinner.  Service and food were excellent! Try John's Snapper with crab and shrimp. Yummy!
author: Lena L.

description: Food was extremely good and Clam Chouder the best ever for us. Steaks very good and nice cozy warm atmosphere. Been in business 100 years or so. Awesome friendly bar tender and very caring owner. Must visit!! Wish they were open even later.
author: Kevin S.

description:
Went for dinner last night... Clam chowder was still good but the seafood pasta was absolutely brutal. Huge disappointment 

It was very busy in contrast to when we've been for lunch so perhaps the kitchen gets overwhelmed...
author: Joe M.

description: Absolutely delicious, the atmosphere was nice but a little bit on the louder side. I'd recommend sitting upstairs if you can! The cioppino was delightful and the best I've ever had. I would definitely come here again.
author: Megan M.

description:
I've been hearing and reading about this place for years,  the legendary century-old institution featured in the Maltese Falcon.  I love historic places, and am a bit of a Bogart/Sam Spade/film noir fan, so I really wanted to check it out.  But every time I've been in the neighborhood, it was totally booked up.  Finally, on my latest trip to San Francisco, I got to try it, a couple of times.

First visit, I met up with a friend for post-conference drinks after a long day at Moscone Center.  The place (or should I say "the joint") certainly looks its age.  From the vintage neon sign out front, to the dark, vaguely musty interior, John's Grill certainly feels historic.  In business since 1908, and apparently never altered since, it's all dark wood paneling, dark wood partition running down the middle, small and cramped, designed for those smaller people of that era, not for big 6'4" lugs like me (sorry, my inner Spade is coming out).  Sure, I can definitely imagine Bogie/Sam Spade grabbing a drink or a bite here. The only addition over the years seems to be the ever-growing collection of B&W photos covering the walls, which range from scenes of post-1906-quake devastation to decades of celebrity patrons.  We sat at the bar, which wasn't exactly comfortable -- smallish, rickety, hard-edged old bar stools and no rail to rest your feet on -- but they served us excellent cocktails.  I had a French Gimlet, which is sort of a citrus-laced martini, my buddy an Old Fashioned, both notably good. 

Second visit, I was on my own, my last night in town, and I went for a full dinner.  To submerse myself in the whole Sam Spade aura of the joint, I downloaded a copy of the original 1929 Dashiell Hammett novel, The Maltese Falcon, and read it while I ate.  Yup, there it is: "...Right.  Have him pick me up at John's, Ellis Street, as soon as he can make it. ... He went to John's Grill, asked the waiter to hurry his order of chops, baked potato, and sliced tomatoes, ate hurriedly, and was smoking a cigarette with his coffee when a thick-set youngish  man with plaid cap set askew above pale eyes and a tough cheery face came into the Grill and to his table."  I wonder if it was my table. 

The food is also old-school, the kind of stuff your grandparents would be comfortable ordering.  I started with a Dungeness Crab Cocktail, which turned out to be just a generous pile of crab meat with cocktail sauce in an ice-chilled dish  -- excellent, fresh, simple.  Then I had the Roquefort Salad (note: roquefort, not "blue cheese." I remember my mom always used to order "roquefort" dressing, back when I was kid), which wasn't quite what I expected (cheese crumbles, not a creamy dressing) but still good.  My main dish was the Seafood Cioppino a la Marinara, which was also excellent.  The flavor was more old-style American than Italian, the tomato-based broth reminding me of Manhattan-style clam chowder, but it was loaded with all sorts of excellent seafood. Very tasty and satisfying.  I topped off the meal with the New York Cheesecake, which turned out not to be a massive wedge (fortunately), but a modest-sized hockey puck of cheesecake topped with berries -- just right, and one of the most delicious vanilla-laced cheesecakes I've ever tasted.

So yeah, even though it's a bit cramped and not particularly comfortable, stuffy in back and drafty by the door, I kinda like this joint.  I'll be back. Maybe bring a dame next time.
author: Steve L.

description:
Tourist Trap and Mediocre Food...Sorry! 
We live in SF and have never dined here and won't bother going back...dinner this past sunday nite was like a over priced Sizzler restaurant meal. I think Black Angus chain steakhouse is way better and w/a coupon WoW!!!
The bread+butter was good here LOL.
The JACK LALANNE'S FAVORITE SALAD (for two) disappointing!
The OYSTERS WELLINGTON was GREAT and unique dish!
The Flan VANILLA CREAM CARAMEL was excellent!
John's Grill needs updating and remodeling but keep the classic Old School look.
author: Ron M.

description:
We asked our concierge about a place to eat. We didn't expect for him to make a reservation, but he did ask what we were interested in eating...  We had JUST arrived in the city after 8 hours on a plane, no real breakfast (protein bars DON'T count) and the peanuts served on the plane aren't food.  So I was -HUNGRY-, I wanted MEAT.  
 
He suggested John's Grill. Not only was it -close- but it is a historical place, having been in operation in the same location since 1908.  Our Reservation was for 3 pm, and the location was literally about 300 feet from the outside of our hotel, so we hoofed it down the street and arrived in plenty of time.  When we checked in, we were seated with an outside view, not bad, but the view is of a boutique hotel painted gray and people waking by. 

The menu... Ok.. it's pretty limited, For a "Steak" place, it's mostly seafood.   There are a few salads, there are a few sandwiches but there are a lot of seafood choices and there are a few grill options.  In the end, once the waiter came to take our order (after delivering some REALLY GOOD sour dough bread!) we ordered 2 lunch salads and the husband got a hamburger and I got the NY Steak sandwich. 

The bread was -phenomenal-! It must be from a local bakery because it was So Good. Of course, Due to my diet, I've not had real bread in ages, so that might have been why too.. but yea! BREAD!.. The salads.. for $5, I expected something more than a half cup of mixed greens, 2 slices of cucumbers cut in half. a wedge of tomatoe and about 2 table spoons of carrots and cabbage.  The dressing, a vinagrette, was pretty tasty though. 

Our mains: The hamburger  was tasty, if cooked a bit too medium for the husband's liking.  My steak sandwich, I asked for medium rare, was more to the medium well side of things, but the meat was good and just what I wanted. Both of us left our buns behind, they just didn't compare to that sourdough we'd just eaten. 

For the price of the meal, we would likely be back, but only once. 

OH! One small thing.. this is the place if you're a Sam Spade fan or into the Maltese Falcon. Be sure to check out the restrooms on the 2nd floor. Well, not the Restrooms but the display cabinet. You'll love it!
author: Dianna B.

description:
For several years we have been coming for lunch once or twice a year.  Came in for lunch on Memorial Day and once again were not disappointed.  We would come more often if closer to home.
My husband had the seafood combo and I had the jumbo prawns.  The entrees were served with some great vegetables, nice and crisp, not mushy-cooked to perfection. The deep fried seafood is the best you can get-thin batter-not greasy-quality seafood.  Portions are just the right size.  Sour dough bread also compliments the meal!

The restaurant is small, quaint, rather dark, totally san franciscan.
Go early, they fill up fast and can get noisy when packed.
Great place for a date, special occasion, or craving the feel of San Francisco!

Last but not least, service is also at its best.
author: Diane W.

description: This place was so good!  It was our last night and town and I'm so glad we found Johns.  The steaks were all amazing and the wine was great.  Our waitress was great, it was an all around good experience.  Don't skip Johns when looking for a great meal!
author: Ashley B.

description:
Returned here yesterday for a business lunch after too long an absence.  Since most of downtown SF looks like a smashed erector set these days, I was concerned that the stretch of Ellis where John's sits might be in upheaval as well; thankfully all was fine.

The room is tight, to put it mildly, but the eclectic group of diners -- tourists, conventioneers, and a gaggle of Herb Caen's "EssEff" literary characters -- makes people-watching well worth the submarine wardroom snugness.

Oh, the food?  As good as ever, predictable, ample courses with good drinks and friendly, efficient service.  I chose their club sandwich with fries, a dish any good restaurant should knock out easily, but so few do.  John's definitely rates an A+.  My colleague gave his fresh fish choice the same grade.

Probably not a destination place for me, but if you are working and/or shopping downtown, by all means it is worth a visit soon, perhaps best for a late lunch.  Be sure to make reservations.
author: Don P.

description: My spouse and I walked in on Friday night at 7:45 with no reservation and fully expected to wait. To our surprise we were seated upstairs immediately. The room was crowded but the live jazz guitar helped the mood. To start, I had a bowl of their thick and creamy clam chowder. My wife had a dinner salad. For entrees I ordered the T-bone steak medium and my wife had the fishermen's pasta.  The food came out quickly and the seafood pasta was terrific. I had to send the steak back as it was barely kissed by the grill and far to rare for my taste. Our server handled it like a champion and without delay and comped my wine. My cooked to order steak arrived in just moments later and was delicious. Our server continued to be attentive without hovering and the remainder of our experience was a delight. I will definitely return. 3/5 only because of the returned steak.
author: John E.

description:
We have been going here occasionally for years and love the place.

It has some very traditional American dishes, plus some pasta dishes and a few more special plates.  Food is always good and we particularly love the Jack LaLanne's Favorite Salad, Oysters Wellington, Lamplighter, Seafood Canneloni, Liver and Onions (well, only I like that one), creamed spinach.  Other salads are good.  Cocktails are good, solid, serious cocktails - we've had better but the cocktails here are always good.  Prices are reasonable, especially for some dishes.  We love the atmosphere, the old San Francisco character of the place, the connection with Dashiel Hammet, etc. 

Beware that it gets really busy, though, so we always make reservations.  We generally prefer upstairs, which is more peaceful and has the Maltese Falcon which the kids like to see.
author: Wulfstan C.

description:
My wife and I were seated promptly. The service could not have been better. Being a frequent flyer at Mortons, I was expecting our steaks to be better. 
I had the Ribeye. It's was good but much thinner than I expected. Morton's ribeye is twice as thick and more tasty but it is also twice the price. 

I was hoping for a Morton's type steak. I wasn't trying to save money. 

All in all it was very good and I was happy to experience a restaurant with so much history. This place has been here since 1908!
author: Alan M.

description: We visited this restaurant on a Friday night and they were packed.  We did not have reservations and sat at the bar...we got lucky there were only 2 seats left as someone had just departed.  Our bartender Jose was busy, but still found time to talk with us about the history of the restaurant, as well as the city itself.  He was a wealth of information and a true professional bartender!  We had dinner while sitting at the bar - our server, Leila?  No positive of her name.  She was great as well - never missed a beat.  Our meal was delicious, (try the house snapper - to die for), and look forward to dining there on our next visit!
author: Georgene C.

description:
We went Jonh's grill many times food and service was very good. Usually we sit at the bar. The bar tender very professional and people work  there are friendly.
It's true San Francisco treat !!!
author: Fariborz G.

description: My girl friend and I went to this restaurant during our first trip in San Francisco, and we really like its food and steak.
author: Boris C.

description:
Just finished my meal here...actually I'm still sitting at the table. Brother picked this place since it was near our hotel. Place was pretty busy for a Thursday night...good thing he made reservations. We got seated right away. The menu was pretty simple..take your pick of steaks and seafood...mostly fish and then they had four other dishes... lamb, liver, chicken and oyster wellington. 

I opted for the oyster wellington...my brother opted for the ribeyed steak... my mom had the grilled liver and my dad had the broiled sea bass. For appetizers we tried the escargot and sauteed mushrooms and creamed spinach for sides. 

The food took a very long time to come out... we waited for about 30 minutes or so. The escargot came out pretty quick...6 nickel-size pieces drenched in a basic white sauce served on a fancy little dish...it was okay...a little on the bland side...would prefer a more buttery based sauce..but that's my personal preference. Our main dishes came out really late.. waited what felt like 30 minutes or so for it after the one appetizer we had. 

My dish came with three mini oyster wellingtons and veggies (sugar snap peas and a couple of baby carrots and two pieces of zucchini)- first bite of the wellingtons were pretty good however I realized it was stuffed with more bacon than oysters...it was stuffed with bacon and spinach. Still pretty good though. The veggies were kinda bad....sugar snap peas were chewy and undercooked...the other pieces of vegetables were slightly undercooked and bland. However, the two side dishes we ordered was much better - good sauteed mushrooms and creamed spinach. My brother's rib eye steak was acceptable - tender and flavorful. The grilled liver was a tad chewy but the crispy bacon compensated for the mild flavor of the dish. In the end only my brother ordered dessert - a rich but very tasty chocolate mousse torte. I was stuffed but still couldn't resist a few bite of it. 

Now onto the service - I straight out didn't like ourl waiter.....perhaps he's tired or whatever but he was so inattentive and I can't say he was all that friendly either. Felt like I had to snap my fingers at him to get his attention and having waited for so long for the food - he didn't bother to tell us. No no on service!

Overall the meal was pretty decent but I need another waiter next time.
author: Joanna L.

description: STRONG drinks and great food. They even had a live piano player there when I came. Nice unique building with beautiful decor. I would recommend trying this place out!
author: Jonah M.

description: Went for lunch, not busy at all but the service was terrible and slow. The food was ok, might be better at dinner. This was highly recommended on Open Table so I would be willing to try again for dinner.
author: Les T.

description:
Went to John's Grill last night, ate at the bar, and was singularly unimpressed. I have dined there several times over the years and regrettably, its gone downhill. How so?

Used to be that there was a knowledgeable and personable bartender who served you drinks and took your food order.  Last night, the bartender took my drink order and that was it.  He was polite enough but made no effort to engage in conversation.  And he only serves drinks.  A waiter came over and took my food order, again he was polite, but rushed.  

I ordered the lamb chops, a house specialty, and 5 minutes later I was served them. Why am I complaining about fast service?  Because they couldn't possibly have been made to order in that amount of time.  The Chops themselves were decent but nothing to brag about, I've had better.  But the message that clearly was being sent was to rush me (and I suppose other diners) through: serve drinks, take your order, and then hurry it to you.  Repeat with next customer. 

John's should know that one of the pleasures of dining at the bar in a "fine" dining restaurant is to have an unhurried meal, prepared to order, and served by a knowledge and conversational bartender. That used to be the case here, no longer. 

I guess they can live off their storied history but it will take more than the Maltese Falcon to get me to dine there again.  Too bad.
author: Robert D.

description: I was able to get a seat very easily on a Monday night.  I ordered a cocktail and the 20oz porterhouse.  It came with freshly steamed veggies and a loaded baked potato.  The steak was okay and filling.  Supposedly all the steaks are from Harris Ranch, which has pretty decent meats here in Cali.  It wasn't prime or anything fabulous I'd come back for but a nice experience to say I've eaten at such an historic restaurant.
author: Jeremy T.

description: Atmosphere was great, food was amazing except my baked potato was lukewarm at best but my steak was cooked perfectly. For the price and history of this place I'd expect better. All the staff I encountered on the floor were great. Our server kind of had a little attitude and wasn't too personable so that's why only 3 instead of 4 stars. I know this place is a legend in SF and has history but they can still fine tune some stuff like making sure all food is served hot and ALL staff are friendly to patrons. I will definitely come back again for sure, I just hope I get a different server.
author: Brian L.

description: We have been coming here for years, but tonight was a total negative. We were seated upstairs and they packed so many tables in our waiter had to hand our plates over another table to us. They are trying to make more money by packing in the customers. Not coming back, there are too many other steakhouses in this town for us to deal with this. And we weren't the only ones upset.
author: Kevin S.

description: Classic, old school San Francisco experience. There's nothing I love more than a great piece of fish, fresh vegetables, and a baked potato. Bliss!!!  I had Halibut, and my husband had the Sea Bass. We were going on to a performance, and appreciated the efficient service, too. Make sure you save a little room for dessert....the cheesecake was excellent! If you want to eat somewhere with character and history, this is a perfect choice.
author: Leigh S.

description: The red snapper dinner I had was "ok".  It was very saucy and didn't have a whole lot of flavor to it.
author: Mark T.

description: From the magnificent sourdough bread while we waited for our meal, to the exquisite entres, there is a reason John's Grill has lasted more than 100 years. I had the New York steak that was perfectly prepared and melted in my mouth. My husband had the halibut with lemon butter sauce and mushrooms. (Of course we shared). Would definitely return.
author: Lillian L.

description:
The worst $90 I ever spent on a meal was tonight in this tourists trap.

If you want a steak they will charge you an extra couple of bucks for a peppercorn sauce without peppercorns served in a tiny ramekin with a skin on top (only after reminding the waiter that you ordered it that way), and don't forget to tell them how you like it prepared because they won't ask. But for only an extra five bucks they with serve you a bland and watery version of creamed spinach, and I hope you like your potatoes baked, because that is the ONLY way they serve them.

For you out of owners, get away from Union Square and hop a cab to Izzy's in the Marina for a great meal. You'll be thanking me later.
author: James S.

description: Loved this place! Good food,great service and a wonderful atmosphere. As I said the food was good but not great. But the price reflects that.
author: Lisa V.

description: This place is super good the service was excellent the waiter pablo super nice. My spinach salad was fabulous! Clam chowder was the best I've had in years.
author: Tom W.

description: Came here with my coworkers as a reward for our hardwork after Dreamforce. I saw that it was 3.5 stars so I was a little eh about this place, but we had amazing service and the Oyster Wellington I ordered was delicious! The sauce that came with everything was so flavorful, the oysters were large and filling with spinach. I was satisfied at every bite! I finished the meal and will definitely be back to try more items on the list :)
author: Amanda C.

description: I was there alone. The waiter was fairly attentive. The people at the table next to me were complaining that their fish tasted greasy and wondered if it was cooked on the same grill as the steak. No answer. My meal New York steak with baked potato and vegetables. The bread brought to the table was really good. The steak was cooked perfectly but was full of grizzle. I probably won't be returning.
author: Sharon P.

description: Trying it for dinner, I enjoyed the food and the pictures of famous San Fran politicos and luminaries that line the walls, but the lighting was so harsh it had the ambience of a Walgreen's. They really need to dim it a bit and the atmosphere would be perfect. Until then, better to stick with Café Tosca in North Beach.
author: Stephen C.

description: Just the best cioppino I've ever had. Everything else on the menu looks fantastic,  but the cioppino has won my heart and I've never ordered anything else. I make a trip to John's whenever I'm in town on business as it's a great place to dine solo and it seems there are always enough characters in the place to make for an entertaining night.
author: Jenni T.

description: I visited John's Grill on April 8, 2017.  It was recommended by the concierge at the Hilton San Fransisco.  I ordered the Fisherman's Pasta, a dish I have thoroughly enjoyed elsewhere many times, and it was a complete disappointment.  The mussels were over cooked as was the pasta which was drowning in a bland white creme sauce.  The entire dish was devoid of taste except for the overly generous Parmesan cheese which itself had minimal taste.  For a restaurant in a city know for sea food, John's Grill should probably stick to steaks.  Service was acceptable.  About the only good thing I can say about the restaurant is that the historic building has a unique charm.
author: Richard D.

description: What a great place for steak and seafood. The Red Snapper was fantastic and the staff was really attentive.
author: Larry P.

description:
Wait staff.....5 stars
Drinks..........5 stars
Crab Cocktail.....5 stars
Surf and Turf........5 stars......steak done to perfection as well as shrimp
Sea Bass.........1 star......mushy and smothered in sauce so you could not taste the fish.  Vegetables were overdone.  

Best part of the entire experience was watching the hostest (dressed in black with long black hair and wearing a black coat with leather sleeves)  snuggle with her boyfriend in the table in front of us.  Between patrons coming in, she would come over and chat with him and make negative comments about the customers.  First time ever that I have seen a hostest help herself several times  to the alcoholic drink (bloody mary) ordered by the patron.  She also liked the french fries that he had ordered.   Epitome of unprofessionalism.  I felt at times, I was watching a satire on Saturday Night Live of bad hostesses.   

Thanks.   One star is the best I can do.   Won't be back.   Hope the hostest didn't drive herself home and make it home safely after that alcohol.    Thanks for the front row seats to the show.
author: Ken B.

description: If I could give this place zero stars as a rating I would. I went in on a Friday night as the dinner rush was calming down. My co-worker and I requested to sit at the bar. As we gazed at the the empty bar the waitress responded "Sorry the bar is full". I then surveyed the restaurant and noticed that my co-worker an myself were the only people of color in the establishment. I then stated that her response was interesting as I was literally looking at the empty bar just ahead. I cannot remember her response but I do remember the condescending smile on her face. It's unfortunate that discrimination is so overt/acceptable in one of the MOST diverse cities in CA. It's definitely a testament to low class, despicable service, and flat out racism; which depreciates the the high end fine dining experience of the restaurant.
author: T M.

description: Found the place tooo pricey for the food they served!! Nothing v special in taste or service...ALSO note they add Service charges besides other taxes before deciding on tips.
author: Mona R.

description: Lots of consruction. It's pretty loud too! Overall however, great steak and amazing service! The decor is a walk down memory lane and the flavors are classic and true to form!
author: Natetron S.

description:
History here with old school charm feel.

Sat at bar, bartender has been working there for 30+ years.  No shakers, use a glass.

Hubby had Anchor Steam, I had a Greyhound and we shared prawn cocktail.
author: Gloria H.

description: After a super long day walking around Fisherman's Wharf and Union Square the tired kids and I still needed to celebrate our daughters 13th birthday. We desperately wanted to avoid chains and stay with local eateries, a nice woman recommended this place. Being 8pm on a weekday we had no wait which was a wonderful surprise. No split fee for us to split a meal between our children. Waiter was patient and fun with great recommendations and even told us kids could get fries instead of baked potato which was not listed on the menu. Food came out fast, was delicious, and perfectly cooked. Prices were not bad, we expected them to be higher. Waiter then surprised my daughter with a caramel custard dessert free of charge and sang HBD to her. This is not a "kids" restaurant but they handled our kids like champions!
author: Stacey D.

description:
This was a decent place to eat a nice meal.  The 1941 version of the Maltese Falcon contains a scene from this location.  It's been around since 1908... Good enough reasons to stop by.

Again, I find myself admiring the location and excusing the food. 

Bread came with little foil wrapped butter patties... That is just not cool.

The meal was just fine, but nothing to write home about.  My filet mignon was well done when I ordered Med-rare.  They took it back and returned in about 2 min with a perfect med-rare steak.  ...some other patron waited a few extra min, I suspect, for a med-rare steak... Don't mess up a $35 steak.

My wife had lamb chops. They were huge and well cooked.  No complaints here.

The vegies were OK.  The potato was served with only sour creme.  

I'm going to say that it was an OK meal at an outstanding location.  I would go back if I was in the company of a Bogart fan, or if I had tried all the other top rate steaks in the city.  Otherwise, it was worth visiting once,but not again.
author: Brad H.

description: My first visit to John's Grill was in 1997.  I get to San Francisco on business a couple of times a year.  I go to John's Grill every time.  The service and food have been consistently excellent for 18 years, which you would expect given that is has been open since 1908.  I almost never have dessert and almost never order cheesecake because my daughter makes the best cheesecake and I am usually disappointed.  But on my last visit, I took a chance and ordered the cheesecake.  It was fantastic.  As good as my daughter's?  I dare not say.  Looking forward to my next trip.
author: Kevin K.

description:
For the amount of people we had on a Saturday night I thought it was a bit crowded, crunched in. We had to be on the bottom floor because we had a couple of elders. 
 I ordered the rib-eye stk. one of the best I've ever had, tender and delicious. My girl had the halibut and was just as good.
author: Greg S.

description:
I made a reservation here about a week prior and I don't normally do this because I find more value when someone else does this. But in the reservation I mentioned that I would be dining at this restaurant because it will be my birthday. 

I picked this restaurant because I wanted steak for my birthday and it was near the location of a bar I wanted to tryout. When my boyfriend I got there we were rushed into the restaurant and told to go upstairs. We weren't asked if we had a reservation and when our server came to us you could tell he was not in a good mood and wanted us to eat and get out as quickly as possible. I watched three people around me get sung happy birthday as a little piece of cake with a lit candle was being placed in front of them. I was already embarrassed enough about writing in my reservation that it was my birthday i wasn't going to ask for a cake let alone disappoint my server even more by asking more from him. The way I felt while I was in the restaurant was that I wanted to get out as quickly as I could because these people did not want me here. 

The food was mediocre. You can get that kind of steak with a baked potatoe almost anywhere. 

Overall, you can tell that if you walked in with a nice suit on and smelling like cold hard cash they are going to treat you with the best fine dining in the city.
author: Lisa Y.

description: Worst experience ever. Horrible service and food tastes like s$*#. I visited this place with my girlfriend and we ended up waiting about 30 mins for our steak. Once it was out, they had to redo it because it wasn't medium rare. They actually made it well done instead. When the second one came out, there was a hair the our plate. Disgusting. Stay away from this place.
author: Elmer M.

description: I went to SF for the annual car show with a good friend of mine and I found this place on yelp. We decided to check it out. I was surprised that it wasn't too busy for a Saturday night expecially after the holidays. We walked in and we were seated in minutes, our waiter was great and always made sure everything was ok. Our drinks and appetizers came out in 15 minutes and our entrées came shortly after.  The escargot was amazing (first time trying them). The butter garlic sauce was delicious. The ribeye steak was perfect. Everything was absolutely delicious. The only thing that I felt needed improvement was the Old Fashioned. I felt it was more like a Shirley Temple with a kick. It should be more like a "Don Draper" Old Fashioned. I highly recommend this place, it is a bit pricey but the food is phenomenal and I can't wait to go back.
author: Nathan T.

description: I have been going to John's for years and love the atmosphere and history. Service is usually good. But on Saturday I was so disappointed in the food I don't think we will be going back. Had a bowl of the clam chowder - it had a nice taste and consistency but was pretty much void of clams. For my main meal I had the steamed clams - well it had a ton of shells, but I would say no more than 15 clams - a complete rip off. It is too bad as it was one of my favorite places near Union Square.
author: S. C.

description: Over rated, even thought it's an famous steak house but the quality didn't add up. And the waiter bring the check back for adding "gratuity" because we have an 3 years old kid + 4 adults. My boy didn't even eat at all.. Expensive and food quality just okay.
author: rita c.

description:
It could be worth the price.

The seafood was perfect. The steak as ordered. And the service excellent.

And it is a historical place with the Maltese Falcon.

On Saturday night there was live music.

So, what's not to like?

The second floor dining room had un finished drywall patches on it. Just a few,  But, still.

The vegetables came out cold.

The live music had a sax player with a mic stuck in the bell of his horn. I could hear the people talking at the tables on either side of me, but not my date unless we were shouting. Well, when the sax wasn't playing we could talk.

The tables are a bit narrow, so you wind up sitting closer to the people at the tables next to you than your dinning partner.
author: Micheas H.

description:
