The fish was great, but the sauce could have been better. The veggies and potato on the side were obviously not made with extreme care, but that is almost to be expected nowadays. 
Very pricy but worth it. I would highly suggest the clams appetizer and dipping you're bread in the juices! Fantastic!
author: Laura D.

description: My family & I went last night. Disappointed with the "jazz" music. There was one man with a keyboard. You could barely hear him with the loud  crowd in the room. The service was great though. I ordered the Seafood Cannoli that was stuffed with mush instead of distinctive ingredients mentioned on the menu. Expensive dinner, unfortunately I walked away wondering what I ate & no real jazz.
author: Melina W.

description: Overall a good experience. I ordered the Ribeye medium and it was cooked to perfection -melt in your mouth delicious. Good quality meat.  My wife ordered the chicken Jerusalem and said it was just okay. the ambiance was a little pedestrian or hum drum. Was hoping for something a little more special. The food came quickly service was attentive but aimed at moving things along. But the steak was good so if you don't care about ambiance go for it.
author: Rika C.

description:
We visited John's Grill last October on a trip to San Francisco.  It was recommended to us by the concierge at the Prescott Hotel.  What a great recommendation!  

We had a late lunch/early dinner there and it was one of my favorite meals in the beautiful city.  We started with the very hearty Dungeness Crab Cocktail followed by the Broiled Deluxe Burger and the Fried Sea Scallops with vegetables.  We enjoyed every last bite.  

The Dungeness Crab Cocktail was fresh and extremely tasty.  We were almost full after the appetizer and delicious bread until we saw our entrees. The Broiled Deluxe Burger was exactly what it said it was -- Deluxe!  The lightly seasoned fries caused me to have plate envy, but the scallops were satisfying all the same.  

The atmosphere and service was top notch as well.  It was in between lunch and dinner, so the upstairs dining area was empty when I went up there to use the ladies room.  With it being so quiet up there and the decor still remaining from the 1930's period, I could feel the history that has come through this place.  It stopped me in my tracks and put a smile on my face.  I highly recommend visiting John's Grill when you are near the Union Square area.
author: Leslie P.

description: Great Place !! Food and Atmosphere .. Maybe one of the better steaks I have ever had !  Service is good .. Slow , because the place is so busy at dinner time .. Bartender said he had been there 30 years .. Great place !
author: Greg F.

description: Once you fight your way past the ever present stench of urine from the street, this is a seriously nice restaurant.  If you have to visit this city, might as well have a nice dinner.  I had the grilled snapper.  Yummm
author: Traveling S.

description: The place has been around since 1908 and the inside feels just that...Not necessarily in a bad way..more of historical feel. I ordered the Fisherman's seafood pasta. I thought is was very tasty and flavorful. Service was pretty speedy and attentive. I would say the prices are a little higher than you would expect (perhaps because of the area its in).
author: John D.

description:
I have been here back in Dec. 2912 for lunch and was VERY satisfied with the steak sandwich it was very filling. I came back tonight and went for the surf and turf. Well lets tell you if you are looking for a nice steak to go with you shrimp. Pass this one up. It is a 4oz steak. The cups that they put on the plate for the cocktail sauce and the sour cream are bigger then the steak was. I was a joke. Now mind you if you a VERY light eater and are looking for a snake this is the plate for you. 
I will be sure to not order it again.
author: Darin L.

description: Hair in food! Service was the worst I experienced while vacationing in San Fran.  From the time our table was sat, our waitress was dismissive and curt. We felt as if we were inconveniencing her. Then, when the my main course arrived with a hair in it, she accommodated us by crediting us for my drink-as if it was a huge gesture on her part-not quite an appropriate accommodation for a ruined dinner.  I give 2 stars because shrimp cocktail was good!
author: S. B.

description: My husband and I take out of town relatives and family here. Love the ambience and the food is good.  The prices are a bit high for what you get but let's face it, it's San Francisco !!! It a nice place for a good dinner!!
author: Cathy K.

description: Nice ambiance and good service! Unfortunately, I took one bite out of a high priced steak that was dry, and had no flavor other that brunt! The waiter noticed I hadn't ate the steak and asked me was it ok, I told him no, that it was dry brunt and had no flavor!! He said that's because I wanted it "well done". We were still charged for the steak but got a complementary small desert that was very good!. Seemed like the waiter got a little bit of an attitude after I expressed my dislike for the steak. Only highlight was a good baked potato and the desert! Kinda hard to mess up a baked potato though! This is high priced Denny's \ Applebees food!! Go to Ruth Chris if you want a great steak!!
author: Tyrone L.

description:
I had read reviews of this restaurant and was looking for a nice restaurant to have dinner with my husband.  The reviews were good and it was close to our hotel.  

The service was wonderful.  Our waitress was very attentive and friendly.  The mandatory San Francisco sourdough bread was brought to our table warm and crispy soon after we sat down.  

I ordered the New York strip medium rare and my husband ordered the rib eye medium rare.  The couple at the table next to us (the tables are very close together) and made comments about the meat not being cooked as requested, and they were so right.  The ribeye arrived medium.  My New York was well done.  I asked the waitress for another steak; she was very apologetic and took away the dish.  Shortly after, my steak arrived.  This time it was not just rare, it practically mooed.  Our waitress had waited until I cut the steak to make sure it was okay, and immediately took it back.  The couple next to us started laughing and we all agreed that if the chef in a steak house can't cook steak, that cook needs to be replaced.  Although the steak was over cooked when it returned, I had given up by then and just ate it.

The restaurant was busy but I was very surprised that after returning the steak twice the manager never came over.
author: Francine L.

description:
John's Grill is a good place to go and eat...if you're out of other options. Don't get me wrong :it's nothing bad here...but, also, nothing to stand out from the crowd.
I came here with a friend of mine. The atmosphere is okay ( I don't mind spending time in a place which is a bit crowded). The service is nice but they could do something in order to speed up things (hire some more waiters...maybe). 
I had lamb chops and baked potatoes. The first impression that I had was that I am eating a fresh meal (and that's a plus). But, it wasn't anything ' glamorous' about it. My friend was satisfied with his Seafood Cannelloni. He said that he liked the fact that his meal was stuffed with cream and cheese.
So, I guess that everything is okay here...but nothing that will amaze you in any way.
author: Sandra S.

description: We just stopped here to have a drink at the bar. My Sierra Nevada was served in a 12oz glass and wasn't as cold as it should have been.
author: Bumble B.

description: Very nice lunch, casual yet authentic. Love the waiters who seem to really be part of this place.
author: Claire P.

description: I brought a party of 9 here tonight and we were seated on the third floor - be aware there is no air conditioning on the third floor so it was hot. If you have children, know that there is no kids menu and only one option of pasta. Finally, the wait was an hour for our meal. This place is not family friendly.
author: Fist F.

description: A local favorite of celebrities and locals alike, John's is just a handful of the original places in the city that has stood the test of decades of time with wave after wave of restaurants that come and go.The location is not in a favorite area of the city and the menu is a bit limited, albeit good.
author: Michael G.

description:
The atmosphere was nice and the service was fine.

Our party of 3 had no one truly satisfied with our meal.  My boyfriend ordered surf n turf, with the tiniest steak I've ever seen and 3 prawns.  My smothered red snapper was missing ingredients listed in its description, and our friend ordered grilled red snapper with no grill marks on it, and didn't feel well after eating his meal.
author: Jen G.

description:
Wow.  What a pleasant surprise.  I yelped Seafood from the Parc 55 and came up with John's Grill; known for steaks and lamb.    Great food, history, and the most amazing food-to-table time I've ever seen.   We had escargot, which were extremely good ... And out as quickly as I had ordered them.  My cocktail (sidecar; very good) barely had a sip before dinner arrived.   I mentioned, seafood, which three of us had.  The added benefit was a succulent steak for the fourth.   The salmon was wonderful.  The Shrimp Dijonaise was very good.  Though I ordered the Chef's special of crab and shrimp atop a Red Snapper and explained the celiac and gluten free thing, and assured I was good ... It arrived with a coating of flour and pan seared.  But ... The server delivering the food immediately took note of my concern and corrected the issue without missing a beat.  
Within minutes, I was also involved with a delicious Shrimp Dijonaise.

Foregoing all the great culinary aspects, it is worth a visit just to experience the history and the Maltese Falcon connection.   Great dining experience.
author: Jeff R.

description:
Went here with a dear friend who had many great memories of the food, company and atmosphere.. I was not disappointed at all. My friend had the lamb chops and I enjoyed a porterhouse.  Both were cooked to perfection.  My waitress, Christine, was awesome...not intrusive, but attentive at the same time.

I'm hoping to get back here the next time I go to the "City".
author: Dwight C.

description:
We enjoyed lunch there early this week and had a wonderful experience. My husband ordered the Petrale Sole and it was excellent. It was served with a butter lemon sauce and toasted almonds. I ordered the Seafood  Cannelloni  and it was also excellent.
 We had lunch here earlier in the year and enjoyed it then also. It is rather expensive, but then everything in the area of Union square is pricey. Decor and ambiance is wonderful!
author: Linda J.

description: Went here a few times when I was younger, but not for a while before I ate here two weeks ago with some friends and we all had a great experience. Had great cocktails, then I had the chicken Caesar salad and then had a filet mignon with sautéed onions. The salad was really good, and the steak was cooked to perfection. It is a pretty classy place, and you'll see some San Francisco politicians here from time to time, so dress nice. Go here for an occasion and it'll be a good time.
author: Aidan O.

description:
The average 3-star rating for this place baffles me. 

I've visited here several times over the last few months, for lunch and dinner and the conclusion is simple: I AM A FAN.

I'm sure there are plenty of steak houses that are fancier, more expensive than this place but can any of them also claim the deliciously, scrumptious, protein-packed Jack LaLane salad? I think not!

Go for the salad alone, stay for the fab clam chowder. 

The seafood and steak platters are delicious (KITCHEN NOTE: Please don't overbake your potatoes) and if you want a side dish that will blow your mind and have you licking your chops...it's gotta be the Sauteed Mushrooms!!!!!

A staple of San Fran, this place has withstood the test of time...old cherry wood furnishings, the bathroom with the hexagon tiles, its like something out of a 1940's movie...oh wait...

Take a chance and check it out!  

You'll love the ambiance, the stiff Manhattans, the Maltese Falcon souvenir glasses, and did I mention the Sauteed Mushrooms?!?!
author: Yahra V.

description: First time here, cute restaurant with dining both up and downstairs. We were seated upstairs, our waitress wasn't too friendly. The tables are a bit too close to each other. We had a snobby couple sitting right next to us who kept staring, which was really rude. Anyways, we had steaks with all different cuts. It was so juicy so good. There was also a live pianist, which was awesome. Will come back again if in the area.
author: Elizabeth H.

description:
This is one of those places where it's like, ok you better have a nice job to pay for this or else you'll be skipping your next few meals. 25 dollars for my salmon linguini? Oh my poor wallet. I went into this meal thinking "this better be the best thing i've ever eaten in my life."

And it actually was pretty good. The salmon was actually some of the best I've ever had, and I normally hate seafood. Salmon basically melted in my mouth. Don't know if it was worth that much money, but it was still really good. My friends that ordered the steaks didn't have any complaints, other than it tasted like most other steaks that they've had.

The service was actually pretty excellent. We were a group of young kids, and they actually treated us like adults. Also, I normally don't give a damn about how nice the place looks inside (i think pho places look decent), but this place was nice. I felt rich just walking into the place. Kind of felt like taking a little step into history as well. And, the live guitarist didn't hurt at all.

When I graduate and get rich, this is the place I'll be bringing all my dates to. But for now, college student top ramen diet .__.
author: Sean H.

description: Huge disappointment. Service was fine very nice guy. Didn't seem surprised that the steak was abysmal. The seafood cannelloni was dreary. I would have expected cheese with seafood. What was inside was more like breading mixed with some seafood with some shredded cheese on top. It was most unpleasant. It was very expensive for the quality of food and while it may have received positive reviews here I can't say I would ever return. $100 for asparagus they took away, 2 cannellonis that we struggled to consume and a steak that was so gristled and undercooked it was inedible and comped. Nice server but never again.
author: Baron C.

description: I met my friend for our annual Christmas lunch. We had reservations at 1pm. We had a drink at  the bar. In a few minutes our table was ready. The atmosphere was warm and friendly. Soup was good, salad was good, Roy's Oyster Benedict were excellent and my Fried Scallops were superb. The bill for a lunch in San Francisco was modest. In my other life I was a restaurateur for over two decades....I heartily recommend John's Grill.
author: Luciano E.

description: My girlfriend and I had a great experience. We started with clam chowder which we loved. I had the Cannelonis and she had Filet. The staff was very friendly and the food came out super fast. Definitely recommend.
author: Jonathan W.

description:
Located just off Union Square convenient to theaters, shopping, and tourist attractions, historic John's Grill is a favorite of San Franciscans and tourists alike.

The home of Daschiel Hammett's Maltese Falcon, the wood paneled dining room makes patrons feel as if they are the stars of a Bogart flick.  Just order one of John's capacious martinis, and one can almost see the fictional Sam Spade or any of the myriad of real-world personalities that have come before you--from Hillary Clinton, Ronald Reagan, and Al Gore to Joe DiMaggio, Baronesse Phillipine de Rothschild, or Andy Warhol.

Classic rather than innovative, the menu features selections like jumbo prawn cocktail, escargots with garlic cream sauce, and the delicious Jack Lalane's Favorite Salad (for 2) consisting of fresh seasonal greens, dungeness crab, shrimp, avocado, and tomatoes--it was so huge one wonders how Jack could have eaten it all by himself.  (Ord er dressing on the side, as the chef seems to believe that lettuce should be overwhelmingly drenched.)  Continuing the traditional theme, entrées include steaks, seafood, and pastas.  A thick, bone-in New York cut, the John's Steak was cooked rare as ordered, a "rarity" in these days of caution in the kitchen.

The compact wine list is not a trophy tome as in many high-end restaurants.  Consisting of selections mainly from California and France, it simply contains the wines that a diner would need to complement John's straightforward food--some good Chardonnays, some great Cabs, and the odd Pinot, all reasonably priced.

Service is friendly and attentive.  Bread arrives, drinks arrive, appetizers are served, drinks get refilled, entrées arrive, drinks get refilled, the check arrives--all like clockwork:  nothing fancy, nothing pretentious, just good, professional, honest service.

No wonder John's Grill has been a San Francisco tradition from before the time of Herb Caen.  John's is an icon--it's not trendy; it doesn't have a world famous chef who has his own TV program; it doesn't have a multi-million dollar marketing budget--it is simply a restaurant that delivers good, classic food at reasonable prices.
author: CJ G.

description: Walked in.... Sat down....waited.... Walked out..... Hot and stuffy in there too .. Way over priced too
author: Heather J.

description: Was excited to go to such a historic San Fran restaurant, but was disappointed. Service was incredibly slow as if they were very short-staffed. Although I asked if there were anchovies in the Caesar salad and was told no, their house-made dressing was so fishy I couldn't eat it. The steamed clams weren't quite right and didn't eat those either. The swordfish and red snapper were great though!
author: Scarlett O.

description:
I love this place, the best clam chowder in San Francisco.... The Best! I tried several dishes along my visits and I have my favourites that will make me back always.
Jack Lalanne's  salad with Dungeness crab is Delicious.
I 've tried the clams and the oysters and I could taste freshness and real good quality seafood, as the same with Calves 'liver and this one is something special that you can not order just in any place (I had this without bacon) I loved it ... again great quality!

Definitely Johns grill has the atmosphere and the food to make a pleasant time. My food always was great and I  highly recommend!!.
author: Carina C.

description: As a NYer I'm accustomed to good food. Johns grill has a reputation as good so I thought I'd try it. I got their signature ribeye steak which was average at best.  This place is a step behind an Outback Steakhouse at double the price. If you love steak, choose a different place. The service though is top notch.
author: Roger R.

description: Had the New York strip, baked potatoes, and veges. The steak was medium well when I ordered rare. Marbling dictates this steak is USDA Choice, a huge step down from the USDA Prime that make up the best tasting steaks. Potatoes is dry and veges overcooked and soggy. For $40 I expected much more. Oh well, I guess that is the price of history. Time to wash this crap down with a nice Merlot. Cheers.
author: Ken P.

description:
We love coming here for a drink at the bar to relax and people-watch before shows or events in the city. The old world, classic vibe, the original Maltese Falcon statue & memorabilia, and the colorful photo library of local & national celebrities make this place well worth the visit.
However, we've been disappointed in recent dinners here where we've had the NY, the Filet, and John's Steak at various times. Steaks were very good, but not great. Did not seem any better than those at steakhouses like Mortons or Ruth Chris. I had to send one steak back because it wasn't cooked the way I ordered it. The baked potato seemed small in comparison to other high-end steakhouses. Service was good but inconsistent and a little scattered. Busboys kept trying to take our plates before we were finished. It is a lively, bustling place during peak hours. The activity didn't disturb our meal but we usually dine right before or after the big rush.
If you like good steak & enjoy a slice of history, you should at least check it out if only for the experience of being in a place so highly praised by so many reputable reviewers and so many famous patrons over the years.
author: HJ B.

description: A definite tourist trap but with the history and San Francisco film noir vibe to back it up. Fun to eat here to pretend you're in the 40s, taking delight at eating what they probably ate in the 40s.  Food isn't exactly inspired but it's definitely classical, like you're eating what Humphrey bogart would have eaten if he went out to dinner. Steaks were cooked well. Fish wasn't as good and soaked in butter. Dining room was very cramped and crowded.
author: Mike L.

description: John himself reached out to our family when there was a mishap with a waitress. He comped the meal and took the time to personally call. Great management!
author: Paige S.

description:
Right when you walk in you can sense the old charm of the place. Great little bar and seating set-up. 

The food was fantastic.  I had the Clam Chowder and Jack LaLanne's Salad (at the hostess's recommendation). Great, great food. The Old Fashioned that I ordered from the bar was pretty good - not great - but pretty good. 

The one knock I have was the service. On a late Tuesday night, my party of two sat for approximately 20 mins before the waiter came over for drink orders. The waiter was quite curt and inattentive. I'm all for giving someone the benefit of the doubt, so  maybe he had a bad day.  

Would I go back? Definitely.
author: Jonathan K.

description:
We decided to stop by for a post-shopping meal here. He pulled whatever restaurant up on his iphone and found John's Grill. Apparently it is famous. I had no idea. But from the looks of the place, the tourists seem to like it. We walked in without reservations and were seating upstairs. Ambiance was nice or what my bf calls "old money". Wood panel walls and hardwood floors. The walls decorated w/ pictures of famous old-time movie stars and the Maltese Falcon in a glass case. Live guitarist played for dinner patrons. 

I ordered the filet and he ordered the lamb chops. The filet was black and rough and hard even though I asked for it to be medium rare. Yikes. BF says I'm used to steak drenched in butter. He knows me too well. The lamb was better. The entrees came with a baked potatoes and veggies which rounded out the entrée. But my filet kind of sucked so I ate up the potatoes and veggies instead.
author: Katie Anne N.

description: One of the oldest standing buildings in San Francisco. The Maltese Falcon resides here and the food is awesome. The fishermans pasta is mouthwateringly delicious. They have great clam chowder for lunch and a full bar. The service is great and it is an overall awesome place.
author: Arky P.

description: This place is fantastic!  Great food, and probably the best clam chowder I've ever had.  It's a tight fit inside and can get a bit warm, but the restaurant has a lot of history and old charm.  Four of us went in for dinner and service was top notch and the food was great.  Definitely worth checking out for the chowder and a great steak!
author: Jordan S.

description: Not worth it! The service was good but the food was not unique. My T-bone steak didn't have flavor so it was nothing special. Save your money and go somewhere else
author: Marlene E.

description:
Friend and I went for dinner based on recommendation from our hotel.  Does have a cool interior and history.

Service was very good. Once we ordered, our meals came in less than 10 minutes!  The steaks were right on target, and the baked potatoes were good.  The snap peas we crisp and right on. The carrot was tired and tasteless, though.

Pretty good meal, but at the prices they charge, it should have been outstanding. So not a great value for money.
author: Adrian M.

description:
John's Grill! I have walked past this place many times on my way for a drink at Lefty O'Douls and never stopped in. My wife and I were going to the Symphony for our anniversary and was looking for a place we had not been to for dinner. Searching for a place in Union Square John's came up. I was intrigued to find it operating since 1908 and it's tie with Dashiel Hammett and "The Maltese Falcon." 

On my online reservation I mentioned that we were celebrating our wedding anniversary and after we were seated at a nice table we were brought a complementary glass of champagne and our waiter was perfect he gave us plenty of time to enjoy our drinks before taking our order.

Rib-eye steak cooled to perfection. (It's difficult to find a place with enough guts to cook my steak as rare as I want it."  and my wife and the salmon, nice and crusty outside moist and tasty inside. Veggies cooked nicely. still with bit of a snap but not soggy. No frills food meat, seafood, veggies and potatoes.   we also has a shrimp cocktail fresh big shrimp. The waiter warned us about the horseradish that came with the shrimp. Atomic horseradish. Hottest I have ever had.  Just a touch with the cocktail sauce was perfect. 

The meal was topped off with a complimentary house made flan with caramel sauce as part of our anniversary celebration.

We were treated like royalty! It was a great start to a special evening! Rarely does one find a restaurant that will go out of it's way like the folks at John's Grill did.

If you are looking for an old San Francisco experience. Go to John's Grill
author: Michael S.

description:
I have been eating at this resturant since I was 10 years old(1953),

I eat there at least once per month and take out of town clients/family there.

There were four of us for lunch today.

First, I ordered Escargot as an appetizer, the others in our party ordered other items.
The waitress came back and stated that the kitchen was out of garlic and could only make it without garlic.  Now, as a native San Franciscan, I have never went to a resturant that was out of garlic!  I cannot believe what I was told. So, as an alternative, I ordered the crab cocktail as what another in our party had ordered.  The special stainless steel dish that the crab came in is a two piece design with a scooped area to hold guess what, ICE.  Now do you think there was ice in there?  Negative.  When I asked the waitress about the ice she looked at me quizically and stated they never serve crab with ice.

The rest of the meal was fine, except that I'll have to re-think spending $189.00 for lunch there again if they do not have garlic and ice!

I feel sad to have to write this, but maybe this should be a wake call.  The management  should call one of the TV resturant shows for help and guidence on how to run a resturant!
author: John P.

description: Great time here with friends from work. We had dinner in the 3rd floor. I had the sea bass with Voss Sauvignon Blanc. Excellent!
author: BenHur C.

description: This place was fantastic. The ribeye was very flavorful... The service was really fast and the vegetables were really good as well.
author: Trevor N.

description: The menu is interesting. I wish I had selected something else besides the seafood cannelloni because it didn't taste like seafood. The steamed clam appetizer was okay. I like the interior and the location. It has a classic American old school style.
author: Denise C.

description: Definitely did not live up to the hype. The soup was all cream and not much substance. My steak was absolutely awful. I liked that it was thin. But it had no flavor at all. We won't return.
author: Dee M.

description:
Decent meal but they killed it by not being able to make a coffee nudge!  Seriously, neither the bartender or the waiter knew how to make one or what went in it.  If you have to ask me what goes into the cocktail I order I'm going to change my order.

I had the seafood canelloni.  It was good but their canelloni were wrapped in crepes, not pasta.  That seemed weird to me.  

Our server was attentive but not overbearing and the atmosphere was very old school in a nice way.
author: Gina K.

description:
A great T-Bone.  Will come again.  Best steak in a long time.
Yum
author: John F.

description:
The menu was so limited! I remember checking it online before booking a reservation and for some weird reason I thought there was much more dishes to choose from but I was wrong. The hostess sat us at the two seater booths and those chairs were not comfortable what so ever. 

The food was ok. We ordered the crab ravioli and 1/2 dozen oysters. The crab ravioli had so much cheese on it, which I love, BUT it was missing the crab taste. I could visibly see the crab in the ravioli but the sauce and cheese most likely overpowered the crab flavor, oh well. The 1/2 dozen oysters were tasty and non-ocean water tasting. Bits of shell were left over from shucking and the oysters weren't detached from the shell, which made it less enjoyable.
author: Christina V.

description: Classic restaurant, very charming and good waiter. Decent wine list. Food was decent too but not fancy at all.
author: Lorraine G.

description:
I'm somewhat biased about the atmosphere of John's because I like places with an old school/skool feel.  My girlfriend and I were seated on the second level, and since the tables for two upstairs are right next to each other, who your neighbors are really matters.  While the couple to our left were perfectly fine, the couple on our right were having a way too loud business meeting.  On a Sunday night?!?  Anyway, my loud neighbors really brought the evening down.

I liked the food (I had the John's steak) and for my one and only, she really enjoyed the mussels and liked her steak as well.  The piano player we had was very good.

The baked potato was fine but it was odd that it only came out with sour cream, no chives, and for butter, I had to take a foil pack pad of butter out of the bread basket.  Do I mind doing these things?  No.  But when I go out to dinner, I'd rather not feel like the scrounger at Stalag 17 trying to put a proper potato together.

Overall, I enjoyed my experience and I would go back.  But I'd probably take my girlfriend's advice and get a seat downstairs rather than in the upstairs section.
author: Fred M.

description:
Visited John's Grill for lunch on last day of vacation before checkout as it was close to the hotel. The reviews where very varied so we thought we would try it for ourselves.

We both had steak, my girlfriend had the rib eye and I had the pepper steak. Both were reasonably priced, cooked as we asked and very tasty.
author: Dave A.

description:
Loved this restaurant. Fabulous menu, large portions, food excellent. Great atmosphere, reservations highly recommended. A true San Francisco classic.  Great area, near Union Square. Well worth a visit.  Will definitely return.
Just a tiny note, if you will  I mention this with some trepidation,  the wait staff a little too anxious to clean table area. Would be much more pleasant if allowed to sit & enjoy a tad longer.
author: Imelda M.

description:
2.5 stars... not quite three. $38 for a mediocre steak? I'll take my money to Flemings, thanks.

This place wasn't BAD, but there was nothing special about it. I don't understand how it's survived since 1908.. Maybe being in such a tourist-trap area has its perks, or maybe the standards of cuisine in SF just weren't as high for most of the 20th century.

Our mussels in garlic butter broth appetizer was good, and generous in portion. My friend had some seafood salad which was very generous in the amount of seafood in it, as well. Our other friend got the lamb, which he liked. I tried a bite and it was okay, but it just did not have the flavor of lamb chops from better restaurants that I've been to. 

I ordered the porterhouse, medium rare. The meat was flavorless for some place that's supposed to specialize in steaks. Even after adding their peppercorn sauce, all I could taste is the char and no meat flavor. The meat was also very overdone -- most of my New York felt very tough and very dry. To top it all off, it was a SMALL porterhouse.

Meh... If the steak cost as much as one from Sizzlers or something, I would think about coming back here. For this price, though, I'm sure the only people coming here are the tourists in the Union Square vicinity.
author: Kazu O.

description:
I must have walked by this place a thousand times, and always assumed it was either a tourist trap or a hole in the wall.  Boy was I wrong.

My boyfriend and I went to John's Grille last night, and I couldn't be happier with the service and the food.  I have lived in San Francisco for the past 11 years, my boyfriend is a Bay Area local, and I have to say that I think it was one of the best meals that I have had in San Francisco since living here. Bravo!

We started out with the Shrimp Cocktail and the Caesar Salad.  Yum and Yum.  They were both incredibly fresh... the shrimp melted in my mouth.  We could have left there and then and been happy with our happy bellies.

BUT, we both ordered the Filet Mignon.  Yummers!  My boyfriends' steak was disproportionately smaller than mine, and he sent it back and got a normal sized one.  Once it came, we dug in and we both loved the way that the steak melted in our mouths.  Amazing!

We finished off the night with the cheesecake, and we were sent home with happy bellies.  There was not a drop left on our plates.  We had some yummy drinks thoughout the night including the John's special drink (which was ok) as well as champagne, wine, and kaluha (sp?) and cream.

Our waitress was amazing.  She was very friendly and was happy to answer any questions.  It was a throwback to the days where it felt like a night on the town was a night with amazing food and quality service.

In a city with amazing food, I felt like we hit a historic gem.  I feel like every time I head out for a special (as in expecting good food for a good buck) meal, it is some fusion meal with a twist.  This was just good ol' cooking of great food with amazing service.

Bravo John's!  You made this San Franciscan one happy camper.  I will be telling people to come that this is a great place to go for some good food. Thank you!!
author: Carley A.

description:
TOURISTA CLIP JOINT
  
As an SF native, I had never dined here, but last night, as a lark, we decided to try it.  The gentlemen at the door were great and got us seated right away, sans reservations.  Once seated everything went down hill... fast.  They were busy so it took a while for the drink order to be taken.   It took even longer for our dinner order to be taken...  once dinner arrived one of our entrees was completely wrong...  how can one hear Cioppino and write down cannelloni???

The only reason for the two stars is due to the n.e. clam chowder...  that was awesome...  everything else?  Eh... the $33 cioppino was a joke... two prawns, 4 mussels, a clam and a scallop!?!?  WTF!   The broth was pink and tastless... a total failure.  

I went simple with the clam chowder and a roquefort salad -  soup was awesome and the salad was passable.  

The Jerusalem chicken was a pile of gray gunge but my bbf was able to choke it down.

All in all, avoid if you can... not worth the price on any planet!
author: Raquel M.

description: The only thing from my meal worth a star was the clam chowder. NEVER order a steak here. SEAFOOD ONLY
author: Lee S.

description: The best clam chowder I've had anywhere (even Boston)!  Our bartender, Cydna, was really great.  She made great recommendations!  We will definitely be back if ever in San Fran again!
author: Mayra B.

description:
Pretty decent food and within walking distance of Union Square.  The portions of food were outstanding, and the food was certainly great.  There was a jazz band playing upstairs, and it was great.

I would say the only reason I didn't give this place 5 stars is the location I was seated...right by the stairs and the kitchen!  The steady flow of people streaming in and out was so annoying.  I would suggest reservations and sitting upstairs to avoid this.  

And if you are a manager there or one of the owner's, might I suggest NOT using the base of the stairs to seat anyone.  It's simply not a good place to sit.

:)
author: Ola P.

description:
The food is nice, well done and I was happy to have big portions especially for salads and sides. 

The steaks are well cooked but the meat I was expecting to be a little bit better, tender, etc.

However, the pasta and seafood were nice, they definitely select good ingredients and charge not to much for those. 

The service is average, I wouldn't say the waiter was taking care of us a lot....

Very crowded sometimes and I think the tables are too close to each other.

Overall, worth coming for good big Saturday lunch...
author: Oleg K.

description: First time there for us and we enjoyed pretty much everything from the atmosphere and the food.  The food was good and priced very reasonable for a steak place.  Would go again.
author: Dave M.

description:
My boyfriend and I stumbled upon this place while out shopping and sightseeing. Starved, we hopped into the first place that promised a place to sit down and rest our feet. We were pleasantly surprised by the bustling lunch spot that seemed to be filled with businessmen and lunching ladies. 

We ordered the normal lunch fare; I had the spinach salad and my boyfriend had the club sandwich. We were in The City during surprisingly good weather and I wanted something light. I was pleased with one of the tastiest salads I have ever had! The Club was so-so but the fries were pretty dang tasty! 

I'd say if you find yourself in the area, stop in and grab a drink!
author: Maura H.

description: I wasn't too impressed especially for the prices (but it is downtown frisco). Ribeye was kind of bland, thin and kind of burnt although I ordered medium well. Baked potato was dry and not many topping. Service staff not really attentive. Seating is awkward and uncomfortable. It's smoky in there - and I prefer to not taste smoke while I'm eating.
author: Nieshelle J.

description:
No happy hour and no one seemed happy at all.

Sat at the bar, under the dirty bird, and had a beer. Listened to other tourists talk about their day.

Asked for the bill -- twice -- and it came 10-minutes later. C'mon, Jose.

Hmmm, $6 for a draft beer.  Nope, can't justify that.  I'll move along.  Glad I didn't eat there.

I wouldn't recommend the bar at all.
author: Dan D.

description: Long wait even with a reservation however the filet mignon was well worth the wait. Reasonably priced! Would go again!
author: Zachary D.

description:
Don't just walk. RUN!! This place is GREAT! Have been here with my wife! we walk in because we were hungry!  have absolutely NO complaints! The burger is AWESOME, the fried chicken salad is equally AWESOME!  Super tasty! Decor is and ambiance are on point! 

Anyways, just go! NOW! My profile photo was taken at this amazing old place!
author: M A.

description: This was my first visit to John's and I was pleased with the entire experience (service, food, price).  I will make this a regular spot whenever I'm in SF.
author: Frankie G.

description:
This is a very average old school place. It reminded me of a smaller, older dirtier "Palm" Restaurant. Primarily a steak and seafood house. We ate upstairs and were greeted by a filthy bus table right at the holding area before being seated.

Not wanting to waste much time on this review, I'll tell you that I  started with the Dungeness crab cocktail weighing in at $17.95. It was not very good at all. It was not fresh by any means and had no taste other than the lemon I squeezed until death on the lifeless and most likely previously frozen crab meat.  John Bob says, pass on this if you go here. I ordered the rib-eye. It was a very thin steak, surprisingly so. It was the size of a Denny's steak you might get with scrambled eggs sitting in a booth with hobos at 2AM.  However, it did have an awesome taste. 

Overall at this point I'm thinking, "I'm pissed I chose this place on my last night with so many great restaurants in town and I'm pissed I spent this kind of money for what I received." To top it off, I woke up the next morning burping steak and shitting steaming crab cocktails out of my ass...
author: John R.

description:
Beautiful historical restaurant. The quite live jazz music was romantic.

The place was cozy, romantic and the staff was extremely friendly. 

Bread came out cold, but the waiter was nice enough to throw it in the oven to toast it for us.

Oysters that were somewhat local were delishious!

Drinks were basic but good. 

Fillet mingnon, cooked to perfection. Calf liver requested to be cooked medium rare, came out medium done. Still very tasty though. both plates had a sorry over cooked pile of veggies.
author: Suzy N.

description:
We were looking for a nice place to top off our day of spending so we waltzed into John's Grill for some steak and seafood, not to mention a shelter from the rain. I had the oysters wellington. While it did not not turn out to be what I thought it'd be, it was good nonetheless, but the oysters were quite chewy. The porterhouse steak was very nicely grilled. The meat was so tender, it was like butter in my mouth. As far as steak goes, this is steak cooked the way you order it.

Errr... the waiter spilled water on us!
author: Jennifer W.

description:
excellent restaurant in downtown. steaks were very good. good service. 
Easy to park there. it's convenient in location to Union Square. I love clam chowder and  salad so good.
author: Suthida T.

description:
John's Grill deserves its 3-star rating; not more. The food is solid but nothing to shout about, wait staff are pleasant enough and I do love the decor. John's reminds me of my favorite steak haunts in New York save for my favorite haunts don't sprinkle parsley flakes all over the plate.  What's up with that?  Do they believe it takes the plating score up?

If it picked up the food a wee bit, it might, might have the thinnest chance of being a destination for guys like me.
author: Jay D.

description:
I am a big fan of John's grill. 

The service was always excellent! 

I hit it often for lunch when I lived and worked in SF in the mid to late 1990's. 

Loved the Prime Rib special with garlic mashed potatoes and steamed broccoli!
author: John G.

description:
Mediocre everything. You can easily have a better steak by buying one from your grocery store and grilling it yourself. Got the asparagus side and they looked like frozen vegetables that someone microwaved. 

The service was fine, and a couple of the drinks were strong, but there's really no reason to come here if you know how to cook, especially considering how many other much better steak places there are out there.
author: Tom I.

description:
(from 12/17/11) Came to John's Grill on the spur of the moment with my friend for his birthday. We were seated right away upstairs, which was excellent as we were both hungry and I hate the idea of anyone having to wait for food on their birthday.

Started off with a Grey Goose martini, which was potent and good. Not sure where they get their bread but it's damn good (and I honestly have no business eating gluten). I also had the house salad with tarragon dressing - great mix of veggies and those itty bitty shrimpies. The dressing was delicious.

We both ordered the steak - I like mine cooked to medium. When our food arrived - which was faster than I expected - I was a little nervous that there wasn't any sauce to dip the meat in. No A1? What?? (Tip: they do have two sauces you can order on the side for an extra charge.) But I thought, this place has been here a damn long time, they know what they are doing. And they most definitely do. The steak was tender and moist and flavorful. I didn't miss the sauce and they obviously get very choice cuts of meat. You definitely get what you pay for here.

For those whining about a limited menu, or small portions for the money, get over yourselves: this isn't Applebees or TGI Friday's. This is a San Francisco legend and a truly legendary restaurant doesn't need to pad its menu with deep fried vegetable-of-the-week, nor does it need to cheapen its items by adding more to the plate. As Bruno the bartender at Persia Aub Zam Zam would say, "There's a place down the street you'd like much more, with a jukebox and everything."
author: Corinne L.

description: LOVE, LOVE this place! There's a reason there's always a line to get in, especially for a restaurant that's been around since 1908 (I believe). I don't even try going without a reservation. Manhattan on the rocks, Caesar Salad and Porterhouse are my go to's and the live jazz on the 2nd floor creates an ambiance second to none!  In fact, I don't even try to order Porterhouse anywhere else, because it always fails in comparison! I can't believe other reviewers call this a tourist trap! Honey, I love traveling and have been to many Tourist Traps in my time, this it ain't!!
author: Michael T.

description: I loved this place.  It's famous and has been open since 1908!  I had lunch here with my good friend, Linda the Great.  How great is she?  She's so great, she makes Alexander the Great look like Alexander the Wuss!  Her Greatness had been here before, but it was a first for me.  In fact, I'd never heard of the place!  It didn't matter. We were celebrating!  I recently got divorced and my Ex and I sold our house!  After you sell the house, there's much more closure, and her Greatness and I decided to have champagne!  It was wonderful!  So, I had the grilled salmon with mashed potatoes and vegetables. Delish!  Her Greatness had the Jack LaLanne's Favorite Salad(Is he still alive?) and loved it.  The food was good, the service was fine, and the prices were OK.
author: Blondie R.

description: I love John's Grill!  This is nostalgic old school San Francisco - dark wood, stiff drinks and giant steaks.  The shrimp appetizer consists of the biggest shrimp known to man.  The steaks are wonderful.  The bar is small, cozy and every drink is made to perfection.  It's not cheap - but located in the heart of Union Square what is?  I take friends who come into town here and they've all loved the place.  It's a landmark for many reasons - consistently good food, service and of course, the Maltese Falcon connection.
author: Amy S.

description: We had a great variety between 4 of us a steak was huge and looked delious,I had the stuffed cannoli with crab WOW ****,my husband had the chicken and rice with a rich white sauce***, and finally the 4 th person had prawns they were great ans so many she had to share
author: Kim P.

description: Clam chowder was great as was the house special! Great place for a rest and refuel while shopping.
author: Deanna C.

description: Food was excellent! Drinks were very good. Service was on point. The staff was friendly! The history is very cool. Definitely a place I would recommend to all traveling in the area.
author: Scott R.

description:
Headed here for dinner on the concierges recommendations from the Palace hotel.

Loved the live entertainment, but the food was a tad disappointing.  Cocktails came at the same time as our food...  I ordered salmon which was heavily covered in a sauce and over cooked. Felt rushed...    not a favorite.
author: Pamela S.

description:
Let me make this short and sweet.

-Service is A-OK
-The few times I've been here my PORTERHOUSE was either overcook with char or rare as it gets 
-Steak sauces were odd tasting

Typical for being right near Urban Outfitters.
author: Ema I.

description: Went to Johns Grill for Valentines dinner during our trip to San Francisco. Made reservations days prior (only thing available). Asked around, not many had positive or negative reviews about the restaurant. We didn't wait long, but we were sent up to the 2nd floor, then the 3rd floor, then back to the overly crowded 2nd floor. The tables were SO close together (maybe to accommodate more for the special day?) I couldn't extend my arm a little without judging my neighbor. Service was quick, food didn't take long at all. Kept getting bumped the entire time. Wouldn't go back.
author: Ashley R.

description: I expected more for the high price and reputation.  The black angus steak was underwhelming as was the plain salad. In this city, Id expect more.
author: Rob N.

description:
Looked and smelled like it would be amazing. I was a bit disappointed. 

Service: Host and servers seemed less that accommodating. Waitress misheard my order and then overcharged me. 

Prices: Very high for the quality of the food. 

Food: I had the lamb and my colleague had the filet. Lamb was unevenly cooked and quite bland. Filet was too small for the price. 

Ambiance: Great! Old school oak with, I assume, famous people who have visited. 

Might go again, but would order something else and speak more clearly to the wait staff.
author: Lauren T.

description: Sunday night at rush. Convention in town, with mainly dinner service to them. Two planters punch,  servicible,  no call. Oysters plump, Louisiana ? Cocktail with mild horseradish. Lobster raviolli, ok no distinct lobster bits. Ordered bone in NY strp medium rare. Served no bone NY strip. Given kalua on rocks as comp. Served medium rare 3/4 inch cooked as requested,  flame broiled.  Choice suspected previous frozen. Side vegetables brocolli raab, steamed, no sauce,  baked potato.  Vanilla ice creame generous portion, high butter fat with side of berries and small cookie. Overall busy, efficient, cost about what you would expect for a downtown SF restaurant with reputation.
author: Vincent S.

description:
I was planning to eat at Tad's around the corner, but I decided tonight I wanted to pay more money (twice as much as it turned out) and get a better quality steak.  I also wanted something thicker than the thin steaks at Tad's.

So I went to John's (first time).  I paid twice as much.  I got pretty much the same meal as Tad's.  The ribeye was *slightly* more tender for about 75% of it, the rest was a tough patch, but it was thin and otherwise just like Tad's.  The baked potato was overdone with a hard crust (cutting the potato was more difficult than cutting the steak!)  The vegetables were not as soft as I prefer but I'm not complaining; I realize most people like them crispy.

The steak came 5 minutes after I ordered it so it obviously was not made to order; it was either pre-made and microwaved, or they have them always cooking and ready like Tad's.  It seemed like they just wanted me out so they could turn over the table.

Not a bad meal, but for this quality I'll save myself half the money and go to Tad's and be done with it.
author: Dean S.

description: Best steakhouse ever will come here again really recommend it :) good customer service.  Waiter recommended a good beer. And most importantly my girlfriend enjoyed her dinner. Good atmosphere & relaxing music for a dinner date..
author: Angel O.

description:
To folks that say "the food is not up to date".... ((cclearing my throat))  Well, that's the idea... it's one of the oldest restaurants that's survived everything in S.F. and is still at 60-80% capacity.. Their cuisine is turn of the century and great! 

"Never heard of "The Maltese Falcon"... look it up.. then you'll understand what this place is about. 

I've been going here for 15years+, owned my own restaurant... So, step back in time to a day gone by and enjoy the food and atmosphere...
author: Foodie D.

description: So I stumbled on this spot by accident on a Thursday night while looking for a place to eat a decent meal.  Getting a table here was pretty straightforward and I give them kudos for that.  I was sat upstairs where a musician was performing live, which was great by me. My first impression of the spot was the table arrangements - it's tight.  You can't really have a private discussion unless you have a booth.  The menu itself was pretty nice and no-frills.  I had the NY Strip steak (medium rare, which is the only way a steak should be eaten). The steak was delicious and done just right.  The service was really good. The server who dealt with me was patient and attentive.  My dinner guest had a glass of wine she did not like and she was given a new glass of a different wine at no charge.  The place is a bit on the pricey side (~$50/person) but it's worth a try.
author: Kelvin B.

description: It's the nicest historical establishment with great ambiance and professional wait staff. my wife and I have been there multiple times and everytime, we get a professional waiter or waitress and we will, for the most part get staff that will go above and beyond what is expected. the food is great I've never had a single complaint. The place is usually packed which is a good sign that the food is going to be fresh. My steaks are always served to my liking I will definitely return and I recommend this restaurant to anyone who is interested in visiting San Francisco.
author: Steven D.

description:
Came here the past weekend to enjoy a quick seafood meal... Seems like your typical bar/gastropub that serves... seafood. 

After sitting down to enjoy the meal.. at the price, you would expect something much better.. but food is not that good, service is not that great, and teh only thing that sets this place apart is the location and its kind of historic look on the place.
author: James H.

description:
Food and service excellent.  Seafood ciappino was overflowing with perfectly cooked seafood base was sweet no spice.
Ribeye steak was one of the best  I've had.  Seemed pricey.  No small portion options and most meals were $30+
author: Brian K.

description: Had dinner on Sat after x-mas, very very busy. Had a reservation so went right in and got seated.  A little disappointed, was here about 15 years ago and it was great.  Had petrale sole, and it was mushy and not enough sauce.  My husband had filet mignon with bearnaise sauce, they forgot the sauce so had to ask.  When the server brought it to the table it was in a little cup the size you would get tarter sauce lucky if it was a tablespoon for $2.00 extra!   The best part was the gentleman that was playing the Sax and easy listening music.  He did a great job and it added a great ambiance.  Most likely will not be back.
author: Pat W.

description: Fantastic evening, great food, well prepared, great atmosphere. The place is small and very loud, hard to hear someone just one person away but it's a must-have San Francisco experience and the food will not disappoint.
author: Ashton M.

description: Perfect meal the evening of March 30.  My only complaint previously was the excessively loud music playing through the audio system.  This time there was live background music.  The music was pleasant and allowed for conversation! 5 stars now!
author: Robert T.

description: My family has eaten here every time we visit San Francisco. For over 20 years this restaurant has had ambiance, excellent service, and incredible food.  One of the FEW PLACES that makes REAL CAESAR SALAD from scratch!!!!!.. The bread is fresh made and delicious, the Steaks are legendary. Yesterday I was "tourist guide" for my co-workers, They asked me to take them to a good steak place, and they were greatly impressed with he restaurant atmosphere and the food.  They have live music, and that adds a special touch to the meal. I highly recommend this historic place. Don't forget to buy a  John's Grill highball glass to take home.
author: mario a.

description: This is a great place if your downtown and want to hit a low profile sport, and the seafood cioppino is spectacular.
author: Madison G.

description: Excellent food. Great service. Just a fun place to be! The musician was an unexpected treat! Love this place!!!!
author: Megan H.

description: Great place to experience great food at a historical turn of the century landmark of San Francisco. Home of the Maltese falcon, John's grill is great place to go out for an out on the town night, anniversaries, large parties and a place to spend quality time with family and friends. I truly enjoy the atmosphere. The staff is amazingly friendly yet professional. They have true restaurant etiquette. I would recommend john's grill to anyone.
author: Carla D.

description:
A 4 for pleasing me. But I won't go back again unless prompted to by work or school. It's far too expensive to want to try again.

 I ordered the seafood linguini ($32.50). It HIT the spot, dead on. I had just come from shopping and was looking for something hearty and creamy. The linguini is packed with seafood - shrimp, clams (like 8 of them!), fish, crab - and mushrooms. I felt the pasta was done right because there wasn't a bunch of sauce leftover once I was finished. I'll assume that the pasta sauce stuck to the pasta (as it should when made properly). I was shocked by how much seafood they gave you. Usually I expect very little meat in my pasta dishes when I order it at restaurants, but they were generous and I appreciate that. 

It was crowded Sunday night when I went with friends. Also my friend ordered the porterhouse steak. Oh my goodness that thing is huge. It covered the entire plate (part of it was bone yes). It looked like it was a 30 oz. steak (?)! So order that when you're super hungry or if you can eat a lot. I got to steal a taste and yes..it was delicious. They do steak right. Salt, pepper, proper cooking time is all ya need to do steak right. That and good beef of course.
author: Sarah W.

description: Waitress was attentive and food was great.  For a Saturday evening, there wasn't a wait, yet it was packed.  Steak and baked potato was excellent. I recommend this place.
author: Jer M.

description: Great old school steak and seafood place in SF. It's not fancy of stuffy, just great place with awesome food. The location is super convenient by union square, and very easy to find. Cool deal with the home of the Maltese falcon and the history of the joint. If you feel like having great steak and great drinks in a nice a cozy old school environment with no pretentiousness, this is the place for you.
author: Jose F. G.

description:
I am sitting here wishing I hadn't eaten any of that.  Every item on the menu has a cream sauce, so I chose Sea Bass but it ended up also drenched in too much butter.  Veggies didn't taste like much either. French bread didn't represent that San Francisco iconic taste.  "John's Chardonnay" was sugary and "John's Caesar Salad" also was lost in too much dressing.  The baked potato was the safe part.

The decor is classic, so get a drink at the bar and eat elsewhere.
author: Sian G.

description: I know everyone likes this place. and ok it was ok. We came with a large group. The wait staff worked hard to serve us. But its a typical SF place, parking sucks unless your there. Food umm, ask them how they prepare it. And even when they bring it out. Its not going to blow your shoes off. Just saying.
author: Ray R.

description:
I've never been to John's before and probably won't ever go again.  My dining partners steak was cooked adequately but very bland.  Bland would describe everything we ordered.  The drinks were subpar.  A spicy bloody mary that arrived with so little tomato juice, it looked pink.  A watered down margarita.  $35 red snapper entree was fried, breaded and bland.  

On the plus side, even though the waiter didn't ask us how the meal was, when I volunteered that the fish was unedible and the margarita watered down he did take them off of the bill.  

Fabulous history, great charm.  Underwhelming cuisine and service.
author: Scarlett B.

description:
A historic restaurant with good, but expensive food. 

My son and I were playing local tourist yesterday, wandering about San Francisco before going to a performance of the Oakland East Bay Symphony.  We decided for an early dinner on a historic restaurant with a literary connection: John's Grill.  (This restaurant was featured in novels by Dashiell Hammett, such as the Maltese Falcon). 

Even though it was a Friday night, as it was early (around 5:30 pm), we had no trouble getting a table.  At this time only the first of three floors was in use. We were seated in a booth in the back; it was surrounded by photos of Dashiell Hammett and photos of historic San Francisco. 

My son ordered Oysters Wellington.  He inquired if it was indeed an entree and not an appetizer and was assured that it was an entree and of sufficient quantity.  He was a bit disappointed to find that it was only three (but they were plumb) oysters, with each coated with pate and a puff pastry, in addition to string beans.  He felt that for the price of $23 there should have been more.  However, he did feel that the taste was excellent.

I had Seafood Cannelloni ($21).  It was two large cannelloni that were stuffed with a very delicious mixture of seafood and covered with a very nice sauce.  (Also served with string beans). 

We had very good service and an overall good experience.  A bit pricey for the portions, but it was a good before-the-symphony dinner. 

John's Grill is conveniently located near the Powell Street Bart/Muni station, one block up Powell and a half a block east on Ellis.  After dinner, we walked to Bart and in about 20 minutes were in front of the Paramount Theatre in Oakland.
author: Mike M.

description: I was pleasantly surprised by John's Grill. I thought it'd be a super fancy, expensive uptight restaurant, but I did not have such a vibe at all. Very nicely furnished, it had a great bar and an adorable older (in his 50s) barman, who was simply great. Very entertaining and fun. He made some strong drinks, too, which was great. He couldn't really make much of the non-specialty cocktails I asked for, but the ones he could make were good. I guess that's my biggest issue. I did not have any food, but it did smell pretty good. Had some nice interactions with guests, too. Overall, a good place.
author: Slavisa M.

description: Have eaten here a number of times over the years . This visit was not as good as before. The decor is nice old wood steakhouse decor . Service was very good , quick and attentive . Delicious basket of sourdough bread .  My wife had the prawns dijonaisse, she enjoyed them , the prawns tasted fresh. My ribeye steak was just OK, particularly for a steakhouse . The food came out very quickly suggesting much is precooked  . Indeed as we passed the kitchen I saw a pan containing a bunch of precooked steaks!! This restaurant is resting on its laurels and has clearly dropped down a few notches. Overall a good but not great dining experience
author: Roger P.

description: I come here daily for lunch and enjoy it every time. I highly recommend the Jack Lalanne Salad and the Club Sandwich. The staff here is also quick to accommodate large take out orders for my office when requested.
author: Steven M.

description: I get why people could say it's loud but it's fun not loud, high energy potential if you want it to be. Lots of history here and sure maybe it borders on a tourist-y trap but then again I guarantee most of their clients are out-of-towners so what. It is pricey but the food was great. I had the rib-eye and it was cooked to perfection. Good wine list as well. I'd highly recommend. Also there was a jazz guitarist who was playing while I was there for a relaxing atmosphere.
author: Jason S.

description: Disappointing.  Very surprised they would serve grilled fish with gravy.  Steak entree looked better.  Clam chowder was way to thick...clearly not true NE clam chowder
author: Michael H.

description: Definitely a more upscale restaurant with a nice quiet setting. I ordered a NY Strip (medium) and it was just okay, however. I was expecting more given the price of the steak and the elegant appearance of the restaurant. The restaurant is in a very convenient location and is probably worth giving it another shot, however. I also overheard the gentlemen who was sitting next to me mention to the server that the suggested tip % was based on the after tax total. I received my bill and noted the same thing. Be leery of this so you don't wind up paying even more for your dinner (FYI - tip is supposed to be pre-tax).
author: Mike K.

description: Very friendly and fast service.  The food was good.  This is a small restaurant so it can get a bit noisy dying dinner time .  And during the summer it gets very warm in the restaurant.  Overall this is a good place to eat in the financial district.
author: Darren S.

description:
We headed to John's Grill for a friend's birthday party. The best part of our meal was that our waiter was exactly like Lloyd from Entourage. We could not stop laughing at the close resemblance.

The food was good though not super memorable. However, they were good at accommodating our non-stop drink ordering. They were sometimes out of the bottles of wine we wanted to order but this just added to our entertainment...

We enjoyed our nice table upstairs and the fact that nobody seemed to mind our rowdiness. I'm not sure if we'll be back but our dinner was a fun experience before heading over to Slide...
author: Meghan P.

description: Good solid steak and seafood in a very traditional, dark, good ol' boys club atmosphere. Walls are papered with signed celebrity photos dating back to the golden era. Good service. Friendly bartender.
author: Ray D.

description:
I was looking forward to a good steak and night out with some friends havent seen in a while.

We were walking by Johns Grill and decided to give it a shot.  The short version? 

The steaks were not that great, over cooked, tough.  Service was SLOW and bad.  Forgot drinks, didngt bring sides, and its hard to order when you do see the person.  The meal was under seasoned.

I wouldnt go back.  Was completely out of line for pricing on what you get.  There are far far better places in SF.
author: J T.

description:
On Saturday, 12/06/2014, two friends and I went to have dinner at John's Grill hoping for a good dinner experience.  All three of us were disappointed.  Three weeks prior I made reservations for three people for 7 PM.  We arrived a couple minutes early and were not seated until 35 minutes later.  Most of the people waiting in line were experiencing the same issue.  

We finally were sat at our table.  The waiter was pleasant and gave a decent service.  Two of us ordered their signature steak dish.  The steak was very hard to cut, to the point that our table shook every time we attempt to cut a piece off.  The folks dining at the table next to us even made a comment that they noticed the steak appeared difficult to cut.  The flavor of the steak was so and so.  I have had better dining experiences.  This is not a restaurant I would come back to any time soon.
author: Ed E.

description:
I could give a hoot about the Maltese Falcon lore..  Went here for first time and what stood out was the service from waiter Mark.  We had a Jack's salad (named for the late fitness guru LaLanne but which likely had more mayo-based dressing than what he would have done) , a shrimp cocktail, a Maine lobster raviioli, a John's steak and berries with cream for dessert.  There were three of us.

Salad served two and was good, shrimp cocktail excellent with huge shrimp, lobster ravioli was creamy but you could not taste any lobster in it, steak was a nice New York style and fresh berries with cream were great.

Total old school decor, old-timer San Francisco pics. I think dinner and drinks for three of us was about $150.

The meal itself was good but the waiter was outstanding.  We had questions about what part of the cow certain cuts are from; he came back in a little while and showed us on his I-phone pictures of the meat sections from where on the cow.  He was friendly without being a blatant ass-kisser.  It made me wonder why wait staff at most other places is not so good.
author: Michael S.

description:
Yea! For once I was the guest rather than the host at a nice restaurant.
We visited without reservations just after noon and were seated promptly despite a busy lunch hour in a small dining room. Judging by the clientele, most were local professionals who were familiar with the location and staff.
Cocktails were first class and the house chardonnay very respectable.
My red snapper over garden vegetables was better than expected. A recent lunch of petrale sole at Scoma's had pretty cheesy vegetables but John's were crisp, fresh and delicious. Coming from someone who is not into vegetables, this is a serious compliment! My host had the Jack LeLane salad, reasonably priced and it would be on my list for another time.
Our wait staff were quick and friendly, good food and perfect for a business lunch.
author: Bruce H.

description:
John's Grill is comfortably one of the best steak houses in S.F.  Last Saturday was our first and we walked out very impressed.  Our steak was prepared perfectly to order.  The staff was very friendly and made great commendation from the wine list.
We will certainly go back to John's Grill!
author: Matt T.

description: I had a WONDERFUL dinner at this restaurant last few days. I started with Dungeness Crab Cocktail and main course was Filet Mignon. Steak was tender and juicy. It was one of the best steaks I've ever eaten in SF.  Love this restaurant. I'll come back definitely.
author: Kiki S.

description: Overall it was okay, I wish it were better. I really wanted to experience an establishment that has survived 100+ years to have done so for something truly outstanding and I wouldn't have minded paying for it. We were seated right away - nice! We ordered steaks; filet mignon and porterhouse. The filet was good; cooked properly and tasty. The porterhouse was a different story, tough and lacking flavor, not a good cut at all. Yes, its tight inside, that's fine but the waitress was off putting, we didn't feel welcome, like a guest. She didn't seem to be happy being there and it showed, for that reason we won't come back.  The greeter outside, if it weren't for own our determination to go inside, it felt like he wouldn't have tried to persuade otherwise.
author: M L.

description: We had the filet mignon, rib eye, and the salmon. It was wonferful. The breads was the bomb. The wife even bought 2 glasses to remember our eating experience.  Great place. P.S. go early or at 9 pm. There is a line that runs 10-15  people deep. But if i had to I would wait!!!!!!!
author: Mike M.

description: Great food, cool atmosphere. I had the ravioli primavera, and my girlfriend had the clam chowder, both delicious! Service was great. Seating down stairs is a little cramped (so only 4 stars) but i hear up stairs is a lot better. Highly recommended! Next time in back up in the Bay Area visiting, I'm going to make the trek into SF and eat here again!!
author: Juvan B.

description: Steak is amazing. My friend got seafood everything yummy. Good service too. I'll back here again !
author: Pllzz E.

description:
We went as a group of 8. Walked up to the 3rd floor and saw the full history of the shop. 

The staff was running around - I couldn't believe there was a guy that walks the stairs with a platter filled with plates of food. All I could think was, "If this guy falls, there are a lot of dinners that would have to be re-made"...

Our waitress was spot on. Food came out in a timely matter. My steak was medium rare (where I ordered medium), but the others didn't have that problem (3 other steaks). 

Music playing was a little annoying. They should upgrade the system.

A good time and good food.
author: Jeffrey P.

description: This place is incredibly good!! I would most definitely go here again. Had the oysters which was tasty and it is most definitely fresh unlike some restaurants, the fisherman's pasta was delicious, (I would recommend) their portion for dinner is similar to the portion of cheesecake factory pasta so it will fill you up! My boyfriend had the salmon which was a big piece of salmon that came with potato and vegetables, he doesn't really like salmon but he loved his dish.
author: Victoria G.

description: Great service, delicious dinner! We are from Indianapolis and we'll definitely return upon our next visit.
author: Tonya A.

description:
beautiful place 
but the folks here are fxxxng rude.

even when they are caught being rude they so do not apologize 

tourist trap n don't bother
author: patrick d.

description: Full disclosure: I'm not a steak lover, so here I am reviewing essentially a steak place. Also, we went on a Monday night when service might be thin after a long weekend. Nevertheless, it's not what I expected for SF. Nothing terrible mind you, but if you add up all the quirks, I just couldn't give it a reasonable score. Our party was seated right in front of the guitarist which was nice music, but we couldn't chat. So, we asked to be moved. The meal was delivered without knives. Odd one, right? We had to flag down a server, not the easiest task. The costs were high, so we expected better.
author: Oliver V.

description: Place is upscale and we liked the environment. I had the fried oysters and they were delicious. Partner had the clams. Both were very good.
author: Joe V.

description: John's grill is classic San Francisco. Many traditional American's dishes, wonderful service, and great atmosphere. I recommend it to anyone looking for amazing seafood and classic San Francisco style.
author: Tie M.

description: Great steak house located in downtown. Yummy steak with homemade mash potato such a good combination. I would highly recommend.
author: Ploynabhas P.

description: Came for lunch with clients, they had the signature salad which looked awesome and they enjoyed it.  I had the snapper franchese and it was delicious. Also had the clam chowder and it was unique and tasty.  Good food!
author: P H.

description: We had steak and ordered it medium. Came back rare and medium rare. For a hefty price tag for the rib-eye steak that shouldn't have occurred. Be aware of the $20.00 minimum per person rule they have there. Tables are so close together I kept getting bumped into (and I am a small person). Bottom line. In my opinion, not worth the price for what you get.
author: Nadia C.

description: This is a small cozy little place that is located conveniently close to Bart and Union Square first of all. So we get there about 15min before our reservation and were immediately seated, which was awesome. Glad we made a reservation because it was pretty much full on a Sunday evening. Our waitress was pleasant and attentive which made the dinner relaxing and enjoyable. There was piano music in the background.  I had the filet mignon which was great.  My friend had the prawns in a sauce that were delish! I would get them if I came back  which I definitely would if I was out in the area for dinner. Its on the pricey side but worth it for sure.
author: Jessica P.

description: The only reason I'm giving it one star is because the interior looks cool and historic. The food was not so great to begin with; the ravioli was way too saucy.  But then we found a hair in our side of sauteed mushrooms! That completely put me off and I was done. The service was terrible. The staff just seemed to stand around and there was no apology. Would not recommend this place to anyone.
author: Joyti K.

description:
John is the oldest man I've ever loved.

He's a centenarian, born in 1908. 

Cialis, Viagra, forget it! John's always up for the challenge of delivering some of the best cuts of meat I've ever sank my teeth into. 

No no, you've got it all wrong! I'm not after John's money. Rather, I'm after his meat-- steak! One of my greatest vices... a big hunk of red meat cooked medium-rare. And of course, a loaded baked potato with fresh chives. And bread with butter. Classic but nothing missionary about it.

Why must you meet John? Well let's see. Johnny Depp parked his gorgeous arse in one of those chairs (hmm, which one?). And Sophia Loren too. Marlon Brando? Check. The Master of Suspense, Alfred Hitchcock? Yep.  And Al Gore may have even created the internet here! I kid. But he joins the ranks of famous patrons who have spent some time at John's. And for you literary types and history buffs: The Maltese Falcon's revered detective, Sam Spade, dropped by John's for "chops, baked potato and sliced tomato."

Now I must write a 'Dear John' letter and effectively quit him. The best things in life are meant for sharing, and because I only spent one amazing night with John, I've gotta let him go. 

Dress is casual (gotta love the cute ol' blue-haired ladies in their polyester pant-suits) and a big red wine is highly recommended. Enjoy!
author: Jelena Z.

description:
This place feels very old school SF.  Given the location and decor, I had low expectations.  I don't know why we ate here.  By normal standards, my OCD about knowing where I'm eating and what I'm eating there would not have allowed us to eat here... spontaneity in dining often ends in regret.

This was a really pleasant surprise in tourist central.  The best mussels ($16.95) I've had and the filet mignon ($33.95) was decent.
author: Erika C.

description:
This place was alright and for a classic and historical restaurant the food was underwhelming.  I thought the menu could have had a few more options, the beer selection is small, and the appetizers were pricey.  Our entrees were fine, the baked potatoes were actually the best part of our meals, to be honest.  They also gave us complimentary cream & kahlua drinks at the end.

Overall it was decent, but would we go again?  Probably not... there are better places in SF to dine.
author: Amy B.

description:
John's Grill is a great locale for business lunches near Union Square.  The decor is old San Francisco -  dark wood paneling with pictures of local politicians gracing the walls.  Last month, I was seated a table away from a dining Willie Brown.
 
I have lunch at John's Grill 2 to 3 times a month.  The food here is fresh and the recipes  have been time tested.  An added plus is their bar - where the drinks are stiff and inexpensive.  The Crab/Shrimp Louie salad is outstanding as is their Petrale Amandine.   If you want a fast lunch, their club sandwich and burgers are both excellent.  Lastly, if you have the time, visit Dashiell Hammett's  Maltese Falcon on the second  floor.
author: Howard G.

description: Was able to make reservations on short notice through yelp. When we arrived a little earlier we were taken to our table right away. The wait staff was great making sure we were comfortable. The food was very good. The atmosphere of the restaurant has a charming feel.  One of our favorites in the city!
author: John P.

description: Good food. Staff was kind and helpful. The place was packed but the service and the quality of the food was really goo. I had a filet with baked potato and vegetables. My mom had a fetuccini with chicken and cream. The pasta was a little unsalted for my taste. The filet was perfect. I do recommend. The prices were ok. Pasta around 10 and filet around 30.
author: Bruno N.
