description: I'm really surprised people are so rough on this place - I've been here probably 7-8 times and have never been disappointed with either the service or the food.  I usually get the broiled salmon which comes with vegetables and delicious, creamy mashed potatoes.  The desserts are excellent too.  The best part is it's a nice intimate spot to dine in a neighborhood normally know for total hustle & bustle...
author: G. R.

description:
It is only April, but this is the worst restaurant meal I have had this year.
I ordered grilled halibut and was disgusted that it was covered with a nasty brown thick  mushroom gravy.  Who does that to a piece of grilled fish?  The veggies were old an limp - some were green, but most looked like canned beans.  The cheesecake was not edible. My friend had their "famous" lamp chops and I have no clue what they are famous for, but they were tough and over seasoned, the baked potato was at least edible.  Service was so-so and it does have some great photos on the walls, or I would have given it only one star.  They are serving food here that is likely the same recipes as they served when they opened in 1906,  but with so  many other great restaurant choices in SF, why would anyone want a meal here?
author: Brady S.

description:
I'm American but currently live in Adelaide , South Australia. My wife and I love this  wonderfully evocative remnant of old San Francisco. Excellent personalized service, great food, a warm, cosy atmosphere and music that soothes without being intrusive.

We came across it by chance one Sunday night years ago; a caring staff member invited us inside from the cold and placed us at what would normally be a much coveted table by the bar. When you look at the magnificent dark wood panelled walls you quickly realise that you're sharing the experience of presidents, movie stars and an amazing array of celebrities past and present. It reeks of atmosphere and is the ideal place for a romantic dinner; on one occasion I ordered roses for my lovely wife from here in Australia and sure enough they were there on our table when we arrived. When we last dined there we invited my family from Palo Alto and they were equally impressed. Like my namesake (McArthur) we will return.
Dr Arthur F. Hughes, Adelaide, South Australia
author: Arthur Festin H.

description: Was there for lunch and dinner today.  The lobster ravioli seemed to be missing some filling.  The steak I had tonight was good but underdone.  The bread is amazingly good.  Service was a little lacking.
author: Rhonda W.

description: I checked a lot of steakhouses out using yelp before deciding on this one. Proximity and pricing were big motivating factors. The location was great and we got right in with no wait on a Sunday night. We got sat upstairs at a two top table right next two other two tops. A bit odd being so close to other couples like we are all dining together, but it was fine. I ordered a dirty martini with extra olives and got no extra olives. I ordered the filet mignon and my boyfriend got the New York strip. We both agreed our steaks were seasoned wonderfully but our steaks were lukewarm when we got them. I could tell they were sitting for awhile. I mentioned it to the server and got a little bit of attitude even though she offered to take it back. I said no, knowing what it's like when take back orders get sent to the  kitchen. (I worked as a server before).  I just wanted to give her feedback is all. She didn't even apologize and avoided eye contact with me for the remainder of the night, but did great in bringing my boyfriend flan with a candle. It was his birthday and the pianist played happy birthday, which was a nice touch. Overall, a very nice meal and experience.
author: Cynthia M.

description: We were treated to a classic San Francisco dinner here while staying in Union Square over Christmas, out to the Smuin Ballet, on way from St. Francis Hotel to Yerba Buena Center. We loved sitting next to the contemporary jazz guitarist upstairs in the bustling cozy room full of families and friends gathering close across tables close up just like the feeling I had out in Paris or New York! I was surprised at the generous variety of greens on the dinner salad, the perfectly prepared side vegetables and how great the food was, I knew it was a landmark, but didn't know it was like #3 of steak houses. I've been to Morton's, Ruth Chris, and Harris's, and you know I have to say, John's is the local downtown vibe, and feels festive and genuine. I've not been to the House of Prime Rib, but I can guess it is more "stuffy," and boring. I'm reviewing it because I do eat at many good places but this old school experience earned throughout with worn chairs, was perfect for a change. I'm a jazz fan and The music made my night, too. I think I recognized a famous face and felt like this is a well loved local scene. John's Grill was endangered at one time and you can feel the love keeping it in the heart of the city.
author: Barbara B.

description:
This place is obviously touristy, considering the location and history.  Places like this are annoying for locals. I went here during the holidays with some family and friends before a show. I chose this place because it was the only place that had a last minute reservation.  The restaurant was "festive" but VERY crowded - over crowded and cramped really, which is understandable for a touristy place on a Saturday night during the holidays in Union Square, but they held true to the reservation and seated us in a reasonable amount of time.

The service was slow on the uptake - we sat for a long time before even getting drinks in.  However, once we told them we were on a time restriction, our waiter was quick to pick up the pace.  One negative report, he forgot our appetizer order entirely and had to bring it at the last minute at the end of the meal.

The food was very overpriced for the poor quality of food.  It was "fine" but not worth the money.  I had the restaurant's famous OYSTERS WELLINGTON, which was actually not great - VERY greasy, and so flavoured with the bacon that there really wasn't a point of having the oysters in there. Just tasted like salty puff pastry that sat too long so that the puff pastry wasn't even crisp. Definitely not worth the price.  My friend had their also famous CHICKEN JERUSALEM, which I tasted, and that was actually deliciously tender; she cleaned her plate.  My sister had the Fisherman's Pasta, which she had no complaints about, but it didn't seem very special.  Her boyfriend just had side dishes, which were clearly nothing special or well-cooked at all.  Our appetizer ended up being the steamed clams, which were in NO WAY worth the price, considering how few clams were on the plate.  

Overall we had a very wonderful evening, but that had very little to do with the food at this place. Maybe we should have had the steak?
author: Renee R.

description: Great burger, best I've had since being in town.  Service was speedy and great for a 40 minute lunch.  The price was was a little high, but the food and atmosphere made it worth while.
author: Scott W.

description:
Thanks to the staff of John's for preserving some old San Francisco elegance. For those who like classic old SF recipes well-prepared and huge cocktails, John's and Tadich's Grills are always a delight. 

We came on a Friday night at prime dining hour without reservations. We were able to get seated immediately on the second floor. The second floor atmosphere is a far cry from the first in terms of charm and space, but we still enjoyed it. If you're making reservations, I suggest requesting the first floor.

The above said, we had a great time. We ordered a caesar salad to split -- it was among the best I've had. Perfectly sized lettuce, delicious croutons, and the dressing was not creamy, but deliciously balanced between the vinagrette, anchovy, and lemon. And perfect for two people. My tablemate had the oysters wellington. Such dishes don't really appeal to my sensibilities - I prefer a clean steak or bit of fish, or maybe one of the decadent seafood casseroles a la Tadich's. But the oysters wellington was delicious - medallions of puff pastry stuffed wtih spinach, oysters, and a binding of rich cream sauce but not overly sauced. A very nice surprise. The deviled prawns were quite good - like an old style dish with a deceptively rich, very flavorful sauce. 

Dinner was served with a very nice serving of al dente veggies and lots of fresh, crusty bread.

John's Grill is excellent quality and the service was way above par in my opinion. The waiter described his favorite dishes with the utmost patience and was great at anticipating our needs, and did not rush us. I was impressed with this place - it is what it is, no nonsense and still proud of what it is. I would say this style of restaurant is not everyone's cup of tea, but I'm thrilled to have finally patronized this gem.
author: Roxmarie M.

description: My son and I went to John's Grill for a holiday dinner after shopping at Union Square.  What a great meal!  Everything, from the host to the bus-people to the ambience, was absolutely wonderful.  The cocktails (we had sidecars) were great.  Not to miss food includes the Caesar salad, lobster ravioli, t-bone steak and pecan pie.  Our waiter was perfect, knowledgeable and gentle with suggestions (which we followed).  This is an iconic San Francisco restaurant that should not be missed.
author: Phyllis O.

description:
Out of the classic San Francisco 'Grills' (i.e. Tadich, Sam's), John's Grill is my favorite.

This place has a vertical 3-story layout, and the circa 1908 dark wood decor add a cozy charm perfect for Fog City, and the setting for Dashiell Hammett's 1930's detective novel, The Maltese Falcon.

This falcon has been stolen a few times from the restaurant, so its replica is now behind glass alongside commemorative do-dads.  You can see it as you come out of the 'John' on the 2nd floor..

Food is pretty good.  Traditional seafood + meats - beef.chicken.lamb.

Share a Jack Lalanne salad to bolster up on greens beforehand.

If you want to pop in for a drink, they have a bar.

Reservations advised - I was there on a Monday and the place seemed packed.  

They claim to have live jazz nightly.  I was dining on the 1st, so I missed it.  Next time I'll have to check out the 2nd floor to catch the musicians.
author: Cathy K.

description: I have been eating at John's Grill for years. Although the clientele has changed, the ambiance and the food have not changed.  It's a true steak and martini kind of place. I always have a hard time deciding between the steaks and the chops. This time around, we all ordered the t-bone, which was cooked to perfection and very tasty. The meat was a bit tough, but otherwise very good. I really enjoyed the baked potato and veggies that came with it. The wine list is prolific. We ended up splitting a bottle of sparkling wine and having crab and shrimp cocktails made with very flavorful fresh Dungeness crab and fresh jumbo shrimp. We were surprised at how generous the portions were. Service was elegant, efficient and lovely. It was a marvelous experience !
author: Lisa F.

description: The meal itself was average at best. I could grill the same steak in my back yard with my eyes closed. The service was one of the more appalling things I've ever seen. From the time we were seated it took 15 minutes for a waiter to come to our table and then another 15 minutes for our drinks to arrive. She was absolutely clueless and didn't seem to care about her job at all. Also I could smell the weed on her from two tables away. I traveled from Texas to visit family and I recommended this place because it is apparently a San Francisco institution. There is nothing more embarrassing than having to apologize to your family after an experience like we had at John's Grill and none of us will ever step foot in there again. Golden Corral would have been a better option.
author: Joseph C.

description: My 16 year old son said it best: like eating mediocre country club food. Service was good, staff friendly. Ambience wasn't as good as it could have been, we were seated on 3rd floor but had made a late reservation and got in quickly, so no complaint there. Very below average steaks and salmon entrées.
author: Sam J.

description: Poor quality of meat for the price. If you cannot taste the difference you shouldn't be eating steak. Don't eat if you appreciate a quality piece of meat
author: Jared F.

description: I am not one to like the usual tourist type places , but the first place we went was so bad we walked out and ended up here. What a treat ! Great atmosphere. Reasonable lunch menu . The prawns Provençal were incredible ! Large, cooked perfectly and delicious. Definitely would go back just for the architecture and great service from the wait staff and the greeter who went overboard telling us where to go and not to go while in the city .
author: Kelly G.

description:
Well, shoot....... we like to try different places when we go to the city, and John's has been on our list for some time. We got there early for lunch on a Friday, and the restaurant hadn't started to fill up yet. Yet! We were warmly greeted and offered a table by the entrance. I thought it would be a good table from which to people watch, but it turned out to be a bit chilly for my wife, so we asked to be moved. No problem. moved to a table with a smile and no fanfare. The hostess was very pleasant.
We started with wine and a Caesar salad... our server offered to split it for us, as it's quite large. It was a very good salad. We LOVE garlic, and it's a dang good thing, 'cause this thing was loaded!
I had grilled salmon, and my wife had linguine with clams. Both were good, and the portions were large. The pasta dish was loaded with clams, and my salmon was cooked just right. It came with garlic smashed and fresh veggies... both were good.
The only reasons I'm not going with 5 stars;  the veggies weren't exactly hot, and the table for two was so small that it barely held our food and wine.... so we were a bit cramped.
The place filled up before we finished our lunch, so it's obviously very popular. Our server knew the menu, was friendly without going over the top, and all in all, we had a good time.
The place has been there since 1908 for cryin'  out loud. Give it a try.
author: Douglas L.

description: Everything was absolutely excellent, appetizer: lobster ravioli, main courses: New York steak, Halibut, and fisherman's pasta...All so very tasty. Great service, ambiance and received all food quickly.. Will definitely recommend to friends and return the next time I am in the city..!
author: Taylor O.

description:
John's Grill - October 2010 - New England style clam chowder was very creamy, butterrr, and the clam was perfectly how I enjoy them. I've been to Boston to try the top 3, so that's sayin' something!

Prawn and Scallops Saute x 3 for our group - mushrooms herbs, and the size of the sea scallops was surprising - big - and the prawns, a bit overcooked and some say "frozen" but it was everything I expected. 

Service was solid, no complaints. The water in San Francisco is some of the best in the world.

I'll try the creamed spinach next time.
author: Wilson T.

description: We had 8 in our group. Our meals were cold and arrived with fries instead of baked potatoes. The girl delivering our meals was rude when we told her that we ordered baked. The waiter tried to fix the situation with free dessert & free drinks. It was a nice try but he didn't ask us first. I don't drink & I can't have dessert!!  Communicate please!
author: Rita B.

description: Great steaks.  Ate during the dinner rush but after a busy day of shopping in San Francisco this was absolutely perfect.  I had John's Steak and my friend had the Porterhouse.  We were both quiet as we devoured each of our steaks.  The tables were a little close together so i can't help but hear other people's convo but if you just need a good piece of steak after an exhausting day of shopping then this is definitely the place to be.  The staff were as helpful as they can be considering how busy it was during the rush.
author: Lara P.

description: Very good service.  The salads are huge and delicious.  They were very accommodating for my diet restrictions.  I have lived in the area for decades, and I wish I had come here sooner!  A San Francisco tradition.
author: Andrea A.

description: Cute restaurant. Great service. Seating was a little crowded. Food was so so and overpriced. Ordered the Surf & Turf. Was surprised to see how petite the filet was. The filet was lacking seasoning and tasted mostly like char.
author: Nickie P.

description: Enjoyed this place so much! All if the Maltese Falcon memorabilia on the walls- great atmosphere. Live jazz the night we visited. Ordered the clam chowder and surf and turf - small portions, but great food. Will be back!
author: Steph P.

description: We were recommended this place by our concierge.  I know it has been around since 1908 and the Maltese Falcon and history  http://www.johnsgrill.com/ is interesting but its all about the food.  I gotta think their food has seen better days as it is really bland below average food for the price.  Yes, I've experienced better and definitely would not return with so many other interesting dining options.
author: Chris C.

description:
On Saturday August 16, my boyfriend and I came to San Francisco to watch the Giant's game and stay the night. We walked around in the 90 degree weather looking  for a nice place to eat. By the time we stumbled upon John's Grill, we were spent, super grumpy and starving!! They sat us right away. We waited for a few minutes before the nicest waiter in the world greeted us. I'm sure he could see that we were almost done! We told him we were starving and he put the order in right away and brought us some ice cold beers and water.
 When our food came out, my club sandwich looked really dry, but Dan's hamburger looked great. Well, he took one bite of his burger and his mood changed 100 percent!! He shared that burger with me, It was the best burger we have ever had!!
Not only did we end up having a great lunch( we shared the burger) but our waiter took the sandwich off the bill!
We will definitely go back the next time we are in San Francisco! Thank you for John's Grill for saving our trip. P.S. And the Giant's won the game too!!!
author: Jill M.

description:
A Superb Stake & The Maltese Falcon At John's Grill In San Francisco 
-By Stacy Poulos www.PostcardTravelers.com 

John's Grill
63 Ellis St., San Francisco, CA 94102
(between 4th St & Market St)
Neighborhood: Union Square
(415) 986-0069
www.johnsgrill.com 


When you've been around since 1908 you know someone has carried on the torch. After spending 3 day's at a MacWorld convention I thought I'd treat myself to a great meal. As I walked down Powell Street I passed by an officer and said "I know you must know where a good place to eat a reasonably priced steak is around here". He pointed right up the street to 120 Powell at 'Tad's Steak Restaurant' and said you can get a good steak for around 15 buck's (almost with a New York accent). So I went in that direction, before crossing Ellis St, being a good citizen looking both ways before I crossed the street, to my right 'John's Grill since 1908' caught my eye. It rang a bell for me, so I thought I'd peek in and it was the home of the movie 'The Maltese Falcon'. It's a little more spendi for my budget. But as a filmmaker, I couldn't help but want to sit in a room where Sam spade from the movie sat and be inspired by History. Why not spoil myself once in a while.

I will say, as frugal as I am, I have a very sophisticated pallet for a great quality steak. My mom spoiled us with her restaurant sized indoor grill and teated us to a good T-bone or New York steak once in a while. Not to mention, we got our meat from cows my step dad's family had raised in Portland Oregon. So trust me, I know a good quality steak. I start out on a steak adventure very skeptical, that it will be near as good as what I have grown up to know. A great steak needs just salt and pepper. Sometimes a hint of butter and garlic. 

Going in a fancy restaurant as a single female alone, isn't always a nice greeting. I was pleasantly surprised all the way around. The first thing I thought about when they sat me down and brought me bread and butter, was the great tasting San Francisco sourdough bread (my best friend in Alabama makes me bring her a loaf when I visit). Most restaurants have this chewy bread. Even if it's freshly made nothing compares to a SF sourdough bread crust. It has its own taste and texture. Even though there's a "Sam Spade's Chops (Broiled lamb chops)" on the menu, I had myself a nice Medium rare New York USDA Prime or Certified Black Angus, the finest available. Corn-fed in the Midwest, it is specially selected for the highest quality and naturally aged for maximum flavor and tenderness steak.  Yummy! Perfect flame broiled on the outside and rare on the inside. The flavor of the meat was superb, As I enjoyed live jazz filling the air. 

33 bucks for the steak includes seasonal vegie, a baked potato and roaming around the unofficial museum of San Francisco's rich History. On the walls are many famous people who have visited including the late Jack Lalanne who said my newest favorite quote "The worst thing you can do to your body is not use it". I sat across from the 1984 Olympic Torch. You know they have to know someone to have that. It's a different experience than going to a museum and observing, than actually sitting where films have inspired a part of your career. Before I left, I got my photo taken next to the Maltese Falcon and Emmy Award to inspire my next generation of filmmaking with a great meal underneath my belt and new technology to expand my horizon. 

A Superb Stake & The Maltese Falcon At John's Grill In San Francisco 
-By Stacy Poulos www.PostcardTravelers.com
author: Stacy P.

description: I stopped in here for a quick lunch while I was out shopping.  Prices are a bit steep, but that is to be expected for the area.  The club sandwich I got was good, and the service was friendly and fast as well.
author: Teri W.

description: Came with a large group to enjoy a good meal after our tradeshow. Unfortunately the food was sub par (rib eye was very thin) and the service was just bad.  Lindsey was our waitress and she just didn't want to be working. Didn't want to engage us as customers in anyway and even when we tried just blew us off.  We spent $500 as a group and honestly we would have been better off visiting the local Chipotle.
author: Jason B.

description: We hadn't had dinner here for many years, but renewing an old friendship, had dinner with friends we had eaten with at John's many years ago.  We were delighted by the food and service.  I had mistakenly reserved the wrong night, and on a busy Saturday night was treated with graciousness, kindness and respect, and given a table within 30 minutes of my arrival in spite of a very busy Saturday night crowd.  The food was solid and tasty and the atmosphere as wonderful as I remembered.  Thanks to the mater'd who was so friendly and helpful, in spite of my blunder. In spite of the bustle it was quite intimate, and we could hear ourselves speak, enjoyed wonderful food, drink and conversation.  Ill definitely return when looking for a place by Union Square.
author: Thomas A.

description:
100 year old restaurant that looks even older, but in a cool way.

Ceasar salad = Top notch

Oysters = Top notch but dirty and not very cold (I didn't try...barfffffff)

Clam chowder = Top notch

New York strip = Top notch

Wine list was good. great meal in a grungy little restaurant. Barely space to move between the tables but the pictures on the wall are awesome as well!!

Staying in Union Square, go here.
author: Gee T.

description: We loved the service, our good and wine. I ordered ciopino, hubby had oysters Wellington and house salad. Free Sourdough bread brought to table is great. We ordered cocktails, in first sip I didn't like the Asian Pear Martini, no problem! Waiter swapped it out for a pomegranate Cosmo. Also got a smooth bottle of Hess Cab-Sauv. We enjoyed the house salad, awesome ciopino, and oysters Wellington. Yes, it's a but noisy in here, but great food and service!
author: Margie P.

description: We ate here at the suggestion of the Hyatt. The place was packed with lines waiting to get in. We were very glad we had make reservations. The food and service was very good. The seating is tight and a bit noisy but the food makes it worth it. Make sure to notice pics on the wall of others that have enjoyed the food and service.
author: Lynda H.

description:
PRO: Anything seafood here is AWESOME. Their special snapper dish has never heard a bad remark.

CON: The steak, although many to choose from, HAS heard negative remarks. Cuts should only be narrowed down to a ribeye or new york (or suffer the consequences).

PRO: It's been here since 1908.

CON: It's been here since 1908.

PRO: They rock live jazz nightly.

CON: Les Joulins next door rocks it HARDER.

VERDICT: It's good. It's a definite must-try-once. I  mean, they've been here for over 100 friggen years. I usually recommend this place when people want something nearby downtown and casual. Well, here's that spot.
author: Arturo F.

description: came here for dinner with my boss -- steak was fantastic, pinot sonoma, walk-in
author: Caroline L.

description: Just so happen to find this great place. Ran into a friend and he suggested the Dungeness crap app. I was by myself and it is an $18 app so I didn't get it but the couple next me did and said it was phenomenal. I ordered a the garden salad that had shrimp on it and if it wasn't for the shrimp I would not have ordered it, very plain. For my entree I had the Seafood Cannalonei and all I can say it was fantastic, rich but fantastic.  The weird part of this restaurant is, I sat at the bar, the bartender got me my drinks but a server took my order, very strange. All in all a good to go with friends or family, kind if boring by yourself. I was in town over the holiday for work.
author: Scott P.

description:
Oh steak, how you still call to me. I love you, steak from John's Grill. 

I went here for a dinner during a conference, and they were able to accommodate a huge group of us upstairs. We had an excellent shrimp salad, which was dressing drenched, but just fine that way. I heard the sole was excellent, but the steak was perfect. Nice and medium rare, but crispy on the outside, it made my night. 

John's is easy to find, right near BART and Union Square. Great for groups, and downstairs looked cute and intimate.
author: Allison A.

description: A long overdue review. One of my favorite places to eat at when I'm in the city. The place is always very busy, but the staff and layout of the restaurant puts you very much at peace and gives you a sense of nostalgia from the pictures on the wall to the Maltese falcon. A timeless place. The staff is always super friendly and attentive, have never had any sort of problem with them. The food is excellent as well, my favorites are the lobster ravioli (could eat that everyday) along with the chicken Jerusalem, but just about everything on the menu is great as well. Keep doing what your doing there john!
author: Kai D.

description:
We were seated upstairs it was very tight and stuffy, live music was enjoyable, 

Food delish!!!! 
Service thumbs up. 

Dim lighted pretty romantic.

OYEA! careful there was a pickpocket recently in here! The incident was in the newspaper!! Point is everyone should be careful everywhere not just here
author: Veranna N.

description: We were in a rush to get food before going to a class at the Revere Academy of Jewelry Arts and had 50 minutes until we had to get going. We got seated immediately. I ordered right away, asking the waiter what the largest dish is (he suggested the Fisherman's Pasta, which is a creamy alfredo-ish pasta with tons of seafood: fish, shrimp, mussels, clams, etc.). I ordered just one entree and told him we're in a rush and that I'd like the bill at the same time. The food came out quickly. There was free bread and butter. They even split the dish into two plates so that it would be easier to eat between two people. They gave us the bill as I asked. Thus, service was on point and the food was good two. It seemed like it would be overkill to have an entree per person because it gets a bit pricey, and the portions are huge, so if you're not that hungry, try sharing a single entree. We were in and out in 45 minutes!
author: Michelle H.

description:
Steak was over-cooked but atmosphere is classic old-school San Francisco.  The service was good and the sourdough was great.  Be sure to visit the second floor (that's where the bathrooms are) to see the Maltese Falcon memorabilia.  

One thing that I did NOT like was that we were greeted by a funky, fishy off-putting, unappetizing smell when we came through the door.  That is something that should be addressed by management. 

Other than that -- a cool, super traditional San Francisco restaurant. Out-of-Towners dig it. Easy to get to on Muni or you can park directly across the street in the Ellis Street garage which you enter on O'Farrell.
author: Bette S.

description:
Wow!  That was unexpectedly good.

Lamb chops for me, sea bass for my wife...both excellent.  Crab cocktail as an appetizer...best I've had in a while.

Everything was simple  and good.
author: Donald B.

description: It was okay but over priced considering the sort of food you can get in San Francisco for far less. Both of us had the New York steak and it was good and done perfectly. Service was okay, nothing spectacular. If you are on holidays and can't be bothered leaving Union Square it's a good option.
author: David M.

description:
stumbled upon this restaurant trying to find food around Union Square, didnt know it was famous, but we were hungry!

Too bad the place was extremely cramped and I had no idea where the live jazz was, however, the food was pretty good. Two people in my party got the Fisherman's pasta (super creamy and cheesy but delicious) and another got the T Bone Steak. We also ordered their Cabernet Sauvignon, it was decent.  

overall, with the ambiance and kind of price range this restaurant is trying to go for, I would've expected it to be slightly classier (like a little less cramped and a little less dirty) but its alright, wouldn't come here for a romantic date or anything though. But decent place for good old american seafood and steak.
author: Katherine C.

description: Excellent petrale sole almandine, great service, great prices at lunch. If I lived in San Francisco I'd go back often.
author: Tori v.

description:
Date of Visit: 09/11/10 @ before Noon.

Stumbled across this restaurant as soon as we came into the city from Los Gatos. I wanted a sit-down, serve me kind of place as I was on vacation and did not mind spending some money. However, I did not know that the ,menu was limited and a little pricey - but I forged ahead and spent money on the New York Steak, thanks to the recommendation of the waiter. Needless to say, it was a great meal, My traveling companion also enjoyed his.  What really made me glad I came in was to find out about the history of John's -- having been host to the writer of the "Maltese Falcon." (Go check out the second floor!)

No trouble with service - waitstaff was on top of the ball and the host was friendly and helpful.

Side note - I did get a chuckle from the visiting younger Asian men that sat next to us -- they were taking so many pictures of each others meals! ... And I thought I was bad! LOL
author: Paul A.

description: Great atmosphere , okay food, kind if pricey, but overall enjoyable. Great place for movie fans of the Maltese Falcon or just history as it is a very old establishment.
author: Barry P.

description:
Man it's sad that I have to review this place poorly. It had so much potential!

My friend was craving some steak so we decided to come here and try this out. The hostess was very nice and showed us our table. The feel of the restaurant was very cozy and also classy which I loved. 

The server took a while to get to our table. When we finally ordered our food we asked for water. It took 25 minutes to get just the water! It seemed to have gotten busy however it didn't seem to be unbearable. Our server never once came back to ask how we were doing or if we needed anything (ie refill of water!). As our frustration grew the people next to us overheard us talking about the poor service and they agreed and left! We applauded their decision and wished we had done the same. We had to wave down the hostess to help us (She seemed to be doing most of the work anyways!). 

Basically it took 25 minutes to get water, 45-50 minutes to get our food, never refilled our water nor asked us how we were doing then the bill came after we had to ask for it twice! When our bill came back she shorted us a quarter which was okay because that's all we were going to tip anyways. Poor service = poor tip, sorry lady. 

2 stars: 1 because the food was good 1/2 star for the atmosphere and 1/2 star for the hostess. Fix your customer service then I'll be back.
author: Ezequiel R.

description:
The Clam Chowder is the best one I've tried. Not that I'm an expert in that area, but lately I've had my fare of chowders. This one is creamier, thicker and flavorful. it looks like all other Yelpers agree with me. Definitely a most try when you go. 

If you're a meat lover, you won't be disappointed. I tried the New York and it was perfect. Served medium well, juicy, tender and lightly seasoned. 

The food is great, but the place was the best part of the experience. Starting with the traditional logo and entrance that transport you in time, followed by a classic San Francisco deco, full of details on every wall culminating with the historic maltese falcon. All of this makes it a no miss for tourists and a must if you're living here. 

The restaurant is set in the middle of a touristy area in San Francisco. Walking distance from the Powell Cable Car, the Convention Center, Union Square and many shops making it convenient for those visiting or those working near the area. 

The service was good. Nothing to complain about and usually if I have nothing to say about the service is probably because it had the right balance to make me feel well served whiteout being rushed to order, pay or get more drinks. 

Will I go back? Sure. Next time for seafood :)
author: Miguel M.

description: I've been here twice, once for lunch (a month ago) and again for dinner.  Lunch was good, had a bloody that was kinda whatever, but got the Jack Lelanne salad which was super good!  I like the ambiance; jazzy old school... and service was on point.  Anyway, went back for dinner last friday night: no reservation, no problem, maybe because we got there just after 9.  I started with a slightly dirty chopin martini.... yum, went well with the oysters!!  Then I went with the Halibut (lots of seasonal veggies and baked potato) and my friend got the Chilean sea bass.  Both were good, I liked the flavor of mine better, but the texture of the sea bass was perfection!   I did get a half bottle of zin to go with my meal, gotta love the half bottles.  Bottom line, this place is a great stop for lunch or dinner, you'll be happy.
author: Stefanie N.

description:
Totally unassuming little place 2 blocks from Union Square in San Fran. I must have passed this place 3-4 times the days before I actually came to meet a friend for dinner. I have to admit that once I learned the location, I did not want to attend. 
The place is quaint and full of history. There are 3 floors. And yes, the servers run all the food from the first floor (great workout). The first floor was quite crowded but seemed very original to the space. I was on the third floor which was quite open and seated larger tables. 
We were able to sample several appetizers including the cheese plate, the crab, and shrimp cocktail. I cannot tell you how amazingly delicious the shrimp and crab were!!!! I'm not typically a fan of theses cold apps but I have to tell you the flavor and freshness were off the charts!
I then had a bowl of clam chowder.... who knew I needed to save room for more?! I will definitely say this is some of the BEST clam chowder I have EVER experienced!
Then I moved on to the seafood cannoli....not that I had any room left:( This dish was surprisingly great! 
My friends stuck with steak and potatoes and they were not disappointed!
I was too full for dessert but I sampled a bite of the homemade vanilla ice cream and regretted that I did not have room for more.
Definitely will return here when I am in town. Great ambiance, great service, great comfort food!
author: Amber H.

description: Ordered medium rare New York steak, but got served well done. Not what you expect from a steak house and at that price.
author: Maheep S.

description: Ooooo Child... Let me say- this was a wonderful place to get a "arrival drink"- wonderful Lemondrop and Manhattan which was what was intended- the clam chowder was spectacular- lemon-peppery goodness... fries were crispy as sin too! They even accommadated us travelers (plenty o baggage) with a space for our luggage- and free key chain  The staff was quick (lunch hour in Union Square!) and very friendly- what drove us here before was the smell of the grill....and Im certain we'll be back off the bus/BART again!
author: Rosemary W.

description:
A 3 star restaurant with 4 star pricing. 

John's Grill has been around since 1908, so it does something right.  What that is, however, is probably having the foresight to be located a few blocks from most of the tourist hotels and conference centers around Union Square.

I've eaten here several times, and each time it was just ok.  The food is adequate, although a bit overpriced for what you get.  I had a New York steak that was actually pretty low quality, and the Bernaise sauce (which is an optional extra) was clearly made with vegetable oil and not real butter.  The other entreee's at my table were a little better, being decent but not fabulous.

Service is good, but not great.  

If you find yourself in the Union Square area and want a traditional steakhouse experience, you won't be horribly disappointed by John's Grill, but you can do better.
author: Bryan M.

description:
A welcome trip back in time.  Dark wood, stiff drinks, and a grill menu that favors seafood, steaks and chops.  The place is briefly memorialized in a single line of Dash Hammett's The Maltese Falcon, but if you order what Sam Spade had, or shell out for the Falcon-themed drink, you deserve what you get for being a sucker.  At least try to pretend you're a local, and order something else from the extensive menu.
The classic cocktails are strong and large, and the food ranges from adequate to excellent.
Like I said, it's a trip back in time, so if, like the average American, you resemble Mr. Gutman more than Mr. Spade, you'll find the tables won't accommodate you.
And I would be remiss if I didn't point out the Dash Hammett history lesson on the menu, penned by fantasy author Fritz Leiber, a mystery buff and erstwhile San Francisco author.
author: Essential S.

description:
Avoid this place.  My salmon was horrible, the place was cramped and the prices are outrageous.

If you want food poisioning, go.
author: Peter M.

description:
If I could put negative infinity stars for this place I would...

Food was ok, a little pricy. I guess you're paying for the atmosphere and service. Let's just say my experience was unique. From the server to owner I have never seen so many people drop the ball. Read on for the full brutal monty kiddies.

Some friends and I were dining & they forgot their credit card so I left my card on the table and went to the restroom.

I came back to find my UNFINISHED meal had been cleared by the waitress, and I was not asked if I was done! The server knew I had shown up late and yet she wasn't smart enough to realize I might not be done.

Additionally John's Grill has some special historic drink glass deal, where you order a really horrible drink but it comes with a free glass you can take home. Apparently she thought it would be a great idea to package them all up and give them to my friends, who were now in a cab on the way to the airport. Meanwhile I was taking a completely different flight/location so there would be no opportunity to get my glass back. Moreover, it's not my responsibility to fix the server's blunders.

I called in and asked to speak with the manager.

They asked me to email in what happened. I emailed the owner, John Konstin, several times. He apologized but never lifted a pinky finger to make good on any reparations. All I got repeatedly was lip service. Apparently John must think I don't matter because I live out of town and wouldn't be a repeat customer.

John's last email to me was that he was "checking his records". I asked him to send me the shipper's tracking # for the glasses he claims were sent to me and I never heard from him again.

He should have sent me another drink glass or wiped out my portion of the food bill. In the end I had to dispute the bill with the credit card company.

I feel like this grill owner slapped me in the face.

Even if I was starving I would not eat at this establishment, or recommend it. Ever.

This all happened to me back in '08, but having recently seen the email chain it reminded me he never made good and pissed me off because they took advantage of me. My only recourse is Yelp.

Thanks for nothing, John's Grill.

To: jkonstin @ johnsgrill.com
Subject: comment - John's Grill experience

Hi,

Some friends and I were in town this past weekend. Right before we all had to board ***seperate flights*** and head home we were hungry for some food so we headed to John's Grill. The food was good but I have to say the service was lacking. I left the table to use the restroom and when I came back the table had been completely cleared and I had not been asked if I was done. A portion of my meal I was looking forward to finishing was now gone.

My friends had accidentally left their credit card in the hotel room so I had to pay the entire bill on my credit card (I'm not a super rich guy). As I paid I asked the witress to wrap up the John's Grill glass I'd used when I ordered that special drink you guys made.

She informed me she'd given my glass to the people who I ate lunch with. I was stunned at this. They were flying out to another location. They were a couple - 2 people - and she had given them 3 John's Grill glasses. Why would you give two people all 3 glasses? This is after not allowing me to finish my meal...

Needless to say, I felt completely snubbed. She made no move to correct her error or even seek a manager. She is the one who gave away the glass to people who did not even pay the bill...

The food was tasty, but upon reviewing the service I have to say it was attrocious and I would probably think twice before I ever recommended any of my friends eating there, or going back again.
author: Chupacabra S.

description:
Was in the city recently on business and came here with two locals after work.

I've been coming here a long time, the first time being the mid-70's probably and I like this place because it hasn't changed and it is what it is, an old school San Francisco restaurant. I'd love to know the age of the reviewers who have reviewed this place recently. If you are looking for modern, sleek and hip, that isn't John's. It is cramped, historic and real.

I usually start with the Roquefort salad here since so few places still have real Roquefort. For my entree I usually get the Petrale Sole or Rib Eye and it was the rib eye this time and it came out perfectly medium rare.

One of my companions had the Petrale sole and raved about it, she said she had avoided John's because her friends had all bad mouthed it. Our other companion had the Porterhouse and he wasn't has happy with his as i was with the rib eye, but then he ordered peppercorns on it, who puts peppercorn sauce on a $34 steak?

If I lived in the Bay Area again John's would be in my regular rotation since it is close to my SF office and it is a nice, comfortable place for a good meal.
author: Scott M.

description:
We have lived in the Bay Area for over half a century, always knew about John's Grill, but had never eaten there. So this was the week! (12/11/13) 

Reserved on Open Table for 11:45 lunch. Easy to reach by BART, short walk from Powell St. station. We were given a double wide window table for the two of us and appreciated the extra elbow room.

Our personable and prompt server Michael brought our gin, beer and bloody mary in no time and did not rush us for the lunch order. We both ordered the clam chowder, Jack Lalanne salad (for the lady) and calves liver (myself)

The clam chowder is really more of a clam/potato bisque: creamy and rich without being gummy or starchy with very tender clams. The serving was most generous: a large soup plate for only $6.95.Very different style from other chowders I've had recently, but oh so good and sinful! 5 stars.

The Jack Lalanne salad $16.95 was good, 3 to 3.5 stars. The calves liver was done just right, medium rare, smothered with onions and several strips of crisp bacon, excellent mashed potatoes and a medley of zucchini and other squashes that were cooked just right - not too soft. This serving too was very generous and the price a most reasonable $14.95. As calves liver goes, this too earned 5 stars, and this is the rare restaurant that even has it on the menu.

Overall I was surprised how reasonably priced the food and drink were, especially when one considers it is in the middle of the touristy Union Square area. Tanqueray gin/rocks (with two olives! cost $7, Tanqueray bloody mary $8, Sierra Nevada draft beer 5.50 and a glass of very nice sauvignon blanc $10. The total lunch tab for two, before tip was less than $89. With a fine lunch like that, I forgot to look for the Maltese Falcon. We'll have to go back and I think I'll order clam chowder and calves liver again.
author: Peter K.

description: I thought it was borderline awesome. According to the bitch-reviews its for old ppl and tourists, whatever (no it didnt have stupid hipster lounge tracks on a p.a. for goatee guys in porkpie hats and bright yellow glasses without lenses lol)- it's just a restaurant with it's own style and history and sticks to it.. service was great, attentive but not pushy or unconfident, just right. My swordfish was really nice. There was some oafish loudmouth complaining nearby but he wanted a free meal I think. It's a good dive for anyone, stop trying to feign elitism and accept the world has many kinds of boxes and many uses for them.
author: Miguel L.

description: This place is a joke. Totally disappointed. If I could give negative stars I would. I set up reservations for dinner for my girlfriend's birthday. This was the night I was going to propose to her. Totally ruined my night and my girlfriend's (well now fiancé). Lets start off with reservations went off without a hitch, that was the only plus. Got seated given water and bread. Proceeded to look at the wine list and was told that they would not serve us any type of alcohol. Asked our server why, was told that the manager told our server not to serve any drinks to us. Now at this time we were totally confused of why this was put on us. We then asked to speak to the manager, we explained that this was my girlfriend's birthday and she wanted a glass of wine, I was to remain sober due to I was driving. The manager then told us that they wouldn't serve us anything because we appeared to have come in intoxicated, I explained to the manager that we were both sober, not one drop of alcohol had touched our lips. Still the manager refused to serve two perfectly sober customers. Now I'm not one to pull the race card, but was this all do to the fact that my now fiancé is half African American and I'm Asian, and that we were enjoying each others company and were overly happy to be together hmmmm makes me think... So now my fiancé is pissed, ruined her birthday dinner and her entire night. Now I ask how many people have ever had a couple of drinks before having dinner has been wrong??? So we got up and left, John's grill wasn't getting a dime from me. So I'd advise anyone that wants to eat here you better beware, cause coming in trying to have a nice dinner (completely sober) you probably be denied any type of wine or alcohol, just because you were enjoying the night out in San Francisco....
author: Gorden D.

description:
I love that this place has been around for 100 years! Downstairs has a great vintage ambiance. (Upstairs is OK, but not as nearly as nice).

Excellent chicken jerusalem. Very good sidecar cocktail and manhattan. Nice prawns provencal. They serve old-school sourdough bread with your meal.

Honestly, the history gives this place a boost of a whole star. So, if you don't care about that, consider this a solid 3 star place.

Why? Fisherman's pasta and lambchops are just OK. Other cocktails, like old-fashioned was not mixed correctly. Upstairs carpets need some serious cleaning.
author: Marcus J.

description:
I have to say this was a spontaneous decision, and thankfully a good one. I thought the menu was priced a little high, but in the end, it was well worth it, and besides it is Union Square, and most people will pay. 
After a 20 minute wait (and a decision to try and get into the horrible jazz place across the street while we waited and no one there even paid us a dose of attention upon sitting at their bar), we were ushered to our quaint table, as if we were honorable guests. 
We both ordered the Filet, I had the peppercorn sauce and he had the baranaise sauce (both are just superb!) and was by far the best steak I've had in a very long time. The veggies and potato were great too, although super generic.
Best of all, the service was unreal. So professional, efficient and fast! 
If you're into the old school SF atmosphere and want a good steak, I highly recommend John's!
author: Eric P.

description:
Not sure why some of the negative reviews panned the atmosphere and "out-of-date" menu.  It's a classic old city steakhouse people-it's going to be dark and crowded with an old-fashioned menu. If that's not your cup of tea, go try something trendy and fun.

Escargot in garlic cream are to die for - not for dieters or heart patients, but oh-so-good.  Steak was good boring on excellent, service was reasonable for a Saturday night and friendly.  The host recommended a great bourbon I'd never tried.

And if you haven't seen The Maltese Falcon, go rent it, really.
author: Lil D.

description:
Ugh. Went to John's after hearing that it was a staple in San francisco. We were greeted and seated by the hostess immediately. 

Off the bat I was turned off by the dated decor. This place needs a make over like no one's business. 

My husband ordered a steak. He could have had better at applebee's. No offense to applebee's but when you are paying $48 or more a plate you expect a tad bit more than an unseasoned undercooked filet and a delicious baked potato. 

I didn't even order a dinner. I had a caesar salad and baked potato. I do not drink, I had two ice teas and no dessert. The bill was $74. This place is over priced, needs a make over in the kitchen and dining room. 

Go here with your grandparents for nostalgia but do not go looking for good food. And do not take anyone you are looking to impress.
author: Megan J.

description: Nice atmosphere...food is bad and specially bartender was not nice. Seriously can you guys put someone in the bar who is more friendly and happy??? What a bad environment there... If I go out I want to have fun and not see boring faces ...why not a nice and friendly woman or man as bartender??? Thank you.
author: Jennifer B.

description: Terrible service!  My fiancé and I just left dinner here.  First he ordered the Budweiser draft beer...it arrived room temperature and CLOUDY.  We had to flag down the waiter and he replaced it, not even bothering to apologize.   Fiancé had the steak.  It was dry and tough...no thanks.  I had the oyster Wellington.  I love spinach, but for $30 I think they could come up with more than 3 oysters and a ton of spinach!!!   Service was slow, dining room was crammed.  I learned far more about the stranger next to me than I ever wanted to because our tables were so close they nearly touched.  What a waste of time!  Never again!
author: Lauren P.

description: I am not from the Bay Area but whenever I come up here I always stop for Breakfast! I am on a life long quest for the best eggs benedict and they are currently #2 The eggs benedict come with mashed potatoes that are to die for and asparagus cooked and seasoned to perfection! Also the bloody mary's are good too!
author: Jessica D.

description: An amazing dining experience at John's, every single time. Friendly staff, unique atmosphere, and some of the best food in the Bay Area.
author: Zander F.

description:
Very enjoyable dining experience!  Hard to top the smooth jazz entertainment, the movie historic decor, experienced servers, not 
to mention the delectable lamb chops you just want to pick up to get every bit. Go there!
author: Pam D.

description: This place is possibly touristy. But I love the space. I've been here at least three different times, and the service and food have been great every time. This is a place that I sort of end up at with friends when we can't decide where else we might want to go. There are certainly fancier places to have a meal in San Francisco, but this place is very solid, and it's fun to point out the Dashiell Hammett connection to friends.
author: Al I.

description: A jewel in the crown of SF restaurants.  I love this place.  Everything I've tried is fabulous.  The seafood is the best though. Get the oysters, get the fish, you won't regret it.  The upstairs rooms are so cool and for a Maltese Falcon fan this place has it all.  Five stars!
author: Sin F.

description:
I am going to mention right-off that we hit this place on a Friday night (which has busy written all over it.) Additionally it's important to note that this joint is sporting some of that great classic early 20th century  San Fran architecture that, although aesthetically is very pleasing, leaves something to be desired in the comfort category. I should also mention that this was our second choice to the Cheesecake Factory ( I know, I know, don't lecture me) where we would have had to wait for 90 minutes to get a table. 

Ok so John's. Your first impression of this place on a busy night is undoubtedly horrible because the place is so packed with tables that they've got the host's desk literally against the door of the entrance. What this means is that when there are more than two people waiting, bodies spill all over - butts in the faces of diners and those who arrive are forced into the cold outside or in between the two sets of doors - BAD PLANNING! Despite this suffocating proximity to the host - he went back and forth between the dining room three times before even acknowledging our presence- no "hey I'll be right with you" or anything. Finally a server passing by welcomed us to the establishment.

We had to wait 20 min. for a table which was to be expected but at the bar there was again, zero room and we weren't even given a passing glance by the bartender for at least 5-6 minutes.

Once we got our drinks, got our table and were able to relax - the experience was great. Our server was attentive and kind despite a very full dining room - the food was outstanding and plentiful. They graciously split a salad for us and made other substitutions without attitude and didn't hassle us as we chatted away the night, drinking a bottle of wine we brought with us, long after our plates were clear.

With some minor space/service improvements I think this place could be somewhere I would frequent when I am in San Fran.
author: J.Nichole S.

description:
Expensive but sub par

Read reviews and was sorely disappointed. No one to greet us at 6 pm on Tuesday. It took about 5 min for someone to come to the front and speak to us. Nice decor. Menu at restaraunt was a lot more expensive than the menu on the web. Already lost 2 stars. Great martini. Now were cooking. Good bread. I order lamb chops. 5 single cut lamb chops arrive and a glance indicates trouble. Way overcooked. I ask the server not to leave and cut into one and show her gray and dry, not med rare. She asks me to check another. More gray cardboard. She removes them and returns soon with another plate of 5. She asks me to cut in and it is very rare but edible so I nod OK. The next one is perfect but 2 others are so raw that the meat looks blue. The last one was med well. 
  wine list was good but markup high. I hate paying $60 for a bottle I buy for $21 in the store.
author: SR C.

description: worse escargot I have ever had!!! Greasy, oily meals throughout.  Seating downstairs on New Years Eve, less than desirable even as we were walked right in on a busy holiday. (Should have been the sigh) .Service was a fail. At those prices if a customer makes a statement about the quality of the food. Do something about it. At the very least, offer up some form of recognition for the inconvenience it has caused everyone. Not worth finding out what a disappointment this experience will be to you, your company or your wallet.
author: Lyric C.

description:
I've never written a review before, because I'm not a picky person, nor have I have ever felt the need to talk about a restaurant.  I'm usually the guy that comes back if its good, and if its not, no harm, I just don't go back.  But John's Grill in San Francisco has CHANGED ME.  

I need to be heard.  THIS PLACE IS THE WORST PLACE I'VE EVER BEEN TO!..and I'm not exaggerating.  This historic hole in the wall has been around for 100 years, and I can't see why.  My guess is like others who have reviewed, in that it traps poor unassuming tourists, (and people like me) who get reeled in based solely on its history.   

I had my first and surely my last experience of this dreadful place on Valentines Day.  The service is my number 1 complaint.  They just don't care.  Only after asking for my waitress did she suddenly appear.  When I asked her where our food was, she replied, " You guys too a long time to order that's why."  What kind of answer is that?  I was furious, but hungry so I decided to let it go.  After a total wait time of 55 minutes our order came out.  The only problem was that it wasn't our order.  Completely wrong!!!!...  That was it, I got up and spoke to the manager, and told him of my experience.  

To all those out there who are thinking about going to John's Grill

DONT!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Jason S.

description:
Boo! Hiss!  We were looking for a place near our hotel for seafood.  The concierge recommended John's Grill as a good place within walking distance for oysters and cioppino.
It was indeed a welcomed short walk, having put many miles in earlier in the day.  We arrived about 6:15, party of two, and were seated right away but the place was packed.  
The tables are placed VERY close.  We love oysters and the oysters of the day were Blue Points.  They also advertised a nice salad menu, seafood, steaks and my desired ciopinno.  There was also a nice, reasonably priced wine list.  I was feeling pretty good about the choice.
Unfortunately it all ended there.  We both ordered the oysters, DH ordered the house salad and steamed salmon and I ordered the caeser and ciopinno.  The table next to us was seated while we were waiting for our drinks.  The woman was sitting less than a foot away and wearing perfume so strong my eyes watered.  Then the oysters arrived.  I seriously question whether they were Blue Points.  They were about the size of a quarter, I wasn't feeling the love but then our salads arrived and they were actually pretty good.  Up to this point our waiter was fairly attentive but the place was really starting to get cranked.  Our main courses arrived.  My ciopinno was ultra bland with everthing but the scallops over done.  The waiter came by and I asked for more lemon and water.  DH dug in to his "steamed" salmon that was actually grilled to well done.  He is not a complainer, saying that the thicker parts were okay but he didn't eat the thinner parts.  I finished my wine and water and never received my requested lemon or refills on either wine or water.  
Normally I would have taken a stand on such a poor experience but it was so crowded and the situation so ridiculous that I just wanted out asap.
Our neighboring tables all ordered steak, since we were seated so closely there were no secrets and it was obvious that every singel table was unhappy with there over-done steaks.  I saw three steaks returned because they were not prepared properly. 
This was such a disappointment.  We were in San Francisco on business and don't have the option of meal do-overs.  This one was a lost cause and not an inexpensive mistake.  Don't waste your time or money here.  If you want to visit for the reputation then go in and have a drink but eat elsewhere.
author: Suzanne S.

description: Came here for dinner during an anniversary weekend with my love. The food was really secondary to the ambience and service. I loved the live music and candlelit tables. The cocktails were perfect, and though my red snapper was slightly underwhelming, my fiance's filet mignon was perfect.
author: Chelsea O.

description:
This place is iconic. On a point-by-point basis, it's not the most memorable dining experience, but overall it's wonderful. The food is not great, but it's better than average. The steaks are always done perfectly, the vegetables are fresh and the Woodford Manhattan is to die for! The selection is not all that broad, but it's more than adequate. The appetizers, the salads, the entrees, the steaks, the desserts are all what one is looking for at a grill. The clientele is eclectic, the wait staff is attentive, the prices are reasonable. 

On our last visit we both had the Roquefort salad, which is very, very Roqueforty, I had the seafood cannelloni, my husband had John's steak.  The cannelloni was exceptionally tasty, the vegetables were crispy, the steak was done perfectly.  We ended up having a great time drinking with some Red Sox fans at the table next to us and the server was just fine with that.

After all is said and done, this is one of my and my husband's favorite San Francisco restaurants. As another reviewer said, it is what it is.  It's not new, it's not trendy. But you always get the feeling that Mr. Hammett might be at the next table.
author: Constance E.

description:
Came here with a friend and he ordered ny strip (was overcooked and tasteless) and I ordered prawns with mushrooms (was ok).  Probably wouldn't come here again because it wasn't all that special.  

Pros: OK prawns and they give you a lot of them (sauce was a little salty)

Cons: our table was so small I kept kicking my friend every time I crossed my legs.
author: Amy C.

description: An authentic old time steak house. Historic, dark wood walls, tables close together, staff hopping. It took us back to the early years. Food was cooked right a nd the steaks were perfectly seasoned for flavor. The shrimp cocktails was cold with very large shrimp with a nice tangy cocktail sauce. The chocolate mousse was a great way to finish a great dinner.
author: Michael H.

description:
Meh is about the best word I can use to describe this place.  I expected more out of this place, given the location and history of the restaurant.

Stacy B went with the Sole which she said was average and at the end of the trip rated as her worst meal while in SF.  True to form I went with the Filet with peppercorn.  Steak was actually prepared perfectly and was quite tasty.

Where it all falls short is the atmosphere.  I understand that San Francisco is quite the busy and touristy town and you have to get in as many people as you can....however, of all the restaurants we visited while here this was certainly the closest that we sat to our neighbors.  I could literally reach out with my elbows and touch the person to my left and the person to my right.  I could hear word for word the conversations going on at the tables.  For a restaurant of this price you would expect a little more personal space.
author: Don B.

description: Let me start by saying that most of the food was lovely for the most part, but a bit inconsistent. We went as family so I will say that we were a large party. 1/3 of the steaks that were ordered were tough. The salads were good but nothing special. As a whole the experience would have been find based on the food but the service was terrible. The dining room we sat in was grossly understaffed and it was very clear in the service. Dinner took roughly 3 hours, and we didn't get to order our appetizers until 45 minutes after getting out seats. They seem to only carry California wines which is fine if the staff knows anything about it but they do not have keep a sommelier. Even when we described what we were looking for they our server could only tell us what lots of people order. We went through 4 really bad bottles before we talked to another staff member and finally got a good recommendation. This place came highly recommend and we were really disappointed.
author: Haley B.

description:
After 2-day camping at AWE (http://www.americanwhitewater.com), Coloma, we drove to SF by 4pm. We were going to check out Tad's but it's under renovation which was a disappointment to us since we came all the way from OC.

One of us claimed she knew where Cafe Claude was but couldn't find it.  We walked up and down and saw Macy probably 5 times before realizing we walked around in circle.  When we found Cafe Claude but they claimed they only have 4-burner and couldn't cater to 11 people and it would be a long wait. 

My sister suggested John's Grill, a steakhouse just across from the parking lot where we had originally parked. Most of us were tired, sored, and starving from the rafting trip.

We were seated at 3rd floor. It has quite interesting character to it. Very vintage and probably very 1900's with walls full of pictures from the old days. 

I had the chef's special red snapper. It was tasty. Some of my friends had the ribeye steak, porterhouse, lamb chop, seabass, etc. The seabass was excellent! Very buttery! My red snapper was pretty good just in the middle it got kinda of blend probably wasn't well marinated. lamb chop, ribeye and porterhouse were good! One of my friends had the steamed mussels. That was absolutely delicious especially you used its juice as dipping sauce for the bread! It was very tasty!

After dinner, my tummy is satisfied and I slept like a baby until next day!
author: Abbe W.

description: I only wish John's was as good as Dashiel Hammett's writing, or it's own website. This place has so much potential, but when we were there, in the fall of 2009, it was strictly a tourist trap. (I realize this is a late posting, but we just joined yelp, and our experice was burned into my brain so badly that I just wanted to write about it...)The food, in my case seafood, was undercooked and my Old Fashioned was watered. The only thing that makes it worth going there is the atmosphere and that was pretty good. Dark wood panelling and crisp white tablecloths give you the feeling that Hammett, or for that matter Sam Spade, could walk in at any minute. Next time we're in the City maybe we'll give them another try. The place has been around long enough that sooner or later the penduluum has to start swinging the other way...... I hope.
author: Bob B.

description:
I had the Fisherman's pasta and it was great. Very big plate and lots of seafood. I am not the biggest fan of American/Italian cuisine but this place did a very good job of pleasing my tummy.

My boyfriend had the Oyster Wellington which he said was good. It was definitely a smaller portion than my plate, so if you're supper hungry this might not be a choice for you.

Waitress and service was nice, place was clean and ambiance was cool. Pictures everywhere of people and celebrities. 

I think the food was reasonably priced for what they offered and I would go back again if I was in the mood for that type of food.
author: LinLin L.

description:
I came here tonight with my husband and his family and we were all pretty unimpressed.  I had a Jack Lalanne salad, which I thought was pretty tasty.  Supposedly there was some sort of blue cheese dressing, but I couldn't taste it.  For my main course, I ordered the filet mignon.  It seemed a little closer to medium than the medium rare I ordered, but that didn't bother me as much as the lack of seasoning.  The peppercorn sauce for the steak was pretty good and helped compensate for the lack of seasoning.  The steak came with a baked potato (you could choose between baked or mashed potato) and veggies (green beans, carrots, and squash).  I generally like my baked potato loaded with extra heart-attack-inducing fixings (butter, sour cream, cheese, bacon), but they only had butter and sour cream here.

Service was very friendly and attentive.  However, the restaurant was ridiculously cramped.  I could hardly squeeze into my chair without bumping into the people sitting at the table behind us.  The waitress could only access one side of the table, so she had to reach over me to do anything.  Basically, the seating arrangement here was the worst I have seen.  Our bill came out to ~$30/person, which in my opinion is overpriced for the quality of the food we received and for the overall experience.
author: Lisa C.

description: My friend and I had reservations for 7PM on a Wednesday.  We were seated down-stairs in an area where we jutted out into the aisle and asked to go upstairs and were quickly escorted up there. That is a much better area, much quieter than the noisy downstairs area.  The food was good, although I felt that my Martini was watered down, which I find more common these days and don't appreciate.  Does anyone else feel that way about mixed drinks? Overall, the food and service was good.  I would go back there, ordering a glass of wine with my dinner.  We stayed at the Westin, St. Francis Hotel and  could walk there--very convenient.
author: Sandra V.

description: Anderson wowed us! An incredible experience. My family and I went for a special occasion and our expectations were blown away. The swordfish, filet mignon, halibut, and salmon were all exceptional. Really made us feel welcome and taken care of.
author: Michelle M.

description: Average food, average service, average prices.  Nothing terribly remarkable about the place.  I had the clam chowder, and it was palatable; neither great nor awful.  Do yourself a favor and don't visit the website; with that awful background music, it's an exercise in obnoxious web design.
author: Matthew M.

description:
This place was packed as usual.  Our server was wonderful.  Too bad the meal was not.  A T-Bone is one of my favorite steaks.  Mine arrived undercooked.  I sent it back to be cooked more.  They replaced it completely, with a new streak.  By the time the second one was served, my companion had almost completed his.  This second steak was also undercooked, and full of gristle.  As I mentioned to the server, I burned up more calories cutting through the steak than I consumed.
We were offered tiny little Kahlua and Creams as a consolation.
Not a good experience.  Especially for the price!!
My overall impression is that "We are busy enough with tourists, we can lose a customer and not feel it"
author: John C.

description: Great steak house located in downtown. Yummy steak with homemade mash potato such a good combination. I would highly recommend.
author: Natacha W.

description:
I was in San Francisco for a week for work with a few coworkers and we decided to check this place out since our Hotel staff recommended it and it was close by.

The location is very convenient close to major shopping area. However, what transpired once we walked inside was nothing more than disappointment from the second we walked in. When we first walked in, there was no one to welcome us and seat us. When the host and hostess came over, the host picked up 2 menus and walked us over to the back where the staircase is and then quickly decided to say something and walk into the bar area. We walked up and were standing there for almost 4-5 minutes waiting for someone to seat us. Several servers came by us but not a single person asked us of we needed some help. My coworker finally went down to the reception/bar area to look for our host. He was informed that someone will seat us upstairs. The manager quickly came up and started walking us to a table and then stopped to run back and get the menu. 

Once we sat down, it took 8-10 mintes for someone to come over and take our order. I ordered a Filet Minion and  when ti came, I had to send it back for reheating. The net steak was actually burnt instead of medium. My coworkers steak was also barely warm and so were the mushroom and spinach side. 

For the price we paid, we were very disappointed with the service and quality of food at this place. We paid more than $60 per head for a lousy cold piece if steak. We definitely will not recommend this place to others.
author: Anks K.

description: Clam chowder was fantastic! Steak was just ok. Lukewarm.
author: Diane B.

description:
We don't come here often only because it is overcrowded and we can't really relax and talk. Seems to be a big hit with tourists, but locals wanting a more sedate repast at the end of a busy work day tend to go elsewhere. 
Has kind of an "old boy's" club feeling to it, with a beef-eating menu to match.
author: joan b.

description:
Went as a party of four. Others ordered the Fisherman's Pasta, Seafood Canneloni, and Cioppino. I got the ribeye. Everyone else's dish looked great, and they were pleased. I ordered my ribeye medium-rare, came out medium-well/well done. Brought out a new one in less than 4 minutes, and it was just blah. You pay $35 for a steak at a place that's apparently known for steak, you expect to be impressed. This steak was so bland, horrible cut, just a poor excuse for a ribeye. 

Atmosphere was good, service was good, just not impressed with meal at all.
author: Todd C.

description:
3 floors of San Francisco History. I wish I had more time to look at all of the historic photos of S.F.


 I had a excellent time at the 100 year anniversary. I had no idea this place was here.


 I don't eat steak or seafood. There were some vegetarian appetizers provided. I needed something to line my stomach after drinking martinis midday.


 I'll be back.
author: Infodiva B.

description: Mediocre and expensive food. Other than its location I'm not sure why this place is so busy. Then to top it all they levy a 19% surcharge (aka tip) for our party of five on the bill. I thought that was illegal?
author: Nigel M.

description:
The bar is great and the bartender has been here at John's for thirty something years and makes a mean Manhattan. 

The menu is small and I found it lacking. The salads were good but overdressed. The filets were only OK and the Sea bass was perfectly cooked but a little overpriced for what you got. 

Lastly, our server was TERRIBLE. Mila needs to be kinder and more welcoming.  Though she was attentive, she was impersonal, arrogant, and dismissive. It was alright overall but don't know if ill be back.
author: Kelsey B.

description:
Stopped here while on a weekend vacation. Atmosphere and menu looked good from outside.

Ordered an Anchor Steam (local brew) and the beers showed up warm. The server blamed the keg lines that were downstairs. Kinda dumb.

Also ordered the lobster ravioli. No flavor at all and they were in a very generic tasteless orange sauce. The ravioli looked like the costco special. Not what you would expect at steak place.

Then our steaks came. They were cooked to the correct internal temp, but burned to a crisp on the outside. So much so that I ended up cutting the outside off. It tasted like burnt charred grill. Very gross.

I should have trusted other reviews and gone elsewhere. Not worth the time or money.
author: Bart J.

description: Classic San Francisco; even Sam Spade ate here.  Good food, (particularly the chops), but the ambiance, the memorabilia, and just comfortable feel you get from a place that has been a regulars haunt for a long, long time.  Not to be missed-
author: kevin f.

description:
After a long day of shopping with some friends to update my ill-fitting and obsolete wardrobe (I never shop so it seemed like foreeever), we found ourselves with a need to eat something nice. From the sign, we deduced that it was over 100 years old, so it must be good. So we entered.

They offered us a choice of seating of downstairs or a live music entertained upstairs. Of course we chose the upstairs area. The choice of music was different from what I was expecting (it was even mellow-er than I thought it would be), but no complaints here. I ordered the porterhouse steak (the biggest one on their menu) medium rare and waited. 

Once it arrived, I found it to be cooked more or less right, although the tenderloin part of the cut was a bit overcooked. It was OK though, since the steak was GINORMOUS. I was defeated by it and couldn't finish the entirety of it. I was sad. I should of left the baked potato alone and finished the steak, but the potato was too good.

All in all, the meal was pricey. You pay for quality here. Considering I'm not really rolling around in money, I don't forsee any return trip here anytime in the near future. But I nonetheless enjoyed my visit here.
author: Andrew M.

description:
We went here on a whim while we were down town.  It looked classy and had a big sign "steaks" outside so I was immediately drawn in.

The decor was fitting for a steakhouse - low light, pictures on the walls, etc.  Nice and mellow.

We started with wine, a glass of pino noir each, which was great.  The waitress was really nice and very freindly without being overly fake friendly.  

I ordered the filet and the lady got something with prawns.  It came in perfect time where we got to enjoy our wine and chat a bit and just when we looked up to see if the food was coming...there it was.

The filet was great (come on...it's filet).  It came with a baked potato and mixed veggies.  Call me old fashioned but that is the perfect meal.

The wife loved hers but there was so much that she took half home and ate it the next day.  

We got slice of pecan pie and an eeexcellent latte for dessert.  That left a good taste in my mouth...figuratively and literally.

Would definitely go back next time we are in the area.
author: Brian N.

description: John's Grill has always left me feeling very full and very satisfied with the service. The building itself is such a cozy little place and the food is incredible. While certain steak cuts can be a little bland, other dishes such as the chicken or soups are SUPERB. It's a little on the pricey side so I only tend to go there on a special occasion.
