It truly is one of my favorite American restaurants and I will be going back time and time again!
author: Alaina K.

description: Was expecting much better but was disappointed. The salads are good, the service was great but the entrees were mediocre. I had the ciopino and my bf had some fish with some sort of crab or seafood mix on top of it. Wish the ciopino had more flavor and I didn't find any crab in it but plenty of shrimp. The fish entree reminded me of wedding banquet food with some sad veggies on the side and a baked potato.  We finished our bottle of wine and left our plate half empty and were still a little hungry. Our waiter surprised us with a complimentary dessert of custard and berries which was nice and creamy and not too sweet. Maybe if we ordered steak it would have been a different experience but this place is definitely not a good place for seafood.
author: Djoe p.

description: Was not at all impressed. The service was so fast it was clear they didn't want you to sit enjoy your food. They just want you to order quickly eat it and clear the table for another customer. Really thought a restaurant of this caliber would've understood the pacing of a fine meal. Insult to injury is that I ordered my steak medium and it arrived raw at the bone.  The waiter never came around to even check on it so I left much of it uneaten. Sad, but a restaurant living on reputation not reality.
author: Russ B.

description:
Had a meal with some business friends here and the food was great. The seafood cannelloni was really nice. One of the better eateries I've found in SF.

Service was a bit slow and the first and second floors were like saunas (waaay too hot) but third floor was fine.

People who had steak weren't overly impressed (one even putting tobasco sauce on it to add flavour). Seems this place is much better at the seafood dishes than the steak dishes, maybe they should rename to John's Seafood?
author: Guy F.

description:
Lobster ravioli was BLEH
Sea bass was just okay BLEH
but the white russian was yummy... I wasnt impressed at all... I could have made better sea bass at home...
author: Wenn C.

description:
greeted immediately. got a nice table and waiter(michael). abalonetti dore(calamari) was fantastic. rum/coke was good and strong. johns cabernet is good.
GREAT SPOT. MUCH BETTER THAN TADDICH AND LESS $$.
author: Jim R.

description: Loved the old school ambience and the music. If you don't like crowded restaurants, you might not want to have dinner here, but I enjoyed it. The seafood canneloni, roquefort salad and escargot were tasty! I would return to this San Francisco establishment again.
author: Elizabeth W.

description:
Do you ever wish Yelp had a broader or at least more finite rating scale? Like maybe 3 or 4 different categories with a 1-10 rating level for each? 

If we pretended this was true and there was a rating category for "humorous yet shitty dining experience" then our trip to John's would rate a 9 (4.5 on the current bullshit 1-5 scale). 

The lady and three of our tightest homies hit up the Sendak exhibit at the Chosen People's Museum (head upstairs to "Jews on Vinyl" for a visual and auditory kosher feast) and were looking for some body nourishment. With the spectre of Christmas perched over us like the Ghost of Stronger Economies Past we ended up picking John's Grill on a lark. 

Gotta stop following larks. Unless you want to wait 20 minutes for someone to finally stop by to bring you a basket of bread and, semi-explicably, maraschino cherry stems take your order and disappear for another half hour. 

Besides the cherry stems (if you're going to combine cocktail toppings with bread and butter at least give us unused toppings) we eventually got drinks (The Bloody Bridgits are tasty yet tiny and firmly "Girl Drink Drunk" category) but, after a long wait, were informed they were OUT of hamburger buns. They offered us toasted bread. Toasted Bread. The irony was, moments before entering John's I'd mentioned going home to make burgers and had it shot down due to everyone agreeing that House Burgers suck. Primarily because they're served on regular bread. 

We turned down the burgers but they brought them (late and on bread) and gave them to us gratis. And they were bad. Burnt (nobody ordered well done but that's what we got), with huge, unconquerable slices of onion. One of our team described it as "the kind of burger someone might offer you at a tailgate BBQ that you'd politely take a bite of and then ditch on the way to your seats". 

The fries. Well, good french fries are not rocket science. This isn't a perfectly grilled steak or a carefully seasoned mole. French Fries for gods-sake. We're in John's Grill where they filmed the fucking Maltese Falcon and we get ruined and I mean not even high on weed edible ruined french fries? I cry. I weep. And the one little cocktail sauce dish of ketchup they gave us? Bitch, please. 

And don't be suckered in by "Jack Lalanne's Favourite Salad". It may sound marvelous but, it's really a fat plate of bland with enough blue cheese dressing to choke a French lumberjack. 

Minor kudos to the waiter for taking shit in stride, dealing with a lot of peanut gallery sniping from us (which I will not apologize for given we  received plenty of strong drinks but inedible food). 

Enough shit went wrong we were able to wrap things around from crappy to hilarious. However, this is not a justification for going. My recommendation would be to grab burgers at somewhere decent such as Taylor's Automatic Refresher then head here and do the bar.
author: Milk N.

description:
John's Grill is magnificent. The last time I had dinner here, I had their patrale sole that was off the hook!! There must have been five pieces of sole on the plate. I could barely finish it all. But, because it was so good, I did. Excellent, excellent, excellent!! The time before, I had their Veal Champagne which is no longer on the menu. :'( :'( :'(. But when it was, damn, that was so good! 
Great food and great people working here.
author: Mark B.

description:
This place is a joke.  I went there Saturday night, and my initial impression was that the place has a funny odor.

I was with a very small group (3) from a convention.  It was very busy.  We were taken to the second floor.  We were seated and they brought water and bread to us right away.  The problem is, that's all that happened!!  No server ever stopped by in 25 minutes to take our order or to even tell us that they were running behind!

We sat and waited and waited and waited and finally we just got up and left, and no one tried to get us to stay.

Unbelievable!

None of us smelled funny, looked funny or were rude.  We couldn't figure it out.  We thought about complaining, but figured if they weren't smart enough to figure out how to serve us without us asking that they didn't deserve our business.

Needless to say, I won't ever be dining here.
author: Cranky Greg M.

description: I must've forgotten to write the updated review, but luckily, the establishment took care of this problem. I don't know if I'll come back but that's just me. The food was excellent quality.
author: Barry M.

description:
Like everyone says - this place is classic. You can feel the ambiance the second you walk in - like it hasn't changed in a century. Although it's a bit more quiet downstairs, the live music upstairs made for a great dinner atmosphere.

The food is good, not great. I ordered a filet which came out a bit dry, but their peppercorn steak sauce was excellent and made up for it. The desserts at John's really shine though - some of the best cheesecake I've ever had, and the presentation (if you're into that sort of thing) was top-notch.

Dinner for two was $125, which included two entrees, two desserts, some wine and coffee.

All in all, a dinner at John's is fun and memorable. Highly recommended for anyone who's visiting San Fran for the first time!
author: Nick S.

description: John's Grill is old school - good food, good service, good prices.  Good if you like red meat but the Jack Lalane chef salad is also good.  If you are looking for trendy head elsewhere. I wish I could eat here every week but I don't work downtown anymore.
author: Boris G.

description: Terrible food, tourist trap, expensive. Avoid. Mandatory 20% service charge to all bills.
author: Jess N.

description:
over priced and pretentious!  its dark and stuffy inside  - i never thought there would be a day when i would say there was too much "wood", but  here there is too much wood - big over sized wooden furnishings.

we had three drinks and they totalled 40.00 even.  that, my friends, is bullshittery!  

the barstools are rickety and crowded together and the bartender (while easy on the eyes) had the personality of a wet bar mop.

pass.
author: Peggy N.

description:
John's Grill is located right next to the Powell Street cable car turnarounds.  I came here for lunch on Friday without reservations and was pleasantly surprised to find the place pretty empty.

I ordered their broiled angus burger which came out to be $16 including taxes and tips.  Lord, that was one pricey burger.  It was good but not THAT good.  Fries were awesome and crispy just the way I like it - definitely better than the cardboard they serve at In-N-Out.

Only thing holding me back from giving this place 4 or 5 stars was our waiter.  Very inattentive and unfriendly.  I'm all for the "it's not the service but the company you keep that makes the food great" babble but seriously - how about a smile so I know you at least like your job?  If not, the pay check?  Don't make me shove a $100 bill into your mouth so you'll smile!  I'll do it!  And yes, that was a Scott reference from "Keeping Up With the Kardashians."

I gotta hang out less with the girlfriend.

==========

-2 Stars for lackluster service

*3 Stars out of 5*
author: Chris Y.

description: It's funny ... the signage does not represent the atmosphere inside.  Not a "grill" at all.  Dark wood and white linen table cloths does not say grill.  It was a nice surprise.  Yelp worked excellent.  Made a reservation with the touch of a button!!  The service was ok, not great not terrible.  Average veggies...the prawns were good and the red snapper too.  Everything is with a cream sauce, so know that.  The clam chowder was yummy.  They comp'd us dessert which was the flan, a nice treat.  Over all it was worth the stop.
author: Angel B.

description:
This place has got THE best lamb chops! 
My husband and I went to John's Grill based on a recommendation from our hotel concierge. 
It was a perfect atmosphere for our anniversary dinner. Romantic, kinda dark, and cozy. 
My husband ordered the lamb chops and I ordered John's steak. In case you didn't see above, the lamb chops were so delicious! The steak was also great, but if I had to go back I would definitely get the lamb chops. 
I also ordered the Pomegranate Martini which was a little strong but not overwhelming. 

The server was such a nice man! He was very helpful and checked up on us frequently but it didn't feel like he was hovering over us. 
All in all, we had a great time and have recommended it to everyone we know!
author: Laura R.

description: I live in the bay area for 12 years now and I didn't know about this homegrown little gem tucked in behind the Union Square. If you want a straight forward food with no fuzz go here. I ordered clam chowder which is delish and thick,  New York strip sand which, my friends ordered the same and ordered some salad. I will go back and will order the lamp chop next time.
author: Ria P.

description:
John's Grill is sadly over rated, I assume because of it's long history, the famous people who have eaten there and it's Union Square location - and there is a lot to be said for all of that.  It's kind of a fun place to go - ONCE.  After you get past the novelty, there is really not much else to get excited about.  The ambiance is loud and spread over three floors This is not a good first date or romantic place to go.  The bar area is very small - a drink at the bar before dinner is rally not an option.   

Service: The service at the front end seems good.  You are greeted by a doorman, and polite and professional  hostess's.  After that, serviced falls short very quickly.  Our waitress was not well versed with the wine selection, we were constantly tracking her down to order drinks, our water glasses were always empty and we had to ask for everything.  Generally poor service. 

Food: Average at best.  There are a lot of other much better seafood and steak places and prices were not that great considering the quality of the food.  Limited menu, and no vegitarian items.  All the dishes came to the table lukewarm.  Out of 8 of us, only one was 'happy' (not excited) with her dish - grilled swordfish.

Bottom line- I would not go back.  To many other great places nearby by.
author: Jake A.

description:
Recommended by The Concierge at The Fairmont Hotel Friday night last. Apparently one of the oldest restaurants in the city and the restaurant was mentioned the novel The Maltese Falcon by Sam Spade. 
The restaurant has alot of memorabilia from the movie. 

Great atmosphere and ambiance and we will go back just for that. We sat on the second floor (a bit cramped) but enjoyed the live guitar music. 

Fillet Mignon was excellent, but the new york was tuff and hard to chew! 

We'll go back to try the pork chops and seafood because we enjoyed the setting and atmosphere that much.
author: Kathleen A.

description: Excellent sea bass and halibut!!!  Good place for fish or steak.  Relaxed, casual atmosphere.
author: Rose L.

description: Great ambiance. The main floor dining area was smaller than I expected and cozy. I arrived around 2:30 on a Saturday when only a few were at tables. Went to the small bar and ordered a Manhattan. They had only one brand of Rye Whiskey. They made the drink without bitters, cherry or vermouth....rather a loutish drink if you ask me. My friend asked for a Gin Ricky. They had no clue what that was.... Now for some old time steeped in tradition bar this was clearly a rather shabby performance. Went upstairs to see the Hammett collection behind glass. Another cheap trick. The books in the display case were all current or recent editions. They couldn't even spring on a replica of the original Maltese Falcon. Very cheesy and cheapo. And after reading the reviews I was loath to put in an order for steak since they aren't able to cook them to order. I'd say this place needs new management and an upgrade in their Hammett display.
author: steve d.

description:
It's been here for over a century.  John's Grill is a classic and "yes" it is the home of the famous maltese falcon movie prop from the old Humphrey Bogart flick.  Located in Union Square my wife and I decide to go here for a few drinks.
It's been said that John's Grill is the place for a killer steak or lamb chops.  I was just there for a few cocktails before heading back to our hotel.  In town on vacation, my wife said this was one of the places we needed to go to.  When we come back to San Francisco I am definitely ordering a steak dinner there. 
Back in the far left corner is a small bar among the many tables spread throughout the restaurant.  The bar is so small that there are probably only eight or nine bar stools to sit in.  Sitting down at the bar my wife and I order some screwdrivers.  Talking to the bartendar we find out that he's been working there for over 30 years.  Good stuff.
 I don't know how long we sat there but we were feeling great after.  Definitely a great place to go for cocktails.  Oh yeah, forgot to see the maltese falcon which I found out later was upstairs.  Didn't know there was a upstairs.
author: Paul S.

description:
We were walking around to find a good spot for dinner when we came across this restaurant. There was a lady in front holding menus and soliciting guests. That should have been the first warning but she was very nice and the place has been open since the early 1900's so we figured it would be good.

It was not.

The food was mediocre at best all across the board. So was the service. Everything is overpriced for what you get and that's a shame. The ambiance however was somewhat interesting as it seems nothing has changed over the long history and you do feel like you are back in time. They had live music in the form of a guitarist who just strummed basic cords. Not really what I expected from a big city like SF. The performer kept staring around too while playing and it was intimidating since the room is so compact and he is right next to you.

All in all, we were disappointed and agreed that we've had better experiences and would not go back to John's again.

Too bad, we were hoping for a good SF experience there.
author: Edson H.

description: Manager John was rude and disrespectful.  We visit SF every month and will not go here again.  We didn't even stay to eat because this person, who is suppose to set a good example for the establishment,  had terrible customer service!!!
author: J T.

description:
Our friend was having a landmark birthday and his wife wanted an iconic "old man" type of restaurant to celebrate. Enter John's Grill. It's definitely a SF icon and it certainly has that older gentleman type of appeal. Lots of references to Maltese Falcon and tons of pictures of movies stars from a bygone era. Fun stuff to look at. 

Our large group was seated on the third floor, which took away from the main floor ambiance, but proved to be a great spot, as we were able to be as loud and rowdy as we pleased.

After reading some of the yelp reviews, I wasn't expecting much in the way of fabulous food, but was excited to take in the history and atmosphere. I started out with a cocktail that seemed worthy of John's Grill: a Manhattan and something I never order, but the occasion called for a stiff, old school drink. I have no idea what to compare it to, but it was strong and good, complete with two cherries. 

I couldn't resist the Jack Lalanne's salad which was chock full of Dungeness crab and shrimp and was way overdressed, however, I'm a sucker for drowning my salad in creamy, caloric-heavy dressing, so I was happy. 

The fisherman's pasta was a huge portion of linguine with salmon, crab, snapper, shrimp and clams bathed in a heavy cream sauce. It was way too much food and so rich due to the overflowing pool of cream sauce. For some reason I also opted for a side of the creamed spinach. There seemed to be an overly creamy theme at John's. 

At the end of the overly rich, overly creamy meal, I found myself in a food coma and in need of a brisk walk around downtown SF. 

Great place for a drink, but I think my dining days at John's Grill are over, however, I know where to go when I'm in need of a creamy meal.
author: Lee H.

description:
The dinner was excellent. The service too. The waiter really seemed to like his job and did not refill the glasses too often, so we could enjoy our bottle of Cabernet Sauvignon blanc instead of gulping it down like crazy!
The grilled Red Snaper and the Canneloni with "frutti di mare" were tasty and the portion size was really good. Same for the house made vanilla ice cream with berries of the season.
This is not a creap place to eat, but the prices are reasonable for what you get regarding food and service. There was always a line up, while we sat in there. Reservation is highly recommended expecially on the weekend.
author: David P.

description: While I eat here a few times a year, it's always for lunch. I tried it for dinner for the first time taking some clients last week. John's was a bit of a disappointment for dinner. They put us in very tight quarters for a party of 7. It resulted in the waiter not having enough room to maneuver and I started the dinner taking a full glass of ice water to the crotch. They pour a generous martini from the bar and the raw oysters were quite good but the rest of the meal was uninspiring and the sides of baked potatoes and badly cooked green beans and carrots might have well been left off the plate. I plan to stick with John's for lunch in the future for their great petrale.
author: Trevor F.

description:
I've been coming here since 2004 whenever I'm in town with colleagues who want to eat here and have viewed it as a fair to middling steakhouse and nothing to write home about.  I've gone through its menu from the seafood to the steaks and while it was okay, its signature steaks of any cut have always been lacking in the top quality I've come to associate with true steakhouses worthy of the appellation.  Yeah, it's got all that history and that ambiance but for a restaurant, I'm more concerned about the food.

That said, I was here just last week for a solo Valentine's Day meal and sampled their Escargot with Garlic Cream and Roast Prime Rib.  I wasn't impressed with either.  A good escargot dish is cooked in a sauce redolent with the aromas of its ingredients.  The "garlic cream" tasted like a cream sauce with a hint of garlic and that's it. How disappointing!  Then the Roast Prime Rib, which I'd assumed to be carved off a huge chunk of roasted prime rib turned out to be a prime rib steak that had been sliced, then broiled in an oven.  There's a difference between the two:  The former is sliced off a bigger roast has the edges nice and crispy with the center red and juicy that's worthy of a true steakhouse  while the latter is brown all over and worthy of a ratty corner diner trying to cut costs yet fake out a customer into believing they're getting top quality product. And for $35???  Surely they jest for such subprime preparation quality!  Compare the pictures of what I ate with the pictures of Roast Prime Rib served by House of Prime Rib in San Francisco or Ben Benson's in New York to see how a true Roast Prime Rib should look like!!!  Service was spotty in that the waitress did go out of her way to make me a creamed horseradish sauce but she kept disappearing on me.  Finding her after the initial order submission was sometimes an exercise in frustrated head swiveling even though the third floor area was kind of small and there was a kitchen on the same floor so she couldn't have vanished into the kitchen (the door was open so I could see the chefs "doing their thing").  

This is absolutely appalling and a new low for John's Grill.  I don't think I'll be back after this--over the years of patronage, their food quality has just taken a nosedive right into the dirt and has just become nothing but a tourist trap.  What a pity because they were pretty decent once upon a time way back when...
author: Tanster M.

description: Good food, good service. Pricey, but then it is SF!   $56 for one:  fish entre with one glass of wine and coffee, including tip.
author: Ann L.

description: Very disappointed in the NY strip steak and baked potato.  Not worth the price.  Service was good, but veggies were cold and hard.  Free bread not very note worthy
author: Steve R.

description:
Mediocre food, terrible drinks, great history

The night we went the first floor was a busy and as quiet as a bus station.

The food is good in terms of 1955. Meat & potatoes. Overcooked string beans

The drinks are bad. The house special Brigid's Blood is  way too sweet, and unbalanced.

We spent $55 per person, wished we'd gone somewhere else.  We've heard about John's grill forever, no we can cross it off our lists.
author: George S.

description:
Ummm this place was ok

We were walking right past it to get to a local sushi joint but my friend was craving steak so we stopped here instead. The restaurant itself is really nice. They have a nice lil jazzy decor going on. So I ordered their filet mignon and it was alright, nothing amazing, Ive actuallly had better. The steak lacked on the seasoning, it tasted very bland. Their baked potato on the other hand was really good and super soft. My friend ordered their rib-eye steak and it was not good lol i felt bad for him since he was the one wanting steak =/ It was super chewy and not cooked right. He managed to eat it tho since he was pretty hunry. The service was really good. Our waitress was always around. 

Overall this is a pretty expensive restaurant and I wouldn't have mind paying if the food would of actually been better. 

Would I come back? Maybeee but i would try something else.
author: Fanny F.

description: Great atmosphere (especially for a movie geek like me), awesome service, and good food.  Honestly, I've had better swordfish back home in the Midwest, but it was still delicious, and I'd highly recommend going here at least once.
author: Alex O.

description:
Hands down BEST clam chowder I have ever had! I used to work around the corner and had lunch here at least once a week! I sent many a tourist here for the Chowder, some even came back to thank me! 

They have a great salad too, the Jack Lalane I think? With the crab? OMG, mouth watering! So good!
author: Rob S.

description: It was ok. Waited too long for our food. The lobster raviolis were pretty good & the ambiance was nice but overall it was ok a little dissapointed. I wouldn't recommend this place to anyone it was overrated and just ok. :/
author: Elizabeth R.

description: Fast service, but got order wrong and food was soaked in oil.   I ordered a spinach salad with oil and vinegar dressing.  They brought the oil and vinegar mixed up in one small bowl and the salad was covered in a very thick oil dressing.   I should have sent it back but I was with someone who was in a hurry.   Then came the red snapper.   That too was drowned in a heavy, salty oil as was the vegetables.  The coffee was OK, but no one ever came by to ask if I wanted a refill.
author: Ed W.

description: Saw this place while walking by. I tried the salmon and it was cooked well (very tender). My friend tried the fried seafood platter and loved it. My only compliant was the creamed spinach was not good (came out watery). Atmosphere was nice and overall would try it again.
author: Samuel W.

description:
Old San Francisco service with white table clothes and jazz in the background. It was charming.
Service was good and steaks (we all ordered the rib eyes) were good.
Nothing spectacular on their dessert menu so we skipped it.
author: Karen F.

description: Came here on a saturday night and it was fairly busy. This three story place can accomodate all sorts of groups, as ours had 10. The food was fanastic, one of the best salmon I ever had. I would say the price was decent due to its location, but the portions were also decent. I had the bloody brigid, which is the house drink, its very sweet and girly, so as a man, it should be avoided. The service was fast  The guy at the front door was nice enough to hail us some cabs.
author: Phan H.

description:
I say 3.5 stars for this place.
I came here with a group of co-workers for lunch. There's one guy in the group who comes here every once awhile and says he still comes here for hearty food. I could tell from looking at other people's plates that they gave generous portions. I ended up splitting half of my food with another co-worker. So we tried their signature salad - JACK LALANNE'S FAVORITE SALAD, Clam Chowder, and FRUITS DE MER. I enjoyed the salad especially with a chunk of avocado/crab and the VINAIGRETTE DRESSING was divine. The soup was creamy and had a good flavor. I was so full from the salad and soup that I couldn't finish the pasta. The seafood was drenched in the tomato cream sauce and noodles prepared just right (not too starchy or soft). I wouldn't make a special trip here, but the food and service is 3.5 stars.
author: Candace F.

description: Wife and literally stumbled on this place....we decided to give it a try and are glad we did. The atmosphere was very old school mob movie...not cheesy. The food was excellent...try the lobster ravioli. Th only issue was our waitress was nice but new...a lil slow at times. We will be back to eat on our next trip.
author: Jeff D.

description: 3.5-4 stars for the food; it is very good but stops short of being truly great.  Very solid, unadorned meals without complaint, in an historic SF atmosphere.  Menu has reasonable selection even beyond the steaks.
author: Rob J.

description: Not what we were expecting given other good reviews. Dinner seating was uncomfortably tight, loud, and ambiance was chaotic.Stay away from the high traffic areas (there are many). While my cioppino was delicious....by boyfriend's "porterhouse" was nothing of the sort. When asking if a t-bone was inadvertently served, the waiter sarcastically and rudely suggested we didn't know what we were talking about. It was by far the thinnest and Porterhouse we had EVER seen. Turns out we were right (like we didn't already know). According to the USDA a true porterhouse has a minimum of 1.25 inches thick. His was not even close to 1 inch (t-bones are minimum of 1/2 inch). We felt bulldozed and unhappy with the service. The couple sitting next to us had their own complaints with the food and service as well. Been there....done that....will go elsewhere the next time we are in town.
author: S R.

description: I went here recently with a group (on a budget).  We were given the 3rd floor -- presumably a 'private' area, but there were many other groups there, many tourists.  Very crowded and noisy.  Hoping that it was a decent steak house, I ordered the basic steak.  Salad was definitely not up to San Francisco standards:  basic lettuce with a few tiny shrimp (frozen) thrown in.  Steak (requested medium) was rather over-cooked and tough with very little flavor.  Portion was generous.  Best thing was the dessert of vanilla ice cream and fresh berries.  I would not recommend this restaurant to friends or visitors to SF.  Very much a thing of the past; dreary, dark decor, etc.
author: Mary W.

description: Can't find more character than this place. Quintessential San Francisco is found in every creaky booth. The menu and the pictures on the walls are just as interesting as the food.
author: Brian J.

description:
We decided to eat at John's Grill because it was the only decent-looking  place we could find that was still serving at almost 9:30 pm. The downstairs was packed and we were glad to be seated in a cute alcove, away from the hustle and bustle.We ordered quickly--i ordered John's steak and my spouse went with the seafood cioppino, which was to die for. It was absolute perfection! 

My steak, on the otherhand, was very tough and would have been sent back were it not for the late hour and the fact that I was extremely hungry! I believe that when you pay thirtysomething dollars for a steak, you are entitled to a tender, flavorful piece of meat. John's steak was a BIG disappointment.

In spite of this, I thoroughly enjoyed the ambience of the place, as well as all the movie memorabiia. I will most likely return, only next time I will order the seafood cioppino!
author: Lee G.

description:
Do you ever end up in a somewhere in SF, clearly a tourist trap, and you wonder how the hell did this happen? The servers smirk at the patrons, asking them where there from, what brings them to the city. And you want to shout "NO! I live here! I normally wouldn't be here if it wasn't for the relatives! I had no choice!"...And then you realize NOT being a tourist and being there is worse then the truth. So you give up, pretend to enjoy this little excursion, while silently seething...

Oh, that's just me?
author: S F.

description: This restaurant is cool because it's been here so long, like a historic landmark.  It's pretty casual and the prices reflect that.  Great service and live piano music on a Tuesday night.  The food was good, not fantastic, but good.  Great clam chowder and a never ending basket of delicious sourdough bread!  The tables were a little too close together.  We were totally eavesdropping on the conversation at the next table.
author: Alexa O.

description: This is what San Francisco used to be in a business lunch sense of things...go for the ABALONETTI DORE, about as close as you will ever get to abalone in this lifetime...of course...this must be proceeded with a dry martini up...you will be living!...
author: Jay F.

description: Came here last night and got the Rib eye.... that was one of the best pieces of meat I have ever had. Perfectly cooked at medium rare. The service is amazing.
author: James W.

description: Classic San Fran, you go here because its an institution in San Francisco the food is average and so it the service but it has a very cool old school vibe.
author: Chris P.

description: Hangtown Fry and a pint of Anchor, hells yeah.
author: Stuart M.

description:
John's is ok, but not that great. It feels like a place that is using it's history to draw in tourists rather then continuing to make great food to draw people in.

I started with the Clam Chowder which was very good. The Porterhouse was cooked as directed but still seemed a little dry for some reason - thought the pepper sauce was quite good, use it sparingly though, you don't want to over power the flavor of the steak. The accompanying baked potato was over done and the vegetables (beans and carrots) were completely forgettable. For dessert I ordered the pecan pie, which i received after about a 20 minute wait. Unfortunately it was served cold - as in it might have just come out of a refrigerator. It first looked like a tiny slice, but it's pretty rich and I'm not sure if i would have wanted a much bigger slice anyway. The whipped cream that comes with it is fantastic though. 

All in all it was an ok meal and the history of the place (including the Maltese falcon replica on the second floor) make it an interesting place to eat but I wouldn't go out of my way to eat there and if I were going to a steak house you'd probably find me at Alfred's or Izzy's before you found me here.

For those watching your budget: soup, entree, dessert and wine will run you 50-60 per person before tax.
author: Russ C.

description:
What a waste of time and money! Made a reservation and upon arriving was barely acknowledged, restaurant was stuffy, loud and cramped.  We were shown to our table and sometime after squeezing the 4 of us into our "booth" the cranky waitress appeared and wanted to take our order for apps as well as dinner, got the impression she was in a hurry.  Food arrived, fish was horrible couldn't eat it, steak was overlooked and then they had the gall to hurry us out.

Don't go here, there are much better options in SF at $33.00 a plate.
author: Debi W.

description:
The Maltese Falcon, you will recall, is a great example of a film MacGuffin - "a plot element that catches the viewers' attention or drives the plot of a work of fiction". Here it is useful as a metaphor for John's Grill. Just as Sam Spade discovered, this falcon is worthless lead.

I had a Clam Chowder and a Caesar Salad after seeing entree prices that just looked way too high after a quick scan of the tables around me. Both were average and would have been fine in a diner for around $5-6 but priced too high at $9 and $10 respectively. Chowder was almost all cream, very few chunks of potato or clam. Salad very dull with no anchovies, few croutons (those out of a box) and black olives. The bread didn't seem that fresh. Table was tiny and so close to the one behind that chairs bumped. 

Service was good, and that's the nicest thing I can say about the place. Ambience is not "classy" and noise level is not "average" but dress certainly is "casual".

If you're staying in town briefly, maybe in Union Square at a big hotel, then the prices of the food and the dress sense of your fellow patrons (lots of shorts, trainers and hats - people, this is not a sports bar) might be OK. But please consider that there is so much better to be found. If you're reading this then you're more than capable of finding those places. I wish I'd looked harder.
author: Adam E.

description: When in SF come here for lunch or dinner... The menu is amazing..service excellent and attentive. It doesn't get any better than this.
author: Mark A.

description:
(January)
Nish: Oooh, this is the place with the Maltese Falcon.
Stephy: Oh cool, let's go in.
Nish: Nah, we'll hit it later.

(February)
Nish: Oooh, this is the place with the Maltese Falcon.
Stephy: Oh cool, let's go in.
Nish: Nah, we'll hit it later.

(March)
Nish: Oooh, this is the place with the Maltese Falcon.
Stephy: Oh cool, let's go in.
Nish: Nah, we'll hit it later.

(April)
Nish: Oooh, this is the place with the Maltese Falcon.
Stephy: Oh cool, let's go in.
Nish: Nah, we'll hit it later.

(May)
Nish: Oooh, this is the place with the Maltese Falcon.
Stephy: Oh cool, let's go in.
Nish: Nah, we'll hit it later.

(June)
Nish: Oooh, this is the place with the Maltese Falcon.
Stephy: Oh cool, let's go in.
Nish: Nah, we'll hit it later.

(July)
Stephy training new CMs during a week in SF.
Stephy: So where do you girls wanna go for lunch today?
Farrah A: I want a baked potato.
Leighann F: Oooh yeah, that sounds good, comfort food!
Melody L: I want something with SF history
Maria A: Yeah, that sounds cool.
Katie S: Yeah!
Stephy: Doh! I know just the place!! Finally!! :)

And so my little training ducks followed Mama Duck to John's Grill for some OG SF grub in the form of baked potatoes, Jack LaLanne salads, deelish burgers and clam chowda! All of the food was great and the environment definitely hits the cool old school vibe home. 

During lunch it's filled with business peeps on laptops and on the day we were here, I am convinced there must have been some sort of senior citizen convention in town. I say this because I aged about 40 years waiting to use the bathroom with 4 little old ladies ahead of me. Luckily for me, the wait gave me a chance to peep the much talked about replacement Maltese Falcon statue compliments of the Academy of Art down the street.

Very cool. And hey, even though I live here now, i get to be a geeky tourist sometimes.
author: Stephy S.

description: Lunch with our son and co-workers mid-week in April.  We were tourists / they are regulars for lunch.  We all had Jack's Favorite Salad and Manhattans (well the three of them had Manhattans for lunch while H & I had ice tea).  The salads were large and filling.  Atmosphere, clubby and business-like at lunch.  Liked it a lot.
author: Geralyn H.

description:
Let's see, what's the worst thing about  this craptastic place?   Is it the overpriced and badly prepared food?   Or perhaps the  simplistic, badly selected (for the food) and overpriced wine list?  Could it be the lackadaisical service that one finds in tourist traps?  

Nope, my vote for why this place sucks goes for the brouhaha around the replica of the movie prop for the Maltese Falcon.  

First they buy a replica of the damned thing and get a boatload of press around the fact that Dashiell Hammett mentioned the restaurant ONCE in his fiction.  

Then the damned thing gets stolen (good riddance say I) and they get more press over that.

Then, they pay to have ANOTHER replica made that looks even LESS like the original prop from the movie, and hold ANOTHER press conference to announce the damned bird's arrival.

Give it a rest and learn to cook....
author: Cheesemonger Jeff D.

description:
We came here for our dinner on our anniversary and what a disappointment it was.  My husband ordered the seafood pasta and the waitress said it was good.  It was a $30 entree so we would expect it to be extraordinary.  When I tasted it, it was so bland, kind of watery, and the noodles were overcooked.  It looked like someone in kindergarten cooked it and just threw it on a plate.  It didn't even look appealing.  Since my husband wanted to give it chance, he asked for more parmesan cheese - didn't help.  We had to send it back - thank goodness.  $30 for a pile of crap!  

The only good thing I had here was the drink.  Even the clam chowder was just ok - they used green peppers as one of the ingredients and it sort of threw the flavor off and it was lukewarm.  Soups are supposed to be hot and steamy!  I do not recommend this place.  The seats are upright and the place was gloomy.  The funniest thing we saw was an old lady at the bar drunk off her butt trying to pick up on any man who sat next to her.
author: The Critic 1.

description:
I used to love this place but now have boycotted for life.  Their food is okay, it's overpriced and the dining room smells.  The service is average.  

I also have a bad taste in my mouth from the owner.  I came in to consult for owner and after many hours of work, 3 meetings, he took my work to his existing provider for a match of price and service. After working with a company that has been robbing you for  years and you still give them the opportunity to keep your business for convenience, I have to question your integrity.  

Nonetheless, business is business and I came in for lunch after the fact.  When I came in the owner needed to be reminded who I was then had my party seated in a cramped space with dirty silverware and glasses.  Now I never expect anything for free but I saved this d bag $2500 a month and he didn't even give me his business. I was hoping he was a decent person and would send over a comp'd glass of champagne.  He didn't. I refuse to patronize a restaurant where the owner can conduct business the way he does.
author: Frankie F.

description:
If I had written about the meal 10 months ago here, it would've been five stars.  Alas, this meal was not so deserving.  

A little background:
I have a good mate from Belfast, Northern Ireland.  His parents and Auntie and Uncle came out here last year and wanted a solid "meat and two veg" meal.  I sent them to John's and they had a great time.   So good a time that they ate there at least twice in their 4 day trip.  That's how good it was.

They come back for my friend's wedding 10 months later and where do they want to go, now with even more relatives?  You guessed it, John's Grill.  Mate calls up and asks if they can make a reservation for 13, fully realizing this is a tall order.  "No problem!" is the reply.  So we show up at the appointed time to find...two tables (round) near each other.  Now realize this is an extended family that has come from a total of four different countries to be together.  They want to sit at the same damn table, but not wanting to rock the boat we just push them together into a "8" shape.  Okay, we got past that.

Move on to ordering drinks.  Waiter screws it up and it takes 30 minutes to get the drinks right.  Another 15 minutes goes by until we can flag down a waiter that is willing to take our order.  We all order quickly enough as we have been there 45 minutes already and have memorized the menu by now.

Another hour rolls by.......

Finally the food comes out.  My potato is hard as a rock from being under a heat lamp for god knows how long, the green beans are like smooshed worms, and my steak is cold.  When I say "cold" I don't mean, "not piping hot" I mean COLD.  As in, "has been sitting on a counter and not under a heat lamp for over 20 minutes".  And its not just my steak that's cold.  Its everyone's.  A total of 13 ruined meals.  

We call the waiter over and his response is, "we only have one chef tonight, sorry".  Then he walked away.  I raised the point that they seem to have plenty of waiters, and last time I checked its the waiters that bring the food, not the cooks.  Basically the food was rendered inedible, at least when you're paying over $30 a plate.

We complained again to a waiter whom called down to the front desk to the manager? owner? someone? who told us this gem: "You have two options.  We can reheat the food, and you can pay full price, or you can leave, and we will still charge you full price."  Neither of these was acceptable to us.  We worked out a compromise in that we would pay for our drinks and appetizers (fine.  No argument there, we were prepared to do that all along), and we wouldn't be charged for the steaks.  No problem.  We even left a 20% tip as the waiters were actually really nice about it all.  

My friend and I went down to talk to the owner/manager guy personally, but when we got down to the first floor, we were informed by a waiter that the guy had immediately hung up the phone and ran (ran!) across the street to his car and drove away before we could talk to him.

Talk about cowardly behavior.  The waiters all to a man told us that that is his standard procedure when faced with a dispute.  He gets in his car and goes off and hides for an hour or so until things cool down.  

Now, is that any way to run a business?
author: Jake S.

description:
i like this place but they do trade heavily on the maltese falcon. i was in here a while back with an out of town friend who insisted on going to john's so we could order 'lamb chops, baked potato, fried tomatoes and make it snappy' and that's just what we did. it was okay but not great. that was hardly the point. the point was doing it.

of course, in our glee to relive some movie and literary magic, we didn't look at the menu where there is the maltese falcon special we just ordered. i'm sure no one does. so the first time they see that gary danko price tag on their woolworth lunch counter meal, it's too late.

we laughed uproariously at the inflated price. and to think that pat o'shea's mad hatter (rip) had the slogan 'we cheat drunks and tourists'.

still, we agreed that if we had it to do over again, we would.
author: Brian B.

description: I was driving back from the airport this week and decided to stop in SF for lunch,  A good friend of mine is always telling me to eat at John's Grill, it is her favorite restaurant in SF.  Well it did not disappoint, WOW from the perfectly made cocktails to the perfectly cooked fish I am now a HUGE fan.  Can't wait to have visitors in and bring them with me.  My mouth is watering thinking about that burger! My husband would only let me have one bite, might need a shopping trip to Union Square this week to feed this craving.  YUMMY!!!
author: Lisa R.

description:
Oh San Francisco, you are becoming just too trendy for me.  I remember reaching that point in my youth when all my friends suddenly became too cool for school.  I feel similar growing pains when a place like John's Grill gets ripped on Yelp.  This spot is not on the same level as the Slanted Doors, or the Boulevard's or the Gary Danko's.  It is not swank or scenester.  The interior is dark old school (think Tadich, House of Prime Rib) and full of grandparents.  The menu hasn't been changed in 100 years.  The steaks are cooked in an old-fashioned style with the criss-cross grill marks.  The cuisine is buttery and hearty--not the place to come if you're on a diet.  There is a dust around the picture frames.  

If you consider yourself a real San Franciscan I would recommend eating here once, especially if you are a Dashiell Hammet enthusiast.  The dinner portions are huge, but their steamed clam appetizer is a great starter.  Probably their most famed dish is the John's Steak.   I had the Chicken Jerusalem (grilled and topped with mushrooms, artichokes and a creamy white wine sauce) which was fantastic.  

Our service was great, though I felt a little rushed.  I think John's Grill is pricey, so I would save it for a special occasion...even better if it involves relatives.

LIVE JAZZ!
author: Kerry D.

description:
Second time going here after a long day of work and there was only once reason why my coworkers and I picked this place. The Seafood Cioppino! Having a great bottle of wine and stuffing myself was bread that was soaked in the soup base kept my stomach all happy after a long day of work. 

It's nice to see an old fashion place still open for business these days considering how many others are closing down. I do have to agree, the price of the dishes is expensive. Also I swear the cioppino bowl use to be filled up a lot more... or maybe I was just too hungry
author: Derrick L.

description:
The thief who stole the Maltese Falcon stole my waiter!

I came here with a party of 10 for a birthday celebration.   The staff almost completely ignored us.  Things we had to frantically, almost comically, flag down anyone who would listen and ask for:
- silverware
- drink menus
- food menus
- chairs (for late arrivals)
- where our food was long after ordering it
- where our drinks were long after ordering them
- can we please order more drinks?
- seriously, can we order more drinks?
- can someone please clear our plates?
- dessert menu
- the check
- any service whatsoever

Oh, and the food was low quality, bland, and really expensive....think Lucky Penny at $30 bucks an entree.  Yikes!   After paying the bill I had this uneasy feeling as if someone had just stolen money from my wallet.  The menu also contained a  "$20 minimum charge per person"  footnote....real classy.    

Another thing I couldn't help noticing... the predominance of people inappropriately dressed for San Francisco weather...Read: Tourists.  I'll don't think I'll ever understand why tourists are drawn to bad restaurants like bees to honey, but this phenomenon may explain why a horrible place like John's can continue to pay for electricity....I can assure you it's not because of return visits by locals.

When I arrive in hell, I'll be dining at John's Grill every night.  Until then, I'll be enjoying dinner at San Francisco's good restaurants.
author: Peter G.

description:
- food: lack of quality ingredients
- atmosphere: historic
- staff: adequate 
- price: way over-priced

additional info:
- this restaurant seems to take advantage of tourists
author: J. B.

description: I ate here before and thought it was good. Returned last night. Server was too busy. Food was poor. The Seafood pasta tasted old and no flavor. The Snapper dish was gloppy and uneventful. So for alot of money it was a waste.
author: Ann P.

description:
This place is a classic. The food is fine; it's popular and known; the drinks are good portions; etc. Prices are reasonable. Friendly service.

The problems are what you'd expect. Jammed with tourists at all times, very cramped, noisy, and there is just no parking anywhere close. Menu also is surprisingly limited. 

Cool to go to, so you can say you went. Part of  San Francisco history, with the Sam Spade and Maltese Falcon angle. Beyond the Dashiell Hammett connection, a worthwhile venue.
author: Frank W.

description:
Fuck yes.

ok well, first things first.   i cant say ive ever really eaten here in the sense that i actually sat down like a lady and ordered an entree and didnt trip on the stairs on the way to the can.  But i did show up for their 100th Anniversary 8 cent drink extravaganza...and just when you think you arent gonna pay any less for a bev...they were FREE.  not even 8 cents...i saved a quarter today.  

im in no place to judge this establishment as it operates on the reg, but the amazing Friday afternoon i just had ..complete with awesome martinis and an exeptional array of appetizers - well, really...the place cant be all that bad.

if theyre handing out free drinks and steak like it aint no thang..then i cant hate on this place.  i just cant.

And if its good enough for Alice Cooper than its certainly good enough for your ass.
author: Kirsten S.

description:
On vacation from Houston, TX. Aweful just doesn't explain the experience here. We came here from a hotel concierge referral for steakhouses that cater for "families". We had a party of 7 people (4 adults, 3 kids), they had us walk up 3 flights of stairs and put us in the corner table. There were 5 wait staff there and after 15 minutes, I finally walked up to ask if anyone was gonna take our drink orders. Our assigned waiter wasn't any better. He didn't greet us, had no menu recommendations, and was only around to take our order and at the end of the dinner to give us our check. 

Even a few minutes after ordering my steak, I wanted to change my order to a seabass instead, but he shot it down and said he'd just punched in the order and cannot do anything about it. When our steaks came out, boy did it SUCK. I had my fair share of steakhouses and this was one of the worst I've ever had. The waiter felt insulted when I asked for A1 sauce to compliment the bland steak I had. Halfway through my steak, I was ready to leave. I give it a 1 star rating only because the other dad had the chef fish special was not bad. What a waste of time.
author: Denki G.

description:
Every time I drink out of my souvenir glass from John's Grill, I throw up in my mouth a little bit. Mostly because that little Maltese Falcon icon conjures up the foul stench of old people and over-cooked steak that billowed out of John's when I first opened the door.  The food itself wasn't bad for a 1940's steak and potatoes joint (I'm sure Humphrey Bogart loved it) but that stench was just too dreadful to ignore.  Also, my group ate upstairs in the Maltese Falcon room because the restaurant was very full the night we went.  The 8 of us were crammed around our table in uncomfortable little chairs and received mediocre service at best.

I'd certainly be willing to give John's another try on a less busy night with a smaller party, but for now it only earns 2 stars in my book.
author: Erin L.

description: Took a wrong turn back to the hotel and decided to give it a try. I see why this place has been around since 1908! The prices were great, awesome service, and amazing food! I had the Maine Lobster Ravioli which was just wonderful! The lunch salad with vinegarette was the best! There are signed photos all over the walls of all the famous people that have been there. I will definitely return!!
author: Michael K.

description:
I understand, it is a vintage restaurant, with quality tradition~ 
but, base on my experience, it might only be the case to jack-up the price on the menu~ 

Neither the services and food were up to the same level of standard. 

I wanted my New York Steak, medium rare
and my CEO wanted his T-Bone, medium well, sat across the table from me.....

at the end~ mine was dry and a bit bitter~
and my boss's T-Bone had juicy blood all over the plate~

The platting wasn't all the impressed as well~ 
And the services could NOT meet up with the demand when the restaurant was at its full compaction. 

Our Waiter often was no where can be found..... 
and the waits on the food, service and check...... just pathetic

Here is the verdict:

Service: C+
Food: B-
Quantity: B-
Quality: B+

Environment: A- 

However, this is still a decent place if you do have VIP client in town, or a fancy date you wanna spend quality time with. 

But, there ARE plenty more options around the town to pick from!
author: Andrew W.

description: Ate there July 3. Jammed in like sardines. Escargot was terrible and my chicken Jerusalem was unidentifiable on my plate . Used to go here. NO MORE.
author: Michael R.

description:
If I were having a secret affair or were an international spy I'd do all of my "meetings" here because John's Grill is cozy and  you won't run into anyone you know since it's mostly an "Out-of-Towners Staying Around Union Square" crowd.

I won't come back for the fries which didn't seem cooked right and were greasy.  I might come back for the mussels (which made the best dipping sauce for the airy house bread).  And I'll definitely come back for the pomegranate martini and great service.

FYI: John's Grill is actually 3.5 stars

Mussels Rating: 3 Stars
author: Natasha R.

description: Great food and service.  Ask for the waiter from Uruguay.  He's a riot.  I believe his name was Che Boludo ;-)
author: Anthony D.

description: They initially lost our reservation.  We were seated within 5 minutes.  Our daughter compared her shrimp to Long John Silvers.  The steak was excellent, but the potato and vegetables were uninspired.  The swordfish tasted good but was very small.  Overall, not our best experience.  We would have preferred somewhere more intimate and quiet.
author: Brenda J.

description:
The server seemed a little bothered by our presence initially, but turned his attitude around before our meal was over. The restaurant only had two other tables with people at lunchtime (they had just opened), so I don't think it was that he was overwhelmed by the number of folks he was handling.

I loved the old feel of the place with the wood on the walls.

I enjoyed a plate of their Maine Lobster Ravioli which was tossed in a tomato cream sauce. I found it reasonably priced at $13.95 and though I tried, I was unable to eat all of it. It might have had something to do with the fresh bread and butter I wolfed down before my lunch was served. My friend and I wrapped our leftover pastas together and gave it to a homeless person while walking back to our hotel. He seemed very happy to receive it.

It was conveniently located to the Hotel Stratford where I was staying. I would definitely consider eating there again should I return to SF! I would like to try it again and see if other entrees are as good.
author: Donna V.

description:
Went on a Friday night.  Food was fantastic.  I had the John's steak, and it was better than most I've had at steakhouses around the country.  Caesar salad was also better than most.
 
I sat at the bar, and the bartender (who's name I unfortunately forget) was excellent.  Drinks were stiff, and while he was very busy he was always on top of things.

Zara, who was greeting people at the door but waitresses as well, was especially charming.

Definitely worth checking out.
author: James C.

description:
This is one of th first places I went to when I got to town. I know it's a bit on the tourist side, bu the food was good. I had a shrimp dish and the b-friend had a nice thick steak. I thought the place had a lot of character and the prices seam pretty good.
Yes, the place gets packed and the tables are close together. The other thing that bugged me, was that the bar had kids sitting at it. I don't like that when I am trying to get a drink, but the food was worth it. I think it would be a cool place to take out of towners, as it has an old feel to it.
author: Lisa A.

description: Every place was packed for dinner that night and after walking around looking a place for over an hour  I walked in here and was able to get a seat at the bar. Nice decor inside and has a very retro feel to it. I tried the Caesar Salad which was average.  I was torn between a few items on the menu but the waitress said the lamb chops are what they are known for. Average at best. They were cooked to perfection but they were flavorless. Your better steak houses serve them crisp on the outside but these were soggy and lacked over all. If a place claims  a certain item is what they are known for then it better be good. Strictly based on the decor I would go back for drinks but eating there again I would think twice.
author: Bif P.

description:
Some places in San Francisco get slammed for being too touristy. Too San Francisco. Too old.

Guess what? Those people are idiots. And here's why.

When a restaurant has been around for 5 or ten years you can unequivocally say that it's successful. John's Grill has been around for 100 years. You don't stay in business that long unless you're awesome. I don't care if you're a restaurant or a hardware store. That kind of resilience through time deserves a nod. 

My two favorite words when it comes to John's Grill (besides the name "John's Grill", I mean, come on, when you name a place, stamp it with something timeless. "Frisson"? WTF did that even mean? It's gone now of course. I could name other restaurants in the area with restaurant names that BLOW, but there's too many and I have to get back to work.

Anyhow, two favorite words about John's Grill -- FILET MIGNON. Im a NY Steak kinda guy, pride myself on being able to put away a pound of steak in a matter of minutes while chasing it with a couple of Manhattans, but the filet mignon at John's is, what's the word I'm looking for? Oh yeah. PERFECT. Run, don't walk.

The service is excellent. No nonsense. Smiles. Of course we can prepare it that way for you's. You know, service like it's supposed to be? Service that you don't find any freaking where else in the city because every other place is too pretentious and snooty?

BONUS: Frigging place is a setting in Hammett's Maltese Falcon. And if I have to explain what the Maltese Falcon is or who Dashiell Hammett is, move back to Boston. Please. 

I'll keep going to John's Grill for another hundred years. And guess what? Im gonna high five a tourist every time Im in that place for making the right choice. And I NEVER high five.
author: mario b.

description:
We loved our experience at John's Grill!
I think we were lucky to have been seated upstairs in this quaint establishment. We had a lovely view, and a single guitarist played a gentle variety of old and modern day favorites. 
The place was full, but the ambience was very pleasant. Our waiter was very attentive, the lobster ravioli appetizers were delicious and our steaks were amazing. I didn't care for the special cocktail, it was a bit sweet for my taste, but I loved being able to take home the souvenir glass it came in. It was neat knowing that a scene from The Maltese Falcon was filmed there too.
I highly recommend John's Grill to anyone seeking a delicious meal in an elegant setting.
author: Tania D.

description:
The charm of this place is the historic ambience.  It opened in 1908 (or so?) and I don't think it has probably changed much since then.

Positives:  It just "feels" good.  Sort of casual and homey.  The food is decent.  I had the Jack Lalanne salad and the clam chowder soup.  Both were good.  I'd get them again.  The service was good.

Negatives:  The tables are positioned very close together.  There is sort of a layer of dirt on the floors, especially on the stairs leading up to the second floor.

All in all, I'd go back.  I never was much for fancy anyway.
author: Sharon L.

description: Dropped in on the advice of a bar waitress. Very friendly service, prices just about what I'd expect from a Union Square restaurant. The salad was very good, lots of shrimp. There were vegetables with my entree - but I like a thick steak, and my rib-eye was only about 3/4" thick, so I was a little disappointed.
author: Greg M.

description:
Our hotel concierge recommended this place.  Maybe there's some sort of deal worked out there because this place wasn't great and in a big city I should be able to find a great steak, no problem. 

If you do find yourself here at least the Jack something or other salad for 2 was good.  Filet, eh, whatever.  Bone in New York...we've had better beef jerky.  Oh yeah, the bread was good.  OK, 2 stars for the bread and the salad.  Don't go for the steak.  You've been warned.
author: Stacey B.

description: Do not make a mistake and go to this place per your hotel's concierge suggestion.   The establishment looks like the "hot ticket" from the constant line in.  We were expecting great things but were disappointed of the quality of the food and service was subpar. I found a bone in my sea bass, ugh.   What a waste of time, go someplace else.  Sorry guys but the competition in San Fran is fierce and there are much better places to spend your money in without feeling like you are at a banquet on the third floor.
author: Laura B.

description: Food was really good, service was good but not great. It has a great San Fran feel to it and would def go back. We had drinks, salads, steaks and cioppino, all was delicious!
author: Katie P.

description: Another good one near union square. A famous spot - scene from The Maltese Falcon with Humphrey Borgart
author: Tracy V.

description:
I went here with my husband, son, and his fiance after seeing the 2pm show of Blue Man Group at the Golden Gate Theater.  The walk from the theater to the restaurant was easy and pleasant in the afternoon.
The food was really good.  The service was awesome.  Our waiter Steve S. was super, very attentive and very pleasant.
Three of us had steak, one had the seafood cannelloni.  Two of us had the rib-eye and our steak came out medium as ordered and was well seasoned.  My husband had the T-bone steak and he was not impressed with the flavor, he said it was bland.  The seafood cannelloni was good, but quite rich. For dessert we all shared a cheesecake, a chocolate mousse and a flan.  We all really liked the desserts.  
Overall I would recommend this restaurant; though warn the pricing is a bit high. The meals, desserts, glass of wine, 2 mix drinks, and coffees came to $190 without tip.
Note: If you are a fan of Sam Spade; be sure to read the back of the menu.
author: Karen V.

description: Great little place in an unsuspecting location, great food, the server (Isis) is fantastic, can't say the same for the sour face hostess ( not sure how or why she fits in here but not hospitality material! My partner and I have been in hospo for years) who really does not want to be there and spent all night on her phone while reluctantly seating guests. Aside from that I recommend this place
author: Nick O.

description: We had a group of 5 for dinner. The place was very loud, but still quite good. The service was OK, not great. I had a margarita - not good at all, not even sure they used tequila! The food was quite good though. Best clam chowder in years! Chef's special snapper was great. Generous portions and very tasty food.
author: Mark D W.

description: Not very good. Total tourist trap. Great central location to Union Square and a good atmosphere. The clam chowder and Cesar salad were pretty good. The "recommended" Halibut was disgusting and not fresh. The Rib eye with prawns was gross too. Go somewhere else.
author: Jen A.

description:
This joint is a classic.  My husband spotted it as we were strolling down Ellis, and we decided that its Dashiell Hammett affiliation, as well as its establishment in 1908 made it impossible to resist. We stepped into its pleasant semi-darkness and were seated at a table with fine white and green linen. I admired the dark woods and celebrity photos as we perused our menus. J ordered the cioppino, since he rarely gets it, and I chose the seafood linguine-style dish. Such savory, wholly filling food! We watched people wander up to the bar and overheard that the restaurant's prized claim to fame had been stolen. Sadness.

I would return to John's Grill in a pinch. It's worth every penny.
author: Beth F.

description: good crab  cocktail and oysters wellington..had never had tht before, sort of like oyster s rockefeller...interesting.. - pleasant staff  ...quiet
author: Adriana O.

description:
Pretty tasty food. Started out with the prawn cocktail and lobster ravioli for appies...and they were quite delicious. I hadt the peppered steak medium rare and it had this delicious wine reduction sauce with just the right amount of peppers. Load it with fresh veggies and a baked potato and it was so filling. 

For their specialty drinks...I ordered a pomegrante cosmo and was sad to have it be a vodka cran it disguise. Not special at all and not mixed all that well. 

To top it off, our waiter was all over us when we sat down but then kinda disappeared after a bit. I think he got annoyed that we were taking a bit chatting. Whatever...

The food was good but I felt it was too touristy and not anything special. Not a huge push from me to check it out...
author: Nicolas H.

description:
"You know, that's good, because if you actually were as innocent as you pretend to be, we'd never get anywhere." - Sam Spade ...

I was here a few years ago and just last week.  The first time was memorable.  The clammiest clam chowder and steak to die for.  The ambiance was something right out of a 50's gangster movie.  We were greeted by this big, no neck host and then seated at what looked to be where the mob counted the money at one of the back tables.  There was even a button (some sort of door alarm) above the lamp.... interesting...then maybe again ive seen too much of the Sopranos.  The Maltese Falcon used to be located here, until it was kidnaped- mob related? You decide....

Our visit last week proved to still be good, but not as memorable.  Seating upstairs was a little cramped.  I kept getting bumped by passerbys.  My Johns Steak was over cooked, but they did bring a new filet that was nicely did, but seemed to need some more aging.  They charred both steaks, so that put a little burnt flavoring in the meat -thats what a grill is supposed to do.  Still good though.  Ive been to some really great steak places since my first visit and I think Ive been spoiled by them and theyve set new standards for me.  The chowder, well that was great again.  My girl had the scampi, which was large and tasty.  We started off with some sort of salad with chunks of seafood in it, which was good also.  All that and a water and soda, we got out of there for 87 smackers including tip.

I would go back again if i were in the area, but would prefer to goto HOPR first, maybe even Mortons.
author: Jon W.

description:
After 30 years of dining at Johns the music has stopped for this local.  Last evening at 5:15 PM I chose to sit at a four top...the joint was empty.  Once I got settled the manager advised me that I could really not sit there because they were expecting a Friday night rush.....Mind you it is now 5:30 PM and the place is still empty and most likely I would have been done by 6:15.

Lack of respect for locals who support your establishment 12 months a year Greg.....you must be more concerned with the visitors from Nebraska.

BML
author: brian l.

description:
I went back here last week.  I'd had a long hard day of shopping with my girlfriends.  I started getting hungry at 6 and couldn't drag them out of Sephora until 9.  Despite my perfect make-over, was HANGRY and John's Grill was the first restaurant I spotted.

You know what?  We got a totally respectable and delicious dinner with great service.  Yeah, it was still pretty old-school, but I have to say that this was leaps and bounds above the last meal I'd had there.

OK, so they didn't totally suck as bad as before.  In fact, they were pretty good.  Yay for a great steak dinner with the girls in a booth big enough to fit all of our shopping bags!!
author: Amy A.

description:
While I had family in town, we decided to have a night on the town in SF which included dinner and a night at the opera. Since they weren't staying far from it, we thought John's Grill would be ideal for the attire we had on (it was opening night). 

The place is nice. It's very old-school in the supper club sense. i loved all the old photos and memorabilia around. The waiter was very patient and able to accommodate all our various requests. 

The food was okay. I had the seafood cannelloni. I wish I would have gone for something different. It was way too rich for my preference. It had crab, shrimp, spinach, cheese and mushrooms but they must put some sort of sauce. everyone who tasted it agreed it was really rich. My sister had the Fisherman's pasta. Plus it had kind of a fishy taste which is not what you want to say about seafood. This was a linguine with mussels, clams, and other suck seafood in a light sauce. This is more my style and I wound up sharing her plate since it was enough for two people. 

I don't think my family would be back here. For the prices, I expected more out of the food. It was an experience though.
author: Jessica H.

description: Not impressive. The food tasted bland. It wasn't a satisfying dinner at all.
author: Kara Y.

description:
Gross, gross, gross...wait, gross and flavorless!!!!!

Who cares about Maltese Falcon when you are paying $30+ for a overly dry filet ( sans flavor....steakhouse quality NOT), and the Chefs Special which is basically cream of mushroom soup with defrosted bay shrimp over uber dry snapper (if in fact that is what is was).... If you bring your kids they will tell you that they have a couple options when really all they have is a bowl of noodles for $10!!!!!!!!!  We bring our kids everywhere and I can tell you never have we seen a bowl of noodles with no sauce, no meat, no nothing for that much...

The food was really disgusting, flavorless, bland, etc....

Not worth anybody's time or money.
author: Susie G.

description: My husband & another couple stumbled upon this place while visiting SF. I am so glad we did it was great the service was good & our food came right away. The ribeye was cooked to perfection & my friend had the new York which she said was great. Will go back again when were in town.
author: Lea G.

description:
This place sucks...it smells like old steak grease and throw up...
The food is overpriced....the fish with this seafood sauce looks like puke on a plate, and tastes like it too.  Yuck...how this place survives I have no idea!  The service was fine but rushed...no conversation and overbearing greasy gelled hair manager breathing down our server's neck...I could tell he was uncomfortable.  The seafood salad was so gross...blue cheese and some other dressing combined and it tasted so yucky I thought I was risking getting sick if I ate it.  Don't bother with this hole...there are too many good places in San Fran to eat!
author: Sweet C.

description: Good steak. John greets you. I had a good waitress. Busy place, workers seem overworked. I was going to order liver but thought it was overpiced. My bill was about $90 for two. Stiff but convenient to the Marriott hotel. Music a a little too loud and only woodwinds.
author: Rey T.

description: I really wish I had Yelp'd before coming here. My friends wanted steak, and I was starving, so we settled for the first place that we stumbled upon. The steaks were overcooked, and the service was pretty snooty for a steakhouse.
author: Tiffany G.

description: I LOVED this cozy, little, almost underground restaurant! My mother and I found it walking around Union Square and had to stop. Service was great the food was delicious and the wine selection was extraordinary. I had the maine lobster ravioli and the lunch salad with bleu cheese dressing; yummyyyyyyy :) just what i needed after a long day of shopping & walking.  Would def recommend this place to anyone willing to try something unique to sf.
author: Iman Y.

description:
I rated John's a 2 because I won't go back. We went for the experience of going to the oldest restaurant in SF filled with history and celeb's pictures and that has been accomplished. It was a quaint old Italian looking restaurant and feel, hearkening back to North End decor. I ordered the Chef's Special Red Snapper topped with Crab, Shrimp and mushroom with a lemon cream sauce. The description sounded better than the dish actually was. The white strings of what I could only assume was crab, the tiny canned shrimp and the rich mushroom soup like sauce was something less than to be desired. The boring old school vegetables and the morning steamed gummy baked potato should have been left in the kitchen. The food was simple, not fresh and inventive. There are too many other city choices. On a positive note the Cesar salad, sour dough bread and my hubby's fillet were all very good. 

The restaurant was packed shortly after we were seated at 5:45 ish so maybe the fish was just a bad choice. Lastly the bar is tiny and not worth visiting. A Kettle one martini at $9.50 and a Stoli and soda in a chimney at $7.75 were a bit pricey considering there was no bar atmosphere.
author: Dianne M.

description:
Union Square seems to have a lot of contemporary places to eat - but when we felt like something with a bit more character and history, we discovered this place based on a recommendation from the Hotel Frank front desk.

The restaurant downstairs seems pretty cool - dark wood, dim lighting - but we were seated upstairs in what seemed to be the mess hall for the employees.  "Jazz" was a solo guitarist playing light jazz - which for me is not really jazz at all but elevator music.  Drop one star for bad music, and another for the excessively kitschy feel of this place - they promote the Maltese Falcon upstairs in a very Disney-like manner.  A bit over the top...as if to distract you from....

The crappy food!

Yes - the steak was tasteless. As were the vegetables - steamed without any seasoning.  The baked potato was ok - but they only brought out sour cream in a plastic cup.  It just seemed like this place thrives on tourists that buy no matter what - which is probably what we were that night.  

Now good quality produce and meat don't need a lot of seasoning...so...the food quality is below par and the preparation wasn't compensating.  

Plus - I ordered a manhattan - which came out looking like some bright red cocktail comprised of cherry juice, ice and a splash of bourbon.  I had to send it back and just get a glass of wine.

I ate half of my dinner - one can only do so much with salt and pepper.

Service was ok - we didn't get the feeling that they really assigned anyone to our table and they were just rushing to get us in an out of there.

I wanted to like this place - I had limited expectations - but really  - this place must be way overrated and shouldn't be charging $25+ for a steak dinner that was this underwhelming.  It's sad that a restaurant that had to have been good at one time has become an overrated tourist trap now.
author: Jim S.

description:
I wasnt expecting anything except that its a pretty historic restaurant in San Francisco.

Obviously I was very pleased with the experience. The drinks were almost too stiff if thats possible. The seafood salad was AMAZING and even though it is like $17 its the perfect app for 4 people. I had something I cant pronounce and actually made an ass of myself ordering it but it had shrimp, crab and was covered in this incredible white sauce. Not a large portion but that was good b/c it was very very rich.

I had a couple bites of my Dads porterhouse which I wouldnt recommend. It was a little dry and tasteless for this red meat lover but he really enjoyed it.

Too bad about the Falcon... I hope someone returns it soon.
author: Nancy B.

description:
I came here with my work associates, I wasn't paying so i got the most expensive thing i saw at 27$ which was the porterhouse steak, I got it medium rare which was exactly what i wanted, but the meat quality...eh..It was a bit rough. 

Everything almost ripped into pieces as i tried to cut into it....with a BUTTERknife, no steak knife. A butterknife. The potato was quite good with the sour cream though. I definetely have had better steaks though. The place was cozy and the staff was very nice, the food could be better though.
author: Terry S.

description:
The wife and I ate here this afternoon while we were in the Union Square neighborhood, The restaurant is located on Ells St right across the street from a parking garage. I did not realize that this was the touristy Maltese Falcon famed restaurant and touts that it has been around since 1906. I just thought this was a rather old looking steak/seafood place to eat so decided to give it a shot. The restaurant is a bit on the crowded side as the tables are close to each other. The bar is very small in the corner of the restaurant and has about 5 bar stools. The service was efficient and attentive as a crowded restaurant can get. The wife had the broiled salmon served with garlic mashed potatoes and steamed veggies and a creamy tartar sauce.
