I had the sauteed dungeness crab legs with mashed potatoes and steamed veggies, Both dishes were very good and I do love crab legs, so did my wife. We did the chocolate mousse for dessert, not a good call. I had a glass of house chardonnay, very tasty and smooth.
Being the first time here, very pleased. This place has an upstairs where the Maltese Falcon is located. Upstairs has the bathroom also.
I would recommend it, next time will try the steak.
author: jack d.

description: I love JOHN's GRILL and I will be coming back here over and over!  Second time I was here, i had their famous drink (comes with a souvenir glass!) and it tasted good.  We had mussels for appetizer, fisherman's pasta (seafood pasta -- all time fav here!), and chicken entree (can't remember exact name but it was creamy with mushroom sauce).  I highly recommend the seafood pasta from this place.  Steaks are bland.  I don't rec them.  AND i love the ambience.  True historical SF experience with LIVE jazz music.
author: Jessica N.

description: My friend and I had the fried seafood combination plate and it was not worth the price.  You can get a better quality meal at Red Lobster. The vegetables with it were very bland and not seasoned.  I've only been here once and this review is only based on 1 dish. You can take that for what it's worth.
author: Brian D.

description:
I am a third generation SF Californian and this was the first time I visited on Saturday night. We did an "apres theater" dinner here with family and it was damned good! The service was excellent - the only *complaint* I have is the biffy is two stair flights up and only two stalls. Plus it is pretty tiny. (not really a complaint - just a frustration mostly as it WAS period)

I highly recommend this for a solid dinner out in SF. 

Our table had both surf and turf - the halibut was amazingly succulent and well cooked (meaning cooked exquisitely not overdone) the steaks were tender and tasty.

One note that I found odd: On the web the menu seemed extensive. When we arrived it was quite edited. Not sure if that was due to seasonality (i.e. it ain't crab season no mo') but no mussels or fried oysters were to be seen!
author: Ping P.

description: Thank you so much for a wonderful evening. It was our 38th anniversary. It was one of the best times we have ever had! It was delicious and fun!
author: Donnie D.

description:
A friend and I had lunch here after a lousy experience at Fang. She'd taken her parents here before and it'd been a good experience.

I had a bowl of clam chowder and the Jack Lalanne salad. The soup was really good, nice and creamy with chunks of potatoes and clams without it being overpoweringly fishy. The salad had lots of crab and shrimp and what looked like an entire half of an avocado. It would've been easy for them to load it up with lettuce and just throw a few pieces of shrimp and crab into the lot of it, but they didn't skimp and I'm glad of that.

The one thing I would have appreciated was a stronger dressing. The salad comes tossed in a bleu cheese vinaigrette, but it had only the faintest bleu cheese flavor and none of the tartness I associate with vinaigrettes. It was really quite mild. The salad wasn't drowning in dressing, which was good; on the other hand, the dressing didn't really contribute much to the salad at all.

The place has been in business since 1908. I don't think a restaurant can stay open for over a hundred years by serving lousy food. This was really good and reasonably priced. If I get the opportunity, I'd like to come back and try a steak for dinner.
author: Steve B.

description: I was here with my wife and friends. I was the only one who had seen the Maltese Falcon, so the historic significance was lost on the rest of the group. But everyone enjoyed their meals and the dessert was terrific. We utilized the online reservation through Yelp and were seated immediately. The room was loud, but it was packed and the line went out the door. It can't be too bad if that many people want to get in.
author: Andrew G.

description:
I should give this place 4 stars as we had a great time in it!  but the menu was smaller than expected so i just can't.

The food on the other hand was great!  everyone at the table order meats!
i stuck with the chicken, that had a fantastic cream sauce and more mushrooms and artichokes than i was expecting.

Our server was great too!  he forgot our appetizer, but didn't blame the anyone but himself.  Not that we were upset, there was plenty of food on the table and our entree's came out super quick.

it was just nice that he said: "whoops, totally forgot... i'll bring one out and put it on the house:"

We saw that he was busy so it wasn't a big deal at all... but it was nice to hear a little honesty.
author: Stephanie R.

description: Love the old-fashioned ambience.  A little piece of San Francisco history -- full of character, and a fun place to hang out. Very busy even at 6pm on a Wednesday.
author: Keds S.

description: Great service and atmosphere!!! I went with a party of four. My friends ordered New York steaks and the broiled red snapper. I ordered the oysters Wellington. Steaks and fish were cooked to perfection. The oysters Wellington was a flavor explosion in my mouth. Food and environment are classic San Francisco. Everything was priced right. I highly recommend and would visit again.
author: shane m.

description:
As a nerdy, unattractive preadolescent with no friends save for history books, I was a regular at John's Grill, where after school I would drown myself in old San Francisco and cream sauces. Fans of Dashiell Hammett books will find this holy grail of a restaurant relatively unchanged in the last century or so, except for countless photos of contemporary celebrities. 

As for the food, it's not cheap and the menu hasn't changed much in 60 years.
author: Megan W.

description:
I was here for a conference and stopped by John's Grill for lunch.  I had no idea of the history of the place...I liked the classic steak-house vibe.  They had classic crooners playing and it had a refined (though cramped) atmosphere. Dont go here if you require special assistance, or dont feel like climbing the stairs to the bathroom.
BAR:  After sitting at the bar I thought an achorsteam draft beer would hit the spot. The friendly bartender pulled an unchilled glass from the rack and proceeded to fill it. The draft beer was only about 60 percent as cold as it needed to be...and the unchilled glass (no fine restaurant should serve beer in an unchilled glass) probably made it worse.  I broke my never complain rule and politely told the bartender about the warm beer. His excuse was that if beer was left in the lines overnight it could be higher in temperature. I sat there and wondered why warm beer left in unrefrigerated draft lin we s would be served to me in the first place. I suggested a chilled bottle anr he let me kbow he fould fetch one "upstairs". I expressed my remorse in him having to visit another floor to find cold beer but he insisted it wasnt a problem. He returned in 5 minutes with bottlesbof anchorsteam.  Since he didnt have any chilled glasses....he improvised by filling a pint glass with ice and water  and waited...prior to dumping the mixture in to the now cold glass. Whew! A cold beer! Halefrickinleiuya.  Lol. Imagine the time savings that could be gleaned by fixing the tap system and refrigerating some pint glasses. If you love beer, you are completely feeling m3 right now.

Here's where it gets weird.  Same bartender is working in the bar sink and I hear the sound of a shattered bar glass. When I worked in a restaurant...if a glass broke in the sink...or God forbid the ice container....the sink would need to be meticulously cleaned out and toweled dry to ensure every shard of glass was removed. If yoy have ever broken a glass...you know that there are large fragments, small fragments, and pieces you can barely see.  This bartender removed 2 large broken pieces of glass from the sink andbwas back serving in seconds.  So...the bar...was a failure.  Bartender was polite...but beer was warm...beer pints were served unchilled and I had concerns over the broken glass which...in my opinion...was not addressed in a way that made me feel like EVERY precaution was taken to ensure the safety of the patrons.

Chowder was excellent.
author: Chris C.

description:
It's interesting to read the other reviews here in light of my own experience.  I just came from throwing a surprise birthday lunch for my husband and 25 friends  at John's Grill, and Neil Hayes and the entire staff could not have been more helpful or more profesional.  The lunch was delightful and the food terrific-and the service great.  Everyone at the party raved about the experience.

And the place--It's John's Grill!   Either you get it and love it, or you don't.  It came to be the way it is before celebrity architects started designing  food "joints". It isn't a chain. It's the place my husband and his buddies hold all their Fantasy Sports lunches.  This is where reporters from the SF Chronicle go to eat and hang out.  The menu is classic San Francisco Dashiell Hammett.  

 It's small, and its crowded because so many people want to be there!
author: Lisa M.

description: This place had lots of decent reviews online but it was awful! It's just one of those places that has been around for 50+ years or so and folks are loyal. I ordered a margarita first and couldn't even drink it. Ordered sea bass in a garlic Burre blanc sauce and it came out in like 5 minutes and it was really Served in garlic butter water. It was truly a horrible meal that cost about $100. I do not see what all the good reviews are about. The server was very nice and gave us a free dessert for the lousy margarita. I read in epi cure magazine that celebs come here often. I just don't get it. Worst meal I had in San Fran.
author: Emily D.

description:
I'm not going to take the fact that it's overpriced into account.
Being John's Grill, I had to get the Sam Spade, and a "Bloody Brigid." If you are a fan of The Maltese Falcon, you need to go here. If you have cash to burn ($40 for those two!) and like tasty food, you need to come here too. My lamb chops were tender and delicious, the baked potato was good and the sliced tomatoes were AMAZING. I don't think I ever had a tomato that was so good. I don't think I would come here all too often, but It was a nice place to go once or twice.
author: Aaron J.

description:
I was pulled to this place (after living in the area for 15 years) by a group of local visitors here for a business conference. The food was OK, the steaks were good but not amazing (far from it), the price was high, of course. The steak that was ordered medium came rare, the one that was ordered rare came medium. They sent them back to the kitchen but well...
But the worst was the service. We were a group of 11 individuals, we discussed with the server before sitting down the fact that we needed separate checks. He said he could not do that but could provide separate receipts. Of course, the payment time comes and this is when he mentions that ha! they take only 4 credit cards per table!! Yeah! He pushed a third of the table to the ATM machine across the street. I was shocked that, when we mentioned we needed to pay separately, that did not show up in the discussion. This is a total tourist trap. I experienced it, next time, I'll be more persuasive in going somewhere else!
author: Carole G.

description: Ambiance was outstanding.  It is an old style downtown steakhouse so it is a bit dark and crowded, but very authentic.  I had John's special and it was done well.  Great flavor.  Service was good.
author: Eric S.

description:
It's a good thing I like liver, 'cause that's what my filet mignon tasted like.  As for the ceasar salad, it wouldn't've been so bad if it weren't gooped in goopy dressing.  The gaggle of frat boys mucking up the center of the room served as an indicator of this restaurant's mediocrity.  

Did I mention I was dragged here by out-of-towners?
author: Janut B.

description:
Come on.  Why steal the Falcon!

When we first moved here the first destination stop was John's Grill as my collection of Humphrey Bogart movies is now missing two.  (this is a complete nerd feet considering how many movies Mr. Bogart made) and we have a healthy collection of Dashielle Hammet books ourselves. 

We also have a Maltese Falcon I got my man from Metro Golden Memories in 1986 as a birthday present.  Wrapped it in newspaper and twine and had my friend drop it at his feet at a party.

So of course the first eatery we went to here was John's Grill.  We were in the Falcon room.  Your best bet when you go there is to make a reservation because it is a landmark place that gets crowded (you can make reservations on line too) and there is literally not a wait and you get a good table.

For an actor going into a place that touted actor and writers hanging out there once upon a time?  The prices now are so not for actors. For an artist, this is a once or twice a year thing.

But it is worth it.  The steaks are prime cut and tender.  The pasta dishes are creamy and rich.  That chocolate mousse cake they have.  It is sex on a plate.  The wines are top quality.  

And I had a cocktail that was so strong?  I honestly had to be a touch ghetto and water the thing down.  That is not a bad thing honestly.  Because how often do you have to *water down your own drink*  :)

The last time we went was for our anniversary lunch/dinner Sunday Feb 18th 2007.   Made the reservation on line Thursday.  Was reminded on Saturday via email, got a phone call from the restaurant at noon saying the Falcon room was not open (because some jackass stole the falcon.  The reason why we went...to support the place).  Not too many restaurants gives that much attention to patrons *before they even arrive*

They were wonderful to us the moment we stepped into the place to the moment we left full and happy with the place that REEKS of nostalgia.  Even the music.  

By the time we were leaving the place was filling up quickly.  If you do not like crowds, go during the afternoons on a Saturday or Sunday and enjoy the atmosphere.

It's a San Francisco landmark.  I love John's Grill.

And if the jackass is on Yelp?  Stop being an ass (and ironic) and RETURN THE FALCON
author: Shaun L.

description: I will never visit this establishment ever again. I can't even give them one star..... Here is why:   I ordered red snapper, when the dish arrived in was cold!  The sauce on the red snapper tasted an looked like Campbell creamy mushroom soup. I'm currently still having heartburn from dinner.  The service was terrible; the waiter constantly reached over in front of me to deliver my friend's plate sitting next to me and when removing the plates. The price of my dinner was over 30 dollars. I expected hot food and good service for such a hefty price tag. I got better service at Applebee's
author: Carmen D.

description:
The interior is too cramped.  The ambiance was dive-y; nothing impressive.  The service was ok, but for the price that I paid, I would have expected better service.  The price was too high for what we got.  I will say that the steak was without a doubt one of the best that I have ever had, but the rest of the food was average, to midland.

I haven't had a steak that tasted that good in a long, long time.  They could have added chives and cheddar cheese to the baked potato, which was otherwise just average.  The wine was decent, but again pricey for what you get.  For as much as we paid for that place, I would have expected more trimmings with the baked potato, and perhaps some more veggies to go with the steak.  Oh, and as for the bread that they gave us to munch on before our meal, I have to say that I don't like the hard crust.

Overall:  If you don't mind eating a fabulous steak in a cramped environment, with mediocre service for the price, then this place is for you.  Else, go somewhere else.
author: Sean R.

description: We walked by John's Grill on our way back to the BART station after a lovely cable car tour of the city holiday lights. It was about 8:30 and the place was packed. It looked old school and had lots of famous celebrity photos up all over the place and only a 20 minute wait for a table for four, so we went for it. The host at the reservation desk was a little snooty, but we got seated in less than the twenty minutes he originally quoted us, so it was fine. We got a really great table upstairs by the front window, and the atmosphere up there was amazing. The tables are very close together, which ordinarily would be annoying, but here it just adds to the cozy atmosphere. They had live music, which was great, as well. The service was just okay. Someone else described it as "sloppy", which I think is a good way to say it. Not terrible, but for the price and the atmosphere, I expected better. The food, for the price, was just average. My Roquefort salad was just okay, and my seafood fettuccine was not hot. If I said it was warm, that would be generous. The seafood tasted average, and there were some mushrooms in it that were underdone. My husband had surf and turf, and it was just 'eh. The kids had fried shrimp and New York steak. The steak looked decent, but the shrimp looked mediocre and the baked potato was nothing special. The bread at the beginning of the meal was the best part. Yummy sourdough! Our drinks were exceptionally overpriced. We paid like over $40 for two diet cokes and two Shirley temples! That was insane, I thought. Over all, the atmosphere is amazing, but you can get way better food and service elsewhere for the price.
author: Emily G.

description: 10 minutes away in Union Square this is an old restaurant with a great menu and wine list.
author: Peter S.

description: Went here for lunch with my bf after not being able to find another restaurant we were looking for. The place feels small. The table they sat us at seemed like it was meant for 1 person. The bread wasn't warm or even room temp. I ordered the fried shrimp with vegetables. The shrimp was ok. I've had better. The vegetables suck. Overcooked and seemed like not fresh. They can't even saute it to add flavor? My bf ordered the steak sandwich with french fries. At least the steak was medium like he asked. Needs some seasoning though. The waitress didn't ask how we were doing. We had to ask her to remove things from our small table cuz there was no space for our plates. Then we had to ask for water refills even though they walked back in forth so many times, they had to have seen our empty glasses, the place is not that big. If only we weren't so hungry we could've walked away from this place.
author: J.Realis N.

description: waitress was annoyed, rude, atmosphere was terrible, definitely did not have The City vibe. Food was worse, cold, bland, sides were pathetic. So disappointed to waste an evening out in SF for this place.
author: Jacqueline R.

description:
This place has lots of history  with black and white photos on the wall. Ambience is dark, upstairs they have someone strumming lightly on a guitar for some background music. Sound level is good and I was able to keep my conversation with my friend without having to speak loudly at all like in many other crowded restaurants.

Steak is the specialty here, I've gotten the T-bone and Filet Mignon, both very good at around $27-29. Normally I just get the meal and no dessert, but since I had so much steak in me I needed some ice cream afterwards to cool down. Steak overload I must say, but that's good. 

I think my friend and I were the youngest there, everyone around was gray-haired, which is expected for a classy steak restaurant.
author: Peter Y.

description:
While we were prepared for this being a tourist trap, we were not prepared for the  hostess who in mere minutes ruined what could have been an enjoyable evening.

She managed to take down the names of the straight diners and directing them inside to wait at the bar, but my partner and I were left in the foyer without seating priority. When approached regarding her hospitality, she began what was going to be 10-20 minutes of eye rolling and passive aggressive fake phone calls decrying quite loudly how the two of us were making trouble for her. Then when called out on her moronic behavior and mocking tone, we were treated to a series of ba-bye's, hand flicking gestures, and a litany of condescending words. Now of course, as a tourist trap, you have a fair number of customers such that fits like these do not hurt your business' bottom line. But in the long run, it's moments like this that define your business' spirit. Bad seed for San Francisco.
author: Sf F.

description: Booked our reservation in open table and they set our small group up with a great table on the top floor at the window.  Our guests from overseas had a great time and enjoyed the ambiance that this classis place has to offer.  The stakes could have been done closer to how they were ordered, but everything else was great. The oysters rockefeller were awesome.
author: kevin l.

description: A classic SF restaurant.  Went on Sunday on the way to a show at the Warfield and split the Jack LaLanne salad for 2.  The crab and bay shrimp were plentiful.  Our server was helpful and attentive.  And of course, I'm a sucker for the old school SF decor, so that was a plus.
author: Ariana L.

description:
Wanted to enjoy a nice steak dinner with my lady. I yelped John's Grill and saw the decent reviews so we decided to go. Got seated within 10 mins, which isn't bad on a Sunday evening. The waiter brought us the sourdough bread and a ROACH fell out of the basket. 

YES I SAID A ROACH!!!! TOTALLY DISGUSTED!!! 

Needless to say we got up and left immediately.
author: rockson t.

description: All of these love/hate reviews are surprising because I had a great overall experience at John's. My steak was perfectly cooked as was the asparagus side. I ordered a $10 Old Fashioned and was not disappointed despite the price. The decor of the place was cool. Overall the service wasn't stellar, but the place was packed the night I was there and it didn't take away from the meal. I'll definitely be back.
author: Bruce P.

description:
I recommend vegetarians dine elsewhere.  Most places nowadays have at least one token veggie option; this place doesn't.  The server told me the only entree that can be made vegetarian is the Seafood Pasta.  Problem for me was that Seafood Pasta without seafood is nothing but noodles and cream sauce.   (Nothing wrong with not being veggie friendly of course - I only say this for informational purposes to like minded persons).

Otherwise, this is the type of place your parents will like.  The atmosphere is nice, and the Maltese Falcon thing is kind of cool.  Although its overpriced, it gets four stars because my parents had a good time and loved it.
author: J Y.

description: I LOVE this place... it's just "San Francisco" to me!  The old dark wood, pictures of famous people, a lot of politicians... warm, cozy... and a smile to greet you... food??  If you love meat, John's Grill is the place for you... I had the New York Steak and I was well pleased, not just with the steak, but the sides!  My husband was hesitant to order the lamb chops, wondering if he would have enough... sure enough the satisfied his hunger!  The hostess is amazing and efficient!  Kind of takes me back to that movie It's a Wonderful Life... just feels good being in there... Oh and jazz music to fill the room with some more goodness!
author: Andrea M.

description: We wanted fish. Every one was coated with a creamy sauce, which we would have preferred not to have. I had the grilled red snapper with lemon cream sauce, which was good but not great. My husband had the halibut, which was much better. The vegetables were anemic. The service was quite good, and the live music as well. We arrived early, the day of a flight from the East Coast. As we left, the place was packed with a crazy scene at the door. People without reservations would let us out. I strongly recommend reservations on a weekend night. I would also stick to the regular meats unless you, like us, like to be heart- healthy.
author: Melissa S.

description:
I didn't steal the maltese falcon statue....I swear!!  Although I can't vouch for the rest of my group!  I went to John's for the first time on Sunday, I've always wanted to go to see a piece of SF history.  The next day, on the news, I saw that someone had stolen the famous 'Maltese Falcon' which is the statue that made John's Grill famous, it wasn't me!

Anyway, we didn't go for food at all, although everything that was being served looked and smelled really good. John's is a fun, quiet place right off the bustle of Union Square that's perfect for having a classy cocktail before going out to dinner. The service was great and the bartender was very friendly. We also kept getting whiffs of ganja off and on, I think one of the servers was hitting the pipe in the back room on a  regular basis, which was awesome!

Lots of old people here, fantastic!
author: Craig E.

description: Apparently John's Grill is a staple here in San Francisco. It's over 100 years old and has been visited by hundreds of celebrities (I only know this from the slew of pictures on the wall). The menu is a bit limited - they have 3 or 4 different kinds of dishes for each main food group (chicken, beef, fish, etc). I wasn't sure what to exactly order, until I saw the Seafood Cioppino. This is a true San Francisco dish. It's a stew of jumbo Pacific prawns, fillet of sole, scallops, mussels, bay shrimp and clams in a marinara broth. Even though I knew it was going to be a bit messy, I had to have it. I love seafood and I wanted to feel like a native here in San Francisco. The dish was very good. The dish was hearty, the seafood was jumbo sized and the marinara broth had a bit of a kick to it. It left me full and satisfied.
author: Crissy H.

description:
Nothing really stood out to me except the clam chowder.  I've been scouring this city for amazing clam chowder, and John's Grill has it.

Steak was ok, prawns were not, service was ok, but I would be back over and over just to have that thick and creamy chowder!
author: Kasia F.

description: Neat, old, SF atmosphere, but nothing special to dine on, yet pricey.  I wouldn't seek it out unless you're a Maltese Falcon fan.
author: Magic M.

description:
Traveling to SF for business, we frequently stay around Union Sq.  It's hard to find a tasty dinner option around there.  Dozens of average to below-average Asian restaurants and random pubs dominate the area... And although those are great for a late night option, after a day of flying, we thought to try something different a few weeks back.

We went with John's Grill for three reasons: it was open on Sunday night, its greeter, standing outside under a heat lamp on a chilly night, caught our eye and we obliged to read the handout menu, and it was not Thai (despite our love of Thai, Union Sq. Thai is typically disappointing, and we were cranky that eve).

We came in and were promptly seated, but it was late on a Sunday night so I did not expect anything other than that.  Rat Pack music softly playing throughout the 3 floors of the restaurant, this place is marketed as the idea behind the Maltese Falcon movie.  This tells me nothing, having immigrated to US much later than the peak of this movie, but I can understand it.  I enjoyed the dark atmosphere and groomed waiter staff.

Onto food: its really good.  Peppercorn sauce for their steaks is a must.  A steak dish is a must.  My husband had a steak while I was feeling 'healthy' and ordered the snapper.  Get the steak, its delicious! Good selection of local beers to help with your meal too.  

Overall, a classic restaurant, with some interesting history, and a solid cut of steak makes it A-OK.
author: Yulia G.

description: I have been coming to this place for 30 years and has many great memories. The menue is traditional meat oriented fare with a full bar.  The Setting is comfortable wood paneled mens club with a Dashel Hamett Theme reminiscent of the 1920's despite the fire and rebuild it maintains its original charm  including the original Maltese Falcon from the Same named movie.  The shopping district location and super good service make the uninspired menue pass.  Go there at least once for the old town experience.
author: Fred G.

description: A New Year's Eve First! I was visiting with my family and must admit when we saw the wall to wall dining we were not too impressed.....until the first response of AWESOME service from our waiter and our dining experience. the food was phenomenal. the steak melted in your mouth and the salmon was worth writing home about. I would recommend this to any foodie.
author: Melissa W.

description: I wish I could give John's Grill more stars.  I love the ambience and have had some good lunches there.  But last night we went for dinner and I ordered the Oysters Wellington and they were too salty, appeared reheated and I couldn't find any oysters inside. They were so bad that I didn't even finish them.  My husband had a rib-eye steak and he liked it.  So if you order right even dinner can be good. The vegetables that accompanied both dishes were nicely cooked and delicious.
author: Ruth K.

description:
An Old San Francisco classic. One of my favorite restaurants ever.

Lovely decor. They know what they're doing here, as they should, since they've been doing it for decades and decades.

The lunch is surprisingly economical, and the sandwiches are excellent. The dinners are very reasonably priced - not cheap, but fantastically good. I try to take all my out-of-town friends here.

Try the escargot and the lamb chops. Good classic cuisine here.

Honestly, you can come in wearing jeans and a t-shirt, but you'll feel better if you come dressed business casual or better. That's what I feel with the wood panelling, the cloth tablecloths, and the black-tie waiters.
author: Michael E.

description: I wanted to like John's Grill much more.  It's such a cool place, the Maltese Falcon connection, the old movie photos, and what I think is the look and feel of a timeless San Francisco restaurant serving American food.   I was excited to go, we had reservations and that was good because this restaurant is jam packed with people spilling out the front door.  The service is attentive and friendly - from the door, to the hosts and our server and serving assistants - they  absolutely  treated us well.   Our smiling adorable waitress is why this has two stars and not 1, she was lovely, and the only saving grace to this experience.  The food is average, the prices are terribly high, the noise level is unbearable, and the way you are packed into the dining areas is a nightmare.  There is live music there, a jazz pianist and although this genre of  music adds to the ambiance and flavor of John's - they've set the pianist up right next to tables, and also amplified the music overhead at a high level, making ordinary conversation  impossible.  Dinner companions need to shout at one and another from 2 feet away.  Not a good place for a date unless you hate each other.  It's easier to talk to the diners seated near you, than to your own date across the table.   I noticed several men dining alone there, and it looks like a good place for a traveling business person to dine alone, since talking was not an option.  The guest seated next to us actually left before his order was served because the noise was overwhelming to him.    The food is OK, and I liked it, (Fillet, Chicken Jerusalem) but didn't love it; as another reviewer wrote, it was bland, needed much seasoning, and there wasn't anything to stand out and make me feel good about spending so much money.  We were in and out of there so quickly, no way I was going to have dessert.   I really couldn't leave fast enough, I felt like if I wanted to enjoy my evening without my head exploding, it wasn't going to be there.  I think that may be the method to this madness.  Get people in and out, turn the tables, make the money, and move onto the next group of diners impressed with the promises of a peek into the San Francisco of years past.    Great service, awful atmosphere.  John's is such a unique place, and one that warrants diners staying and exploring the wall photos and memorabilia, drinking in the period furniture and historic qualities, and yet I feel like they drove us out of there by design.
author: Kris K.

description: We decided to try a bit of San Francisco history by going to John's Grill. That is what we got. This place is all history. They are counting on a reputation that their kitchen and waitstaff cannot support.  The food was bland and not prepared well. This included the entree, sides and unfortunately the desserts. The waitstaff was unconcerned and inattentive. The dining room upstairs was claustrophobically close and so loud you could not carry on a conversation.  Spend your money on another place!
author: Stan W.

description: Very nice place. I made a reservation online with note: private table for 2, birthday celebration. And guess what - we got nice private table, great seafood, perfect white wine and free cake with a candle !  Great service and food, highly recommended.
author: Vic P.

description: wanted to try something cool and old.  Since 1908.  I don't know how.  Slow service, cold food.  Had the hang town fry.  A big omelet wad with like 3 fried oysters in it.  Pretty bland.  So disappointed
author: geoff c.

description:
My family and I have eaten here on the Friday after Thanksgiving since I was old enough to sit in my own chair. (let's just say a few years now).  One of the old San Francisco restaurants, it hasn't changed a bit, which I love!  It has that classic SF feel.  Small and long, there is more seating upstairs, although I've never sat up there.  The wait staff is always very attentive.  If you order certain drinks, it comes with the John's Grill glass.  Of course, this was a lot cooler when I was 10.

I will admit, the food is not 5 stars, but neither are the prices.  They are higher than other places, but mostly because John's is located in tourist central (union square).  The burgers, the fried calamari, the john's special all solid very filling meals.  

If you're looking for a traditional SF restaurant where the food is good, this is your place.  Read up about it's history and the Maltese Falcon too.  If you're looking for Aqua like food and atmosphere, it's not here.
author: Emily G.

description:
The crab louis brings me back.  Not the funky smell of old shoes and cheese.  I'm guessing that's from the lack of fresh air because the place has three windows, none of which open.  Don't get the jack lalane, it's the crab louis minus some crab and with those sucky small bay shrimp.  

During lunch, it's a suit and tie affair in there.  Dark wood.  Lots of guys in suits. A guy's place for business lunches.
author: Bruce B.

description: I've been to John's Grill several times but I was just there last night and my experience was not a good one. We ordered oysters on the half shell and they were served at room temp. Not a good way to eat an oyster - we didin't even finish them and that says a lot for us as we love to have our oysters. We complained but nothing happened. Next we ordered a bottle of wine and they wre out. We ordered a Ribeye, Filet and the petrale sole - very good but the potatoe was dry and they veggies were OK. We were seated upstairs and there someone playing an electric guitar - the music choices were something you might expect at bad vegas lounge act. Too bad as I relly did like this place.
author: Shirley P.

description:
Definitely a tourist trap, but you should come at least once in your life for fun. 

The Sam Spades' Lamb Chops were good. Seafood Cioppino a la Marinara was presented in an ugly manner, but was tasty. I don't think any of it was worth about $29/plate. 

We were on the floor with the live jazz band, which was interesting. Tried to have a nice intimate dinner with the boyfriend, but the tables are a bit claustrophobic and the woman next to us thought he was proposing when he gave me a ring for my birthday. She was practically breathing down my neck.

Our waiter was friendly and attentive. 

Lost stars mostly because it rubs the Maltese Falcon gimmick in your face, and the food was tad pricey. Dark, brooding ambiance is probably an acquired taste.
author: Nadia S.

description: I've eaten there twice in the past 2 months. One time a 4-star and one time 1-2 stars. First time was fine. 2nd time was probably the worst service I've ever received in a SF restaurant. Was with a group of business associates for an early Friday dinner. A group likely to tip big, yet were were ignored. Took about 45 minutes between appetizers & the main course. I finally had to get up & try to find our waiter to get the bill at the end. We weren't in any hurry, so we didn't make any sort of fuss about the slow service.  Maybe the 3rd floor should be avoided, as it seems that all of the food is hand carried up 2 flights of stairs. They over/under cooked 3 of the 5 meals. Seams they may be living of their legend & tourists.
author: Tim B.

description:
Pre-steampunk - the original John's Grill has historic San Francisco flare!  Many black and white pictures of famous people and olden day SF. Although I don't know much about SF history, John's grill has a special maltese falcon room. 

Got a salad. The special salad (forgot the name) - with crab, avocado, shrimp and blue cheese dressing. It was a little overdressed - but SOLIDLY good. No fishy taste. I've heard raving reviews about the lobster ravioli. Gotta go back for the steak.
author: Judy L.

description:
Strictly for tourists and locals who are feeling touristy. Which I was the couple of times I visited. 

There is a $20 minimum. I know because the waiter made a point of announcing to my friend when we sat down at my first visit. Tacky! 

I like their mussels, but everything else on the menu is too heavy for me.

To keep with the tourist mood, order the Bloody Brigid. You'll get a souvenir glass to take home!
author: Wella L.

description:
Cramped, loud and busy as hell...what more could a girl ask for? OK so not every time I go somewhere do I wish it to be this way, but at the end of the day I do appreciate a full house and a great environment. Dinner was superb and I had no complaints. Sure the fellow tables heard my conversation, but who cares? I think Americans are too picky about their personal space anyways...we should all be more accommodating and enjoy each other's company more often!

Enough ranting, I really did enjoy this place and it's downtown close to work so I can't beat it. If anyone ever wants to take me to dinner there I wouldn't mind...
author: Stephanie J.

description:
What can I say... After 100 years they might want to spruce up the place a bit?  I mean come on?  A Russet Potato as a side to everything on the menu?  So--- I don't know---- 1908ish...

Food was bland and atmosphere is cheesy.
author: ein bier bitte k.

description: Be sure to try the Lamplighter, one of the signature dishes. It's filet of sole, stuffed with shrimp and crab in a white wine butter sauce.
author: Matt P.

description:
On a weekend trip up to San Francisco I decided to stop by this place to after seeing online that a jazz pianist was about to play. I informed the host that I was there to catch the music and he proceeded to direct me upstairs. I ordered an old fashioned which happened to be tasty, the only positive of the night. The waited returned and asked if I was ready to order and I politely told him that my friend and I were there to see the pianist, and were planning to order more drinks. I watched as he quickly shuffled to the manager  and whispered something,all the while looking in my direction. The manager came immediately and told me that the "jazz was only for those who ordered food" told us to leave, and to take our time with the drinks....... 

The funny thing was, there were only two other tables being occupied, and at least 10 open. On top of that the waiter had the nerve to offer us more drinks as he brought the bill. 

I obviously cannot speak for the food, but the uninteresting menu only solidifies my decision to never return here. 
What I can say, is that this restaurant obviously does not care about the music it showcases, and it should probably not have any at all. 
There's, not much here that you can't get anywhere else, except perhaps selective waiters who kick you out and try to sell you drinks on the way out.
author: Robert C.

description:
Decent food, not so decent prices. 

The Salads were really fantastic, but the steak wasn't all that special, and the portions are small. 

The service was impeccable however, and the waitress brought us some free drinks at the end of our meal...which we needed to soften the blow of receiving the check. You don't really get what you pay for.
author: Arthur W.

description:
Sure, the place has a history (being referenced in the original source material for "The Maltese Falcon" and all) and the old timey neon sign out front really gives you that vintage San Francisco feel.  But really, once you go inside, it has the same feel as any other small cafe you might find in San Francisco.

Grossly over priced, you'd be better off finding a better steak elsewhere.  Last time, I had their Canneloni, which was OK, but had something in it that gave me a headache.

If you're in a bind and want a semi-SF experience with really fast service, then by all means, go here.  But don't make an evening of it.
author: Jonathan B.

description:
Fantastic restaurant!

Very professional attention to detail. Excellent staff and cozy dining environment. The Porterhouse I ordered was out of this world. Their in-house steak sauce was out of this world!
I had their special 'brown bear(?)' cocktail with kaulua & creme. 
John is running a wonderful establishment and this is a great place to bring your guest from out of town to show off how great our restaurants are in San Francisco.
author: Larry J.

description:
John's Grill is a San Francisco landmark and provides a pleasant and classy environment to dine in.  It is definately not the best deal in town, but you can have an excellent meal if you order right.

My order generally consists of their special salad (Is it called Jack Lelaine), Lobster Ravioli appetizer, and the Lamb Chops----- Do this, and you will be 100% satisfied.   I order the same thing everytime here and have never ever left unsatisfied.

HOWEVER--- I have ordered their steaks before and althought he meat seems quality, I was a little dissapointed that they seemed to put very little preperation into marinating/seasoning their steaks in anyway. I I think they just throw the meat on the grill and thats it....
author: James M.

description: I will NEVER ear seafood here again. Halibut burnt, red snapper soggy and overcooked, Idaho baked potatoes annilhilated. Nice sauce over fish to cover the fact they can't cook. Generous pour at bar from observation only. Did not go away hungry but did not go away with any remotely pleasurable gastro experience.
author: Jennifer F.

description: Started off with the 1/2 shell oysters Blue points and clam chowder,waitress ask how did we like the oysters I told her i like the Pacific oyster better she told me the the blue points were from the pacific they have blue points from the pacific Angel Island I was thinking WTF.The clam chowder was to creamy for my taste we also ordered the seafood pasta it was very good.Had the porterhouse steak was nothing special okay
author: Sam W.

description: This place should count it's blessing for getting 3 star. Probably the worse steak i've ever eaten for the price. Maybe worthy of a $10 steak at best.  I can't believe how crowded it was in there. Must have been because it's close to Union Square because I can't imagine any other reason. Definitely not the food. Waiter and service was terrible. I really didn't want to tip the guy at all. The steak was dry, overcooked and no flavor whatsoever. My friends got the fish and it was dry and overcooked too. I didn't know you can screw fish up that bad. Another Yelper summed it all up when they said you are better off going to Costco and buying a steak and cooking it yourself.  This just goes to prove my theory, most restaurant around tourist area are usually crappy. You would think a restaurant that has been around that long would get it right. Don't waste your time and hard earn money. Save it for the $40 overnight parking in SF.
author: Le L.

description: Stopped by for lunch on a whim based solely on external appearance - looked like a place my grandfather would have hung out. Clam chowder alone makes me a fan - excellent selection of spices, fresh clams. Half baby spinach salad was more than enough portion with wonderfully fresh bacon and rich bleu cheese dressing. Bread was very fresh - perfect compliment to the meal. Can't speak for noise level or attire for dinner - but a very relaxing and quiet place to spend a rainy afternoon.
author: Chris C.

description: Me and my boyfriend decided to go to the city and take in some local flavor. We had originally planned on going down to the wharf on the waterfront but decided to just stay in the Financial District area. We happened on to John's and it was very busy for a Sunday evening. We were seated immediately at a table for two. Our order was taken within 10 minutes of being seated and our drinks were brought to us promptly. We were immediately captivated with the nostalgic feel of the place. Not knowing the history of the place our imagination ran a muck! We ordered Oysters on the half shell for out appetizer. They were some of the freshest oysters we have had, my boyfriend rated them quite highly. He is from the Seattle area and has had his share of them. We ordered the filet, medium rare and the halibut with the intentions of sharing. Can I just say the filet was cooked to perfection and it was fork tender and very tasty. The halibut was grilled and moist on the inside with this mushroom caper sauce that was to die for! The bread was very good but I do agree that the butter in the foil is a little cheesy for image that they are trying to portray. The service was good and our overall experience was very nice. I have been to some very nice steakhouses having lived in Las Vegas for 18 years, the quality of food was very good. The restaurant was very quaint and filled with history...if those walls could talk!  We got out of there for just over $100 and that's with 2 rounds of of imported beer! We thought the prices were reasonable and the food quality was very good. Yes, the area is a little cramped, but if you like the person that you are with... you really don't mind..it adds to the intimacy!
author: Amanda C.

description:
Love this place. We stumbled upon it during the fateful vacation that caused us to pack our bags and move here, and John's played no small role in that decision.

They're supposedly known for their steaks, and my husband says they're delicious.  So far I've had broiled sole, excellent, with crisp vegetables cooked to perfection; the fisherman's pasta, creamy and extremely filling (I actually order it almost every time); the calves liver, sounds scary but it was absolutely delicious; red snapper, also great.

The clam chowder is thick, rich, and creamy.  Seriously, I have never had such good clam chowder.  It may be the very best in the city.  They also have oysters on the  menu, and they were fresh and tasty.  I don't have the nerve to try the escargot, but maybe one day...

One thing to note: their scotch pours are MIGHTY generous.

The service is always attentive and excellent.  The atmosphere is low key so that you can actually hear yourself speak.
author: Jamie C.

description:
What,s not to love about John,s Grill??? It is an old well known establishment and unlike other reviews I found The Maltese Falcon history kind of cool, did not feel they put it in your face!!! You have a choice to read the history or not!! We dined here due to a recommendation and were certainly glad we did!!
The restaurant has a certain dark wood,  cozy charm! We started with the dungeness  crab appetizer!! Trust me, you can,t go wrong! It is fresh and wonderful and is a huge portion of succulent crab!
We went seafood crazy, even though it,s touted as a steak house for the most part! We shared the Cioppino, mostly in search of  the dish being properly prepared and presented! We were not disappointed! It was amazing and again very generous!! We almost couldn't,t finish it!!! In fact, the young couple next to us( yes close proximity) overheard us oohing and awhing and decided to have it as well!!! We ended up having dinner conversation with them, as my husband is very outgoing and we often chat with other dinners!!! Certainly won,t complain that the tables are too close!! It just made for an interesting  eveg!! In fact our waiter insisted on giving us a free desert as he said we were so friendly and  enjoyed the fact that we were chatters!!! It was the Flan,which beats anything I,ve ever tasted in Mexico!!!
Service was impeccable!!! John,s Grill is on my list of fav,s whenever in San Fran!!!
author: lynda M.

description:
We went there on New Years Eve. Service was good but very rushed.
The steamed clams were sooo good. I'm still dreaming about them.
T-Bone, Filet and Snapper were all very good. Everything else was predictable for a place that is living on their 100 year old legend. The atmosphere (and the martinis) at Musso and Frank (in LA) is much better.
Not sure I would go out of my way to eat here but for the steamed clams.
author: Julie S.

description: The food here was just ok, nothing special.  I think that tourists come here more for the atmosphere than the food. My grandparents made reservations here when they were staying in the area for the first World Series game (GO GIANTS!!).  This place was bigger than I thought it would be with three floors for seating.  The waitstaff wasn't particularly helpful.  We had to flag them down if we needed anything and didn't really come back to check on us.  Lucky for them the gratuity was added on because of the size of our party. I can't say I'd come back with all the other options in the city.
author: Lindsey S.

description: If you're looking for a great steak at a reasonable price, this is the place.   Over all, I'd recommend it -- a little shy on getting the steak to "medium-well" but overall tasty and worth visiting again.
author: Mike G.

description:
I, like many Yelper's before me, thought of this place as a tourist trap, a steak house with no soul, a spot that dumb out-of-towners who frequent Olive Garden and Applebee's would "treat" themselves to when on vacation...  This is not the case....

This place is a great white tablecloth and napkin spot for lunch or dinner and you will be treated to a tasty meal.  The fish is fresh, the steaks are large, the sauces buttery and the drinks are stiff.  

This reminds me of Alfreds.  It's not Mortens or the HOPR, but good in it's own right.

I did a lunch with my father and a business lunch here, and was impressed both times.  I will go back.  I had the Lamplighter both times, a couple of sole fillets stuffed with crab and shrimp with a delicious sauce.  

Try it, you will be surprised.
author: Tony A.

description:
I had the clams.  I loved them.  The broth was great.  They quickly and repeatedly brought me the bread to soak up the stuff.  My dad got the lamb chops or maybe the pork chops?  He thought they were great.  The food overall was excellent.

The wait was not worth it.  I should have made reservations. The table was awful.  By the stairs in the back.  

Overall, I'd say it's got its place but it's not meant for my generation.
author: Heidi P.

description: Found John's Grill 5 years ago while out on the town to see a play.  Have been a big fan ever since! The classic atmosphere, small restaurant ambiance and historical charm make this a must stop eatery while in San Francisco.  The Chicken Jerusalem is absolutely fantastic; my wife's favorite.  I've tried every steak on the menu, and have the say that the New York with the touch of peppercorn sauce is a favorite, but the Dijon Prawns are great change of pace from the steaks. Typical dinner for 2 with drinks will run you about $100, but for a fine meal in a nostalgic spot, it's a deal.
author: Mitchell O.

description:
I wasn't at all impressed.  I decided to suggest it based on the reviews here.  Perhaps we were there on an "off" night, but I doubt it.  

Oh, sure, the service was polite and prompt.  My cocktail was good.  And my fish was tasty, but not really worth comment.  And, in my opinion, not worth the $25.  

One of my dining partners, though, ordered a steak cooked medium rare, and received a totally rare steak.  He tried to eat it anyway, and found he was "relieved" to find that it wasn't cooked any longer, because as it was the rare steak was so tough if it had been cooked more, it would have been "shoe leather."

That said, I would have given them 3 stars, but I was terribly disappointed in their bathrooms.  How can they have a ladies room in San Francisco that does not have a coat hook?  Do they expect us to put our purses on the floor?!
author: Karen P.

description: My fiancé, Joe, and I checked into our hotel around noon and were starvin' marvins.  So off we went to scour the area for a lunch spot.  We came across John's and figured it wouldn't be bad.  The walls were lined with pictures of famous patrons who have dined there over the years.  It was pretty dead in there. So we got a chance to just relax with a cocktail while glancing over the menu.  Joe ordered their signature cocktail, the Bloody Bridgit, which comes with a complimentary souvenir mug.  After looking over the menu I had to have the clam chowder.  It is only fitting since we were in SF.  My fiancé had the lobster ravioli.  He cleaned his plate clean and even helped out with my chowder.  Overall, I would come here for a bite but wouldn't make it must go spot when visiting the city.
author: Myra R.

description:
I walked in an the tall man led me to a seat and said he would return with a glass of water. Seven minutes went by and another guy, silent Derek
asked if I wanted a glass of water. There happened to be a menu at the vacant table next to me. Although there were 4 waitresses in and out of the kitchen, the tall guy was making drinks behind the bar and waiting on other tables.
The steak was ok, A-1 sauce was watered, the bread was not sized sliced. The green beans were not trimmed, however the potato was tasty.

As I was eating a few more women came in to begin their shift. The ladies with the shinny party eyes.

The on line menu listed the Filet Mignon at $31.95, I was charged $32.95.
Possibly, the on line menu has not been updated. or I was overcharged.

When I arrived at home there was a charge for $52.00 on my card.
The receipt I received at the table before the tip was $42.10, I had a beer.

I think the correct amount will resolve itself in the next day or so.

I have been here before and this Friday's afternoon experience suggest I not return.

Derek has the social skills of a blanket. The tall guy is too busy.
author: Bill G.

description: Save your money and just go to the Westfield food court and you will have a better meal than this place.  Hubby and I had two friends in town so we decided to try this place.  It just shows that if you're in a busy Union Square area, you're gonna get customers coming no matter how bad the food is.  2 people in our group ordered steak (porterhouse & rib eye). Costco steak is 10x better than their $37 piece of rubber so-called meat.  My husband had the Halibut and it was so overlooked and dry that he had to submerged it in my Cioppino broth to be able to eat it.  I wanted to send it back but hubby thought he might get another surprise when it came back.  My Cioppino was overcooked as well and so bland.  Our waiter was about as friendly and joyful as a retail employee working the midnight shift on Black Friday.  I mention the fish was very dry and he just looked at me and walked away.  Best thing about our meal was the bottle of wine we bought in.  One final tip:  do not eat the free bread.  Those carbs were so not worth it!
author: BXN B.

description: We have eaten here periodically for 25 years. Love the food & menu. The chiioppino is excellent, a nice light tomatoe broth, not the heavy marinara style.. We are more inclined to a late lunch, so realized that Friday night was not for us. We were seated upstairs which is normally quieter, but tonight it was louder than a 49r football game.  We could not even have a conversation (unless we rudely screamed at each other). No dessert or coffee for us tonight, couldn't get out of there fast enough.
author: Linda K.

description: Food was terrible. As mentioned before, the decor is dated. Skip it..
author: Kevin F.

description:
iconic classic san francisco bar.  i can only imagine all the different people this bar has encountered through the years (101 this year) and decades.  i love the dark wood that dresses this restaurant.  

great place to chill out and have a cocktail.  i haven't tried the food, but it seemed to be quite popular as all the tables in the house were full.
author: Sheri N.

description: Was there recently on vacation and was very disappointed. The waiter was rude and not courteous. The Steak was over cooked and over priced for what we got. Dessert menu is limited. Our table was no clean. there was left over rubbish and a napkin on the ground that was not cleaned up. This place may be old and a historic landmark, but the food and service is old also. Needs a renovation for ambiance and menu.
author: Kimmy C.

description: I am a sucker for old-school restuarants that give you the feel of the city as it was years ago, and John's is definitely one of these places. If visiting the San Francisco "proper", make this a destination. ALl food and service met expectations. If you sit downstairs, take the time to explore upstairs.
author: Kevin W.

description: I ordered the swordfish tonight which was tasteless.  If you had blinfolded me I wouldn't have known I was tasting fish - seriously.  Would have returned it for something else but I had to get to the theatre.
author: Paul S.

description: They don't have coffee and they cannot boil water so don't bother asking for an after dinner drink. The chicken was good. Baked potatoes were dry. Not great.
author: Ginger P.

description: My favorite steak restaurant hands down. The meat itself was delicious, full of flavor and juice in every bite. I thoroughly enjoyed the whole experience. The location is ideal and the food was amazing. I highly recommend John's to any steak lover!
author: Esther K.

description: In sf for work and hungry for steak.  Ordered a t bone. It was so chewy my jaw hurt and it was missing the other side of the "t". Service was weak. Had a drink but the waiter never came back to see if we wanted another. Got the dessert menu but the waiter never came back to see if we wanted dessert. Finally gave up and had to flag the waiter down to get the check which was way more than it should have  been for what we got. Boooooooooooo.
author: Max T.

description: Really want to make my rating 3.5 stars. But I can't quite take it to 4. Despite that, John's Grill is a Union Square institution as a site used in the filming of the Sam Spade classic with Humphrey Bogart, the Maltese Falcon. They even have the falcon on display upstairs.Over the years, I have eaten here maybe a half dozen times. In each case, I have been happy, receiving good service and a reliably good meal. I think the most common item ordered at John's is one of the 8 or so steak or chop choices. The only real negative is that it is a bit pricy. Prices are definitely $$$ and reflect that John's receives a fair amount of tourist trade in the Union Square area. Other menu items worth trying are the clam chowder, the big salad for two, and the petrale sole. The wine list is pretty decent and provides enough range for most diners. John's Grill, like Tadich Grill on California, just keeps trucking along.
author: Robert H.

description: I should have checked yelp first, but based on the Google reviews I came to eat here last night. We started with the dungenes crab app. For $17 it really was delicious and fresh, though I could have done without the ketsupy sauce on top. We ordered the chef's special red snapper expecting really fresh snapper only to find a somewhat battered (maybe with flour) fish-stick tasting fish. The veggies to meat/potato ratio was way off and the sauce was more of a gravy with mushrooms and crab/frozen shrimp. The fish was basically inedible and save the gravy sauce I would have just sent it right back and walked out. The menu was not exciting and this place really isn't worth the money OR your time with so many better restaurants in SF. the service also left something to be desired. Didn't refill our drinks or offer another glass of wine. The only great thing there was the bread, and even then after having eaten at Boudins earlier-it was a stretch. Would NEVER go back or recommend.
author: Rebecca P.

description:
I've been meaning to write the review for John's Grill but always forgot.  I suppose now's a good time then any other.   How we came about ending up in SOMA at 8:00 PM on the day before Christmas Eve, don't even ask.  My sisters were with me and so we decided since we were in the area we'll check up on some Christmas shopping and try some new places to eat.  One of my sister's was aching for some seafood and and the other beef.  I didn't have a preference but anything that tastes good and greasy.  As we were making out way back to the park structure we found John's Grill.  They had everything that we wanted to eat so we stepped in and the hosts seated us immediately.  Gave us our menus and got us some bread while we were deciding what to get.  I browsed through the menu the first thing I noticed was price ($$$) so I figured that if I'm spending this much I better have good portions and really good food.  While browsing I decided on their Chef's Special Red Snapper .  My sisters on the other had decided on Prime Porterhouse Steak and Chicken Jerusalem.

The waitress came back and we gave her our orders and while we waited for the food we were admiring their Holiday decor.  Very nice and homely you can say - great place to bring your other half here and enjoy the evening.  While we admired, the waitress filled out drinks up again and gave us more bread.  15 minutes later, our dishes arrived and boy was it looking good.  The Chef's Special Red Snapper dish was just smothered with butter, crab meat, and shrimp.  Just looking at the dish made me salivate and full already.  My sisters dishes looked divine as well - great portions on sides and main dishes.  After ah-uh's we started eating, Sea Bass was like heaven flowing on Cloud 9 and the Prime Porterhouse Steak and Chicken Jerusalem was just so succulent.  Refills on the drinks just kept on coming - I think I finished my usual 3 cups of AP if not more... 

Final review, funny how I was the one ending up getting the Seafood.  I would recommended coming here if your not too worried about the overall cost.  Good times!!!
author: Kong Y.

description: I had lunch here at holiday time.  Nice old San Francisco feel about the place, but the food was just not up to snuff.  And the wait staff were just OK - to the point and efficient.  I guess for this kind of experience I was hoping for a bit more of a personal touch and graciousness.  John's really just trades on its storied name now and I guess the tourists still like it.  The Maltese Falcon is upstairs, but I am not sure it is the real one - wasn't the real one stolen a few years ago?
author: Paul M.

description: I come here once a week and haven't had a bad meal yet. The place has a warm feel and the staff take care of you at a level expected at more expensive restaurants. 'The Maltese Falcon' connection adds some cool points to the place.
author: Scott K.

description: John's Grill is, simply put, one of the best restaurants I've ever enjoyed.  Last night, Better Half took me to John's Grill for dinner before heading off for a show at the Rrazz Room.  We made a reservation earlier in the day in person.  We mentioned at that time how we like the front window - and a large table there was waiting for us when we returned.  I wasn't overly hungry so I passed up my usual rib-eye steak (the best - juicy and perfectly prepared) for the house salad (delish mixed greens and veggies topped with loads of bay shrimp), filet mignon (perfectly cooked - juicy in the middle and not dry at all on the charred outside), baked potato with skin thicker than anywhere else I've eaten, and string beans (very crisp-tender).  BH had red snapper with a sauce that included shrimp and crab, and was superb.  Drinks were outstanding, as always, and service was professional without being snooty.  John's Grill, to me, is the ultimate traditional San Francisco restaurant.  I can't believe it only has three stars on Yelp.  Don't be deterred - John's Grill is truly dining at its best and worth the price.
author: Craig B.

description: Coming to John's Grill is a wonderful childhood memory. My grandmother used to take me on the bus downtown for the day where we would visit her old friends from her days of working at Woolworth's. After we would venture down the alley way to eat here at John's. I remember three distinct things--the people that worked there were nice and always knew my Grandma by name, the decor was fascinating (the Maltese falcon come on!) and the food was delish. Being that creature of habit, I am happy to see they still have my favorite "Marco Polo" on the menu. It's chicken and ham, asparagus, cheese and creme sauce. I've just got to pay a visit here soon..ah memory lane is great!
author: Virgo M.

description:
I love, love, love John's Grill. Entering this grand old establishment instantly transports one back to the civil days of high society when men wore suits and ties with hats all the time, ladies wore their finest dresses and life was generally finer.

I had the John's Steak (bone in New York) - very nice. Served with baked potato and veggie. And the Roquefort salad was great too. I won't say it was the best steak I've ever had but the service was great, and again the decor and ambiance was just perfect.

For those who complained about the place being noisy or crowded or whatever, please leave it to those of us who appreciate the more gentile and nostalgic things in life.

Oh and this is not a kid's place. Come on people - the little ones don't belong in every restaurant!

A must-see and eat (and drink of course) in old S.F.
author: Jeff L.

description: Classic old-school San Francisco. Busy but well staffed. Excellent and well priced cocktails. The wine list, while uninspired, has some good bargains. The food was very good including one of the best steaks I've had in a while. Perfectly cooked, juicy, and nicely seasoned. I would highly recommend bringing out-of-town guests for a taste of SF. And the Black Bird!
author: Chris E.

description: John's Grill is steeped in history and flair but the food isn't. The Oyster dish proudly listed as being mentioned by Cuisine magazine was bland - the spinach  tasted as if it had come out of a can and the oyster smelled fishy. Dad's red snapper special was a frozen fish - it had that rubbery texture. The place was hopping and had pictures of the famous on the walls touting the menu. It left us wondering if they ever returned. Advise you instead go to Farallon or Zuni Cafe - or even Scoma's.
author: Mark H.

description: I wish I could give zero stars if I could...My family and I went here hoping to enjoy a fine San Francisco eating establishment, but we were wrong. We started off by ordering the clam chowder and cesar salad. The clam chowder had a potato to clam ratio of about 10:1 and the cesar salad was so salty that it was virtually inedible. We had already ordered our main course and figured, "well, we already ordered, so we might as well stay and give the food a chance right? WRONG!" I ordered the fried oysters and not only were they oily, they smelled like they have been a few days old. I'm sorry, but I won't eat old oysters. My Mom ordered the crab ravioli, but she mentioned that the taste of crab was lacking. Not only that, but the ravioli's were completely drenched in sauced. (It looked a bit like the clam chowder we had earlier to be honest.) My Dad, being a huge steak lover, ordered a steak and told them to cook it medium rare. The meat was really tough and overdone and had very little seasoning. When we received the check we were blown away by the price. I am fine with paying a little more for good quality food, but this is unacceptable. We ended up eating a slice of pizza at Blondie's down the street because we were so unsatisfied with our meal. Word of advice: if you are looking for a fine dining restaurant in downtown San Francisco do NOT, I repeat DO NOT eat at John's Grill!!
author: Jason R.

description:
I didn't know this place had so much history.  I'd often pass by and wonder what it was like inside.  It looked like it had been around for a long time..1908 to be exact.  The place still has that turn of the century charm to it....dark woods with a low light ambiance.  The only thing that made it somewhat touristy were the celebrity photos plastered all over the walls.  Daschiel Hammett fans will consider John's Grill to be the mecca...the story of the Maltese Falcon takes place around John's Grill.  It's definitely a place of mystery and intrigue, as it seems like a lot of backroom deals take place here.  

I had been hoping to have dim sum that day, but our consultant said he made reservations at John's.  I was game...since he was picking up the tab.  Sure enough, we got there and they had a large table waiting for us.  The place is deceivingly small-looking.  There's actually 3 floors, so while the 1st floor doesn't look like they can handle a crowd, they actually can, and do, especially at nite when they have live jazz upstairs.  While I would've like to have tried one of the steaks, I opted for something healthy...the Jack LaLanne salad.  It fit the bill perfectly.  Fresh greens (no iceberg lettuce), sliced avocado, tomatoes chunks, mushrooms, bay shrimp, and chunks of fresh dungeness crab.  It was delish!  I should have stopped at half the bowl.  The lunch steaks didn't look that expensive at about $22 for a rib-eye.  My co-horts indulged on the same salad as well as  some of the pasta dishes.  Overall, it's a great place to for a meal down memory lane...4.5 stars.  In the words of Bogie..."You're good. You're very good. "
author: JeFF T.

description: I so wanted to like this place, but left feeling sad. Not just disappointed, but sad. Remove the Maltese falcon (both the book and the bird), and what's left is a restaurant which is uncomfortable, grossly over-priced and kind of depressing. If a Maltese Falcon experience is essential to your San Francisco vacation, have a drink at the bar. For God's sake, however, do not allow yourself to be tricked into paying +$30 for chops, a baked potato and three tomato slices. This place defines "tourist trap".
author: Daniel W.

description: My goodness I've never had such a good bloody mary in my life anywhere else. I was fortunate enough to go on a fairly quiet early evening and had a very well prepared and delicious meal. The wait staff was always attentive even when the crowd picked up and quickly it got packed at dinner. I have only been once, it's seems to me kind of like a 'special dinner out' kind of place, but intend on going again very soon since the food was delicious and my experience was that more than memorable =)
author: Posi P.

description: My husband and I just enjoyed a wonderful meal at John's Grill! Our waiter Tony was especially helpful. My shrimp was perfectly done; no problem substituting fresh tomatoes for the baked potato. My husband's grilled liver wasn't quite right so Tony returned with a new entree in a matter of minutes.  This time done perfectly. Would we return? Absolutely!  Would we recommend this place to others?  You bet!
author: Susan B.

description: The hotel recommended this place.  It was great food, great service and I loved the upstairs with the live Jazz music.  It was a surprisingly nice evening.  Great ambience.
author: Stacy T.

description: The Maltese Falcon connection got me in the door. Unfortunately the Grilled Swordfish ($34 total cost) was average at best and the restaurant was extremely loud (annoyingly so) compared to similar restaurants in the Union Square area.
author: Scott M.

description: this place hits the spot when it comes to seafood in union square. it is so funny; i have probably walked past this place like a million times in my life and have never tried this place until now. there are three floors in this restaurant and good thing there are 3 floors because there are sooo many people checking this place out each time i have been here. the place is always packed! i can't say that i am disappointed with the service and the food either. the waiters and hosts are all very friendly and the food was delish. i really recommend the halibut and the lobster ravioli; they were the best dishes on their menu!
author: The Hangry Chef O.

description: Again, objectively, my experience is as follows: It was fantastic. I went with  friends from out of town at last minute on a busy Friday at 6:00 PM and got in right away. The service was very attentive and not obtrusive. We never waited for anything from the fantastic oysters as appetizers, to main courses that were served perfectly timed in between  drinks and soup and all the bread and other stuff.  Nothing was sub-par as far as quality. Yes it is a "famous  place'  due to the Maltese Falcon, but go there because of the food. I sampled  everything from my friends dinners, as we were all curious, and everything was very good. Even the plates I don't care for, like New York strip (it was very tasty an exceptionally tender). It was very crowded, but we were not rushed, and  the place has terrific atmosphere. Initially I did not want to go there but am very glad we did. We even bought some souvenir glasses. There are a lot of bad  restaurants in the Union Square district, and this is sort of touristy due to the Maltese Falcon deal, but if you want an upscale  quality place to have a very good dining experience, go here! I will definitely go again. And as I live here and have for  some time, I rarely eat at Union Square other than Sears, but that is a different type of  restaurant). This place is excellent. Expensive , yes but worth it (in light of all the places in Union Square that are overpriced, and have poor service that are there to fleece the tourists!). this place is excellent, and Objectively, I could not find anything to complain about and tried to give this four and a half stars, but have not figured out how to get the half star yet. GO TO JOHN'S GRILL, IT IS EXCELLENT!
author: Jeff V.

description: We at at John's Grill on our concierge's recommendation on 6/17.  It was a Sunday night, we didn't arrive at the restaurant until almost 9 pm and were seated immediately although the place was almost at capacity.  We were with our two boys, 18 & 14.  Perhaps a bit tourist and cliche but it is San Francisco and, especially with the kids, kind of what you are hoping for! We had a nice meal and good service.  First time the 18-year old ordered clam chowder and is now a big fan!
author: Jen V.

description: I might come back and change my review, but for now I am giving it one star. I was not  able to actually try the food unfortunately because they were so unorganized! We made reservations on New Years Eve, and I understand that is it a busy holiday, but seriously they told us it was a 30 minute wait from our scheduled time. Then when it was almost 30 minutes they said another 30 minutes. We had to leave to go somewhere else because of our other plans. The Restaurant was packed beyond belief as well. There were people standing everywhere, I felt bad for the people who were sitting near the front because they had ass in their face when they were eating. I am not sure if I will ever try to eat there again.
author: Aly W.

description: I ate here with a small group of friends.  I could not believe how crowded such a mediocre restaurant was; I can only conclude that a lot of tourists are being given a bum steer. Basically my problem with this place is that I paid $28 for a listless Ribeye that tasted like it came out of the bargain bin at Safeway. Seriously this was a semi-tough piece of choice meat that was barely of supermarket quality. Bread, average sourdough served with butter packs. For the money you can do a lot better. Plus tables are on top of one another. The Outback would have been a better pick, and I shudder at the thought of the Outback.  Drinks? $13 for a house merlot that tasted like it was poured out of a box courtesy of the Central Valley. I could go on, but  why bother. Many better choices in the Bay Area; avoid like the plague.
author: Eric R.

description:
Three of us were headed out to dinner to celebrate the finish to the end of the work week.  We couldn't find a reservation anywhere else for the time we wanted, this place had an opening, so we though, "why not".  I should have guess it wasn't good when at 6:30pm on a Friday we got a 7:00pm reservation.  It did however pick up while we were there and the place was pretty full when we left around 8:30.  

Let's start with the wait staff.  Our waiter didn't know the menu.  When we asked him to suggest a bottled of wine, he said the house and then could not tell us anything about it.  We had to ask multiple times for Lemon and Steak sauce by catching him as he walked by our table.  

We split the house speciality salad which was okay, despite being very over dressed and finding lots of crab shell.  The bread was stale.  My friend had the Ribeye, which was over done and tasteless.  He took it home for the dog.  I had the prawns, which were not fresh and fishy tasting.  I was only able to eat two because they were that bad.  The sauce they were swimming in tasted like a stick of butter had just been melted and thrown in with some mushrooms.  It was awful!  The vegetables were plain green beans and carrots but they didn't mess those or the baked potato up.  So, pretty much we paid over $25 a plate for veggies and a baked potato.  

I would not recommend this place to anyone, on the contrary, I would steer people away from it.
author: Megan S.

description:
Aye Caramba John's!!!!  The aliens beamed up what was once a great old San Francisco restaurant and transported down a mediocre menu that sells out for the tourists that won't be back. Used to love this place going back 20 years but my last meal wasn't so hot. The bread was served cold, lacked the distinctive SF crunchy exterior, and tasted like it had been wrapped in plastic at some point. The Caesar salad had no anchovies...not even in the salad dressing which tasted bottled.  Fire the chef and get the old one back.
