One that understands a Caesar without anchovies might as well be made from iceberg lettuce.
The waitstaff was inexperienced evidenced by our waitress asking if we wanted a dessert menu, and because we said no, she trotted off without asking if we wanted coffee. The plates were removed haphazardly by whomever walked by. I am going to give you one more chance but if you mess up again, I'll just do the wait at the Tadich Grill.
author: OffToRio B.

description: Had dinner with a large party (25 or so).  Atmosphere was nice and clam chowder was good but steak was marginal at best. Similar responses from the people I ate with. Probably many other steakhouses with better food. Would only go again for someone interested in the Maltese Falcon.
author: Jeremiah P.

description: My friend, is newly into film noir; what better place to celebrate his birthday than John's Grill?  It would be very easy for a restaurant with such a historical legacy to depend upon its name to stay in business, but John's does more than that.  My New York steak was cooked perfectly, partially because the server took the time to make sure we both had a similar understanding of "rare".  The pepper sauce I ordered on the side was as I hoped.  My friend raved about his fish.  I didn't taste it - not a fan of fish.  He remarked on how tender my steak was.  The server gave us time to decide, patiently awaiting a signal from us.  No interruption of our "catch up conversation".  I felt like our interactions with the staff were all geared to my friend's and my enjoyment.    I think I always thought that this place was more for tourists or the very wealthy, but it is very much in reach of the the SF working stiff for special occasions.  I have found a new favorite.
author: Linda B.

description: Yummies. After a weekend of Italian and French food, we decided on good ol' American and were not disappointed. We walked around and couldn't find an American food place open Sunday night in Union Square. Savory seafood was stuffed in our tummies. Very cool atmosphere with the historical pictures on the wall and detailed story on the back of the menu. Good service, too.
author: Darla V.

description: Daniel W was right on. This place is nothing but a "tourist trap". Disgusting, overpriced food. The worst service I have ever experienced and $30 entrees- YIKES!!! I assume they are banking on the one time customer. I can't imagine anyone would subject themselves to this place twice!
author: Michelle D.

description: Had a 'bloody brigid' at the bar... signature drink of the place and apparently the name of 'the girl' in 'The Maltese Falcon'... the bartender was a cool guy... and I got a free glass with the drink.. woo-hoo!  haven't eaten there yet, just stopped in to rest my weary feet on Black Friday (too much shopping!)  The inside looks like an old NY, NY joint.
author: Tessa R.

description: Just returned from dinner, We treated out of town guests and had a simply wonderful  dinner at John's Grill. We were seated on third floor since there were five of us and the tables are larger. Lovely room with flowers in center of table. It felt like a private room.  The food was exemplary. Two had steaks, one had liver, one sole and I had Prawns Dijonnaise.  I licked my plate.  Service was wonderful with the waiter recommending John's label Cabernet which was delicious. After reading some mixed reviews on Yelp I was a bit nervous to take guests to this restaurant. But we were absolutely delighted with food, service and old San Francisco atmosphere.  Don't hesitate to go!
author: Fran G.

description: One word - EXCELLENT! OK, I'll elaborate - clam chowder was by far the best I've tasted in years. Phil's in Moss Landing has always been my favorite but now I have a new favorite! If you like sole, crab and shrimp order their famous "Lamplighter". Tasty!! It doesn't hurt that it has that old SF ambiance. Great place to eat in the Union Square area.
author: Nancy D.

description: We went here to celebrate my Dad's 65th birthday. The ambiance is very classic San Francisco. Got to love that. The food is another story. It could be my fault that I didn't order a steak at a steakhouse, but the night before I had a filet at Ruth's Chris (that's another review that will be forthcoming), so I opted for sea bass. It had potential but it was a bit underdone for my liking. My boyfriend ordered crab cocktail as an appetizer. It was soooooo good. Add a star for that dish alone. My Dad had a steak and he seemed very happy with it. Another star for pleasing him on his birthday. We brought our own cake and they cut it and added fresh fruit and a few other touches which was a very nice touch. Star for that. I made our reservation on Yelp, that's the last star.  All in all it was a good experience.  My only gripe is that we waited a while for our server and I had to ask for refills on my water more than once. What can I say, I love San Francisco tap water. When I'm visiting my hometown I want my water. Nuff said.
author: Michelle H.

description: Walked through the restaurant to the top floor and the fish smelled like stinky feet.  So I decided to order a steak.  Told the waiter med rare and if not right, to make the error on the rare side.  Steak care medium.  Ordered another and it was cooked perfectly.  However the quality of the meat was mediocre at best.  So many good restaurants in the area, skip this place with ok food and bad atmosphere.
author: Adam B.

description: not a bad place for some steak.  the filet mignon was decent...not too expensive and it came with veggies and mashed-tatoes.  adding an extra star because of the pianist that was there this past saturday night.  beautiful voice and played good soul music.
author: Mike B.

description: 7 of us ate there last night.  The steaks and sea bass were quite good.  The "seasonal vegetables" were quite plain and included those "snack-sized" carrot pieces sold in grocery stores.  At a restaurant like this, I find that barely a notch above frozen veggies.  But perhaps the biggest disappointment ... we ordered a $48 bottle of "old vine" zinfandel, which turned out to be Gnarly Head which can be bought at Trader Joe's for about $10.   When dining out, I expect to pay double for a bottle of wine what I can buy it for retail.  But 5x mark-up?  That's getting a bit ridiculous.
author: Mark L.

description:
Our experience here was great. 

We started with a delicious crab cocktail and a glass of wine. For our main curse, my husband ordered steak and I ordered their jumbo prawns. My dish had this delicious sauce (If you like shrimp, you will love this dish!.) It wasn't too heavy and it came with vegetables and a baked potato. I loved it. My husband really liked his dish as well. Next, we ordered dessert. Their pecan pie was delicious!!! 

Our waitress was really nice and friendly. The place has this elegant/classy decor. I could tell people around me was having a good time, too. I am dependently coming back.
author: Shirley S.

description: One goes here for the history and for the lamb.  I think the location great fun, it is very old school, skip the seafood, stick with the lamb!
author: Susan M.

description: I had a good prime rib though not really phantastic. It was crowded and had a nice atmosphere. I remembered the Maltese Falcon.
author: aliknecht

description: I'll get right to the food which was inconsistent at best. The prawn cocktail was sizable and cooked perfectly, however the cocktail sauce tasted like ketchup. My filet mignon was done well and was good. The asparagus was soggy and the hollandaise sauce was salty. Vanilla bean ice cream was excellent as was the berry dessert. The pecan pie around the sides tasted really dry untill you got to the middle and it was moist and good. For such an historic restaurant, the first floor atmosphere  was blah and dark and we sat by the window. Walking up to the second floor bathroom, the dining room was beautiful. We did not have a reservation and maybe that is where you sit with a reservation. I believe that is what I overheard the hostess saying. All in all a mediocre dining experience and not worth the money. There are many other dining options in the area which are better.
author: Ryan D.

description: I must have walked this place a hundred times, and I always thought it was a hole-in-the-wall tourist trap.  It is so not.  John's Grill is the place to go to if you want that authentic, old time San Francisco feel.  Great place to take out-of-town guests, especially those who have seen the Maltese Falcon or are into 1906 earthquake memorabilia.  Come on, you know Mom and Dad will love it.
author: Ryan L.

description: Overrated, cool atmosphere, too bad they can't add the flash from the walls into the pan.
author: Drew H.

description: Great steak?!  Hardly!  I ordered prime rib,my wife ordered steak, and we tried each other's.  So did the couple we were with. The only thing consistent was that ALL the meat was tough and lukewarm.  I love my steak, but I'm the kind who also likes the vegetables, too. Too bad -- their's were way overcooked and oozed all over the plate.  The baked potato was great -- but it's hard to screw up a baked potato.  If your in SF near Union Square, try someplace else.  Any place else...
author: Harry E.

description: Just to let you know, this review is based on a less then enjoyable experience about two years ago (don't plan on going back).  The food was what one could expect in the heart of a tourist area; edible and you make it out the door in one piece (and we did).  The beef was not fully cooked (ordered well done) and reminded me of the steak sandwiches they used to have at Carl's Jr. many years ago.  The friends salad was anything but fresh (lettuce brown on edges).   If you are starving and need food you can get about the same quality at the Jack in the Box up the street and save 80%,
author: John C.

description: The staff was friendly (but not a quick meal by any means) and the food was good, but they need to do something about the cockroaches.  I finished eating just to see one scurry across the bar...and the bartender seemed to think it was normal to have roaches hanging around.  news flash- it is most certainly not.  I dont care if the building is 100 years old; no one wants anything to do with cockroaches.  needless to say I won't be coming back until they exterminate those things.
author: Tom J.

description:
I went here with a group if seven. Big mistake. We were seated on the third floor where I can only assume that the new servers are trained. This is the only reason I can think of why we would have such HORRIBLE service. Our server could not remember who ordered what, addressed the ladies at the table as girls and rudely interrupted conversations for no good reason. To top it off, at the end of the meal we were commanded to basically either order dessert or get packing because the kitchen was closing... At 9:30 on a Saturday night? Really? It's obvious that the server saw a party over 6 and knew his gratuity would be included so there was absolutely no reason to try and do his job in any respectful manner. 

As for the food: pretty much everyone ordered the filet cooked from either medium rare up to medium well. I assume that the server guessed which ws which as they came out because no one got what they wanted and the "medium well" looked like straight hamburger. The cold steaks are served with cold green beans and an undercooked baked potato with nothing on it. We had to ask for butter and/or sour cream. No chives, no bacon and oh yeah... It was cold just like everyhing else. One girl ordered the halibut and I applaud her for even taking a bite. I am very weary of iffy looking seafood. 

As we were leaving, my friend ripped her new sweater on the broken chair. When she informed the waiter he told her that she should write the owner to have him pay for it. No apology, no nothing. Pretty much topped off a horrible meal, but it will make for a good story to tell when we all get together again and I'm glad that I now have a restaurant that I feel comfortable talking trash about to everyone I know!
author: Liz W.

description: My dinner was fabulous, and I'm glad they take reservations very seriously. We arrived 2 minutes before 7pm and we were seated by 7.15pm. There were lots of people who dint make reservations but had to wait in case of no-show or cancels. The halibut was awesome. Will definitely come back
author: Sandie K.

description: dont really know whats up with the mixed reviews i really liked this place.  old school pictures on the wall kept my attention while waiting for my fabulous steak dinner.  i will definitely be back next time i have out of town company!
author: sarah w.

description: Yes, I know it's touristy and pricey, but this place has history.  It's a real "man's club" kind of place - dark wood walls, cocktails, steaks.  The filet mignon I had was good - cooked just as I requested, and buttery.  Vegs were nothing to write home about, (overcooked broccoli/undercooked baked potato) but the garlicky sauteed mushrooms were delicious.  Nice wine list, and "continental" fare for when you're feeling a little dapper and want an old fashioned supper with a nice  broad.
author: Asteridae A.

description: We stop off here a few times for a couple of drinks on the way to the BART station at Powell. The place is old and comfortable, especially in the late afternoon before the crowds come in. Nice and quiet and dim. Drinks are good, and I had the best dirty martini there yesterday.  Never eaten here yet so can't comment about the food.
author: Mr P.

description: We were around downtown and started getting hungry. There weren't a whole lot of choices where we were, so we decided to eat at John's for lunch. Now, normally, I understand that dim lighting is great for a nice romantic dinner, but for lunch? It was dark in there. Not only that, but that place had a funk. Like stinky feet. The carpet can use a serious steam vac. I ordered a burger. This is not a fancy burger, but just a simple restaurant style burger. Guess how much? $12 bucks!!! yeah, $12 for a freaking burger. Definitely not worth it.
author: Jun W.

description: First time was a great experience...although it was take out.  Dined there for my birthday and the service was terrible.  Good steak not so great seafood...I'm still on the fence with this one...it is unique to San Francisco but they need to step it up if they want to stay in business for another hundred years.  (they've been open for a hundred years)
author: Christina G.

description: 90 minutes after we placed our order the food NEVER ARRIVED!!!  We left in disgust.  VERY unprofessional service.
author: Vincent B.

description: WHO LOVES CRAB?????????? This is the place to go if you love crab...order the crab cocktail...it might be considered a bit pricey but boy is it worth it!!! they give you a lot of crab and a really good cocktail sauce...if you like chicken marsala...make sure u try their chicken jerusalem...they also have good lambchops....then check out the decor while u r eating...very interesting and a lot of history there....
author: Mee-stique K.

description: I love this resturaunt.  My husband and I went there for the first time in November and the ribeye was the best i have ever hadwe went again recently and the lamb was just as good as the ribeye.   Great jazz music played on the second floor.  my only complaint is how close you are to everyone else in the resturaunt... not a whole lot of space.
author: Michelle C.

description: A cockroach climbed up the wall and then up  my sleeve. I went postal and the staff seemed to think cockroach enfested lunches were acceptable. They are not.
author: Robin P.

description: Not very good. The halubit is overwhelmed with a mushroom sauce. The baked potatoes are clearly overcooked in a microwave. The chef seems to be uninspired and taking short-cuts impacting the taste and quality of the dishes. I would go somewhere else with all the choice available is SF.
author: Pat c.

description:
One star for the history.  Barely two stars for the food.  So a total of three stars.  Or is it two stars for the history and one for the food?  How can a famous grill with a long history not know how to make a steak?  Ours were overcooked, bland and DRY.  So disappointing - this is the kind of place where you should be able to eat well.  

I can almost (almost) forgive the salad with the cup of bland blue cheese (really, it was supposed to be blue cheese?) dressing - you do pay extra for it so I guess they want you to get your moneys worth, at least quantity-wise.

Go in for a drink (expect they should be good) and the old-time atmosphere, but forget the food.
author: sweaterhead x.

description:
I'm giving them one star because the food was really good. The service was terrible. We waited 20 minutes for water and had to ask 4 times and go to the bar before we were served water. Our server never once checked on us to see how we were doing and if we needed anything. 45 minutes after ordering, our food finally arrived at that time we asked for our check. The check never came until we asked the hostess for it again, 10 minutes later. We paid cash for our check and when they change came back we were shorted a quarter. I know what you're thinking, it's just a quarter. But that was also the servers tip which she didn't get because that quarter never made it back to me. I am all about tipping well for good service and trust me when I tell you a 25 cent tip was more than she deserved. 
The Hostess was pretty amazing she filled up our water and fetched our server from time to time. I would give another half star for the hostess if I could.
author: Cyndee G.

description: There are certain places in every city in the world that are so steeped in history and ambiance, that simply being there and dining in the same surroundings where so many others have created history makes it spectacular.  John's Grill is such a place, a legend in a city where the word cannot be applied lightly.  To have survived 101 years should count for something, and it does.  The food is exactly as one should expect...good, solid, marvelous American fare.  The service has always been gracious, prompt and efficient.  If you go to San Francisco, this is a must dining experience.
author: Bert B.

description: This place is fun. It's small and romantic and is a great addition to any weekend away in the City because of it's historical aspect. My boyfriend and I have been here twice and have been impressed each time. Kinda pricey, like most things in the City, but the service is top notch and the food is great! I don't recommend this place for people with younger children because it is small and quiet. We've ordered both steak and seafood dinners and they were exactly as ordered. I had the seafood cannelloni, which was the best I've had, but you must like seafood because it's cram-packed!  A full, creative bar also. John's Grill seems to be a staple in the area, as the waitstaff knew peoples names with recognition.
author: Kelly O.

description: Best clam chowder I have had west of the Mississippi.  Nothing in the city has touched it and usually is the only thing I go for.  Have been hungry enough for a pasta dish and a couple of the salads at times.  Would also recommend Jack's Favorite Salad, a good treat but hard to down by yourself.  The ambiance is sort of an old school, rustic but classic feel, with some emphasis on old.
author: Matt C.

description:
just had to go even though its a big tourist spot.  staff was great.  dining is cozy.  menu is about as simple as it gets - seafood or steak.  no column a column b column c.

i never considered myself a food snob but maybe my friend is right when he says its human nature to get spoiled.  its really hard to find a good steak.  the only places that make it better than in my own kitchen are l'incontro trattoria in astoria (filet mignon) and kai mishimaya steak.  i've got to give john's credit, they have angus, dry aged, they cooked it just right pink an dbloody inside torched outside.  i really want to say i loved it but it just tasted like a peter luger piece of plastic.  so sorry to say.

its still a good trip to check out this place though.  and its fun to walk around union square when you're done.
author: Norman S.

description: Went to John's Grill and once again was not disappointed. Good service, good food and a real step back in SF history. Yeah, the place in small and the seating is tight, but it gives you a true sense of "old San Francisco".  It's been in the same location since 1908 and serves great steaks & stiff drinks - try their "Bloody Bridget" and keep the glass!
author: Kenny P.

description: John's Grill has the best New York Steak I have ever had in my life!!. I went here with my friend before a Giants vs Dodgers game on Sept 27, 2008 and I had the NY Steak with a baked potato, veggies, bread and clam chowder with a coke, the clam chowder is some of the best I have ever had too, my friend had the halibut steak and also had clam chowder too and he loved the food too. It's expensive but you get what you pay for. I will be back again!!
author: Ryan D.

description: The sole was extremely good and it had large portions.  It's a good place for a romantic dinner.  The only downside was the service was slow and a bit rude.  It is also a bit expensive, but it is reasonable for the level of restaurant.
author: S D.

description: A San Francisco institution.  Dashiell Hammett sent Sam Spade here in The Maltese Falcon, and the decor hasn't changed since. Dark, moody and just a little seedy, but ooozzzeess ambiance. However, since vegetarians didn't exist in the 30's (that was sarcasm, folks) those of you who are herbivores would be wise to eat elsewhere, and then come for a drink.
author: Jude F.

description:
Have you ever went to such a FINE establishment and had so much to say that you did not know where to start that is where I am. I went to the Historic Johns Grill, open since 1908 and the home of the Maltese Falcon. When I arrived at the three-story building at 63 Ellis I learned from the host that it is one of the oldest and most famous establishments in San Francisco. Funny thing is, every time I have looked down Ellis (between Stockton and Powell) I have wondered what it was like inside because of the HOT location and traditional red awning...reading steaks, seafood, and cocktails.

The host was extremely friendly and with a beautiful smile he asked us where we would like to dine. We told him it did not matter. He suggested the upstairs where the guitar player would be and we agreed. As we walked through the restaurant, I noticed the plethora of past customers and celebrities covering the walls inch by inch. It was amazing...so many faces and names from Hillary Clinton to Clint Eastwood. We were escorted through a full house on the first floor to the second, which is known as The Maltese Falcon Room. The room is in honor of Author Dashiell Hammeett who used Johns Grill as a setting in his book. I also learned that Johns Grill is a National Literary landmark. I did not get a chance to see the third floor but maybe I can hold a private party there hmm  The furniture was totally original and from The old San Francisco. It provided an exquisite atmosphere to dine in. The host informed us of the specials for the evening before he departed our lovely table. Shortly after our waiter came over and asked us what we would like to drink and if we had any questions about the menu.

Cyril ordered the special house drink called the Bloody Brigid which came in a souvenir glass and it tasted SO delightful. Rene had a beer and I had a Bay Breeze. We started off with the Jumbo Prawns and Dungeness Crab Cocktail ($10.95). The nice sized portions came in the most adorable silver I have ever seen. The seafood was fresh and tasty. We also ordered a bowl of the New England Clam Chowder ($5.95) which I HIGHLY recommend. The soup was so splendid, it melted in my mouth and I groaned after every spoon full. For a salad we ordered the Seafood Florentine ($15.95) for two. The salad consists of fresh spinach, crab, shrimp, and special dressing. The dressing was light yet creamy, it was the perfect combination.

For our main course I ordered the Broiled Swordfish ($21.95) and they each ordered a steak (Filet Mignon ($26.95) and New York Cut Steak ($24.95). The slab of meat was the perfect size sitting next to a baked Idaho potato. The fish and steaks were just so full of flavor! To top it all off after unbuttoning my pants we had the White Chocolate Cheesecake ($5.95), Carmel Flan, and coffee. It was so yummyevery bite had my approval. The meal was just TO DIE FOR! It was absolutely the best meal I have hadmy mouth is still watering! The secret is out, Johns Grill is the MOST PHABULOUS place to go for steaks and seafood in the city!
author: Tamara M.

description: I love this place for lunch, service is very smart and quick.  The prime steaks are probably the best deal in SF and a great location too boot.  You have to luv the atmosphere.  But please do not try and rely on your cell phone in this joint.
author: Paul L.

description: Stopped here for lunch after an interview.  Everyone working was very nice and professional.  I had the beef tips and a salad special for $9.95.  Very, very good.  Place is a little small, but there is a second floor.  The bar could have hung a little further out, but no biggie.  Didn't catch the bartenders name, but he had been working there for over 20 years.  Pretty cool guy.  Wait staff messed up a couple Anchor orders so he gave them both to me.  You have to give five stars just for that.  :)
author: Shawn S.

description: Went here on a lunch date expecting to have a great steak meal due to the hisory of this place. I was disappointed. Ordered the Porterhouse medium well and got a half steak, half fat slab. Nothing great with this meal, just an ok steak with way too hard and crunchy asparagus. The service was slow and unattentive and the place wasn't even busy. This place has been in the city since the turn of the 20th century and it smelled like it. It's no bigger than my bedroom. I'm going to try Morton's steakhouse next a few blocks away. I could get a better steak at an Applebee's.
author: Erik W.

description:
I've experience much better. In fact, when I was there, I'd ordered one of their fish entrees. After it was brought to me and I'd taken a bite, the waiter came by and took it from me, claiming they'd brought me the wrong meal. I said I didn't care, I liked it fine and would gladly pay for this other dish. He still took the plate from me and made me wait for the "correct" dish. What the hell is this? I took a bite! What'd they do with the dish I ate? Did they give it to someone else? I took a bite from a plate of food. Isn't there some rule out there stating once someone takes a bite from a dish that dish is theirs - even if served  to them by mistake?
Avoid. They steal your food. And then they replace it with something less edible.
Oh, and my wife said her food sucked, too.
author: David A.

description: We came to SF for labor day weekend and wanted to eat at a local steakhouse for dinner. I googled and found John's Grill to be of walking distance from our hotel. I called and made last minute reservations, literally 20 mins before we were going to arrive. We have a 4 year old and were prepared for a non "child" friendly restaurant (like most steakhouses). They were very accommodating! We were seated on the 2nd floor with soft live jazz music. We ordered the escargots, steam clams, T-bone steak and surf & turf (petite filet mignon & prawns). They also did a pasta w/butter sauce for our son. The food was excellent!! There are tons of steakhouses where we live.... I have yet to go to one where they are able to cook a med well filet the way I like. John's did it perfectly! No redness, no charring, nor was it tough. The huge prawns were very lightly breaded and delicious! The only thing I thought was just ok was the complimentary bread; it was cold and a little hard. Other than that the service was wonderful and food came out in a timely manner. My son loved the music so much he did not fuss at all. We will eat here again next time we visit SF.
author: Twiggy S.

description: This is still one of my favorites in all of San Francisco. I first went here on a Saturday afternoon for a stiff drink before I visited my accountant upstairs (I was expecting bad news). The barman poured a Tanq & Tonic that was 80% Tanq. I said, "I like the way you pour a drink". He said, "We wanna keep you coming back". And that they do. The Porterhouse steak is my favorite in The City. This is the place that got me to eat & like clam chowder. The seafood cannelloni is riiiich! Delicious. This place is "old San Francisco". A bit touristy, yes, but still mainly locals from all the times I have been there (about 80 times). Luis is the man to see at the bar. My only gripe is that, for as many times as I have been there, would it kill them to comp me a drink? Not one so far. Anyway, try this place out and you won't be disappointed.
author: Eddie L.

description:
Wow, I guess this was an off night at John's Grill. We had eaten here in November and it was wonderful.  Based on that experience I suggested John's Grill for our party of eight.  I made reservations a day in advance and we were seated at once in the upper dining room. There was a guitarist playing as entertainment which was a nice addition.  We ordered drinks and our salads and wonderful sourdough bread was served as well.  The salads and drinks were all very good.   You can imagine my suprise when we received our food.  I ordered the Sea Bass, another person ordered the Chef's Redfish and the third ordered Halibut.  I asked my friend to the right of me if her fish was warm, she tasted it and she said not really.  Uh oh..  I asked my husband and another man in our party how their Porterhouse steaks were and I got the so so hand motion from them.  The other three in the party said their food was okay but we all realized that the green beans and the carrots which were part of the veg melody were not warm at all.  Yes, we should have said something, and I'm kicking myself now for not bringing it to the attention of our server.  Having eight people all send back their food would have not been pleasant at all, but again, we should have said something.
I would have loved to given John's a much higher rating but I just can't. Bummer.
author: Kate L.

description:
We went on the Valentine's night.  Initially, we were very happy that we got our table within 10-15 mins when we were 30 mins late due to traffic in downtown SF.  
Unfortunately, my steak is overly cooked; medium rare looks like a medium well.
Crab cocktail was delicious; 5 stars for it!, and so is the mash potato.

My wife was very disappointed with the service at the end, where we should be receiving a gift and a free desserts.  Everyone was received them except us.  Waiter came and gave us a bill without even asking us.  
I waited and call the waiter back to ask about the desserts and he said with exact quote "oh, i thought it was gone, so i didn't get it for you guys, let me check again".
I believe he should told us that in the beginning.  This is unacceptable!

There were supposed to be a Jazz music playing, but i guess not.

For the price, i wouldn't want to go back again, although this place has been opened since 1906.

Not going back again!
author: James L.

description: John's Grill is an Ok place to have a dinner. We did go on Valentines Day, So maybe I'll have to try it again. However, during our time there. The food was way over priced, $10.00 for a $5.50-$6.00 Caesar Salad. The Prawn Cocktail was great! The Drinks were good as well. Futhermore, I had the Poterhouse Steak Medium Rare, it had no flavor. They offered me A-1 sause. I shouldn't have to add A-1 to a $40.00 Steak. The Service took awhile aswell, about 30-45 min between each item. Overall, I would give them a chance again but maybe not during a holiday.
author: Jack S.

description: Had their mussels (tasty) and steak (juicy and perfect medium rare) which were both GREAT! Love the ambience and deco.
author: T L.

description: So my delicious and perfectly sized (small) filet mignon steak was more medium than medium rare.  Not a deal breaker.  What a relief not to have a choice of what goes with your entree.  The baked potato was good and the veggies were delightfully al dente.  The jazz music was sporadic, the carpet on the stairs is funky (I don't want to know what happened there) and the bar tender was too loud.  Otherwise, I was pleasantly surprised by my first foray into "Herb Caen" world.  Perfect place for the steak and potatoes people. The fish is good too.
author: Holly B.

description: I don't know what possessed me and one of my closest friends to eat at this place. It's not that the food was bad, but with their prices you expect more. I ordered the filet mignon and it was kinda dry, which was disappointing cause our server kinda hyped it up a little. My friend got a huge steak and he was a little too well done. Also, when we ordered water they gave us some kind of high priced water. Service was good, and the food wasn't unbearable, but most definitely not worth the price.
author: Rommel N.

description: I could live on the Jack LaLane Salad!  Steaks, chops and drinks good too.  Nice room with an interesting history.  Great for dinner, and I've been to some nice events in the upstairs dining room. The only disappointment I've had with this place over the years is the size of the bar area.  Several times I've come in with a group of friends for a drink after an event downtown and there's been no space for us, and the hosts are often uncooperative about it.
author: Kim M.

description:
This place was very disappointing. I thought the food was average and definitely not worth the price. I did like my drink though, especially since it came in a souvenir glass. I don't like most souvenir glasses, especially plastic ones, but I felt compelled to get one for some reason. 

Anyway, the food was forgettable, but the place is fairly interesting. There are lots of photos on the wall and that kept me occupied while waiting for my dinner. It's good to have something to do while waiting.

The biggest disappointment of all was the Maltese Falcon display. I expected something grand. It wasn't even close. The best part was seeing the book in different languages.
author: Aileen P.

description: Good seafood. Not on the "lighter" side but if you are in the mood for  a dark joint and some good buttery seafood - this is a good place.  Old School through and through.   If you are down in the Union Square area and need a place for a business lunch - this place gets a big "Okay."   Dinner, steak, red wine and a cigar after.
author: Rick L.

description: Had a really good time here. The food was good, the drinks are strong and the energy is high!
author: S. L.

description: Great attentive service with good suggestions - wine list is reasonable - not certainly something a wine snob would be happy with - but appropriate for the fare. Mussels were done correctly, sauce was very good for dipping with house bread. Wine selections from waiter were well-placed. Porterhouse steak was just the right consistency - not overdone - with some life left in it still (ordered medium-well) flavorful throughout. Appreciated the generosity on the sour cream for the baked potato - and even the side vegetables were not overdone. Chocolate mousse dessert was very very good with the right selection of fruit sides without overdoing it. Espresso was flavorful - not burnt. Overall, an experience I would have expected from a top-notch steakhouse like one of my favorites, like Morton's (the one in Chicago). Definitely a consideration for a Saturday night meal to start off the evening.
author: Adrian J.

description: I love the little gems of old San Francisco and this is definitely one of them. It seems like the reviews here swing dramatically. I've only been here once so I must've went on a good day. The steaks were great as were the side dishes. The cocktails were really good and strong. The ambience was lovely and I really dig all the old photos and dark wood. It's old places like this that exude the charm that made people fall in love with SF in the first place.
author: Gerald U.

description: Johns has a pretty good steak, ok sides, and a nice bar menu. It has a darkness that you would equate to a really romantic place, but the closeness of your table to the table next to you negates that. overall it is good, but people should get a little more elbow room.
author: dave d.

description: Good old time feel atmosphere. Nice and comfy on the second floor. Good  dungeon crab cocktail. I ordered the pepper steak medium rare on the rare side. Minus one point for giving me medium rare. Minus one point for not letting me substitute my baked potato for a small garden salad. It's a nice enough restaurant where the customer should get what she wants. Tables are kind of  small where plates are cluttered and cramped. Gives you a good reason to not order too much. Nice patient waiters which is good. Delicious pinot noir. Not bad  because of the company but it  is definitely NOT comparable to Morton's or Ruth Chris.
author: Yenly M.

description: Sam Spade would definitely approve - although it would probably take him a while to decide on what to order. It must have taken me at least 20 minutes to decide. There are so many great options - and if you're hungry you're definitely going to want a bit of everything. Here's what I recommend: the shrimp and crab stuffed sole, crab ravioli and clam chowder for starters. Oh, and don't forget the Bloody Mary to get it all going!
author: Ivy M.

description: Don't believe the hype.  This place is a tourist trap with terrible service.  The steak was so-so.  You could do better buying a steak from Safeway and cooking it at home.  Sorry John's Grill, but you suck.
author: Daniel B.

description: My husband and I decided to be spontaneous and wander around San Francisco to find a hidden gem of a restaurant for our anniversary dinner. When we walked past this restaurant, a gentleman outside handed us a menu and asked if we wanted to come in for dinner. We had been wandering for awhile so this seemed like fate. The place does look like a nice anniversary dinner spot inside. Dark, intimate, fresh flowers on the table, and a romantic atmosphere. Except for the strong rotten fish odor that nearly knocks you out before you can sit down. Our waiter brought us cold, disgustingly sour sourdough bread with a very tough crust. The butter was frozen and would not spread, nor did it taste good. I thought those little foil wrapped bars of butter were only served in back alley truck stops in the middle of hick town. The waiter made no suggestions when he saw I was struggling to make a decision on a drink from the wine list. He huffed off. When he came back, he had a poor attitude. My husband ordered the bloody something or other signature drink. It was gross. I ordered the pomegranate cosmopolitan and after a 20 minute wait, my husband asked the waiter what happened to my drink and the waiter said they had to go get more pomegranate juice. Thanks for telling me that sooner, you know, I think for a $10 drink, you could at least let me know what's going on. The alcohol in the drink was a disaster! The alcohol made my lips, mouth, throat, and stomach instantly turn into a pit of fire. Even the slice of lime was a disgrace, more like a little square chunk. How do you screw up a lime slice so badly? FOR TEN BUCKS???? I tried a second drink and the fire only burned worse. I ordered the filet mignon, which came with a potato that was burnt on the outside and undercooked on the inside and a pile of practically uncooked, untrimmed green beans that had sharp edges perfect to cut your mouth with! Mixed in with the awful green beans were two little pieces of flavorless, but perfectly steamed carrots. The steak was rather good and had some good flavor. My husband and I both ordered our steaks medium well, but mine was pink and slightly bloody and his was a grayish brown color inside. Overall, really a horrible experience. The dinner has ruined my anniversary and my feelings towards San Francisco. My husband and I have never eaten a $100 dinner together before because, quite frankly, a dinner doesn't need to cost $100 to be delicious. How can I not be mad that we spent $100 (the bill was $94 and change for 2 steaks and 2 drinks, the waiter got the change from the $100 for his tip) to eat the worst meal of our lives on our anniversary no less? This is the smallest tip I have ever left anywhere and I don't feel guilty because the waiter was rude. Everyone working there was very unprofessional. Arguing, whistling at each other, no courtesy, smacking each other with towels, and I heard one waitress arguing with a customer because he was complaining about his $10 cocktail being awful! We wanted to send our food back, but since the staff so unprofessional we chose not to. I would rather be stuck with undercooked food than eating green beans that got stomped on and spit on! Oh and let me add, the glass that my cosmopolitan was served in was a disaster and kept spilling all over the place. This restaurant was so bad I don't even want to come back to San Francisco ever again.
author: Phylicia B.

description: I'll be the first to admit I had a good time here.  The staff was really nice and helpful.  The downside was that the place felt really cramped and I can't imagine having a smaller table.  The meal was good but did not justify the price.  I'll go there again, but I'll be better prepared to deal with the downsides.
author: prior O.

description: Being a Humphrey Bogart fan and all, I of course demanded a pork chop, potato, and a slice of tomato. It was...eh. For the dollars I shelled out, the food was a bit lackluster. BUT...those goddamn cocktails are stiff. My Manhattan had about four droplets of vermouth, which is both rewarding and ridiculous. So if you're a tourist in desperate need to dine next to the maltese falcon, might as well drop by. It's, you know...kind of pretty.
author: Ryan R.

description: The only thing good about this place was our server. The food was bland and dry. Seriously, how hard is it to cook a steak? The fish you ask? Do people out here no how to cook with any type of spice or herbs? Not to mention the food being served on what looks like early a.d. pottery. Drinks were overpriced and weak. The ambiance all together is non existent. I hope John can appreciate the hard work and professionalism of his server. It wasn't a surprise to hear he was from New Orleans.
author: Jonathan R.

description: John's is an alright restaurant to sit down for a steak and a drink. It appears to be always busy, and is cramped in space. Our waiter was acceptable, but also disappeared for periods of time. The highlight of our dinner was the Jack LaLanne's salad. That would be five stars if I could rate it separately! My steak was decent, but not spectacular. My wife's cannelloni was overly cheesy and spinach-y. A little more attention to the amount or flavor of the crab in the filling could have improved the taste, but the amount of cheese would have been overwhelming still.
author: Mike B.

description: If you want to pay $31.00 for a rubbery steak that could be better prepared at home, and boring baked potato with some steamed peas...buy all means order the "John Steak".
author: Andrew S.

description: I wanted to like it - based on what I read.  But couldn't get past the fact that the bar seating had zero leg room.  In other words, all the space under the bar was reserved for bar storage, not customer comfort.  So if you wanted to eat say...a burger, you had to pull the plate up to the edge of the bar, lean way forward and basically jut both knees out to the side.  It sucked, and I can't believe I'm even giving it two stars.  Anyway, the burger was average, and so was the service.  Nobody seemed very happy.
author: Chris D.

description: unfortunately, the maltese falcon was not enough of a draw to make up for the mediocre steak. really awful old fashioned cocktails as well. however, my waiter was nice and i had a good time. i'd say go once for the historical value...
author: eve l.

description: I don't know if it is the Maltese Falcon...or location, but something about going to John's Grill makes me happy. The food is so-so, the bar is cramped, the bathrooms are located 2 floors up- the dining room is cold....but if you do get a seat at the micro-mini bar, drinking wine at the bar seats can be a great waste of a day.
author: Sarah C.

description: Having enjoyed this restaurant probably 3 or 4 times now with a diverse group of friends, I have to say my most recent experience here was disappointing. My food experience has overall been OK. But upon arriving last evening at about 3-4 minutes till 10 (their closing time) and standing at the front door to be seated for  a number of minutes then having a female server stare at us at the front door and yell across the room, 'We're closed!" was not cool. You see darling, when you do that to a good customer it makes me think less of your establishment. I'm sure you were in a hurry to get home but you still had a good number of patrons in your restaurant. And call me stupid but I thought if you're open til 10 PM that means we can be seated and enjoy a meal if we arrive just before by several minutes. The right thing to do would have been to seat us and serve us. Yelling across the restaurant over customers is something they do in a hamburger joint. Shame on you. Management you need to give her a refresher course on proper etiquette. As I recall she was rather plump in disposition. That's the one there. The one who came off as lazy, unprofessional and with an attitude problem. Oh, last night I walked across the street to enjoy a terrific filet mignon at the jazz restaurant. That's probably where I'll be taking my business in the future.
author: mark z.

description: John's deserves 5 stars for quality and perseverance in addition to its history and damn good food and drink.  The staff is also great and the owner is almost always there to make sure you've had a good experience.  It is one of those rare joints that caters to tourists and native alike, along with visiting celebrities, gourmands and conventioneers.  It's famous also for being home to the Maltese Falcon which has been stolen, recovered and stolen again, pretty damned romantic and brazen.  John's is always doing wonderful civic duty as home to the unique celebration of the 1906 earthquake, home to The Media Excellence Awards (Pubbies) and a host of other great and worthy causes.  They are also home to one of the greatest PR maestro's still creating headlines and long lines for the food, drink and experience only John's Grill can provide.  They do a lot of dishes really great, and one of my favorites is Petrale Sole with lemon, garlic and parsley gently grilled and a generous portion, perfectly served and accompanied by a wide choice of vegetables and starch, go for their fries or roast potatoes.  My other favorite, you can't go wrong with anythinbg here, is their collosal burger, huge, cooked to order with a great bun, fixin's and fries.  This is one of the great restaurant/saloons of San Francisco and convenient to all transit and downtown.
author: Stu S.

description: Being a native San Franciscan I felt that it was just wrong that I had never dined at John's Grill. I recently decided to amend my this travesty earlier this week. My girlfriend and I came in on a Friday night and were seated in a cozy booth by the bar. Our server was over right away and was extremely knowledgeable about the wines and the menu ( I think his name was Dirk or Drake I can't quite recall). We started with two of their specialty cocktails the Pear Martini and the John Daly. Delicious. We then ordered their famous Jack Lalanne salad which was packed with crab and shrimp. After the salad our server recommended a fantastic bottle of Pinot to go with our dinner. For dinner my girlfriend had the Cioppino and I had the Lamb Chops. The cioppino was excellent and loaded with fresh seafood in a delightful marinara broth. My chops were mouthwatering, they were served along with the traditional tomatoes and spinach. We were so full we decided to skip dessert even though the ones we saw brought to other table looked very nice. To sum up, service was great, drinks were great, food was great and I'm looking forward to returning.
author: Derek P.

description: Ewww, just read on Every Block SF that their last inspection on June 3, 2010 scored only a 62 with violations that range from unclean food surfaces to rodents/roaches/flies and other animals!  I don't feel safe bringing my family there to eat.  Have ate there once, but don't know if I ever will again.
author: David L.

description: In business since 1908, this landmark restaurant is where fictional detective Sam Spade of ''The Maltese Falcon' fame usually headed for lunch, and it's headquarters for the Dashiell Hammett Society of San Francisco. The interior is filled with original period furnishings and authentic memorabilia, and the dark oak-paneled walls are covered with photos of well known patrons like Lauren Bacall, George Lucas, and Hillary Clinton. Over the years, the kitchen has resisted experimenting with nouvelle cuisine, so the menu is heavy with simple preparations of steaks, chops, and grilled or broiled seafood. A favorite is Fisherman's Pasta, linguine with salmon, crab, snapper, shrimp, mussels, and clams in a basil cream sauce. Desserts are very basic; the best is probably the New York cheesecake, served with a berry sauce that changes with the seasons. Dinner entree prices range from $18.95 - 29.95; the lunch menu is less expensive and actually more extensive. Many of the waiters have been here for years and move accordingly, although this is a place where you want your meal to be more relaxed than rushed.
author: Gourmet G.

description: I went to this restaurant in hopes to find a good dinner in the city. Well, I did not even get to eat the dinner, because of the horrible service. I asked if there was room at a bar for one person, and the host said to me, "The bar is full." I was still trying to keep cool and asked him how long the wait was. His response was, "See if you can squeeze in... maybe you can fit somewhere.... " This was a deal breaker.
author: Anastasia M.

description: This place is a hole and a tourist trap.  Went in for lunch.  Everything from the food to service was just poor - nasty turkey club sandwich.   John's has been here for years and it shows in so many ways.
author: Paul G.

description: Atmosphere, service, drinks, and food - it was all outstanding.  I like a real drink with a real meal and John's Grill delivered the goods.  I had the Chicken Jerusalem - where else would this even appear on the menu?  Sounds simple, right?  After all, how good can chicken get?  You can't make this at home, home chef.  It was delicious - not your ordinary dinner.  The side of creamed spinach was a good sized portion, cooked just right, and not at all heavy.  Most places screw this up and you feel like you're eating cream with some spinach in it.  This was cooked in the correct proportion and you could actually taste spinach - wow, who knew?  Our waiter wasn't gabby, chatty, or overly nosy - he was friendly, professional, and attentive without lingering - he was a pro.  The Sidecar wasn't overly sweet or bitter - it was old school good.  I've seen this place many times and thought it was just for tourists - mistake.  All this time and I've been missing out.
author: Mark Z.

description: Overrated. This is a tourist trap that plays on the Maltese Falcon history. It offers little else. The food reminded me of the type of surf & turf places that used to serve to the blue hair set 20 years ago. Time has passed them by. The salad was bland. the halibut was not thick - in fact, very thin. The most disappointing was the service. "Want anything else?" Bill slapped down. Will not go again.
author: Jared J.

description: This place was ok the service was pretty good and the food was alright although a bit over priced for the quality of food. They were generous with the glasses of wine for the price you paid. The seating arrangement was very cramped and a bit claustrophobic especially when you are coming in with heavy winter clothes trying to squeeze through the aisles along with that we could hear the two other table convos to our left and right crystal clear way to close for our taste!  The floor was very slippery if in dress shoes both my girlfriend and I slipped when walking down the stairs on the hard wood floors so watch ur step!! I def got the feeling they were going for the close family dinner type vibe warm and inviting but got stuffy and cramped. Def a tourist type of place.
author: Jason O.

description:
This is the first time I have ever written a review but was so disappointed I wanted to let others know.
Last night my wife and I went to Johns grill as we have every year for the last 15 years when we come to the city in December. When we went last year we thought it may have been an off night as the food was average. Last night...what a disappointment. I dont know if the current chef just doesnt know how to cook many things or the economy has left them with the ability to purchase only so many ingredients because the menu selection was pitiful. When we started coming 15 years ago, it was amazing. The Jack Lalannes Favorite Salad was to die for and it was huge! Last night when my wife ordered the Jack Lalannes Favorite Salad the portion was smaller than when we used to split a single order. This establishment used to be in the league of other iconic restaurants in San Francisco such as the Tadich Grill on California and Scomas on the wharf. In my opinion this iconic establishment has let San Francisco down. I used to feel very confident letting friends know what a fine enjoyable place this was to eat. The Salmon (since it was one of a hand full of choices) was marginal at best. You go to Scomas or Tadich Grill and you have so many choices it is hard to make up your mind. The service was also deplorable. They did not even serve us San Francisco sourdough bread with the meal or offer ground pepper with the salad. When they brought the check we had our check and some other tables check in with ours. I am so sorry to say that we would have been better off eating at any number of the walk in places in Union Square and that at this point I will never go back again. What a shame.
I originally gave it a single star but since the interior is still very interesting as well as the history, I gave it another star.
author: Scott P.

description: have been to top steakhouses the world over, johns is as good if not better, great ambiance, excellent cocktails and wine, fantastic food and service, resonable prices, was in san fran on buisness, cant wait to go back
author: Bob S.

description: Tourist trap. Atmosphere is a little cramped, food is almost worthy of being sent back to the kitchen, and it was definitely overpriced. The "jazz" we were promissed was a classical guitar student practicing his scales. Really pathetic. Nobody got sick, so I'll give it 2 stars.
author: Richard H.

description: My husband and I had lunch at John's Grill on Fri. 12/18/09  Asked our waiter what he recommended and both of us loved the choices.  Our service was excellent  and a special thank you to our waiter, Bertan. We will certainly return.
author: Pat S.

description:
First of all, the hostess seemed like he was having the most horrific day of his life and he didn't even bother to look at any of the guests who were trying to talk to him. Although I had made reservations in advance, the place was still ridiculously cramped and crowded. Ok, my boyfriend and I went on Valentine's Day, but still, the overall space is generally small. The tables are extremely close together and people just always seem to be in the way. I commend the waiters though for being able to hop around with plates and trays, because I would fall over and drop everything with the amount of space there is to move. On a more positive note, I enjoyed the live jazz and the decor, which consisted of antique sepia photos of SF. I ordered the Fisherman's Pasta, which was presented beautifully and came in a large portion with generous amounts of seafood. In most cases, there's lots of pasta, but hardly any seafood, whereas, this dish contained a wonderful amount of both. The sauce was surprisingly flavorful and all the mussels, clams, and fish were cooked to perfection. Our waiter was very attentive and genuinely nice. He knew exactly when to take our plates away and we got instant refills without a word. He knew what he was doing and since it was Valentine's Day, the restaurant gave out complimentary chocolate-covered strawberries, mmm! It was a bit of splurge for dinner, but the quality of the food was definitely worth it.

Random note: Our waiter looked like Nicolas Cage, ahaha.
author: Katie N.

description: A friend recommended this place, and while I appreciate the history and all, and the staff was very good, I thought the food was wholly bland. In a city with so much great food I was really annoyed that I wasted a meal here. Maybe my husband and I ordered the wrong thing (he the salmon and I the seafood canneloni) but we were disappointed.
author: Christine A.

description: A hole in the wall that you would never notice. Amazing history and lots to look at inside. It was a great place to retreat to after shopping all day. Food was good and moderately priced. I'd recommend it
author: Courtney W.

description: My wife and I are being tourists from Oakland during MacWorld week. John's Grill is a definite tourist restaurant, from the Dashiell Hammett display to the photos of 'The Maltese Falcon' on the wall. The food, however, does not live up to the tourist hype. My wife had the Cioppino, which was passable, but watery. Lots of seafood, though. I had the Petrale Sole, which was overwhelmed by a thick mushroom sauce that seemed like it was simmering all day. The green beans were great; al dente and tasty.
author: Jim P.

description: Every once in awhile this lone spirit gets it in his head to visit a restaurant he's never tried and have a fine dinner for one.  Last night I decided to try John's Grill because I had a hankering for a steak.  I ordered the bone-in New York Strip.  It was cooked medium rare, just like I asked.  But it was bland.  A great cut of steak requires nothing else, but I found myself dunking each bite in some Lea & Perrins.  Lea & Perrins is typically reserved for my bloody mary or my Chex Mix, not my entree.  The potato was overbaked and likely sitting under a heat lamp for a few hours.  The green beans were limp.  The Manhattan was shaken, for crying out loud!  A good Manhattan should be stirred so as to prevent frothing.  The best parts of the meal were the sourdough bread and the Hayman and Hill Cabernet - neither of which, to the best of my knowledge, were prepared onsite.  Sure, the ambience is swell.  Dark, lots of wood, old SF photos everywhere.  But I don't imagine I'll ever find myself eating there again - not unless I'm with someone else and they're picking up the tab.
author: Todd G.

description: Great place to have a great Manhattan and a New York Strip. Very, very consistent. When I asked the bartender how long he had worked here he said 4 months, then corrected himself and said 40 years.
author: mark f.

description: Over priced steak.  The fries were cooked in oil with fish, thus taking like seafood.  I wouldn't recommend it.  No space and poor service by the wait staff.
author: Vance C.

description: Dinner was packed and we wound up upstairs in a cramped table.  Food was adaquate but overpriced and some items that are on the lunch menu are not available at night.  Lunch is a much better deal.  Doesn't seem to have aged well and probably won't go back.
author: Brian R.

description: Don't expect a classy romantic restaurant. It's crowded, busy and noisy. Steak I had was OK, with the price of US$29, the quality considered good, portion was big. The "signature" drink Bloody Brigid taste like cough syrup. House wine was so so, kind of cheap quality.
author: Virginia T.

description: What a bust this place was for my husband and me over the holiday weekend! We were told our table would be about a 20 minute wait, so we opted to have a drink at the bar first. We ordered gin and tonics - a simple drink to make. They came without limes. When we requested limes 4 shriveled slices were presented to us by the barman on a crumbled napkin. This gesture raised eyebrows from several patrons at the bar, but we let it go. The drinks were over powering - no tonic at all. Everything was downhill from here. Our table was ready in the time alloted - upstairs in a corner right next to a bin of dirty dishes. We told the staff we would wait for a better table which even the waiter said he would not accept. Finally, once seated downstairs a male waiter asked us what we wanted to eat. Not welcome, may I take your order - what do we want to eat?!! Geez, no style at all. We didn't even have menus yet - we had to ask. We also had to ask for water which never came. We settled on filet mignon and a baked potato. They were so bland and uninteresting - almost tasteless. The beans were barely cooked and barely warm like the steak. it was like cafeteria food only MUCH more expensive. Please, please don't get sucked into the hype of this restaurant - it was very disappointing.
author: Carolyn W.

description: Went to John's Grill this past weekend on the recommendation of a friend. We arrived at the height of the dinner rush, 7:30-ish and were told it would be a 20 minute wait. Ok, we'll wait. Barely 5 minutes later we were seated. Unlike the experiences of some other Yelpers, our table was quite comfortable and we were not at all crowded. This place screams early 20th century San Francisco. It's old and rickety and has a really awesome atmosphere inside. If you're turned off by that, as apparently alot of people are, you may not dig it too much. We enjoyed it alot, chuckling all the while about the flickering lights due to the 100+ year-old wiring in the building. As for the food, all 4 of us in our party cleared our plates with no problem. So good. We even managed to polish off a couple of desserts, and enjoyed the cocktails very much. The service was excellent, the food was excellent, the company was great. No complaints at all.
author: K H.

description: My family tried out this restaurant after a long day of sightseeing in San Francisco with relatives visiting from out of town. We were starving, the concierge at their hotel recommended John's Grill, so we headed over. Big mistake. The first problem was trying to get in the place- there was this huge crowd of people who were all trying to eat there too. Once we got in, it took a few minutes just to flag someone down who works there. The restaurant is cramped and claustrophobic. The stairs are not ideal for starving customers who were served chardonnay but no food. Anyway- we were finally seated and someone took our orders. We ordered a salad for my 8 year old daughter, another salad for 2 of us to share, and fish for all of us. The salad to share came after about 20 minutes, but my daughter did not get her salad. So 2 of us ate salad, while the rest of us just sat there with nothing to eat for 45 minutes, other than some stale bread. We ordered some chardonnay to pass the time, which actually did come. Finally we cancelled our orders and left, at which point we were billed $60 for a couple of glasses of chardonnay and some salad. We won't bother going back.
author: Wendy S.

description: From the outside looking in it looks nice, a somewhat classy joint. As soon as we walked in, the first thing I noticed was the smell. I asked my culinary elitist friend if she smelled it, and she replied, "Yeah, it's called kitchen." We were seated next to the kitchen, so there was a lot of foot traffic and general commotion around our table. Our server was pretty cool: he checked on us a lot and kept our water glasses full. He even tried to help us sell a pair of Giants tickets to the staff members, but no one had that particular day off to go to the game. I didn't have much of an appetite so I just had the house salad, and my friend had the filet mignon. The food was good but not great. I wanted to give one star but we had a great server and we got a free arm-wrestling show, which helped lighten the mood. I doubt I'd come back, unless they seat me upstairs, far away from that gross smell. But then again, I think I'd rather spend my money at Morton's.
author: Alani F.
